He was taken off the track in a wheelchair.\n\nIt was later revealed that Lyles had tested positive for COVID-19 two days prior to Thursday's race, NBC Sports reported. Lyles was seen wearing a protective mask prior to the event. Lyles has battled severe asthma in the past.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history. Bednarek, who also won silver in Tokyo, finished in 19.62, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nLyles had not been beaten in a 200 since that night in Tokyo, and after his win in the 100, he brought the bronze medal to the press conference, slammed it on the table and said that had been his motivation for three full years.\n\nNow, he'll get another one.\n\nThursday's final marked the second straight night Tebogo beat him to the finish line in Lyles' favorite race.\n\nIn the semifinal, Lyles finished second and skipped his traditional meeting with reporters to head to the medical tent. {"uri": "8265895284", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:13:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:13:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:13:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/lyles-battling-covid-finishes-3rd-in-olympic-200-meter-final-won-by-botswanas-tebogo", "title": "Lyles, battling COVID, finishes 3rd in Olympic 200-meter final won by Botswana's Tebogo", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair suffering with what The Associated Press learned was a case of COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and eventually sat up to be tended to by medical staff. A person familiar with Lyles' condition, who did not want to be identified, told AP he was diagnosed with COVID two days before the final.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nREAD MORE: Noah Lyles wins 100-meter final by .005 seconds, among closest finishes in Olympic history\n\nLyles came into Paris having not been beaten in a 200 since that night in Tokyo, and after his win in the 100, he brought the bronze medal to the press conference, slammed it on the table and said that had been his motivation for three full years.\n\nNow, he'll get another one.\n\nThursday's final marked the second straight night Tebogo beat him to the finish line in the Lyles' favorite race. Lyles' win streak ended when he finished second in the semifinal. After that one, skipped his traditional meeting with reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nThis time, Tebogo was leading as the sprinters reached the curve. {"uri": "8265860239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:41:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:41:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:40:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/2024/8/8/24216244/olympics-2024-paris-letsile-tebogo-wins-historic-200-meter-gold-covid-stricken-noah-lyles", "title": "Letsile Tebogo wins historic 200-meter Olympic gold over Covid-stricken Noah Lyles", "body": "The Olympic 100-meter champion was unable to win his first Olympic 200-meter gold medal, finishing with a bronze medal behind fellow American Kenny Bednarek and Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, whose 19.46-second gold medal performance makes him the fifth-fastest in history.\n\nLyles is already one of the great 200-meter runners in history and the third-fastest all-time, but the one thing he hasn't won is the Olympic gold medal. As the favorite in Tokyo, Lyles was beaten by both Bednarek and gold medalist Andre De Grasse (who didn't make this year's final). It was only the second time Lyles had lost a 200-meter final since turning professional after the US Olympic trials in 2016.\n\nIn Wednesday's semifinals, Lyles came in second behind Tebogo in an uncharacteristic performance. LetsRun.com revealed at the time that Lyles \"would not stop in the mixed zone as he was being taken to medical.\"\n\nFollowing the final, Lyles, who is asthmatic, was lying on the track struggling to catch his breath and required medical attention before being taken off in a wheelchair.\n\nDuring the NBC broadcast, reporter Lewis Johnson told viewers that Lyles was diagnosed with COVID-19 on Tuesday, which was a day off for Lyles in between 200-meter heats and semis. With restrictions no longer in place regarding a positive Covid test, Lyles opted to run anyway.\n\nThis is the second time Lyles has contracted the virus. Lyles had Covid just prior to the 2023 US World Championship trials in Eugene.\n\n\"I've been sick since [the] New York [Grand Prix], I actually got COVID,\" Lyles told reporters afterward. \"I didn't get cleared until Sunday and flew out Monday, so it's been a wild week, a very wild week.\"\n\nLyles finished third to make his first USA 100-meter team on his way to pulling off the 100/200/4x100 triple gold in the World Championships in Budapest.\n\nIn an interview with Lewis Johnson, Lyles explained what happened and how he felt after the diagnosis.\n\n\"I woke up early on Tuesday morning and just feeling really horrible,\" Lyles said. \"I knew it was more than being sore from the 100. Woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for Covid.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic. I've been in worse situations and I've run with worse conditions I felt. We just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much and quarantine off. It's taking it's toll for sure but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal, whereas last Olympics I was very disappointed. This time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nLyles said that he never considered withdrawing from the final, but in terms of running the anchor leg of Friday's 4x100 relay, it's a different story.\n\n\"At the moment I don't know,\" Lyles said. \"I'm feeling more on the side of letting team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me. If that's the case coming off today, I'm perfectly fine saying 'Hey, you guys go do your thing. You've got more than enough speed to get the gold medal.\"\n\nIt's a monumental victory for Tebogo, who's been competing with a heavy heart since the unexpected passing of his mother back in May. The 21-year-old has been one of the best sprinting prospects in recent memory. He holds the U20 world record in the 100 meters at 9.91 seconds and won the silver in the 100 and bronze in the 200 at last year's Worlds.\n\nWith this win, Tebogo is the first gold medalist for Botswana in Olympic history, as well as the first African Olympic champion in the 200 meters. There is no doubt that he will be a chief rival of Lyles for years to come in both sprints, and he's pulled off one of the greatest 200-meter performances in history.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8265940776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:58:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:58:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:57:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.theroot.com/noah-lyles-didnt-live-up-to-fastest-man-alive-claims-1851617273", "title": "Noah Lyles Didn't Live Up to 'Fastest Man Alive' Claims, and Fans Have Theories Why", "body": "Fans and critics were concerned after gold medalist Noah Lyles fell short during the 200-meter final, a race he's known to dominate. Lyles, who has been claiming to be the fastest man in the world, collected bronze in the final, and some are questioning if it has do to with COVID-19.\n\nLyles is fresh off a gold medal win for his 100-meter performance on Aug. 4. Just four days later, Lyles placed third after unexpectedly losing to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo. But what was even more shocking than Lyles' loss was when the athlete was carted off by medical staff in a wheelchair following the race.\n\nSources confirmed to AP News that Lyles tested positive for COVID two days before the Thursday final. The virus, known to affect the respiratory system, was especially scary for Lyles, who has a history of asthma.\n\nImmediately following news of Lyles' diagnosis, X users began debating if COVID caused the athlete's underperformance.\n\nX user @marL0wE called Lyles a \"Buffalo soldier\" for continuing the race despite his condition.\n\nAnother user expressed their sympathies for Lyles as he continues to recover.\n\nComing into the Paris Olympics, Lyles held the top 200-meter time in the world this year at 19.53 seconds. At the semifinals, he ran a 20.08, and during the finals, Lyles stopped at 19.70 seconds. Even with COVID, Lyles managed to earn a medal, and X user @_Zeets said that makes Lyles' performance especially impressive.\n\nUsed to making history, Lyles became the first American to win gold in 100-meters finals since 2004. The 27-year-old was set on becoming the first American to win the sprint double since Carl Lewis in 1984, but for the second time in Lyles' career, COVID prevailed.\n\nLyles went to Tokyo for the summer Olympics in 2020, during the height of the global pandemic. Although he won a bronze medal during the games, Lyles spoke about how the empty stands affected his mental health:\n\n\"I just remember being so [like] 'this is not it,\" Lyles said recalling his mindset before the 200-meter race. \"'This is not what I wanted. This is not what I thought it was gonna be like,'\" he continued.\n\nDespite his COVID diagnosis this time around, Lyles was determined to still hit the track. \"I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy, so that was kind of the strategy for today,\" he told reporters after the race. \"This is by far the best day I felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I'm 100% but I would definitely say I'm closer to like, 90 to 95%.\"", "source": {"uri": "theroot.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Root"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-08-448621748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:35:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:35:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:53:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/2024olympics/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-collapses-after-getting-bronze-one-of-8-us-medals-at-olympic/article_ece75b35-fa99-5f25-bcdf-4e8f90626eac.html", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles collapses after getting bronze, one of 8 US medals at Olympic track", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- The first sign of trouble Thursday night came when Noah Lyles started rounding the curve in the Olympic final of the 200 meters -- the sprint that has always been his best race.\n\nNormally at the curve, Lyles starts making up ground, then pulling away from what have been, for the last three years, game but overmatched contenders.\n\nThis time, his momentum stalled. Instead of Lyles reeling in the runner two lanes to his right, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Tebogo pulled farther way. The American favorite, who had gone three years without losing in the 200, labored into the finish and ended up in third.\n\nThe insidious specter of COVID, the killer virus that upended the globe four years ago and made the last Olympics part of its collateral damage, struck at the Paris Games, too.\n\nIn a bracing reminder that the virus is still very much a factor, even if its deadly fingerprint has been blunted, the world's marquee sprinter racing on the world's biggest sports stage revealed he had tested positive two days before his shocking, but now not-inexplicable, bronze-medal finish in the 200.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" Lyles said, wearing a mask, as he spoke to reporters, whose mere congregation in a jam-packed scrum underneath the stadium was unthinkable three years ago. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWith the blessing of officials at USA Track and Field and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee, who said they followed protocol, Lyles did run.\n\nHe finished in 19.70 -- .39 off his personal-best, and .24 behind the 21-year-old Tebogo. Lyles' U.S. teammate Kenny Bednarek finished second, marking the second straight Olympics in which he and Lyles finished 2-3.\n\n\"When I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far, far away behind us,\" Tebogo said. \"So that means I'm the Olympic champion.\"\n\nIt was Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone vs her own world record\n\nAn hour after that shock, Americans Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThat was one of three gold medals and eight overall the U.S. won on a night filled with big events.\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters to capture the long jump and get in the Olympic win column next to some greats, including Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Brittney Reese.\n\nGrant Holloway cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss.\n\nLyles seemed like a sure thing, until things got weird the night before\n\nComing into Paris, Lyles, the three-time world champion with the American record and the world's best time of 2024 on his resume, had seemed like as sure a thing as any single athlete at track this side of McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nAfter opening with a scintillating win in the 100 four nights earlier, he was trying to become the first man to complete the 100-200 double since Usain Bolt did it eight years ago.\n\nA troubling sign, however, came the night before when Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat, also to Tebogo. It marked the first time he had lost a 200-meter race of any sort since his disappointing third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nHe also hurried out of the stadium after that loss and went to the medical tent -- a rare occasion when he didn't stop to talk to reporters. His coach said he was fine.\n\nLyles said he tested positive two days after the 100 final\n\nTurns out he wasn't. Lyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\nHe drank fluids, rested as much as possible and tried to gear up for the race. USATF said in a statement that Lyles was given \"a thorough medical evaluation\" and chose to compete.\n\n\"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely,\" the statement said.\n\nThe scene after the race was jarring. Usually one of the most energetic guys on the track, both before and after the race, Lyles collapsed to the ground, rolled on his side and gasped for breath. He turned over on his hands and knees, then went to one knee, and balanced himself with his fist.\n\nHe finally stood up and wobbled toward the medics, signaling for a cup of water. Then, he left in a wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nThis bronze medal feels different than the last one\n\nIt will take time for all the repercussions of this race to play out.\n\nThere's still a chance Lyles could end up as the bigger-than-track superstar he set out to become after his disappointment in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThose Games, delayed by a year and staged in front of no fans while the COVID pandemic raged, took a mental-health toll on Lyles, one he said made him less than himself and led to his disappointing finish in Tokyo.\n\nAfter he won the 100 Sunday night, he took that Tokyo bronze medal out during his news conference, dropped it on the table and explained it was the thing that motivated him to become a new person and a new sprinter for this Olympic cycle.\n\nThe 100-meter thriller sealed the first half of the deal. But instead of breezing through the 200, just getting to the starting line became a product of \"trying to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to just keep the momentum going.\"\n\nThere's a chance for one more gold medal in the relay\n\nLyles could still walk out of Paris with two gold medals.\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles would have normally been expected to run the anchor leg.\n\nHe said he was feeling around 90 to 95%, and that he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision on whether he should be in the lineup for a race the Americans haven't captured a medal in since 2004.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said.\n\nEither way, Thursday's race threw a damper on, at least temporarily, the carefree Olympics that were supposed to be all about the return of fans, the return of the celebration, the return of the Games as we used to know them.\n\nLyles reminded us that there will never be a \"post-COVID\" Games.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 meters, a season best.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "hjnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8265962819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:19:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:19:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:17:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.espn.in/olympics/story/_/id/40780740/noah-lyles-wins-200m-bronze-covid-diagnosis-revealed-race", "title": "Positive COVID test revealed after Lyles' bronze", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Moments after he finished in third place during Thursday night's 200-meter Olympics final, American sprinter Noah Lyles told reporters he ran the race with COVID, after having been diagnosed with the illness two days prior.\n\n\"I tested positive around 5 a.m. Tuesday morning,\" Lyles said, wearing a black KN95 mask inside the media mixed zone. \"I woke up in the middle of the night just feeling really chills, aching, sore throat.\n\n\"And those were kind of a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting COVID, and I was just like, 'I need to test this one.'\"\n\nThe moment the test came back positive, Lyles left the Olympic Village and was quarantined at a nearby hotel, he said. He also said he was administered whatever medications he could legally take without causing problems during postrace drug testing. Paxlovid was among the medications he took, a USA Track and Field spokesperson confirmed.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, they said it was still possible,\" Lyles said. \"So we just stayed away from everybody and just tried to take it round by round. And to be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy.\"\n\nHe added that he tried to keep his diagnosis as \"close to the chest as possible\" for several reasons.\n\n\"One, we didn't want everybody to go into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete,\" Lyles said. \"And then two, we wanted to be able to make it as discreet as possible. And, you never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nLyles isn't sure if he will still participate in the 4x100-meter relay at 1:45 ET on Friday, but he said the Americans have the speed to run the race without him.\n\n\"I'll talk to the coaches,\" Lyles said. \"I'm going to be very honest and transparent with them, and I'm going to let them make the decision. I believe that no matter what happens, I believe that this 4x1 team, they can handle anything and everything. I've been with them in practice, and they are more than capable to come out with a win and even break as many records as they take their mind to.\"\n\nOne day after losing the 200-meter semifinal to Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Lyles was unable to surpass him once again in the final Thursday night.\n\nTebogo ran an African-record 19.46 to earn the 200-meter gold medal. Finishing just behind him with silver was American Kenny Bednarek, who posted a 19.62-second showing. Bednarek was pleased to have received a second silver after he earned one in the 200 at the Tokyo Games, but he believed he had more he could have shown Thursday.\n\n\"I knew the race was gonna be tight and sometimes you see people in your peripheral visions and you want to do a little extra,\" Bednarek said. \"I felt like I didn't do anything extra, but I know for a fact that this wasn't my best performance.\"\n\nWhen he spoke with reporters, Tebogo said he didn't know Lyles had COVID. Bednarek said he had no concerns about getting it from his teammate himself.\n\n\"I don't care. I mean, If I get sick or whatever, I'll be fine,\" Bednarek said. \"I don't view those things as a big deal. I'm healthy, I do everything I can to make sure my body's healthy. So it doesn't really bother me at all.\"\n\nTebogo said he noticed Lyles wearing a mask during warmups the last two days but didn't understand why. He felt like Lyles must have been going through something. In terms of feeling like Lyles put him at risk for being sick, Tebogo added: \"I don't know he put anyone at risk ... We are Africans. We are strong.\n\n\"Hopefully he will recover, then I hope the team win the gold medal in the 4x100-meter.\"\n\nAs soon as he crossed the finish line third, Lyles laid down on his back on the track. Within moments, he was surrounded by athletic trainers and members of the Paris Olympics medical staff, who moved him toward a wall as they administered treatment.\n\nAt one point, Lyles was seen wearing a mask before being placed in a chair which was eventually wheeled into the nearby tunnel.\n\n\"I was quite lightheaded after that race and the shortness of breath and chest pain was definitely active,\" said Lyles, who has been quite public about his longtime experiences with asthma. \"But after a while underneath, I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me. I'm doing a lot better now.\n\n\"This is by far the best day I felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I'm 100 percent, but I definitely would say I'm closer to like 90-90%.\"\n\nAfter Wednesday's semifinal heat, Lyles did not come through the media mixed zone. He instead was taken directly to medical for what was an undisclosed reason.\n\nDuring Thursday's race, all eight runners got off to a somewhat even start. Lyles was in the hunt early. Around the 100-meter mark, Tebogo and Bednarek began pulling away. Although Lyles was still hanging close with them, Tebogo's lead was one he was not relinquishing easily.\n\nMinutes after the race, Lyles was also handed a yellow card for a violation of Technical Rule 7.1 for \"improper conduct.\" It wasn't immediately clear why he was given it, but during introductions, he did demonstrably jump onto the track as he heard his name.\n\nWhile pumping up the crowd before the race, Lyles smacked the box housing the speaker in his lane so hard that the number on the box fell off.\n\nLyles' 200-meter showing followed his 9.79-second, personal-best effort in Sunday's close 100-meter dash. He earned the gold medal in what was the closest 100-meter final since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or perhaps ever. Back then, Great Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in 10.25 seconds in an era when timing didn't go down to the thousandths of a second.", "source": {"uri": "espn.in", "dataType": A person familiar with Lyles' condition, who did not want to be identified, told AP was diagnosed with COVID two days before the final.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nLyles came into Paris having not been beaten in a 200 since that night in Tokyo, and after his win in the 100, he brought the bronze medal to the press conference, slammed it on the table and said that had been his motivation for three full years.\n\nNow, he'll get another one.\n\nThursday's final marked the second straight night Tebogo beat him to the finish line in the Lyles' favorite race. {"uri": "8265987422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:44:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:44:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:43:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.khou.com/article/sports/olympics/did-noah-lyles-win-200m/507-0e50ad4b-29fa-4581-99a4-43c3e7af2bf1", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles finishes 3rd in 200 meters won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo", "body": "PARIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles said he had COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games.\n\nHe also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said that decision had not been made as of late Thursday.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time -- nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. A person familiar with Lyles' condition, who did not want to be identified, told AP was diagnosed with COVID two days before the final.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nLyles came into Paris having not been beaten in a 200 since that night in Tokyo, and after his win in the 100, he brought the bronze medal to the press conference, slammed it on the table and said that had been his motivation for three full years.\n\nNow, he'll get another one.\n\nThursday's final marked the second straight night Tebogo beat him to the finish line in the Lyles' favorite race. Lyles' win streak ended when he finished second in the semifinal. After that one, skipped his traditional meeting with reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nThis time, Tebogo was leading as the sprinters reached the curve. {"uri": "2024-08-448562966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:58:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:58:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://omaha.com/sports/other/olympics/paris-olympics-noah-lyles-covid-200-meter/article_ec7667df-4759-5fff-9925-de1e29d75823.html", "title": "Sprinter Noah Lyles announces COVID diagnosis after finishing 3rd in 200 meters", "body": "Can the Olympics thrive with all the top professionals playing tennis and golf? Insights on Noah Lyles & what makes a global champion in the sports world.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles said he had COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" he said.\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games.\n\nHe also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said that decision had not been made as of late Thursday.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time -- nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. {"uri": "8265972280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:26:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:26:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/sports/article/2024/08/08/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-finishes-3rd-in-200-meters-won-by-botswana-s-letsile-tebogo_6711553_9.html", "title": "Covid-stricken Noah Lyles finishes 3rd in 200 meters won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo", "body": "Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters on Thursday, August 8, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had Covid-19 but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair. \"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\"\n\nIt is the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nAfter winning a thrilling 100 meters four nights earlier, Lyles came to the press conference, pulled out the bronze medal from Tokyo, slapped it on the table and said that had been his motivation to add the shorter sprint to his repertoire in an attempt to become a larger-than-track star. Now, he has two of those bronze medals, though the tale of this one played out much differently.\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine. \"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\" The US track federation released a statement saying it and the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\" \"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" the statement said. \"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to... guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine. It became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the home stretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of a race that, before this week, he hadn't lost since the third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nThis time - nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track. \"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. {"uri": "8266002322", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:02:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:02:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:01:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-collapses-after-getting-bronze-one-of-8-us-medals-at-olympic/article_42425cf7-acaa-5384-8a63-e0e2a3240088.html", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles collapses after getting bronze, one of 8 US medals at Olympic track", "body": "Tara Davis-Woodhall, of the United States, celebrates winning the women's long jump final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Thursday, Aug. 8, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- The first sign of trouble Thursday night came when Noah Lyles started rounding the curve in the Olympic final of the 200 meters -- the sprint that has always been his best race.\n\nNormally at the curve, Lyles starts making up ground, then pulling away from what have been, for the last three years, game but overmatched contenders.\n\nThis time, his momentum stalled. Instead of Lyles reeling in the runner two lanes to his right, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Tebogo pulled farther way. The American favorite, who had gone three years without losing in the 200, labored into the finish and ended up in third.\n\nThe insidious specter of COVID, the killer virus that upended the globe four years ago and made the last Olympics part of its collateral damage, struck at the Paris Games, too.\n\nIn a bracing reminder that the virus is still very much a factor, even if its deadly fingerprint has been blunted, the world's marquee sprinter racing on the world's biggest sports stage revealed he had tested positive two days before his shocking, but now not-inexplicable, bronze-medal finish in the 200.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" Lyles said, wearing a mask, as he spoke to reporters, whose mere congregation in a jam-packed scrum underneath the stadium was unthinkable three years ago. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWith the blessing of officials at USA Track and Field and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee, who said they followed protocol, Lyles did run.\n\nHe finished in 19.70 -- .39 off his personal-best, and .24 behind the 21-year-old Tebogo. Lyles' U.S. teammate Kenny Bednarek finished second, marking the second straight Olympics in which he and Lyles finished 2-3.\n\n\"When I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far, far away behind us,\" Tebogo said. \"So that means I'm the Olympic champion.\"\n\nIt was Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone vs her own world record\n\nAn hour after that shock, Americans Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThat was one of three gold medals and eight overall the U.S. won on a night filled with big events.\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters to capture the long jump and get in the Olympic win column next to some greats, including Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Brittney Reese.\n\nGrant Holloway cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss.\n\nLyles seemed like a sure thing, until things got weird the night before\n\nComing into Paris, Lyles, the three-time world champion with the American record and the world's best time of 2024 on his resume, had seemed like as sure a thing as any single athlete at track this side of McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nAfter opening with a scintillating win in the 100 four nights earlier, he was trying to become the first man to complete the 100-200 double since Usain Bolt did it eight years ago.\n\nA troubling sign, however, came the night before when Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat, also to Tebogo. It marked the first time he had lost a 200-meter race of any sort since his disappointing third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nHe also hurried out of the stadium after that loss and went to the medical tent -- a rare occasion when he didn't stop to talk to reporters. His coach said he was fine.\n\nLyles said he tested positive two days after the 100 final\n\nTurns out he wasn't. Lyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\nHe drank fluids, rested as much as possible and tried to gear up for the race. USATF said in a statement that Lyles was given \"a thorough medical evaluation\" and chose to compete.\n\n\"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely,\" the statement said.\n\nThe scene after the race was jarring. Usually one of the most energetic guys on the track, both before and after the race, Lyles collapsed to the ground, rolled on his side and gasped for breath. He turned over on his hands and knees, then went to one knee, and balanced himself with his fist.\n\nHe finally stood up and wobbled toward the medics, signaling for a cup of water. Then, he left in a wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nThis bronze medal feels different than the last one\n\nIt will take time for all the repercussions of this race to play out.\n\nThere's still a chance Lyles could end up as the bigger-than-track superstar he set out to become after his disappointment in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThose Games, delayed by a year and staged in front of no fans while the COVID pandemic raged, took a mental-health toll on Lyles, one he said made him less than himself and led to his disappointing finish in Tokyo.\n\nAfter he won the 100 Sunday night, he took that Tokyo bronze medal out during his news conference, dropped it on the table and explained it was the thing that motivated him to become a new person and a new sprinter for this Olympic cycle.\n\nThe 100-meter thriller sealed the first half of the deal. But instead of breezing through the 200, just getting to the starting line became a product of \"trying to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to just keep the momentum going.\"\n\nThere's a chance for one more gold medal in the relay\n\nLyles could still walk out of Paris with two gold medals.\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles would have normally been expected to run the anchor leg.\n\nHe said he was feeling around 90 to 95%, and that he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision on whether he should be in the lineup for a race the Americans haven't captured a medal in since 2004.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said.\n\nEither way, Thursday's race threw a damper on, at least temporarily, the carefree Olympics that were supposed to be all about the return of fans, the return of the celebration, the return of the Games as we used to know them.\n\nLyles reminded us that there will never be a \"post-COVID\" Games.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 meters, a season best.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8266091732", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:54:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:54:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:51:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://omaha.com/ap/sports/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-collapses-after-getting-bronze-one-of-8-us-medals-at-olympic/article_706630b4-adc5-54b2-a2fc-18de5f279ad1.html", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles collapses after getting bronze, one of 8 US medals at Olympic track", "body": "Tara Davis-Woodhall, of the United States, celebrates winning the women's long jump final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Thursday, Aug. 8, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France.\n\nBy EDDIE PELLS and PAT GRAHAM - AP Sports Writers\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- The first sign of trouble Thursday night came when Noah Lyles started rounding the curve in the Olympic final of the 200 meters -- the sprint that has always been his best race.\n\nNormally at the curve, Lyles starts making up ground, then pulling away from what have been, for the last three years, game but overmatched contenders.\n\nThis time, his momentum stalled. Instead of Lyles reeling in the runner two lanes to his right, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Tebogo pulled farther way. The American favorite, who had gone three years without losing in the 200, labored into the finish and ended up in third.\n\nThe insidious specter of COVID, the killer virus that upended the globe four years ago and made the last Olympics part of its collateral damage, struck at the Paris Games, too.\n\nIn a bracing reminder that the virus is still very much a factor, even if its deadly fingerprint has been blunted, the world's marquee sprinter racing on the world's biggest sports stage revealed he had tested positive two days before his shocking, but now not-inexplicable, bronze-medal finish in the 200.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" Lyles said, wearing a mask, as he spoke to reporters, whose mere congregation in a jam-packed scrum underneath the stadium was unthinkable three years ago. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWith the blessing of officials at USA Track and Field and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee, who said they followed protocol, Lyles did run.\n\nHe finished in 19.70 -- .39 off his personal-best, and .24 behind the 21-year-old Tebogo. Lyles' U.S. teammate Kenny Bednarek finished second, marking the second straight Olympics in which he and Lyles finished 2-3.\n\n\"When I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far, far away behind us,\" Tebogo said. \"So that means I'm the Olympic champion.\"\n\nIt was Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone vs her own world record\n\nAn hour after that shock, Americans Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThat was one of three gold medals and eight overall the U.S. won on a night filled with big events.\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters to capture the long jump and get in the Olympic win column next to some greats, including Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Brittney Reese.\n\nGrant Holloway cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss.\n\nLyles seemed like a sure thing, until things got weird the night before\n\nComing into Paris, Lyles, the three-time world champion with the American record and the world's best time of 2024 on his resume, had seemed like as sure a thing as any single athlete at track this side of McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nAfter opening with a scintillating win in the 100 four nights earlier, he was trying to become the first man to complete the 100-200 double since Usain Bolt did it eight years ago.\n\nA troubling sign, however, came the night before when Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat, also to Tebogo. It marked the first time he had lost a 200-meter race of any sort since his disappointing third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nHe also hurried out of the stadium after that loss and went to the medical tent -- a rare occasion when he didn't stop to talk to reporters. His coach said he was fine.\n\nLyles said he tested positive two days after the 100 final\n\nTurns out he wasn't. Lyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\nHe drank fluids, rested as much as possible and tried to gear up for the race. USATF said in a statement that Lyles was given \"a thorough medical evaluation\" and chose to compete.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely,\" the statement said.\n\nThe scene after the race was jarring. Usually one of the most energetic guys on the track, both before and after the race, Lyles collapsed to the ground, rolled on his side and gasped for breath. He turned over on his hands and knees, then went to one knee, and balanced himself with his fist.\n\nHe finally stood up and wobbled toward the medics, signaling for a cup of water. Then, he left in a wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nThis bronze medal feels different than the last one\n\nIt will take time for all the repercussions of this race to play out.\n\nThere's still a chance Lyles could end up as the bigger-than-track superstar he set out to become after his disappointment in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThose Games, delayed by a year and staged in front of no fans while the COVID pandemic raged, took a mental-health toll on Lyles, one he said made him less than himself and led to his disappointing finish in Tokyo.\n\nAfter he won the 100 Sunday night, he took that Tokyo bronze medal out during his news conference, dropped it on the table and explained it was the thing that motivated him to become a new person and a new sprinter for this Olympic cycle.\n\nThe 100-meter thriller sealed the first half of the deal. But instead of breezing through the 200, just getting to the starting line became a product of \"trying to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to just keep the momentum going.\"\n\nThere's a chance for one more gold medal in the relay\n\nLyles could still walk out of Paris with two gold medals.\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles would have normally been expected to run the anchor leg.\n\nHe said he was feeling around 90 to 95%, and that he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision on whether he should be in the lineup for a race the Americans haven't captured a medal in since 2004.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said.\n\nEither way, Thursday's race threw a damper on, at least temporarily, the carefree Olympics that were supposed to be all about the return of fans, the return of the celebration, the return of the Games as we used to know them.\n\nLyles reminded us that there will never be a \"post-COVID\" Games.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 meters, a season best.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8265791861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "18:40:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T18:40:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T18:38:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/paris-olympics-noah-lyles-upset-by-letsile-tebogo-in-200-183515031.html", "title": "Paris Olympics: Noah Lyles upset by Letsile Tebogo in 200", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles' historic pursuit of an Olympic sprint double ended with a humbling defeat.\n\nThe world's most unbeatable 200 meters runner, the man who just four days ago insisted he'd leave his rivals \"depressed\" when he came off the turn, lost his signature race.\n\nLyles didn't appear to have his usual burst right from the start of Thursday night's Olympic men's 200 meters final. The American fell behind early and struggled to make up ground rounding the turn, leaving himself too far behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana to overtake him before they reached the finish line.\n\nTebogo won in 19.46 seconds. American Kenny Bednarek claimed silver in 19.62 seconds Lyles settled for bronze in 19.70 seconds, well shy of his personal best (19.31) and even further away from the Usain Bolt world record that he had aspirations of breaking.\n\nAfter the race ended, Lyles sat on the track and appeared to receive medical attention.\n\nLyles had hoped to become the first American man to complete the Olympic sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago. He seemed to be well on his way after , dipping at the finish line to edge Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by five thousandths of a second.\n\nThat Lyles didn't add the 200 gold to his haul is a massive surprise. This race is Lyles' specialty, his first love, the event that comes most naturally to him.\n\nThe 100 penalizes Lyles for struggling to accelerate out of the blocks as quickly as other world-class sprinters. He has spent years tinkering endlessly with his start in an effort to find a way to remain in striking distance at 30 meters without sacrificing his ability to reach maximum speed and sustain it.\n\nThe 200 reduces the impact of Lyles' mediocre starts and emphasizes the qualities that make him special. The two-time reigning world champion in the 200 holds his speed as well as any sprinter since Usain Bolt, typically enabling him to swallow up anyone in front of him as he rounds the curve and streaks toward the finish line.\n\nWhen asked earlier this week how confident he felt about winning the men's 200, Lyles grinned and said, \"Pretty confident, can't lie.\"\n\nSpeaking specifically about fellow American Kenny Bednarek, Lyles added, \"That man ain't winning. None of them is winning.\"\n\nIn retrospect, perhaps there should have been more concern on Wednesday when Lyles took a rare loss in the 200 semifinals. He sprang out of the blocks slowly, languished in third place as he came off the curve and never caught up to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nIn the 100, Lyles also lost his semifinal but came through when it mattered. In the 200, his favorite race, Lyles couldn't repeat that feat.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448617415", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:26:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:26:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:07:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.news-herald.com/2024/08/08/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-collapses-after-getting-bronze-one-of-8-u-s-medals-at-olympic-track/", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles collapses after getting bronze, one of 8 U.S. medals at Olympic track", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- The first sign of trouble Aug. 8 came when Noah Lyles started rounding the curve in the Olympic final of the 200 meters -- the sprint that has always been his best race.\n\nNormally at the curve, Lyles starts making up ground, then pulling away from what have been, for the last three years, game but overmatched contenders.\n\nThis time, his momentum stalled. Instead of Lyles reeling in the runner two lanes to his right, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Tebogo pulled farther way. The American favorite, who had gone three years without losing in the 200, labored into the finish and ended up in third.\n\nThe insidious specter of COVID, the killer virus that upended the globe four years ago and made the last Olympics part of its collateral damage, struck at the Paris Games, too.\n\nIn a bracing reminder that the virus is still very much a factor, even if its deadly fingerprint has been blunted, the world's marquee sprinter racing on the world's biggest sports stage revealed he had tested positive two days before his shocking, but now not-inexplicable, bronze-medal finish in the 200.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" Lyles said, wearing a mask, as he spoke to reporters, whose mere congregation in a jam-packed scrum underneath the stadium was unthinkable three years ago. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWith the blessing of officials at USA Track and Field and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee, who said they followed protocol, Lyles did run.\n\nHe finished in 19.70 -- .39 off his personal-best, and .24 behind the 21-year-old Tebogo. Lyles' U.S. teammate Kenny Bednarek finished second, marking the second straight Olympics in which he and Lyles finished 2-3.\n\n\"When I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far, far away behind us,\" Tebogo said. \"So that means I'm the Olympic champion.\"\n\nAn hour after that shock, Americans Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThat was one of three gold medals and eight overall the U.S. won on a night filled with big events.\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters to capture the long jump and get in the Olympic win column next to some greats, including Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Brittney Reese.\n\nGrant Holloway cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss.\n\nComing into Paris, Lyles, the three-time world champion with the American record and the world's best time of 2024 on his resume, had seemed like as sure a thing as any single athlete at track this side of McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nAfter opening with a scintillating win in the 100 four nights earlier, he was trying to become the first man to complete the 100-200 double since Usain Bolt did it eight years ago.\n\nA troubling sign, however, came the night before when Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat, also to Tebogo. It marked the first time he had lost a 200-meter race of any sort since his disappointing third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nHe also hurried out of the stadium after that loss and went to the medical tent -- a rare occasion when he didn't stop to talk to reporters. His coach said he was fine.\n\nTurns out he wasn't. Lyles said he tested positive early Aug. 6 and quickly got into quarantine.\n\nHe drank fluids, rested as much as possible and tried to gear up for the race. USATF said in a statement that Lyles was given \"a thorough medical evaluation\" and chose to compete.\n\n\"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely,\" the statement said.\n\nThe scene after the race was jarring. Usually one of the most energetic guys on the track, both before and after the race, Lyles collapsed to the ground, rolled on his side and gasped for breath. He turned over on his hands and knees, then went to one knee, and balanced himself with his fist.\n\nHe finally stood up and wobbled toward the medics, signaling for a cup of water. Then, he left in a wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nIt will take time for all the repercussions of this race to play out.\n\nThere's still a chance Lyles could end up as the bigger-than-track superstar he set out to become after his disappointment in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThose Games, delayed by a year and staged in front of no fans while the COVID pandemic raged, took a mental-health toll on Lyles, one he said made him less than himself and led to his disappointing finish in Tokyo.\n\nAfter he won the 100 Aug. 4, he took that Tokyo bronze medal out during his news conference, dropped it on the table and explained it was the thing that motivated him to become a new person and a new sprinter for this Olympic cycle.\n\nThe 100-meter thriller sealed the first half of the deal. But instead of breezing through the 200, just getting to the starting line became a product of \"trying to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to just keep the momentum going.\"\n\nLyles could still walk out of Paris with two gold medals.\n\nThe men's 4\u00d7100 relay is set for Aug. 9, and Lyles would have normally been expected to run the anchor leg.\n\nHe said he was feeling around 90 to 95%, and that he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision on whether he should be in the lineup for a race the Americans haven't captured a medal in since 2004.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said.\n\nEither way, the Aug. 8 race threw a damper on, at least temporarily, the carefree Olympics that were supposed to be all about the return of fans, the return of the celebration, the return of the Games as we used to know them.\n\nLyles reminded us that there will never be a \"post-COVID\" Games.\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 {"uri": "8265837248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:19:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:19:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:19:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.tsn.ca/olympics/american-sprinter-noah-lyles-secures-200m-bronze-wheeled-off-post-race-with-covid-1.2159943", "title": "American sprinter Noah Lyles secures 200m bronze, wheeled off post-race with COVID | TSN", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair suffering with what The Associated Press learned was a case of COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and eventually sat up to be tended to by medical staff. A person familiar with Lyles' condition, who did not want to be identified, told AP was diagnosed with COVID two days before the final.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nLyles came into Paris having not been beaten in a 200 since that night in Tokyo, and after his win in the 100, he brought the bronze medal to the press conference, slammed it on the table and said that had been his motivation for three full years.\n\nNow, he'll get another one.\n\nThursday's final marked the second straight night Tebogo beat him to the finish line in the Lyles' favorite race. Lyles' win streak ended when he finished second in the semifinal. After that one, skipped his traditional meeting with reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nThis time, Tebogo was leading as the sprinters reached the curve. Usually at that point, Lyles puts on his trademark close, but there was no strong finish -- only a desperate push in to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n___\n\nAP Summer Olympics: Mandatory Credit: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIt appears to be a wrap for Noah Lyles at the Paris Olympics.\n\nThe American sprinter Lyles, who won gold in the men's 100m race on Sunday, suffered an upset in Thursday's 200m race. Letsile Tebogo of Botswana took home the gold, and Kenny Bednarek of the United States secured the silver, while Lyles settled for the bronze. You can see the video of the race here.\n\nAfter the race, Lyles, who went down to the ground after crossing the finish line and had to be taken off in a wheelchair, revealed he had been diagnosed with COVID-19 earlier in the week. Apparently, Lyles had competed in the 200m race while battling COVID.\n\nThe news led to questions about whether or not Lyles would still be able to compete in the men's 4\u00d7100 relay, which is scheduled for Friday. In a post to his Instagram page several hours later, Lyles indicated that he would not be doing so.\n\n\"I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics,\" Lyles wrote in his post as he offered congratulations and thanks for his Olympic run.\n\nThe 4\u00d7100 team for the U.S. still has plenty of firepower to get the job done. Bednarek, Fred Kerley (who won bronze in the 100m), Kyree King, Christian Coleman, and Courtney Lindsay are the other members of that team.\n\nAs for Lyles, he may have had a disappointing finish to the Olympics (on top of getting clowned for his bronze finish in the 200m after talking smack in the lead-up to the race). {"uri": "2024-08-448580064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:25:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:25:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:18:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://time.com/7009337/noah-lyles-covid-200m-paris-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles on Deciding to Race With COVID-19", "body": "In a scene unimaginable at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago, Noah Lyles -- who was wearing a black mask -- told a bunch of unmasked journalists in a sweaty indoor facility in France on Thursday night: \"Yes, I do have COVID.\"\n\nLyles said he woke up in the middle of the night on Tuesday feeling chills, aches, and a sore throat. \"Those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting COVID,\" Lyles told reporters after finishing third in the 200 m, a race he was favored to win He was the three-time defending world champ in that event. Lyles came off the track on a wheelchair at the Stade de France and felt lightheaded and short of breath. But he was OK now.\n\nRead More: Noah Lyles Wins Olympic Bronze in 200 M Despite Having COVID-19\n\n\"I was just like, I need to test this one,\" said Lyles. He tested positive for COVID-19, Lyles said, around 5 a.m. on Tuesday. Lyles quarantined in a hotel near the Olympic Village, he said, and started taking Paxlovid to treat the symptoms. \"I still wanted to run,\" said Lyles. \"We just stayed away from everybody, and just try to take it round by round. And you know, to be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy.\"\n\nLyles ran in the semifinals -- with COVID-19 -- on Wednesday night.\n\nThere's no blanket COVID-19 protocol for athletes at these Paris Olympics. Each federation can sort of make its own rules, and it seems that teams have handled decisions on a case-by-case basis. Since Lyles participates in an outdoor event, rates of transmission and risk of infection to others are relatively low. The silver medalist, Team USA's Kenny Bednarek, said he had no issue with Lyles hugging him after the race.\n\nThe 200-m winner, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, also did not object to Lyles lining up for the race. \"I wouldn't say we were at risk, because it's not a contact sport,\" said Tebogo. He thought something might be askew with Lyles when he saw him keeping to himself in the warm-up area before the race. \"I thought maybe it's just one of those days when he's not having a great day,\" said Tebogo. \"I didn't think of COVID or anything else.\"\n\nRead More: The Inside Story of How Noah Lyles Pulled Off That 100-M Win\n\nLyles kept the news of his diagnosis in a tight circle; his family, medical staff, and coach knew, he said after the race. \"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic,\" he said. \"We wanted to be able to make it as discreet as possible. You never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nIn a statement, the sport's governing body USA Track and Field (USATF) said that it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee (USOPC) stood by Lyles' decision to compete. \"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" USATF said in a statement. \"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely. As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nLyles believes COVID-19 impacted his performance. He was coughing all through the night. \"To be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything,\" he said. \"Coming out to get the bronze medal with COVID [for] three days.\"\n\nLyles wasn't sure if he'd run the 4x100 relay tomorrow night. \"I'm going to be very honest and transparent with them, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" he said. \"I believe that no matter what happens, this four-by-one team can handle anything and everything. I've been with them in practice, they are more than capable to come out with a win.\"\n\nIn Tokyo, Lyles believed the COVID-19 isolation rules, and lack of fans in the stands due to the pandemic, kept him from winning gold. (He was also favored in that race. He also won bronze.) This time around, he contracted COVID-19. Lyles enjoyed his glory moment on Sunday night, with his photo-finish win in the 100.\n\nAt the same time, the Games have been cruel to Lyles. -- with reporting by Alice Park/Saint-Denis, France", But Tebogo pulled off the shocking upset to win gold, with Kenny Bednarek of the United States taking silver.\n\nCameron Tabatabaie of USA Today shared a two-second clip of a visibly exhausted Lyles having to be carted off following the race. It wasn't immediately clear if Lyles suffered an injury or was experiencing an asthma episode.\n\nAlso Read: More Crazy Photos Emerge Showing How Close USA's Noah Lyles Came To Finishing In Second After Dramatic 100m Olympic Final\n\nSoon after, it was reported by both NBC and BBC that Lyles tested positive for COVID-19 two days ago, and that the 27-year-old decided to run anyway. They decided to poke fun at Lyles while questioning his decision to run despite dealing with COVID-19:\n\nLyles also captured a bronze medal at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Canadian Andre De Grasse claimed first on the podium, with Lyles' fellow American Kenneth Bednarek finishing second.\n\nLyles' loss is unquestionably one of the more shocking moments of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris. But it doesn't diminish his legacy as one of the all-time great runners and American athletes.\n\nHe already won his first Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter race, to say nothing of his three world championships and other first-place finishes in the World Relays and Diamond League.\n\nLyles will be 31 years of age by the time the 2028 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, California roll around. {"uri": "2024-08-448693966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "01:14:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T01:14:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T01:01:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/olympics-news-200m-winner-calls-out-noah-lyles", "title": "200m winner savagely calls out Noah Lyles", "body": "Letsile Tebogo won the gold medal and upset Noah Lyles in the 200m.\n\nUnited States sprinter Noah Lyles was the favorite to earn a gold medal in the 200-meter at the Paris Olympics. However, Lyles made headlines on Thursday when he surprisingly finished in third place after it was revealed he was racing even though he diagnosed with COVID, losing to Botswana sprinter Letsile Tebogo.\n\nAfter the race, Tebogo, who ran a personal best 19.46 during Thursday's final, was asked about potentially becoming one of the faces of track and field after his gold medal performance.\n\n\"I can't be the face of athletics because I'm not an arrogant or loud person like Noah [Lyles],\" Tebogo said. \"So I believe Noah [Lyles] is the face of athletics.\"\n\nWhile it's not clear whether or not Tebogo is directly calling out Lyles, or simply noting that Lyles is known for being outspoken and confident, this is still a shocking thing to say about one of, if not the best runners in the world.\n\nLyles made headlines last year when he called out NBA players for referring to winning the NBA Finals as being \"World Champions\" during his now-infamous press conference where he said \"World Champions of what? The United States?\n\nMore recently, after Lyles won gold in the 100-meter, he was already boasting about how he believed he would win gold again in the 200m.\n\n\"None of them is winning,\" Lyles said. \"When I come off the turn, they will all be depressed.\"\n\nWhile his latest comments were made before he was diagnosed with COVID and his health took a turn for the worse, it looks like Lyles has certainly developed a reputation amongst his peers. Who can fault Tebogo for his comments after what Lyles has been saying?\n\nLetsile Tebogo is a rising star\n\nWhile it was shocking to see Lyles lose the 200m, his signature event, it was not a surprise to see the 21-year-old Tebogo perform so well. Tebogo currently has a world record in the 300-meter (not currently an Olympic or World Championship event), won gold in the 4 x 400m relays at the 2024 World Relays and won silver in the 100m and bronze in the 200m at the 2023 World Championships. Tebogo also has a host of gold medals in various youth races.\n\nEspecially after Tebogo's comments after his gold medal winning race on Thursday, it looks like there may be a new rivalry brewing, both on and off the track between him and Lyles.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_korn@clutchpoints.com", "name": "David
