{"uri": "2024-08-448563571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:59:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:59:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T18:42:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/08/08/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-finishes-3rd-in-200-meters-won-by-botswanas-letsile-tebogo/", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles finishes 3rd in 200 meters won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nIt was Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone vs her own world record\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games.\n\nHe also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nAfter winning a thrilling 100 meters four nights earlier, Lyles came to the press conference, pulled out the bronze medal from Tokyo, slapped it on the table and said that had been his motivation to add the shorter sprint to his repertoire in an attempt to become a larger-than-track star.\n\nNow, he has two of those bronze medals, though the tale of this one played out much differently.\n\nLyles said he tested positive two days after the 100 final\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4\u00d7100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of a race that, before this week, he hadn't lost since the third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nThis time -- nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nDavis-Woodhall and Holloway take two more American gold medals\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters on her fourth jump to capture the gold medal and join the likes of Tiana Bartoletta, Brittney Reese and the great Jackie Joyner-Kersee as Americans to win that event.\n\nGrant Holloway of the U.S. cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss. He won the world championship in 2019, 2022 and 2023. American teammate Daniel Roberts took silver.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 Usain Bolt accomplished that double at three Olympics in a row -- in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. But until the Jamaican, no man had done it since Carl Lewis at Los Angeles in 1984.\n\nThe 200 is Lyles' preferred, and better, distance -- one at which he had not lost a race in three full years. That streak was snapped earlier this week at the Stade de France in a semifinal, where Letsile Tebogo of Botswana beat him to the line by crossing in 19.96 seconds, 0.12 faster than runner-up Lyles.\n\nBefore pulling out his narrow win over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in the 100 final on Sunday night, Lyles didn't finish first in his heat or his semifinal.\n\nAs anyone who pays any attention is well aware, Lyles is a showman who loves the spotlight and enjoys spending time with a microphone.\n\nSo it raised some eyebrows when Lyles skipped the interview area after Wednesday's run, and U.S. team officials said he was heading to the medical tent. Turns out, he has COVID", "body": "Lyles came in third in the men's 200m final with a time of 19.70 seconds, meaning he was among the best, even while sick. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds and the USA's Kenneth Bednarek won the silver finishing with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nThe \"World's Fastest Man,\" as Noah Lyles has become known at the Paris Olympics, was diagnosed with COVID a couple of days ago, his mother told NBC Olympics Thursday -- the same day he fell short of earning the gold for the United States in the 100m and 200m sprints.\n\nLyles came in third in the men's 200m final with a time of 19.70 seconds, meaning he was among the best, even while sick. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds and the USA's Kenneth Bednarek won the silver finishing with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nThe 200m is Lyles' premiere, preferred event and he's ranked number one in the world for it. Lyles needed medical attention after the race, but it wasn't clear what the issue was or if it was related to his COVID diagnosis.\n\nNBC Olympics' commentator Lewis Johnson described to viewers what he saw as Lyles was taken off in a wheelchair by medical personnel.\n\n\"As we saw Noah Lyles being taken off there in a wheelchair, I ran down underneath the stadium to try to find where he was. I ran into his mom, Keisha Caine Bishop, who was distraught trying to find him as well. We found Noah Lyles in medical there being tended to,\" Johnson said.\n\nJohnson went on to say that Lyles' mother \"did confirm Noah had been diagnosed with COVID two days ago. That's right, diagnosed with COVID two days ago. But he decided, he was going to run anyway. And obviously, what he has there, may have affected how he performed. He is now, again, with medical people and again, his mom is also distraught. But that's the issue, Noah has COVID.\"\n\nAdditionally, according to The Associated Press, after crossing the line third, Lyles fell to his back and eventually sat up to be tended to by medical staff. A person familiar with Lyles' condition, who did not want to be identified, also told the AP was diagnosed with COVID two days before the final.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and a year delay before the Games led to depression that he said hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nIt was a star-studded crowd at the stadium for the 200m and included Simone Biles, Mick Jagger, Snoop Dogg, Mikaela Shiffrin and Leon Marchand.\n\nLyles is still scheduled to compete in the {"uri": "8265938785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:55:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:55:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:54:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.greenfieldreporter.com/2024/08/08/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-finishes-3rd-in-200-meters-won-by-botswanas-letsile-tebogo/", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles finishes 3rd in 200 meters won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo - The Daily Reporter - Greenfield Indiana", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nIt was Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone vs her own world record\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games.\n\nHe also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nAfter winning a thrilling 100 meters four nights earlier, Lyles came to the press conference, pulled out the bronze medal from Tokyo, slapped it on the table and said that had been his motivation to add the shorter sprint to his repertoire in an attempt to become a larger-than-track star.\n\nNow, he has two of those bronze medals, though the tale of this one played out much differently.\n\nLyles said he tested positive two days after the 100 final\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4\u00d7100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of a race that, before this week, he hadn't lost since the third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nThis time -- nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nDavis-Woodhall and Holloway take two more American gold medals\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters on her fourth jump to capture the gold medal and join the likes of Tiana Bartoletta, Brittney Reese and the great Jackie Joyner-Kersee as Americans to win that event.\n\nGrant Holloway of the U.S. cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss. He won the world championship in 2019, 2022 and 2023. American teammate Daniel Roberts took silver.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 'I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.'\n\nTebogo's victory was an incredibly moving story in its own right, coming just a few months after the death of his mother and inspiration, Seratiwa.\n\nTebogo's mother accompanied him to Budapest in 2023 when he won a silver medal behind Lyles in the 100m at the World Championships.\n\n'Letsile is not a man of many words,' Seratiwa said not long before she died. Which makes him the opposite of Lyles.\n\nLast night, though, Tebogo dedicated his victory to his mother and shouted out his talent with his performance.\n\nTebogo was so comfortable at the front that he started beating the palm of his hand against his chest before he had even crossed the line. Remind you of anyone? If there was one sprinter laying claim to Bolt's crown in the Stade de France, it wasn't Lyles.\n\n'Comparing somebody to somebody else is the lazy man's understanding,' Lyles said recently of the way he is measured against Bolt.\n\nAfter collapsing on the track, Lyles wasted no time in telling the world that he had been suffering from Covid for the last three days\n\nTebogo was so comfortable at the front that he started beating the palm of his hand against his chest before he had even crossed the line\n\nTebogo's victory was an incredibly moving story in its own right, coming just a few months after the death of his mother and inspiration, Seratiwa\n\nBut the truth is that he invites those comparisons by laying claim to Bolt's mantle as athletics' greatest showman.\n\nBolt always backed up his bravado. He won the 100m-200m double at the Olympics of Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016.\n\nRead More\n\nBREAKING NEWS\n\nGold medal favorite for 200m COLLAPSES and reveals he has COVID - then hugs rivals despite infection\n\nLyles may be even more of an extrovert than Bolt, and his antics before the start may be wilder and he may talk more than the great Jamaican but he is a long way from inheriting his crown.\n\nHe has had a fantastic Games here in Paris. A gold medal in the 100m -- the race he calls his mistress -- and now a bronze in the 200m -- the race he calls his wife -- is some performance.\n\nThe thing is, whatever your excuse, when you aim for the stars, when you win the 100m and say, 'Goodness gracious, I'm incredible', you better live up to it.\n\n'I'm pretty confident,' Lyles said ahead of the 200m final. 'I can't lie. I'll be winning. When they come off the turn, they will be depressed.' When you say that, you better back it up.\n\nLyles couldn't do it. He is a brilliant athlete but he is not a phenomenon, as Bolt was. The same goes for Jakob Ingebrigtsen. A superstar but way too fallible to be remembered as the greatest of all time.\n\nAs Tebogo celebrated becoming the first-ever African winner of the men's 200m at the Olympic Games, Lyles lay flat on his back yards from the line, gasping for air.\n\nLyles may be even more of an extrovert than Usain Bolt but he is a long way from inheriting his crown\n\nLyles couldn't do it. He is a brilliant athlete but he is not a phenomenon, as Bolt was. The same goes for Jakob Ingebrigtsen\n\nRumours soon began to circulate that USA Track and Field had said Lyles was suffering from Covid and teammate Bednarek said he had heard his compatriot had 'some sickness going on'\n\nThe man that one publication christened The Big Noise was quiet now and struggled to rise to his feet. Eventually, he hauled himself on to one knee and stayed like that for some time.\n\nHe began to try to walk back towards the athletes' tunnel but he could not make it and he collapsed against a wall and asked for help from medics.\n\nRead More Fans MOCK Noah Lyles for bold 200m prediction after American fails to land historic Olympics double\n\nSeveral crowded around him, helped him into a wheelchair and pushed it out of the stadium. A Paris 2024 spokesperson said Lyles had been unable to walk away on his own.\n\nRumours soon began to circulate that USA Track and Field had said Lyles was suffering from Covid-19 and Bednarek said he had heard his compatriot had 'some sickness going on'.\n\nAfter the race, Lyles confirmed he had tested positive for Covid in the early hours of Tuesday morning and had been quarantining at a hotel since and trying to recover.\n\nHe said he had recovered a lot of his energy by Thursday but did not want to tell anyone about his illness because he did not want to give his rivals an edge before the race.\n\n'I've had better days,' Lyles said afterwards, 'but I am walking around again. I was quite light-headed after that race.\n\n'The chest pain was definitely active. But after a while I caught my breath and had my wits about me. I feel a lot better now.'\n\nWhatever the reason for his performance, whether it was down to his failings, his illness or to the brilliance of Tebogo, Lyles never got close to his rival.\n\nHe might have won the 100m by five-thousandths of a second earlier this week but this time, he could not get within a country mile of Tebogo.\n\nGiven he was sick, it might perhaps have been wise to conserve some of his energy instead of sprinting out of the tunnel before the race like a man possessed by furies.\n\nHistory, after all, was on the line here. Only nine men have ever won the sprint double at an Olympic Games and it is an impressive list. Men like Jesse Owens, Valeriy Borzov, Carl Lewis and, of course, Bolt are on it and Lyles desperately wanted to join them in the pantheon.\n\nAfter his double at those World Championships in Budapest, he wanted another double here to set the seal on his greatness.\n\nThe only double he got was a second bronze to go with the one he claimed at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.\n\nA second gold of these Games never looked close to happening. Lyles was slow out of the blocks, as so often happens, and he did not once threaten to close the gap to Tebogo.\n\nOnly nine men have ever won the sprint double at an Olympic Games and it is an impressive list. Men like Jesse Owens, Valeriy Borzov, Carl Lewis (pictured) and, of course, Bolt are on it\n\nHe might have won the 100m by five-thousandths of a second earlier this week but this time, he could not get within a country mile of Tebogo\n\nAs the race flattened out after the bend, it became obvious just how much work Lyles had to do to catch the man from Botswana.\n\nHe could not close the gap and Tebogo flew over the line, carried by shoes that bore his mother's date of birth.\n\n'It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,' the new champion said. {"uri": "8266152199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "01:11:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T01:11:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T01:10:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://nybreaking.com/letsile-tebogo-delivers-savage-verdict-on-arrogant-noah-lyles-after-beating-team-usa-sprinter-to-win-200m-gold-at-2024-olympics/", "title": "Letsile Tebogo Delivers Savage Verdict On 'arrogant' Noah Lyles After Beating Team USA Sprinter To Win 200m Gold At 2024 Olympics - Ny Breaking News", "body": "Insile Tebogo won a surprise gold medal in the 200 meters on Thursday and delivered a harsh verdict on Noah Lyles after he beat the American sprinter.\n\nLyles had confidently told reporters beforehand that he would win the race and made a most bombastic entrance into the Stade de France, jumping around and waving his arms at the crowd.\n\nBut the American (who later revealed he had COVID) finished third in the race, while Tebogo led. The Botswana sprinter subsequently called Lyles \"arrogant\" and \"loud.\"\n\nThe newly-crowned 200-meter champion was asked if he wanted to be the face of track and field, and claimed that his laid-back approach would not allow him to reach Lyles' level of fame.\n\n\"I can't be the face of athletics because I'm not an arrogant or loud person like Noah,\" he said.\n\nInsile Tebogo (right) called Lyles 'arrogant' and 'loud' after beating the American sprinter\n\nLyles confirmed after the race that he had COVID and was placed in a wheelchair\n\n\"I believe Noah is the face of athletics.\"\n\nThe comment caused Lyles' American teammate Kenny Bednarek, who won silver in the race, to briefly crack a wry smile.\n\nLyles boldly predicted before the 200 meters that he would complete the double after winning gold in the 100 meters in a nail-biting final.\n\n\"...None of them win. When I come off the turn, they're going to be depressed,\" he said.\n\nHowever, that prediction proved to be wrong as Lyles finished a struggling third and was placed in a wheelchair shortly after the race, clearly out of breath due to his COVID diagnosis.\n\nHe later revealed that the Olympics were likely over and thanked his fans on Instagram for their support.\n\nLyles was scheduled to compete in the 4\u00d7100 meter relay, but said he \"hopes\"[d] Everyone enjoyed the show.'\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nLyles (rear left) finished third despite being the outright favorite before the race\n\nLyles was clearly struggling to breathe after finishing third in the event on Thursday\n\nThe sprinter's mother confirmed to NBC that he had COVID before speaking to the network himself.\n\nHe told NBC, wearing a mask: \"I woke up early, Tuesday morning at 5 a.m., and I felt absolutely horrible. I knew it was more than muscle soreness out of 100. My first thought was not to panic, I've been in worse situations, I've been in worse circumstances.\n\n\"I just took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much as I could. It would definitely take its toll, but I've never been so proud of myself to come here and get a bronze medal.\"\n\nLyles later said that the other competitors were unaware of his diagnosis: \"We tried to keep it a secret. The medical staff, my coach, my mother knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everyone to panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to keep it as discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors that you're sick. {"uri": "8265829047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:12:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:12:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:11:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/us-track-star-noah-lyles-takes-bronze-200-meter-letsile-tebogo-botswan-rcna165841", "title": "U.S. track star Noah Lyles takes bronze in 200-meter as Letsile Tebogo of Botswana wins gold", "body": "PARIS -- With a chance to join the likes of Usain Bolt and Carl Lewis in Olympic history, American sprinting star Noah Lyles was upset in his bid to add to his gold-medal haul Thursday.\n\nRacing in the 200-meter final inside Stade de France, Lyles finished a distant third in 19.70 seconds, behind gold medalist Letsile Tebogo of Botswana in 19.46 and fellow American Kenny Bednarek in 19.62. Lyles was attempting to become the first man to sweep both sprints at an Olympics since Bolt in 2016, and the first from the U.S. since Lewis 40 years ago.\n\nChants of \"USA\" rang out as runners stepped into their blocks, then silence overtook the stadium. Running from the fifth lane, Lyles was behind by a sizable margin coming off of the turn into the homestretch. He had run from behind to win the 100-meter title four nights earlier but in this race, the gap was too big to overcome.\n\nThe result was a surprise because unlike the 100 meters, where Lyles had developed into a medal contender only during the past two years, he was the heavy favorite in the 200, his specialty. Lyles had won 26 consecutive races dating to 2021 until finishing second in Wednesday's semifinal -- also to Tebogo -- and had been 38-5 all-time against the seven other sprinters in Thursday's final.\n\nTo say Lyles entered the final confidence would be an understatement; \"I'll be winning,\" he had predicted four nights earlier, after his 100-meter gold medal. He vowed to leave his competitors \"depressed\" as they rounded the turn, halfway through. The opposite happened, as Lyles was clearly behind and having to work to gain any ground on Tebogo and Bednarek entering the homestretch. It was Bednarek's second consecutive Olympic silver medal.\n\nLyles entered the Tokyo Olympics as a favorite to win the 200 after dealing with what he has called lingering physical and mental-health struggles but left with bronze, a result he called \"boring\" in the moment. In the three years since the 27-year-old Lyles, who first gained prominence as a high schooler in Virginia, has openly showed vulnerability away from the track while also displaying few weaknesses on it. After earning his first Olympic gold medal Sunday, Lyles shared on X, formerly known as Twitter, that \"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become.\"\n\nHis opportunities to win more gold are not over, but his bid to become the first man to win four track and field medals in one Olympics since Lewis in 1984 is done. The U.S. men have qualified for Friday's final of the 4x100-meter relay, and Lyles has lobbied for months to run a leg on the 4x400-meter relay, as well.\n\nAfter winning his 100-meter gold medal, Lyles stayed up until 2:45 a.m. Monday morning while rewatching his victory by five-thousandths of a second, getting a massage to recharge his legs ahead of his 200-meter first-round race later that afternoon, and carrying out what he called \"boyfriend duties.\" His girlfriend, the Olympic Jamaican sprinter Junelle Bromfield, had forgotten her spikes at their massage therapist's room and asked Lyles to pick them up on his way back to the Olympic Village.\n\n\"So here I am at 2 a.m., waddling with a spike bag, my bag and some toiletries,\" Lyles said. \"I'm like 'huh, here I am, Olympic champion, 100 meters'.\"\n\nMaybe that wasn't exactly how he envisioned the aftermath of winning his first Olympic gold medal, but he laughed at himself as he told the story the next day. He wasn't expecting the 200 to end in a similarly unexpected way.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448538756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:23:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:23:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.espn.co.uk/olympics/story/_/id/40780740/noah-lyles-wins-200m-bronze-covid-diagnosis-revealed-race", "title": "Positive COVID test revealed after Lyles' bronze", "body": "Previously covered Florida State for Orlando Sentinel and Georgia Tech for Macon Telegraph\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- After Noah Lyles finished in third place in the 200-meter final, NBC's broadcast indicated it had spoken with his mother, who said Lyles had been diagnosed with COVID on Tuesday.\n\nLyles later joined the broadcast and said he got tested after not feeling well around 5 a.m. Tuesday morning. He added that he never thought about not running after his diagnosis.\n\nLyles isn't sure if he will still participate in the 4x100-meter, but he said the Americans have the speed to run the race without him.\n\nOne day after losing the 200-meter semifinal to Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Lyles was unable to surpass him once again in the final Thursday night.\n\nTebogo ran an African-record 19.46 to earn the 200-meter gold medal. Finishing just behind him with silver was American Kenny Bednarek, who posted a 19.62-second showing.\n\nAs soon as he crossed the finish line third, Lyles laid down on his back on the track. Within moments, he was surrounded by athletic trainers and members of the Paris Olympics medical staff, who moved him toward a wall as they administered treatment.\n\nAt one point, Lyles was seen wearing a mask before being placed in a chair which was eventually wheeled into the nearby tunnel.\n\nJust after Wednesday's semifinal heat, Lyles did not come through the media mixed zone. He was taken directly to medical for an undisclosed reason.\n\nDuring Thursday's race, all eight runners got off to a somewhat even start. Lyles was in the hunt early. Around the 100-meter mark, Tebogo and Bednarek began pulling away. Although Lyles was still hanging close with them, Tebogo's lead was one he was not relinquishing easily.\n\nMinutes after the race, Lyles was also handed a yellow card for a violation of Technical Rule 7.1 for \"improper conduct.\" It wasn't immediately clear why he was given it, but during introductions, he did demonstrably jump onto the track as he heard his name.\n\nWhile pumping up the crowd before the race, Lyles smacked the box housing the speaker in his lane so hard that the number on the box fell off.\n\nLyles' 200-meter showing followed his 9.79-second, personal-best effort in Sunday's close 100-meter dash. He earned the gold medal in what was the closest 100-meter final since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or perhaps ever. Back then, Great Britain's Allan Wells narrowly beat Silvio Leonard in 10.25 seconds in an era when timing didn't go down to the thousandths of a second.", "source": {"uri": "espn.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-448466402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "18:45:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T18:45:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:37:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.wthr.com/article/sports/olympics/did-noah-lyles-win-200m/507-0e50ad4b-29fa-4581-99a4-43c3e7af2bf1", "title": "How did Noah Lyles do in the Olympic 200-meter final?", "body": "The newly crowned World's Fastest Man looked to make history in the 200 meters.\n\nPARIS, France -- Noah Lyles came up short in his quest to win the 200 meters, just days after his close-as-can-be win by five thousandths of a second in the 100 meters.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo won, American Kenny Bednarek got silver and Lyles finished third.\n\nLyles fell to the track in the immediate aftermath and was tended to by trainers before getting up and walking over to a nearby bench.\n\nThe 200 was supposed to be the easy half of Lyles' historic Olympic sprint double for the newly crowned World's Fastest Man.\n\nTebogo crossed the finished line in 19.46 seconds, followed by Bednarek in 19.62 and Lyles in 19.70.\n\nFellow American Erriyon Knighton finished 4th in 19.99 seconds.\n\nGetting golds in the 100 and 200 at a single Olympics is a rare feat. Usain Bolt accomplished that double at three Olympics in a row -- in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. But until the Jamaican, no man had done it since Carl Lewis at Los Angeles in 1984.\n\nThe 200 is Lyles' preferred, and better, distance -- one at which he had not lost a race in three full years. That streak was snapped earlier this week at the Stade de France in a semifinal, where Letsile Tebogo of Botswana beat him to the line by crossing in 19.96 seconds, 0.12 faster than runner-up Lyles.\n\nBefore pulling out his narrow win over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in the 100 final on Sunday night, Lyles didn't finish first in his heat or his semifinal.\n\nAs anyone who pays any attention is well aware, Lyles is a showman who loves the spotlight and enjoys spending time with a microphone.\n\nSo it raised some eyebrows when Lyles skipped the interview area after Wednesday's run, and U.S. team officials said he was heading to the medical tent. {"uri": "8265835428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:17:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:17:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:17:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/noah-lyles-wins-bronze-after-being-diagnosed-with-covid/", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins Bronze in Men's 200m After Being Diagnosed with COVID", "body": "Noah Lyles took home the bronze medal in the men's 200m final at the 2024 Paris Olympics two days after being diagnosed with COVID.\n\nTeam USA's Lyles, 27, won bronze in the tightly-contested race on Thursday, August 8, his second medal in Paris. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won gold with Lyles' fellow American Kenny Bednarek taking home silver. Lyles finished with a time of 19.70 seconds, which was .24 seconds off Tebogo's winning pace.\n\nAfter the race, Lyles looked absolutely gassed, falling to the track as he attempted to regain himself. \"He looks like he is struggling to breathe,\" NBC Sports' Leigh Diffey said.\n\nMoments later, NBC Sports reported Lyles had been diagnosed with COVID on Tuesday, August 6, but decided to race anyway. COVID guidelines in Paris do not require athletes to isolate or miss events.\n\nLyles -- who was seen wearing a mask shortly before the race -- was greeted by medical staff who eventually put him in a wheelchair to escort him off the track. NBC reported Lyles' mother Keisha was \"distraught\" trying to find her son, who has a history of asthma, after the race.\n\nLyles won gold in the men's 100m final on Sunday, August 4 in a race that was decided by 0.0005 seconds. The American barely eclipsed Jamaica's Kishane Thompson, who won silver. Lyles' Team USA compatriot Fred Kerley took home bronze.\n\nAfter the race, Lyles posted an inspirational message on social media to his followers.\n\n\"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression,\" he wrote via X. \"But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\"\n\nLyles -- who has never lacked for confidence -- said \"it feels good to back it up\" after winning gold in the 100m.\n\nWhile his eyes remained set on the upcoming 200m, he didn't shy away from discussing his post-Olympics plans, too.\n\n\"I want my own shoe,\" Lyles boasted after winning his first gold medal. \"I want my own trainer -- I'm dead serious. There ain't no money in spikes, it's in sneakers. And even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. I feel like for how many medals we bring back, for the notoriety we get...the fact that that hasn't happened, that's crazy to me. I was like, 'Yeah, that needs to happen.'\"\n\n\"The most misunderstood thing is the balance between cocky and confident,\" Lyles said. \"There is a strong line that people assume my confidence is cockiness. I will say this. Anybody who thought I was cocky and met me, they're instantly like, 'Oh, that's the nicest, coolest guy I've ever met in my life.'\"\n\nLyles continued, \"I never blame anybody who thinks that I'm cocky. It's just a 'you haven't met me situation.' That's all.\"\n\nUp next, Lyles is tentatively scheduled to compete in the men's 4\u00d7100 relay final on Friday, August 9 where he would look to take home his third medal of the 2024 Paris Olympics. He received medical attention and collapsed into a wheelchair after the run. Letsile Tebogo of Botswana won the gold, and American Kenny Bednarek took the silver.\n\nLyles has asthma, as he noted after winning the gold medal in the 100-meter dash Sunday to become the \"World's Fastest Man.\"\n\nLyles lay on the track after crossing the finish line. After receiving medical attention, he collapsed into a wheelchair and was wheeled off the track. He was offered oxygen but did not appear to take it.\n\nNoah Lyles has COVID: What is his status for rest of Olympics 2024?\n\nLyles said after the race he tested positive for COVID on Tuesday. He did the interview in a mask.\n\n\"I just was feeling really horrible and I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100, so I woke up the doctors and we tested, and unfortunately it turned up that I was positive for COVID,\" Lyles said in an interview with NBC. He said he quarantined and stayed as hydrated as he could.\n\nAsked if he ever considered not running in the 200m final, Lyles responded \"No.\" He said he did not know whether he would compete in Friday's 4x100-meter relay final with Team USA.\n\nWho is Noah Lyles?\n\nLyles was born in Gainesville. The 26-year-old was raised in Alexandria, Virginia, and committed to run track at the University of Florida before turning pro.\n\nAfter a disappointing bronze-medal finish at the 2020 Olympics, Lyles broke the American record for the 200m at the 2022 World Championships. He then won three gold medals at the 2023 World Championships, making him a favorite to be a star at the Paris Olympics.\n\nThe brash Lyles came to Paris aiming to equal Usain Bolt's mark of three gold medals in one Olympics. He won the 100m gold in a photo finish but settled for bronze in the 200m, his best event. {"uri": "8265943275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:00:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:00:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:59:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.news4jax.com/health/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-competed-in-the-olympic-200-with-covid-and-finished-3rd-what-we-know-about-his-illness/", "title": "Noah Lyles competed in the Olympic 200 with COVID and finished 3rd. What we know about his illness", "body": "SAINT-DENIS - Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere's what we know about the timeline of Lyles' illness:\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nWhen did Lyles know he had COVID?\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWhat happened in his 200-meter race?\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nWhy was he allowed to run?\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nWhat races does Lyles have left?\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4x100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "news4jax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News 4 Jax"}, "authors": [{"uri": Letsile Tebogo of Botswana won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds, and Lyles' American teammate, Kenny Bednarek, won the silver with a time of 19.62. Lyles crossed the line in 19.70 seconds, well clear of Tebogo.\n\nLyles was taken off the track in a wheelchair, according to a Paris 2024 official, and was receiving medical attention after the race. NBC reported that he was diagnosed COVID-19 two days ago.\n\nThree years ago, Lyles was the heavy favorite in this race at the Tokyo Olympics. He finished third and broke down in tears while talking to journalists afterward. Lyles was diagnosed with depression during the pandemic, and the absence of fans in Tokyo sapped his energy. He opened up about this difficult stretch, then needed to be convinced by his coach and sports psychologist to run in the Prefontaine Classic a few weeks later, to get back on a winning track. Lyles relented, then won that race.\n\nRead More: Welcome to the Noah Lyles Olympics\n\nHe had been ascending ever since. At the 2022 world championships in Eugene, Ore., he broke Michael Johnson's American record of 19.32 seconds, running it in 19.31. Lyles defended that title last year, added the 100 m to his program and won that world title in Budapest, making him the world's fastest man, and then on Sunday, caught up to Kishane Thompson of Jamaica at the very, very last moment, winning the 100-m Olympic race by .005 seconds.\n\nLyles watched his memorable 100-m victory a few hours after winning the race, while receiving treatment. \"When I first saw it, I was like, 'Oh, I really was in last place,'\" said Lyles after running his first 200-m round on Monday. His reaction time at the start was tied with Letsile Tebogo of Botswana for slowest in the sprint.\n\nRead More: Omelets, Air-Conditioning, and Embracing the Emotion: How Gabby Thomas Won 200-M Olympic Gold\n\nBut Lyles couldn't go out and celebrate his victory -- he had to run the next day. And before that he had to report for boyfriend duty. His girlfriend, 400-m runner Junelle Bromfield of Jamaica, asked him to pick up her spike bag from their massage therapist, who has an Airbnb near the Olympic Village, and return it to her. \"So here I am at 2 a.m., waddling with a spike bag, my bag, and some toiletries,\" says Lyles. \"And I'm like, huh, here I am, Olympic champion, 100 meters, waddling in my girlfriend's room with all this stuff.\"\n\nHe'll return to the track, spike bags and all, for the 4x100 relay tomorrow night, to try to win his second gold of these games.\n\nBut Lyles expected more, guaranteeing to TIME before the Olympics that he'd win three gold medals. He displayed his usual showmanship before the race, jumping over the rail during his introduction, and knocking the lane number off his block when he struck it before the start. {"uri": "2024-08-448610992", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:14:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:14:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:01:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.theroar.com.au/2024/08/09/noah-lyles-shock-diagnosis-after-falling-short-in-sprint-double-bid-pre-race-antics-raise-questions/", "title": "Noah Lyles' shock diagnosis after falling short in sprint double bid -  pre-race antics raise questions", "body": "Noah Lyles' bid to win the Olympic Games 100m-200m double came to grief in the Stade de France with the American removed from the stadium on a wheelchair, saying he had Covid, but opted to run anyway.\n\nThe 200m world champion, and winner of the 100m gold earlier in Paris, was beaten into bronze in a race won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles looked fatigued down the straight - although he had jumped around before the race in his usual exuberant style, leading many to question why he would waste so much energy on that if suffering illness.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for his second straight Olympic 200m bronze, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"I do have Covid,\" Lyles said. \"I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday. I woke up feeling chills, aching, sore throat. Those were a lot of the symptoms I have had before getting Covid. I was like: 'I need to test this one.' It came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and they got me on as much medication as they legally could to make sure my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, they said it was still possible so we stayed away from everybody and took it round by round. I have definitely had better days but I am walking around again. I was quite light headed after that race and the chest pain was definitely active. After a while I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me. I am feeling a lot better now. It definitely affected my performance.\"\n\nThe US track federation released a statement saying it and the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4\u00d7100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek of the United States finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles got the bronze in 19.70.\n\nOlympic Games Paris 2024. Every Event. Ad-free. Live & On Demand. 4K. 8 Exclusive International channels from Eurosport, Viacom18 and Sky NZ only on Stan Sport.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lacklustre semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of a race that, before this week, he hadn't lost since the third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nThis time nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nYet Lyles gave little away when he came out for the race. He's known for his enthusiasm and it was all out there again.\n\nHe jumped and danced around the track, flapping his arms and screaming at the crwod. He booted his starter's block, and picked up a yellow card.\n\n\"I already had a bunch of energy. This is by far the best day I've felt out of the last three days. Still not 100%, but closer to 90 to 95%. That only works for one shot. I got to settle down for a while. It's one and done, there's no holding back,\" Lyles said of his pre-race antics.\n\nThe serenity of the eventual champion was a distinct contrast.\n\n\"It was really a beautiful race for me,\" Tebogo said. \"When we made it to the final, my coach just told me, 'Now my job is done, it's up to you to see what you can do. Whether it's a medal or not, just finish the race healthy'.\n\n\"That's all I could've wished for. I'm happy I finished the race healthier than before.\"\n\nTebogo runs with his mother's date of birth written on his shoes.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" said the sprinter, who took a month off training and competition after her death.\n\n\"It gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy. I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.\" Tebogo added: \"I'm really grateful for the team around me. They really pushed me through thick and thin.\n\n\"We had our ups and downs, but we just made sure that we pulled through and made it to the Olympics.\"", "source": {"uri": "theroar.com.au", What we know about his illness", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere's what we know about the timeline of Lyles' illness:\n\nWhen did Lyles know he had COVID?\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWhat happened in his 200-meter race?\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nWhy was he allowed to run?\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games in China, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nFrance, which once had tight COVID restrictions, no longer has rules for people with the virus, just recommendations to those who test positive to self-isolate.\n\nThe World Health Organization said Tuesday that 40 athletes at the Olympics had tested positive for the virus amid growing cases worldwide.\n\nWhat races does Lyles have left?\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4\u00d7100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as {"uri": "8265826296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:09:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:09:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/noah-lyles-comes-short-olympic-183411350.html", "title": "Noah Lyles comes up short in Olympic men's 200 meters while reportedly battling COVID", "body": "After a thrilling, historic victory in the men's 100 meters earlier this week, Noah Lyles reportedly was diagnosed with COVID and finished third in the 200-meter final.\n\nOn Thursday night at the 2024 Summer Games, the American sprinter came up short in the 200, thereby ending his hopes for an Olympic sprint triple.\n\nLyles finished a surprise third in the race amid great hype entering the contest.\n\nLetsile Tebogo of Botswana took gold in 19.46 seconds, with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62 seconds. Lyles was third across the line in 19.70 seconds.\n\nAfter the race Lyles, who has battled asthma, sat on the track winded and received medical treatment.\n\nMedical personnel wheeled Noah Lyles down a hallway deep beneath the stands at Stade de France. As he was taken by wheelchair for examination, someone asked if he wanted to call his mother. He shook his head.\n\n\"I just needed some time,\" he said. \"So they wheeled me off the track. \"\n\nRead more: How timekeepers determined Noah Lyles won 100 meters by slimmest of margins\n\nA minute later, his mother rushed down the hallway after him.\n\nNBC news reported his mother confirmed Lyles was diagnosed with COVID two days earlier but still was committed to running.\n\nThe COVID safety restrictions that dramatically altered the Tokyo Olympics were abandoned for the Paris Olympics and mask use was limited.\n\nThe last man to accomplish the Olympic triple Lyles sought was Usain Bolt, who did it twice, at London 2012 and Rio 2016.\n\nLyles has another shot at gold in the 4x100 relay Friday, but it's unclear he will be healthy enough to participate.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448570526", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:10:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:10:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T16:20:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/aug/8/covid-stricken-noah-lyles-finishes-3rd-in-200-mete/", "title": "COVID-stricken Noah Lyles finishes 3rd in 200 meters won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, the Alexandria, Virginia, native fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games.\n\nHe also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nAfter winning a thrilling 100 meters four nights earlier, Lyles came to the press conference, pulled out the bronze medal from Tokyo, slapped it on the table and said that had been his motivation to add the shorter sprint to his repertoire in an attempt to become a larger-than-track star.\n\nNow, he has two of those bronze medals, though the tale of this one played out much differently.\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of a race that, before this week, he hadn't lost since the third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nThis time -- nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters on her fourth jump to capture the gold medal and join the likes of Tiana Bartoletta, Brittney Reese and the great Jackie Joyner-Kersee as Americans to win that event.\n\nGrant Holloway of the U.S. cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss. He won the world championship in 2019, 2022 and 2023. American teammate Daniel Roberts took silver.\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 What we know about his illness", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere's what we know about the timeline of Lyles' illness:\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4x100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as After the race, the 100-meter dash gold medalist was seen struggling to catch his breath and had to be taken off the track in a wheelchair.\n\n\"I tested positive around 5 a.m. Tuesday morning,\" Lyles said in the media mixed zone while wearing a black KN95 mask, per ESPN's Coley Harvey. \"I woke up in the middle of the night just feeling really chills, aching, sore throat. And those were kind of a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting COVID, and I was just like, 'I need to test this one.'\"\n\nFollowing the positive result, Lyles was quarantined at a hotel near the Olympic Village and received medical treatment. He said he kept his diagnosis a secret for multiple reasons.\n\n\"One, we didn't want everybody to go into a panic; we wanted them to be able to compete,\" Lyles said. \"And then two, we wanted to be able to make it as discreet as possible. And you never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nLetsile Tebogo of Botswana took home the gold medal after running an African-record 19.46 in the 200-meter. After kneeling for about 30 seconds, he got into a wheelchair,\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nHe said that after his Tuesday diagnosis, \"I still wanted to run. They said it was possible.\"\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo won the race, with American Kenny Bednarek winning the silver medal.\n\nLyles said there was a strategy behind keeping his COVID status a secret.\n\n\"We were trying to keep this as close to the chest as possible. You never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\" he said, according to NBC.\n\nLyles said following his finish, he was \"quite lightheaded after that race, and shortness of breath and chest pain was definitely active.\"\n\n\"But after a while, I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me. So I'm feeling a lot better now,\" he said.\n\n\"I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. {"uri": "8265986501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:43:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:43:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-competed-in-the-olympic-200-with-covid-and-finished-3rd-what-we-know-about-his-illness/", "title": "Noah Lyles competed in the Olympic 200 with COVID-19 and finished 3rd. What we know about his illness", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID-19 two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere's what we know about the timeline of Lyles' illness:\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal Wednesday and finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak with reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95% when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually when the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line, then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID-19 test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says it followed current policies.\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4\u00d7100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as {"uri": "2024-08-448624105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:40:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:40:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:34:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/article-paris-olympics-covid-stricken-noah-lyles-finishes-third-in-200-metres/", "title": "Paris Olympics: COVID-stricken Noah Lyles finishes third in 200 metres", "body": "Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 metres Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-metre hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles's trip to the Games.\n\nHe also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nAfter winning a thrilling 100 metres four nights earlier, Lyles came to the news conference, pulled out the bronze medal from Tokyo, slapped it on the table and said that had been his motivation to add the shorter sprint to his repertoire in an attempt to become a larger-than-track star.\n\nNow, he has two of those bronze medals, though the tale of this one played out much differently.\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95 per cent.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of a race that, before this week, he hadn't lost since the third-place finish in Tokyo.\n\nThis time - nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 metres on her fourth jump to capture the gold medal and join the likes of Tiana Bartoletta, Brittney Reese and the great Jackie Joyner-Kersee as Americans to win that event.\n\nGrant Holloway of the U.S. cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss. He won the world championship in 2019, 2022 and 2023. American teammate Daniel Roberts took silver.\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France. Nadeem set an Oympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 metres in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008. {"uri": "2024-08-448645951", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:24:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:24:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:08:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://thesource.com/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-runs-away-with-bronze-medal-in-200-meter-race-after-testing-positive-for-covid/", "title": "Noah Lyles Runs Away With Bronze Medal in 200-Meter Race After Testing Positive for Covid", "body": "Winning medals in the Olympics with COVID? Okay, we thought we've seen it all during the Paris games but add this to the list. Just two days after revealing that he had tested positive for COVID-19, American sprinter Noah Lyles took home the bronze medal in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics.\n\nVisit streaming.thesource.com for more information\n\nHere's the nitty gritty ... Lyles finished the epic race with a time of 19.70 seconds, securing third place behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, who won gold with a time of 19.46 seconds, marking a historic moment as Botswana's first-ever Olympic gold medal. American Kenny Bednarek claimed the silver with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nBut wait, despite testing positive for COVID-19, Lyles remained determined to compete. He moved into a hotel to quarantine away from the Olympic Village and arrived at the track for Wednesday's semifinal wearing a mask. He chose not to disclose his diagnosis publicly before the race, stating, \"You never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nYou may expect him to slow down in the lead up to the race but the 27 year-old Lyles appeared as energetic as ever when introduced before the final, displaying his signature enthusiasm by jumping and sprinting down the track as the sold-out crowd at Stade de France fell silent.\n\nIn a scary moment after crossing the finish line, Lyles collapsed and later asked for water while seated on the track. He was eventually placed in a wheelchair and taken away from the stadium -- a stark contrast to his triumph just days earlier when he won his first Olympic gold in the 100 meters by five-thousandths of a second. After that victory, he had boldly predicted that he would win the 200 meters as well.\n\nThinking on his performance, Lyles admitted that testing positive for COVID-19 \"definitely affected my performance,\" but he remained proud of his resilience. \"To be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID in three days. It's been a wild Olympics,\" he said.\n\nUSA Track & Field and the U.S. Olympic Committee released a statement on the matter:\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles was vying to become the first man to win both the 100-meter and 200-meter sprints at an Olympics since Usain Bolt in 2016 and the first American to do so since Carl Lewis 40 years ago. Nice company.\n\nHis run at more gold medals is far from done. In he upcoming 4\u00d7100-meter relay, Lyles said he would leave the decision to USA Track & Field on whether he should run in the final, for which the U.S. team had already qualified with the fastest time in the preliminaries.
