{"uri": "2024-08-448597466", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:52:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:52:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:52:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://omaha.com/not-meant-to-be/article_629f0f1f-8f9c-5810-ac98-6602affc8474.html", "title": "Not meant to be", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nMore gold\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters on her fourth jump to capture the gold medal and join the likes of Tiana Bartoletta, Brittney Reese and the great Jackie Joyner-Kersee as Americans to win that event.\n\nGrant Holloway of the U.S. cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss. He won the world championship in 2019, 2022 and 2023. American teammate Daniel Roberts took silver.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 He did get the bronze, but had been aiming to be the first American to win both in 40 years.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo took the gold in 19.46 seconds, running away from American Kenny Bednarek -- who took silver -- and Lyles. Lyles was the favorite in the event, but ran only 19.70.\n\nUsain Bolt is the last person to accomplish the 100 meters and 200 meters -- in 2016 -- when he did it for the third straight Olympics. Carl Lewis was the last American to win the 100 and 200 when he did the double at the Los Angeles Games in 1984.\n\nLyles won the 100 meters on Tuesday in a historically close race. He edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just 0.005 seconds.\n\nLyles was attempting to win three golds at the Paris Games by also winning in the 100-meter relay. Lewis is also the last person to win the 100 meters, 200 meters and 4x100-meter relay when he did it in 1984.\n\nMORE: 'Fastest person on Earth': Team USA sprinter Noah Lyles arrives in Paris with grand Olympic ambitions\n\nFollowing his win in the 100 meters, Lyles was asked how he felt about completing the triple.\n\n\"Pretty confident,\" he said. \"I can't lie.\"\n\nLyles ran the anchor leg in the qualifying heats Thursday, taking first place in the group. {"uri": "8265834266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:16:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:16:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:15:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10131205-noah-lyles-ran-olympic-200m-final-with-covid-needed-wheelchair-after-bronze-medal", "title": "Noah Lyles Ran Olympic 200m Final with COVID; Needed Wheelchair After Bronze Medal", "body": "United States star Noah Lyles, who was taken off the track in a wheelchair after winning bronze in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday, competed after being diagnosed with COVID-19, U.S. Track and Field announced.\n\nLyles, visibly exhausted, sat down on the track after finishing the race and received medical attention just past the finish line.\n\nLyles finished Thursday's race in 19.70 seconds, just behind his United States teammate Kenny Bednarek, who won silver, and Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, who won gold.\n\nThough he earned bronze, Harvey reported that Lyles was given a yellow card for violating Technical Rule 7.1, which falls under \"improper conduct.\" Why he was given the penalty is still unclear.\n\nLyles has had an impressive showing at his second Olympics. Last week, the 27-year-old gave the United States its first gold medal in the 100-meter since 2004, beating Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a photo finish. Lyles finished with a personal-best time of 9.784 while Thompson finished with a time of 9.789.\n\nThe bronze medal on Thursday gives him his second medal of this year's games and third of his Olympic career, as he also won bronze in the 200-meter in Toyko in 2021.\n\nLyles was scheduled to compete with the men's 4x100-meter relay team on Thursday morning but sat out as the team qualified for the final. {"uri": "8265858343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:39:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:39:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:38:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/botswanas-letsile-tebogo-becomes-first-african-to-win-olympic-200m-final-6458690-Aug2024/", "title": "Botswana's Letsile Tebogo upstages Noah Lyles to become first African to win Olympic 200m final", "body": "Noah Lyles said afterwards that he tested positive for Covid two days before his bronze medal-winning performance in the men's 200m final.\n\nBOTSWANA'S LETSILE TEBOGO became the first African to win the Olympic 200 metres as he upstaged Noah Lyles' plans for a sprint double in Paris.\n\nMeanwhile, Lyles said afterwards that he tested positive for Covid two days before his bronze medal-winning performance in the men's 200m final.\n\nLyles was taken off the track in a wheelchair following the men's 200m final.\n\nIn an interview with NBC, Lyles said: \"I woke up early, about 5:00 am on Tuesday morning and I was feeling really horrible.\n\n\"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100 (metres). We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nLyles said the Covid \"has taken its toll, for sure.\"\n\nTebogo, 21, was able to ease up at the end and still clocked an African record of 19.46sec for gold with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62sec and Lyles fading to bronze in 19.70sec.\n\nThe sole African to have won a short sprint title at an Olympic Games is South African Reggie Walker, over 100m at the 1908 Games in London.\n\nHis time saw him leapfrog American Erriyon Knighton to go fifth fastest in the all-time list. The gold was also Botswana's first ever at an Olympics.\n\n\"It was really a beautiful race for me,\" Tebogo said. \"When we made it to the final, my coach just told me, 'Now my job is done, it's up to you to see what you can do. Whether it's a medal or not, just finish the race healthy'.\n\n\"That's all I could've wished for. I'm happy I finished the race healthier than before.\"\n\nTebogo's gold is even more impressive given that he lost his mother Seratiwa in May. His running shoes bear his late mother's date of birth.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" said the sprinter, who took a month off training and competition after her death.\n\n\"It gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy. I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.\"\n\nTebogo added: \"I'm really grateful for the team around me. They really pushed me through thick and thin.\n\n\"We had our ups and downs, but we just made sure that we pulled through and made it to the Olympics.\"\n\nThe final lacked the pre-race hype of the 100m, falling mid-session at a packed Stade de France.\n\nLyles was given a huge reception when introduced as cameras showed him up on the big screens at either end of the stadium.\n\nThe newly crowned 100m champion was drawn in lane five, outside Alexander Ogando and inside American teammate Erriyon Knighton, while Tebogo was in seven.\n\nThe American bounded into the stadium, as he had done before the 100m final, cupping his ear to the crowd, but his exuberant showboating saw him yellow-carded for breaking the starting block.\n\nTebogo, however, walked quietly on and went straight to his blocks.\n\nAfter the gun went for the start, Lyles was quickly up on Ogando.\n\nHe, Tebogo and Bednarek all rounded the bend well, but coming into the home straight, Lyles was in third spot.\n\nBut Tebogo looked in total control, even relaxing as he went through the finish line, making a brushing-off gesture to the rest of the field.\n\nBednarek held on for silver, with Lyles prone on the track after being unable to replicate his gold medal showing in the 100m.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024", "source": {"uri": "thejournal.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheJournal.ie"}, "authors": Despite getting off to a decent start, Lyles appeared unable to find his stride, and never really gained ground on Letsile Tebogo, from Botswana, and USA's Kenny Bednarek.\n\nMany were puzzled by how Lyles just looked different ... but now with his positive diagnosis, it makes much more sense.\n\nLyles -- who sported a mask prior to the race -- fell to the ground after crossing the finish line ... and required wheelchair assistance.\n\nTebogo finished with a time of 19.46, and Kenny, 19.62. {"uri": "8265844108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:25:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://balleralert.com/profiles/blogs/noah-lyles-tested-positive-for-covid-19-before-winning-bronze-medal-in-mens-200m-final/", "title": "Noah Lyles Tested Positive for Covid-19 Before Winning Bronze Medal in Men's 200m Final", "body": "Noah Lyles, the reigning 100m Olympic champion, finished third in the men's 200m final at the Paris 2024 Games after testing positive for Covid-19. Despite a strong start, Lyles couldn't sustain his speed, allowing Botswana's Letsile Tebogo to surge ahead and clinch gold with a time of 19.46 seconds.\n\nLyles' teammate, Kenneth Bednarek, made a remarkable late push to grab the silver, leaving Lyles to settle for bronze. Post-race, the 27-year-old was seen sitting in a chair and was wheeled off the track, raising concerns about his health.\n\nOlympic legend Michael Johnson, during his punditry for the BBC, dismissed the idea of an injury, stating, \"He certainly isn't carrying an injury because you can't do this with an injury, you can't run 19.70. If there's anything, there's some sort of illness that has zapped his energy.\"\n\nSoon after, it was confirmed by US Track and Field that Lyles had run the race despite testing positive for Covid-19.\n\nLyles had aimed to achieve a rare Olympic treble by winning the 100m, 200m, and 4x100m relay. After a thrilling victory in the 100m final by a mere five-thousandths of a second, he seemed poised to join the ranks of American legends like Jesse Owens, Bobby Morrow, and Carl Lewis, as well as Usain Bolt, in securing the triple. However, just as in his semi-final, Lyles was unable to close the gap on Tebogo in the 200m final.\n\nLetsile Tebogo's victory was historic, as he became the first African to win the Olympic 200m title, setting an African record and earning Botswana's first-ever Olympic gold medal. Tebogo, who previously won bronze at the World Championships and set a national record in the 100m, delivered a dominant performance, making him the fifth-fastest man in history over the 200m distance.\n\nKenneth Bednarek, with his second consecutive silver, finished in 19.62 seconds, while Noah Lyles, hoping to become the first American to achieve the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.'\n\nAfter his words came back to bite him on Thursday, fans took to social media to mock the Olympian for predicting that his competitors would be left 'depressed' when he came round the bend.\n\nOne said on X: 'Guess Noah Lyles [is] the only person depressed after the turn'.\n\nAnother commented: 'Saw a video of Noah Lyles saying at the bend his competitors will be depressed. Guess who is now'.\n\n'Noah Lyles said everyone was gonna be depressed when they hit that turn.... Wellllllll,' wrote a third.\n\nLyles had to settle for bronze after finishing behind winner Letsile Tebogo and fellow USA star Kenny Bednarek\n\nBefore the race he had boasted that the win was definitely his and that his rivals would be left 'depressed' when he came off the turn\n\nA fourth put: 'Noah Lyles is definitely the depressed one now - loud mouth'.\n\nA fifth posted: 'Noah Lyles was talking about how these guy's will be depressed only to lose. There's a fine line between confidence and arrogance.'\n\nWhile another said: 'Talked that s**t and didn't back it up this time'.=\n\nFollowing his third-place finish, the disappointment soon gave way to a frightful scene as Lyles was wheeled away from the track by medics.\n\nIt has since been claimed that the 100m champion ran Thursday's 200m with Covid, which may well explain his slow start.\n\nLyles' mom claims that he ran Thursday's 200m final with Covid, according to NBC\n\nNBC said they spoke to his mom, who confirmed he had the virus but still decided to run at the Olympics.\n\nLyles was plagued by a slow start Thursday and was unable to catch Bednarek, who had been the top runner in the 200 throughout the ongoing Paris Olympics.\n\nHe now has two bronze medals Lyles' mother told NBC Olympics that Lyles was diagnosed with Covid a couple of days ago.\n\nLyles came in third in the men's 200m final with a time of 19.70 seconds. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds and the USA's Kenneth Bednarek won the silver finishing with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nThe 200m is Lyles' premiere, preferred event and he's ranked number one in the world for it. Lyles needed medical attention after the race, and later he was seen by NBC Olympics in a wheelchair, as he mother told Lewis Johnson the runner has COVID. Lyles has been seen wearing a mask recently.\n\n\"[Lyles' mother Keisha Caine Bishop] did confirm Noah had been diagnosed with COVID two days ago. That's right, diagnosed with COVID two days ago,\" Johnson reported. \"But he decided, he was going to run anyway. And obviously, what he has there, may have affected how he performed. He is now, again, with medical people and again, his mom is also distraught. But that's the issue, Noah has COVID.\"\n\nLyles had a thrilling triumph in the 100m final on Sunday. The 27-year-old turned on the jets late to win the race by a fraction of a second, capturing his first Olympic gold medal and Team USA's first 100m title in two decades.\n\nUsain Bolt at the Rio Olympics in 2016 was the last male athlete to win both the 100m and 200m at the same Olympics.\n\nIt was a star-studded crowd at the stadium for the 200m and included Simone Biles, Mick Jagger, Snoop Dogg, Mikaela Shiffrin and Leon Marchand.\n\nLyles is still expected to compete in the men' 4x100m relay final on Friday.\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- will it be in the 200m final?\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals in Paris.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal time overall behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nLyles already competed in the men's 100m and will be competing in the 4x100m relay as well. {"uri": "8266075886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:30:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:30:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:29:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-13725859/letsile-tebogo-noah-lyles-verdict-olympics.html", "title": "Letsile Tebogo delivers savage verdict on 'arrogant' Noah Lyles", "body": "READ MORE: Noah Lyles reveals he has COVID after third-place 200m finish\n\nLetsile Tebogo pulled off a shock 200m gold medal win on Thursday - and delivered a savage verdict on Noah Lyles after defeating the American sprinter.\n\nLyles had confidently told reporters beforehand that he would win the race, and made an extremely bombastic entrance into the Stade de France as he jumped around and waved his arms towards the crowd.\n\nBut the American (who later revealed that he had COVID) finished third in the race as Tebogo led the pack, and the sprinter from Botswana went on to call Lyles 'arrogant' and 'loud.'\n\nThe newly-crowned 200m champion was asked whether he aspired to be the face of track and field, and claimed his more laid-back approach wouldn't allow him to get to Lyles' level of fame.\n\n'For me, I can't be the face of athletics because I'm not an arrogant or loud person like Noah,' he said.\n\nLetsile Tebogo (right) called Lyles 'arrogant' and 'loud' after beating the American sprinter\n\nLyles confirmed after the race that he had COVID, and he was placed in a wheelchair\n\n'So I believe Noah's the face of athletics.'\n\nThe remark caused Lyles' USA teammate, Kenny Bednarek, who claimed silver in the race, to briefly crack a wry smile.\n\nLyles brashly predicted before the 200m that he would complete the double after winning gold in the 100m in a nail-biting finish.\n\n'...None of them is winning. When I come off the turn, they will be depressed,' he said.\n\nHowever, that prediction aged poorly as Lyles labored to a third-place finish and was placed in a wheelchair moments after the race, clearly out of breath from his COVID diagnosis.\n\nThe sprinting star's mother confirmed to NBC that he had COVID before he spoke to the network himself.\n\nHe told NBC, while masked up: 'I woke up early about 5am Tuesday morning, feeling really horrible. I knew it was more than being sore from the 100. My first thought was not to panic, I've ben in worse situations, I've been in worse conditions.\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nLyles (back left) crossed the line in third place, despite being the red-hot favorite for the race\n\nLyles was clearly struggling for breath after finishing third in the event on Thursday\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Gold medal favorite for 200m COLLAPSES and reveals he has COVID - then hugs rivals despite infection\n\n'I took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much. It would say it has taken its toll, for sure, but I have never been more proud of myself coming out here and getting a bronze.'\n\nLyles later said that the other competitors were unaware of his diagnosis: 'We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mom knew.\n\n'We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick. Why would you give them an edge?'\n\nNow, Lyles will hope to compete in the USA's 4x100m relay on Friday - though he admitted he's leaning towards sitting out the race.\n\n'At the moment I don't know, {"uri": "8265984808", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:41:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:41:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:40:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2024/aug/08/noah-lyles-reveals-covid-diagnosis-after-winning-b/", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals covid diagnosis after winning bronze in 200 meters", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France - Shortly after finishing third in the Olympic 200 meters Thursday night, American sprinter Noah Lyles revealed that he tested positive for covid Tuesday morning.\n\nSpeaking to a crowd of reporters wearing a black mask, Lyles said he concealed the test from those outside his inner circle so he would not cause alarm within the Olympic track meet and so his rivals would not receive a competitive advantage.\n\nAfter his positive test Tuesday at 5 a.m., Lyles moved out of the Athletes Village and moved into a hotel to isolate himself and said he worked with USA Track & Field's medical staff to follow medical protocols. He took \"as much medication as we legally could,\" Lyles said. Lyles said he ran while on Paxlovid treatments.\n\nLyles fell to third place in his signature race, losing to 21-year-old Botswanan Letsile Tebogo, who won his country's first gold medal, and fellow American Kenny Bednarek. Lyles crossed in 19.70 seconds, well behind his standard and distant from Tebogo's 19.45-second masterpiece.\n\nAfter he crossed the line, Lyles began breathing heavily and laid down on his back. He slowly rose to sit, and medical personnel attended to him. Lyles unzipped his tracksuit and climbed into the wheelchair, fully conscious and regaining control of his breathing.\n\n\"Shortness of breath and chest pains were definitely active,\" Lyles said. \"But after a while underneath [the stands], I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me.\"\n\nLyles said he never considered pulling out of the 200 meters competition after his coronavirus test, which he said took place Tuesday at 5 a.m. Once he finished second in Wednesday's semifinal, Lyles considered that a sign he could continue. Lyles had won in every international competition since the Tokyo Olympics until he finished second in his semifinal Wednesday.\n\nLyles is still eligible to run in the men's 4x100 meters relay Friday night. He did not rule it out, but said he would let U.S. coaches decide.\n\n\"I'm going to be very honest and transparent with them, and I'm going to let them make a decision,\" Lyles said. \"I believe that no matter what happens, they can handle anything and everything.\"\n\nBoth the Tokyo Games in 2021 and the Beijing Winter Olympics in 2022 had strict covid protocols in place for athletes and most people connected to the competition. The Tokyo Games were held with no spectators as the world was still in the throes of the pandemic. The Paris Games do not have specific covid protocols, however, instead leaving it to athletes, teams and National Olympic Committees to decide how to respond to positive cases.\n\nThe U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee follows guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Earlier this year, the CDC rolled back much of its guidance, no longer asking Americans to stay home for five days after testing positive.\n\nAccording to a statement from the USOPC and USA Track and Field, the organization \"swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the well-being of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" the statement said. \"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nEven before Lyles's positive test, at least 40 Olympians competing in Paris tested positive for covid in the past two weeks, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nWhen Lyles won the 100 meters Sunday, he captured the event his mother once jokingly christened his \"side chick.\" Thursday, Lyles won only bronze in the race Keisha Caine Bishop considered his \"wife,\" the bread-and-butter event Lyles has dominated on the world stage since he turned professional out of T.C. Williams (now Alexandria City) High in Alexandria. His pursuit of three gold medals ended with his second consecutive Olympic bronze.\n\nLyles won every 200 meters race he entered between the Tokyo Olympics final and Wednesday's semifinal, when he started slow and conserved energy on his way to second place. That hiccup could have cost him a preferable lane assignment, but he still started in favored Lane 5.\n\nLyles had declared his intentions - and brash confidence - Thursday morning. He borrowed a line from one of his favorite anime stories and posted on social media the Japanese phrase, \"Omae wa-mo shinde iru.\" Translation: You are already dead.\n\nIf Lyles was feeling ill, he didn't show it before the race. Instead he delivered his customary showmanship. As he warmed up, he jogged around the curve and cupped his hand to his ear. As he trotted back around to the blocks, he waved his left arm and asked the crowd for even more noise. When the public addressed introduced him, he charged on to the track, leaped over the barrier and bounded down the track some 25 meters, just like before his 100 victory.\n\n\"I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" Lyles said. \"I didn't have any time to save any energy.\"\n\nLyles suffered from serious asthma as a child, frequently spending nights in the hospital hooked to a nebulizer. He has experienced flares as an adult, but they had never affected him in competition in a major way. {"uri": "8265980916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:38:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:38:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:36:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/noah-lyles-competed-in-the-olympic-200-with-covid-and-finished-3rd-what-we-know/article_451056c2-35c2-5a52-a8ae-5a33e11369af.html", "title": "Noah Lyles competed in the Olympic 200 with COVID and finished 3rd. What we know about his illness", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere's what we know about the timeline of Lyles' illness:\n\nWhen did Lyles know he had COVID?\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWhat happened in his 200-meter race?\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nFeatured Local SavingsWhy was he allowed to run?\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games in China, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nFrance, which once had tight COVID restrictions, no longer has rules for people with the virus, just recommendations to those who test positive to self-isolate.\n\nThe World Health Organization said Tuesday that 40 athletes at the Olympics had tested positive for the virus amid growing cases worldwide.\n\nWhat races does Lyles have left?\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4x100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-08-447580219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "03:58:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T03:58:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T03:58:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/noah-lyles-sprint-double-200m-final-2024-olympics/5682757/", "title": "How Noah Lyles can make rare Olympic history in the 200m final", "body": "Watch U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles win the men's 100m at the Paris Olympics.\n\nLyles has already earned the title of fastest man in the world at the Paris Games, and he's now on the doorstep of joining very exclusive Olympic company:\n\nHow many sprint doubles at an Olympics have there been?\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nWhen was the last sprint double at an Olympics?\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat three straight at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the individual sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double twice. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nList of sprint doubles at an Olympics\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nWhat's Noah Lyles' best time in the 200m?\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals at the Paris Games.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nWhat's the world record in the 200m?\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- could it be in the 200m final?\n\nWhen does Noah Lyles run the 200m final?\n\nLyles will look to become just the 10th man to ever pull off the Olympic sprint double when he races in the 200m final on Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET.\n\nHow to watch the men's 200m final at the Olympics\n\nThe men's 200m final will be shown on NBC and Peacock. It will also be available to stream here:\n\nHow many medals does Noah Lyles have?\n\nLyles enters the 200m final with two Olympic medals: a 200m bronze from the Tokyo Games and a 100m gold from the Paris Games.\n\nHe's also a three-time world champion in the 200m and the reigning world champion in the 100m.\n\nWhen is Noah Lyles' next race?\n\nFollowing the 200m final, Lyles is scheduled to next move over to the men's 4x100m relay. The relay event begins with the first round on Thursday followed by the final on Friday.\n\nSo there's a chance Lyles will enter the weekend with an Olympic sprint triple under his belt.", "source": Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, the bronze medalist said he had COVID.\n\nTampa's Erriyon Knighton placed fourth in the event. The Hillsborough High School graduate finished one spot out of a medal in the event for the second straight Olympics.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed around in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time -- nothing. {"uri": "8265959869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:16:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:16:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:14:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/u-track-star-noah-lyles-210916407.html", "title": "U.S. track star Noah Lyles takes bronze in 200-meter, says he tested positive for Covid", "body": "PARIS -- Two days after Noah Lyles said he tested positive for Covid, the American sprinter finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics, unable to chase down gold medalist Letsile Tebogo of Botswana.\n\nLyles ran 19.70 for bronze, behind Tebogo's 19.46, which earned the first gold medal in Botswana's history. American Kenny Bednarek earned silver in 19.62.\n\nFollowing his positive test, Lyles said he moved into a hotel away from the Olympic Village to quarantine himself and arrived for warmups before Wednesday's semifinal with a mask on. He said he never considered not competing in Thursday's final and intentionally did not disclose information about his diagnosis.\n\n\"You never want to tell your competitors you're sick,\" he said. \"Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nLyles, 27, appeared his usual energetic self when he was introduced before the final, jumping and sprinting down the track before getting into his blocks as a sold-out crowd inside Stade de France grew silent. Lyles was running from behind right from the start, looking little like the sprinter who had won 26 consecutive races dating to 2021 until he finished second in Wednesday's semifinal -- also to Tebogo -- and had been 38-5 all-time against the seven other sprinters in Thursday's final.\n\nAt the finish line Lyles collapsed, then gingerly stood while asking for water and sitting back down on the track. He was put into a wheelchair and carted off underneath the stadium. It was a stark contrast to Sunday night, when Lyles won the first Olympic gold medal of his career by winning the 100-meters by five-thousandths of a second and afterward guaranteed that he would win the 200 meters, as well.\n\nTesting positive for COVID \"definitely affected my performance,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything coming out and get the bronze medal with COVID in three days. It's been a wild Olympics.\"\n\nIn a statement, USA Track & Field said that it and the U.S. Olympic committee had adhered to guidelines set by the Centers for Disease Control and the International Olympic Committee to \"prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\"\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles was attempting to become the first man to sweep both sprints at an Olympics since Jamaica's Usain Bolt in 2016, and the first from the U.S. since Carl Lewis 40 years ago. Earning bronze also ends Lyles's much-discussed ambition of becoming the first track athlete to win four gold medals at a single Olympics since 1984.\n\nHe said he would let USA Track & Field decide whether he should run on the U.S. 4x100-meter relay team that qualified for Friday's final with the fastest time in preliminaries.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": behind only Usain Bolt and Yohan Blake.\n\nTebogo, 21, was able to ease up at the end and still clocked an African record of 19.46sec for gold with Bednarek taking silver in 19.62sec and Lyles fading to bronze in 19.70sec.\n\nLyles was unable to produce his trademark burst of speed on the home straight as he crossed the line in third place.\n\nThe American superstar collapsed on the side of the track shortly after finishing the race as medical stuff rushed to his side.\n\nLyles was eventually put on a wheelchair before being taken out of the stadium.\n\nIt was later reported the American had tested positive for covid ahead of the race which perhaps explains his sluggish run and inability to chase down his rivals.\n\nLyles confirmed he had tested positive Tuesday morning but kept it under wraps to not let his competitors know he was sick.\n\nESPN's Cole Harvey wrote on X: \"Noah Lyles confirmed he tested positive for Covid at 5am Tuesday morning Paris time. {"uri": "8265837238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:19:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:19:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:19:05Z", "dataType": "news", COVID", "body": "Noah Lyles tried to keep up with the greats, Usain Bolt and Carl Lewis, but fell short after racing with COVID.\n\nThe 27-year-old star for Team USA ended up on his back after running the 200m men's final and received medical attention on the track in Paris during the 2024 Olympics.\n\nHe was eventually escorted off the track in a wheelchair, with US Track And Field later confirming that the superstar had tested positive for COVID.\n\nIt was an odd race for Lyles, who previously won the 100m in a photo finish.\n\nBefore the 200m on Thursday night at Stade de France, he bounced around the track, engaged with fans and appeared to celebrate early.\n\nOnce the race started, Lyles began slow and couldn't overcome Letsile Tebogo, who took gold and stole Lyles' spotlight, with the American only managing to claim bronze.\n\nLyles had hoped to become the first male runner since the legendary Bolt to pull off an Olympic sprint double.\n\nLyles also could have become the first USA men's runner to achieve the 100m and 200m double since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nBolt completed a double Olympic sprint crown multiple times (2008, 2012, 2016) while becoming the biggest name in track and a worldwide phenom.\n\nLyles has become one of the biggest stars of the 2024 Olympics, helping push Team USA to the top of the medal board while fulfilling the potential of his generational talent.\n\nIt took an up-close view with the Omega Scan'O'Vision to determine that Lyles won gold in the 100m in classic thrilling fashion, becoming the first American since Justin Gatlin in 2004 to win gold in the ultimate Olympic sprint.\n\n\"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression,\" Lyles tweeted. \"But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\"\n\nHe's also been supportive of his Team USA track teammates, posting supportive words after big finishes.\n\n\"That was an amazing 1500!\" Lyles wrote. \"Cole Hocker you Got me screaming my head off!\"\n\nOn Thursday, Lyles pumped up the crowd and bounced around the track before locking into the starting blocks and fifth lane for the 200m.\n\nAs he clapped his hands and pointed toward the stands, an electric Lyles embraced the pressure -- and potential -- of a race that could double down on his status as the fastest athlete in the world.\n\nBolt's name appeared on TV while Rolling Stones singer Mick Jagger was shown in the stands, further highlighting how much was at stake in Paris.\n\nBut Lyles started slow and couldn't recover.\n\nWhen pure speed was needed to win gold in the 200m, Lyles simply wasn't fast enough - hardly a surprise given his positive COVID test.", "source": {"uri": "talksport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "talkSPORT"}, "authors": [{"uri": "brian_t_smith@talksport.com", "name": "Brian T. {"uri": "8265793170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "18:40:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T18:40:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T18:39:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/olympics/article-13725013/Noah-Lyles-Letsile-Tebogo-Olympics-sprint-200.html", "title": "Lyles becomes FIRST man since Bolt to win Olympics sprint double", "body": "Noah Lyles fell just short of a historic sprint double at the Paris Olympics with a third-place finish in the 200 meters behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana. Lyles' American teammate Kenny Bednarek won his second consecutive silver medal.\n\nGetting golds in the 100 and 200 at a single Olympics is a rare feat. Usain Bolt accomplished that double at three Olympics in a row -- in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. But until the Jamaican, no man had done it since Carl Lewis at Los Angeles in 1984.\n\nAt his last Games, eight years ago, Bolt was shutting it down late in his 200 semifinal, and suddenly realized Andre De Grasse was running hard. So Bolt dialed his speed back up and wagged a finger at the Canadian. Fast-forward to the final: Bolt won easily.\n\nThe field for the men's 200-meter final featured several contenders, including 2020 silver medalist Kenny Bednarek, 20-year-old sensation Erryion Knighton and Tebogo , who beat Lyles in the semifinals.\n\nLyles previously won the 100-meter final in a historic photo finish.\n\nNoah Lyles already had one gold medal to his name entering Thursday's 200-meter final\n\nThe American showman edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson on Sunday by five-thousandths of a second -- that's .005 of one tick of the clock -- in a race for the ages.\n\nThe final tally in this one: Lyles 9.784 seconds, Thompson 9.789.\n\nThe new champion said that before he left for Paris, one of his physio guys ensured him this race would be a squeaker.\n\n\"He said, 'This is how close first and second are going to be,'\" Lyles said as he pinched his thumb and his forefinger together so they were almost touching. \"I can't believe how right he was.\"\n\nFor perspective, the blink of an eye takes, on average, .1 second. That was 20 times longer than the gap between first and second.\n\nIt was so close, that when the sprinters crossed the line and the word \"Photo\" popped up next to the names of Lyles, Thompson and five others in the eight-man field, Lyles walked over to the Jamaican and said \"I think you got the Olympics dog.\"\n\nThompson, who raced three lanes to the left of Lyles and had no clue where he was on the track, wasn't convinced.\n\nRead More NFL star takes bizarre shot at Noah Lyles after sprinter's Olympics win\n\n\"I was, 'Wow, I'm not even sure, because it was that close,'\" the Jamaican said.\n\nTime would tell. It always does. When Lyles' name came up first, he snatched his name tag off the front of his bib and held it to the sky. Moments later, he shouted at the TV camera: \"America, I told you I got this!\"\n\nThe first four racers were separated by less than .03. The top seven all finished within .09 of each other.\n\nAmerica's Fred Kerley came in third at 9.81. \"That's probably one of the most beautiful races I've been in,\" he said.\n\nIn the photo finish, Kerley's orange shoe crossed the line before anyone, or anything. But it's the chest breaking the barrier that counts. Lyles' chest crossed first.\n\nThis was the closest 1-2 finish in the 100 since at least Moscow in 1980 -- or maybe even ever.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": American Kenny Bednarek earned silver in 19.62.\n\nFollowing his positive test, Lyles said he moved into a hotel away from the Olympic Village to quarantine himself and arrived for warmups before Wednesday's semifinal with a mask on. He said he never considered not competing in Thursday's final and intentionally did not disclose information about his diagnosis.\n\n\"You never want to tell your competitors you're sick,\" he said. \"Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nLyles, 27, appeared his usual energetic self when he was introduced before the final, jumping and sprinting down the track before getting into his blocks as a sold-out crowd inside Stade de France grew silent. {"uri": "8266094439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:57:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:57:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:55:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://wtop.com/olympics/2024/08/noah-lyles-competed-in-the-olympic-200-with-covid-and-finished-3rd-what-we-know-about-his-illness/", "title": "Noah Lyles competed in the Olympic 200 with COVID and finished 3rd. What we know about his illness - WTOP News", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere's what we know about the timeline of Lyles' illness:\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games in China, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nFrance, which once had tight COVID restrictions, no longer has rules for people with the virus, just recommendations to those who test positive to self-isolate.\n\nThe World Health Organization said Tuesday that 40 athletes at the Olympics had tested positive for the virus amid growing cases worldwide.\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4\u00d7100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. They said it was possible,\" he said.\n\nThe US track federation released a statement saying it had adhered to all guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. That big of a gap certainly didn't seem like a fluke, or just a bad day at the office. Especially on what is a pretty fast track in Paris. And it was at the Olympics, where heavy-flowing adrenaline typically provides an extra boost down the stretch.\n\nIt was the opposite for Lyles, who struggled to kick down the stretch and collapsed to the ground shortly after he crossed the line.\n\nLyles overcame severe asthma as a child and still deals with the disease today. He could not catch his breath.\n\nIt was glaringly obvious that something wasn't right.\n\nLyles wore a mask in the tunnel before each of his last two races. He lost an event as the heavy favorite. He could not breathe and needed a wheelchair. All kinds of mystery loomed over the frustrating result.\n\nHowever, it is actually remarkable that Noah Lyles reached the podium at all. United States Track & Field confirmed on Thursday afternoon that its star sprinter tested positive for COVID-19 two days ago.\n\nLyles finished in third place at the Olympics while fighting an illness that ravages the respiratory system as someone who deals with asthma. Think about that for a second! Carl Lewis was the last American to win the 100 and 200 when he did the double at the Los Angeles Games in 1984.\n\nLyles won the 100 meters on Tuesday in a historically close race. He edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just 0.005 seconds.\n\nLyles was attempting to win three golds at the Paris Games by also winning in the 100-meter relay. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nHoping to get himself close to full strength for the race, Lyles took several legal medications after the diagnosis. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- The first shocker came when Noah Lyles, the fastest man on Earth, won bronze in his specialty event, the 200-meter. Then, moments after race on Thursday night, the other shoe dropped: Lyles said he'd tested positive for COVID two days earlier.\n\nAfter crossing the finish line, Lyles looked ill, bent down to the ground, struggled to control his breath, and called for water. He was later seen rolling out in a wheelchair.\n\nLetsile Tebogo of Botswana won gold and Kenneth Bednarek came in second place for silver.\n\nIt wasn't revealed until after the race that Lyles -- fresh off winning the 100-meter sprint on Sunday -- had tested positive for COVID on Tuesday.\n\nOn the NBC broadcast after the race, Lyles appeared wearing a mask and confirmed the diagnosis.\n\n\"I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning just feeling really horrible,\" he told the Olympics broadcaster. \"Unfortunately, it came back that I was positive for COVID.\"\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic, you know, thinking I've been in worse situations -- worse conditions, I've felt,\" he said.\n\nHe said he never considered skipping out on the race.\n\n\"We just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off,\" Lyles said. \"It's taken it's toll for sure but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here, and getting a bronze medal.\"\n\nUSA Track & Field confirmed Lyles' diagnosis in a statement to NPR after the race.\n\n\"In response, [the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee] and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors,\" the organization said, adding that it has been following CDC guidelines to prevent the illness' spread.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles has one final event -- the men's 4 x 100m relay on Friday -- but said he isn't sure whether he will stay in the race.\n\n\"At the moment, I don't know. I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me.\"\n\nBefore the crowd of 80,000 at the Stade de France, the 27-year-old was hoping to go down in sprint double history -- aiming to be just the 10th man to win the 100- and 200- meter races in a single Summer Games.\n\nOnly nine men have pulled off the sprint double this before. One of those men -- Jamaican Usain Bolt -- did it at three straight Olympics. The last time an American managed the sprint double was Carl Lewis 40 years ago in 1984.\n\nAfter winning his 100-meter race, Lyles posted a motivational message to his social media:\n\n\"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression,\" he said. \"But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. {"uri": "8265846598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:28:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:28:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:27:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/noah-lyles-bronze-200m-final-no-sprint-double-gold-letsile-tebogo/3516900/", "title": "Noah Lyles earns bronze in 200m final as mother reveals Covid diagnosis", "body": "Lyles mother told NBC Olympics' Lewis Johnson that Noah was recently diagnosed with Covid\n\nNoah Lyles, who already earned the title of \"World's Fastest Man\" at the Paris Olympics, fell short Thursday of his goal to become the first American to win gold in the 100m and 200m sprints since Carl Lewis in 1984. Lyles' mother told NBC Olympics that Noah was diagnosed with Covid a couple of days ago.\n\nLyles came in third in the men's 200m final with a time of 19.70 seconds. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds and the USA's Kenneth Bednarek won the silver finishing with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nThe 200m is Lyles' premiere, preferred event and he's ranked number one in the world for it. Lyles needed medical attention after the race, and later he was seen by NBC Olympics in a wheelchair, as he mother told Lewis Johnson the runner has Covid. Lyles has been seen wearing a mask recently.\n\n\"[Lyles' mother Keisha Caine Bishop] did confirm Noah had been diagnosed with Covid two days ago. That's right, diagnosed with Covid two days ago,\" Johnson reported. \"But he decided, he was going to run anyway. And obviously, what he has there, may have affected how he performed. He is now, again, with medical people and again, his mom is also distraught. But that's the issue, Noah has Covid.\"\n\nLyles had a thrilling triumph in the 100m final on Sunday. The 27-year-old turned on the jets late to win the race by a fraction of a second, capturing his first Olympic gold medal and Team USA's first 100m title in two decades.\n\nUsain Bolt at the Rio Olympics in 2016 was the last male athlete to win both the 100m and 200m at the same Olympics.\n\nIt was a star-studded crowd at the stadium for the 200m and included Simone Biles, Mick Jagger, Snoop Dogg, Mikaela Shiffrin and Leon Marchand.\n\nLyles is still expected to compete in the men' 4x100m relay final on Friday.\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- will it be in the 200m final?\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals in Paris.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal time overall behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nLyles already competed in the men's 100m and will be competing in the 4x100m relay as well. Lyles' mother told NBC Olympics that Noah was diagnosed with Covid a couple of days ago.\n\nLyles came in third in the men's 200m final with a time of 19.70 seconds. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds and the USA's Kenneth Bednarek won the silver finishing with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nThe 200m is Lyles' premiere, preferred event and he's ranked number one in the world for it. Lyles needed medical attention after the race, and later he was seen by NBC Olympics in a wheelchair, as he mother told Lewis Johnson the runner has Covid. Lyles has been seen wearing a mask recently.\n\n\"[Lyles' mother Keisha Caine Bishop] did confirm Noah had been diagnosed with Covid two days ago. That's right, diagnosed with Covid two days ago,\" Johnson reported. \"But he decided, he was going to run anyway. And obviously, what he has there, may have affected how he performed. He is now, again, with medical people and again, his mom is also distraught. But that's the issue, Noah has Covid.\"\n\nLyles had a thrilling triumph in the 100m final on Sunday. The 27-year-old turned on the jets late to win the race by a fraction of a second, capturing his first Olympic gold medal and Team USA's first 100m title in two decades.\n\nUsain Bolt at the Rio Olympics in 2016 was the last male athlete to win both the 100m and 200m at the same Olympics.\n\nIt was a star-studded crowd at the stadium for the 200m and included Simone Biles, Mick Jagger, Snoop Dogg, Mikaela Shiffrin and Leon Marchand.\n\nLyles is still expected to compete in the men' 4x100m relay final on Friday.\n\nHow many sprint doubles at an Olympics have there been?\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nWhen was the last sprint double at an Olympics?\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nList of sprint doubles at an Olympics\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nWhat's the world record in the 200m?\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- will it be in the 200m final?\n\nHow many sprint doubles at an Olympics have there been?\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nWhen was the last sprint double at an Olympics?\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nWhat's Noah Lyles' best time in the 200m?\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals in Paris.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal time overall behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nWhat other events is Noah Lyles competing in at 2024 Paris Olympics?\n\nLyles already competed in the men's 100m and will be competing in the 4x100m relay as well. Here's what the schedule for that event looks like:\n\nLyles' races will also be shown either live or on replay in primetime on NBC.\n\nHow many medals does Noah Lyles have?\n\nNow Lyles currently has {"uri": "2024-08-448638726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:11:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:11:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:06:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-covid-19-paris-olympics/74728652007/", "title": "How Olympic athletes felt about Noah Lyles competing in 200 with COVID-19", "body": "Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone wins 400m hurdles with ease, Noah Lyles battles COVID and settles for bronze and US men's basketball survives scare against Serbia.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France - Keisha Caine Bishop ran through the bowels of the Stade de France with an understandably frantic look on her face. Her son, Noah Lyles, had been removed from the track moments earlier on a wheelchair. She was trying to find him after he took third in the men's 200-meter dash at the 2024 Paris Olympics but looked unwell afterward.\n\nBeside her was NBC track and field reporter Lewis Johnson. As they dashed down a hallway, Johnson turned around and gestured with his hands, making a wheelchair motion toward a volunteer, who pointed him in the direction of the venue's medical center.\n\nJohnson later described Caine Bishop as \"distraught\" during his update on Lyles' condition; the 100-meter Olympic champion received medical attention on the track and was breathing heavily (Lyles has asthma).\n\nConcurrently, a rumor started floating through the mixed zone: Lyles had COVID-19. Soon enough, the news was breaking everywhere. Johnson ran back the way he came from, toward his NBC camera station, while speaking on his cellphone.\n\nAthletes from other events and those who took part in the 200 began trickling through the mixed zone. Some, particularly those who competed shortly after the men's 200, were clueless about the news cycle that had just begun.\n\n\"Noah? I didn't know, wow,\" said Jasmine Jones, who finished fourth in the women's 400-meter hurdles. \"That's crazy. Congratulations to him. He's fantastic for that. That's really impressive. Congratulations. Hats off. Yeah, wow, I didn't know that.\"\n\nThat's because, Lyles later said while speaking with a mask on in the mixed zone, the circle of people who did know he tested positive Tuesday was small: just his family, his doctor and his coaches. Not even his teammates knew. He raced in the 200-meter semifinals Wednesday.\n\n\"I was going to compete regardless,\" Lyles said. \"If I didn't make it to the (200) finals, that would've been the sign not to compete.\"\n\nLyles showing up to the mixed zone came as a surprise. His publicist informed the media he would not be speaking and that the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee, along with World Athletics, would be releasing statements. He'd disappeared from the cameras only to suddenly pop up again on NBC. He entered the mixed zone shortly thereafter.\n\n\"To be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything - coming out and getting a bronze medal with COVID,\" Lyles said.\n\nOverwhelmingly, the other athletes cared little that Lyles competed with the virus.\n\nThe winner of the race, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, first noticed something was wrong with Lyles on Wednesday. He noticed that the 27-year-old was wearing a mask and that the protection remained on his face during the pre-finals warmups.\n\n\"Not in his best shape,\" Tebogo said. \"He's going through something.\"\n\nA reporter then informed him that Lyles had COVID.\n\nThe most laid-back about the night's drama was Kenny Bednarek, the silver medalist in the 200.\n\n\"From what I heard, he's got something that went on. So, I don't really know what's going on with him,\" Bednarek said. \"I mean, I will probably talk to him after this to see if he's OK, which I hope so. But yeah, like for me, I don't really know. I'm kind of out of the loop.\"\n\nBednarek hugged Lyles after the race and said he was unbothered by Lyles' decision to race.\n\n\"I'm healthy,\" Bednarek said. \"I do everything I can to make sure my body's healthy.\"\n\nBednarek was asked if he had noticed an uptick of colds circulating throughout the athlete's village.\n\n\"There was a message that came out saying there was something going around,\" he said, \"but I haven't seen it.\n\n\"I guess I'm carefree.\"\n\nLyles said he'd rate his health anywhere from \"90 to 95 percent\" out of 100, though he wrote on Instagram late Thursday he believes \"this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics.\" (He was expected to run in the 4x100-meter relay.) He knew that he had one \"blow\" and that it could be used over those 200 meters. That didn't stop him from putting on his customary pre-race show, as he bounded out of the tunnel when his name was called over the stadium's loudspeakers during introductions. He bounced all over the track and even knocked over Lane 5's marker near the starting block in excitement.\n\nIt wasn't long before Lyles took bronze in his best event and he laid on the ground looking up at the sky. Then came the wheelchair - and a concerned mother looking for her son, trying to make sure he was OK.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-08-448563685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:00:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:00:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:58:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.ksbw.com/article/noah-lyles-letsile-tebogo-paris-olympics-200m-race/61829720", "title": "Watch: Noah Lyles, running with COVID, upset by Letsile Tebogo for 200m gold", "body": "ABOVE VIDEO: Letsile Tebogo wins gold in the men's 200m final, defeating bronze medalist Noah Lyles and silver medalist Kenny Bednarek. It's Botswana's first-ever gold and third-ever Olympic medal. Can't view the above video? Click here. Letsile Tebogo has won gold in the men's 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics, defeating bronze medalist Noah Lyles and silver medalist Kenny Bednarek. It's Botswana's first-ever gold and third-ever Olympic medal. The rising star raced to victory with an African record of 19.46-seconds, denying pre-race favorite Noah Lyles of his second gold medal.Lyles, who won the Olympic 100-meter gold in dramatic fashion, was tended to by medics after the race, who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"Tebogo dedicated his country's first ever to his late mother, who passed away last May.\n\nABOVE VIDEO: Letsile Tebogo wins gold in the men's 200m final, defeating bronze medalist Noah Lyles and silver medalist Kenny Bednarek. It's Botswana's first-ever gold and third-ever Olympic medal. Can't view the above video? Click here.\n\nLetsile Tebogo has won gold in the men's 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics, defeating bronze medalist Noah Lyles and silver medalist Kenny Bednarek.\n\nIt's Botswana's first-ever gold and third-ever Olympic medal. The rising star raced to victory with an African record of 19.46-seconds, denying pre-race favorite Noah Lyles of his second gold medal.\n\nLyles, who won the Olympic 100-meter gold in dramatic
