{"uri": "8265884480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:05:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:05:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/noah-lyles-falls-short-of-double-after-testing-positive-for-covid-19/", "title": "Noah Lyles Runs 200-Meter Race With COVID-19, Wins Bronze", "body": "The American had talked about using his Olympic success to grow the sport and his brand.\n\nNoah Lyles ran the 200-meter sprint in Paris after testing positive for COVID-19 and settled for bronze in the event for the second straight Olympics.\n\nThe U.S. sprinter was trying to become the first man since Usain Bolt in 2016 -- and the first American since Carl Lewis in 1984 -- to win the double, the combination of the 100- and 200-meter races, in the Olympics. But he settled for third behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek.\n\nLyles fell to the ground after the race and was surrounded by medical personnel. He tested positive Tuesday, USA Track & Field announced. He reportedly visited medics after his semifinals heat Wednesday.\n\n\"I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal,\" Lyles said, in a mask, after the race.\n\nLyles finished with a 19.70, nearly four-hundredths back of his own personal best of 19.31, the third-fastest time in history. He still would've had his work cut out for him even if he were fully healthy, as Tebogo finished with a 19.46, faster than Lyles's gold medal time in the 2023 World Championships in Budapest.\n\nEven if Lyles won the gold Thursday, it was unlikely he would surpass Bolt's eight gold medals.\n\nUnfortunately for Lyles, he is running out of time to try to achieve the double in the Olympics, which Bolt did three times in 2008, 2012, and 2016. Lyles will be 31 years old by the 2028 L.A. Olympics, and Bolt was just weeks away from turning 31 when he won his third and final double in Rio.\n\nThe American still has other records to strive for, including a fourth world championship in the 200 meters -- tying him with Bolt for the most in history -- which he can achieve by the 2025 World Athletics Championships in Tokyo.\n\nHowever, the Olympics showed that Lyles's competition is deep. The American won a photo finish in the 100-meter race over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson. Tebogo will continue to be a threat -- and perhaps win a double himself -- as he is only 21 years old and placed silver in the 100-meter event at the 2023 World Championships.\n\nPerhaps more important than a medal tally, Lyles has expressed he wants to break world records. Last year, he posted two target times on social media: 19.10 in the 200 meters, 0.09 seconds faster than Bolt's world record, and 9.65 in the 100 meters, short of Bolt's 9.58 world record but faster than anyone else in history.\n\nWhile the bronze medal adds to his r\u00e9sum\u00e9, falling short of the double in the sport's grandest stage does hamper his ultimate goal of transcending the sport.\n\n\"After you get the medals, more and more people gain interest,\" Lyles said after winning the double in Budapest. \"You can go into fashion, you can go into music. You can start collaborating with people and start meeting bigger and better athletes. From athletes, you go to artists, and from artists, you go to the world.\"\n\nHe already expressed he wants his own signature sneaker -- a training shoe, not a running spike -- after winning the 100 meters Sunday. Kenneth Bednarek, Lyles' fellow American teammate, made a sudden push towards the end and secured the silver medal, pushing Lyles into third place.\n\nRELATED: Sha'Carri Richardson Says She's 'Standing With' Noah Lyles After His Comments About NBA Players Calling Themselves World Champions\n\nFollowing the race, the 27-year-old athlete was seen seated in a chair and subsequently taken off the track on a wheeled chair, raising concerns about his physical condition. Shortly after the race, the US Track and Field team announced that the bronze medallist had competed in the event despite testing positive for Covid-19.\n\nTebogo made history by becoming the first African to win the title, setting a new African record in the process. This victory also marked Botswana's first-ever Olympic gold medal. Following his bronze medal win at the previous World Championships and his national record-setting performance in the 100m final in Paris, Tebogo delivered a commanding performance to secure his place as the fifth-fastest man in history over the 200m distance.\n\nBednarek pursued Tebogo throughout the race and finished with a second consecutive silver in a time of 19.62 seconds. {"uri": "8265920497", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:37:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:37:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:36:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/letsile-tebogo-noah-lyles-olympics-33426673", "title": "Lyles deserves sympathy but this glorious Olympic occasion was all about Tebogo", "body": "He entered the stadium leaping up and down, urging the crowd to get to their feet, gallivanting down the back straight while his rivals waited by their blocks.\n\nAnd a few minutes later, Noah Lyles - very sadly and very worryingly - was being wheeled away in a chair by concerned medics after collapsing at the end of the men's 200 metres. After it was announced that Lyles is suffering from Covid, let's hope there are no long-term effects and that we see the 100m champion again soon.\n\nBut this was not about Lyles being unable to take the chance to become only the 10th man in Olympic history to do the 100m-200m double. This was not about Lyles' showboating and bravado coining back to bite him. This was not about Lyles failing to put himself into a historical bracket that includes the likes of Carl Lewis and Usain Bolt.\n\nThis was not about Lyles' claims to have iconic potential proving to be fanciful, to say the least. This was not about whether Lyles' illness was what cost him in the end - after all, he took bronze in a decent time of 19.70.\n\nThis was not about Lyles being beaten by silver medallist and American team-mate Kenneth Bednarek. This was not about Lyles getting a yellow card next to his name for something he did at the start, apparently.\n\nNo, this was about one young man, one ground-breaking athlete, one hero for his country and his continent. This was about as smooth a 200 metre run as you are likely to see and about a hugely unassuming runner, whose humility cannot fail to impress you. This was about Letsile Tebogo, of Botswana.\n\nTebogo only turned 21 in early June and, two weeks before his birthday, his mum, Seratiwa, passed away after a long illness. He promised to win gold for his mum and, on a wonderful night in Paris, he did just that.\n\nHe did it with an African record of 19.46 seconds and he never looked in a moment's danger of being beaten. It was an imperious run and this, don't forget, was the athlete who comfortably beat Lyles in the semi-final. It truly was a landmark moment in Olympic history.\n\nIt was not only Botswana's first-ever gold medal, it was Africa's first gold medal in the 200m. While all eyes were on Lyles to see if could emulate the like of Carl Lewis and Usain Bolt in winning a 100m-200m double (and the Jamaican did it three times on thespian, don't forget), Tebogo's fantastic form had him as favourite in a lot of judges' eyes.\n\nAnd from the gun to the tape, he blazed a trail that had Bednarek and Lyles in its wake. When he crossed the line, it was almost a canter.\n\nThis has to be one of the most exciting developments in African sport and win world athletics for a long time. While many were expecting a coronation of Lyles, this was the dawn of what could be a new era.\n\nAnd rather than Lyles joining that ultra-elite bracket, the possibilities for the young man from Botswana are endless. You have to feel a bit sorry for Covid-struck Lyles but this was not about him. Lyles registered a time of 19.70 to earn bronze. Lyles and Bednarek also claimed respective silver and bronze medals in the event at Tokyo 2020.\n\nTebogo's finish resulted in the first gold medal in the history of the Olympics for Botswana.\n\nLyles completed the first leg of the feat by becoming the first American man to win the 100-meter final in 20 years Sunday in Saint-Denis, France. He was attempting to become just the 10th male Olympian to complete a sprint double.\n\nThe American got off to a choppy start out of the blocks, allowing Bednarek to pace the pack into the turn. Tebogo then gained speed, slipping by Bednarek on the inside. Lyles tried to gain steam down the stretch, but could not match the pace.\n\nHe limped after crossing the finish line before going to the ground, showing signs of exhaustion. Several trainers then tended to the track star, giving him water and escorting him away from the track.\n\nSources later told NBC, USA Today and the BBC that Lyles was diagnosed with COVID-19 earlier this week.\n\nTebogo also posted the fastest time (19.96) in the semifinal round for the 200. seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nThis is McLaughlin-Levrone's second straight gold and also the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games.\n\nHe also said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement He said that decision had not been made as of late Thursday.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. {"uri": "8265874011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:54:23", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:54:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:53:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.runnersworld.com/news/a61829099/noah-lyles-200-bronze-olympics-covid/", "title": "Noah Lyles Takes 200-Meter Bronze After Testing Positive for COVID", "body": "Two days after testing positive for COVID, Noah Lyles earned an Olympic bronze medal in the men's 200 meters at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games. Lewis Johnson of NBC reported Lyles's diagnosis on the television broadcast. Lyles later confirmed the news in an interview with Johnson.\n\nHours after winning Olympic gold in the men's 100 meters, the U.S. record-holder said he woke up at 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and felt \"horrible,\" before meeting with doctors and testing positive for COVID.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic and I was thinking, you know, I've been in worse situations and I've run with worse conditions,\" Lyles said. \"We just took it day-by-day trying to hydrate, quarantined off and it's taking its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for coming out here and getting a bronze medal.\"\n\nLyles is also in the relay pool for Team USA, but was unsure about his availability for the race. \"At the moment, I don't know. I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing,\" he said. \"You know, they've proven with great certainty they can handle it without me, and if that's the case coming up today, then I'm perfectly fine saying, hey, you guys go do your thing.\"\n\nLyles wasn't able to match the closing speed of Letsile Tebogo of Botswana and American teammate Kenny Bednarek, who collected 200 Olympic gold in 19.46 seconds and silver in 19.62, respectively. Lyles crossed the line third in 19.70 seconds at Stade de France.\n\nThe three-time world champion repeated as an Olympic bronze medalist three years after making his Olympic debut in Tokyo.\n\nLyles is among several athletes who have competed with COVID at the Paris Games. In 2021, the Tokyo Olympic Games were delayed by a year because of the global pandemic and the Games were mostly held without spectators in the stadiums.\n\nAfter Lyles won Olympic gold by five-thousandths of a second in the men's 100 meters in Paris, the 27-year-old predicted another victory in his signature event. \"None of them are winning,\" he told the media. \"When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.\"\n\nHours later, the U.S. record-holder flew through the first-round heats of the 200 meters in 20.19 on August 5. But he didn't appear as dominant in the semifinal when Tebogo handed him a surprising loss. It was the first time in three years Lyles lost a race in the half-lap distance.\n\nTebogo is the first African man to win the event. The 21-year-old was sixth in the 100 meters on August 4. Positive COVID test confirmed after wearing mask, leaving 200-meter in wheelchair", "body": "Noah Lyles entered the 200-meter dash at the 2024 Olympics as a heavy favorite to win. He was fresh off a gold medal in the 100-meter dash, and the 200-meter race was considered his best event.\n\nBut Lyles couldn't deliver on the proverbial \"Double\" and win gold in both races. He came in third behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and his USA teammate, Kenny Bednarek, after clocking a time of 19.70 seconds in the race.\n\nLyles couldn't celebrate his bronze medal win very long either. He congratulated Tebogo and Bednarek after crossing the finish line but then motioned to event staff that he needed water. After being handed a bottle, he went to the ground on one knee, appearing exhausted.\n\nLIVE OLYMPICS MEDAL COUNT:\n\nOverall table | Who is winning the Olympics? | Who's won the most gold?\n\nThe medical staff tended to him and eventually took him off the track in a wheelchair, leading many to wonder whether he was OK or if he was dealing with an illness during the event.\n\nHere's what to know about Lyles' health after his bronze finish in the 200-meter dash.\n\n2024 PARIS OLYMPICS\n\nFull Olympics schedule | How to watch in USA | Meet NBC's broadcasters\n\nLyles' mother revealed that the USA sprinter was dealing with COVID during his 200-meter run, as detailed by NBC's Olympics broadcast. He was diagnosed with the virus two days earlier but decided to run in the event anyway.\n\nThe NBC broadcast said that Lyles' mother -- Keisha Caine -- was \"distraught\" after seeing her son taken off in a wheelchair. She was trying to find him after the race to make sure that he was OK.\n\nLyles spoke to reporters after he received medical attention. Clad in a mask, he revealed that he had quarantined after his diagnosis but \"never considered not running.\"\n\nBut what's next for Lyles? He is still weighing whether he will participate in the USA's 4x100-meter relay. He told the NBC broadcast if he has to choose now, he won't run, but he isn't ruling out participating if he feels better.\n\nLyles was spotted wearing a mask before running the 200-meter dash semifinals on Wednesday, which was the first sign that the U.S. sprinter wasn't at 100 percent.\n\nNow, track fans know that Lyles was wearing a mask because he had been diagnosed with COVID. He continued to wear the mask after running in the 200-meter race even though he wasn't seen wearing it before then.\n\nNonetheless, Lyles decided to run rather than opt out of the event. He still earned a bronze in the 200-meter dash -- an impressive feat but also a dangerous one considering that he not only had COVID, but also asthma.\n\nBEST U.S. OLYMPIANS\n\nTop 33 rankings | Simone Biles | Katie Ledecky | Jesse Owens\n\nLyles had bad asthma as a child, a fact about which he has been open. He mentioned it in a post to X (formerly Twitter) after he won the 100-meter dash and hasn't been shy about sharing his experiences with others.\n\nIn 2020, Lyles detailed to CNN that he dealt with severe asthma issues as a child. It resulted in him being homeschooled and his mother making significant changes to their home environment.\n\n\"So, about 3 to 4, all the way to about 7 years old, I was dealing with asthma and asthma attacks seriously, like in the hospital, maybe every third night; coughing fits, constantly sick because my immune system was weak,\" Lyles said at the time.\n\nThat's part of the reason Lyles took extra precautions during the 2021 Tokyo Olympics. He did the same by wearing his mask after catching COVID in Paris, but his decision to compete certainly couldn't have been easy considering his health and chronic condition.\n\nFor those wondering why Lyles was allowed to compete with COVID, the Olympics is allowing infected athletes to compete in events in 2024. The event no longer has testing requirements for the disease either.\n\nThat said, athletes who feel sick \"are encouraged -- though not required -- to wear masks, wash their hands and avoid close contact with others,\" per the Scientific American. They also are granted access to single-person rooms in the Olympic Village while some countries \"provide separate transportation for sick participants.\"\n\nUltimately, it was Lyles' decision to run the race. Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles said he had COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed around in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time -- nothing. {"uri": "2024-08-448482285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:07:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:07:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-covid-olympics-200/", "title": "Noah Lyles has covid, NBC says, after Lyles wins bronze in 200", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nThe pursuit Noah Lyles had dreamed about and publicly stoked for years lived as he sprinted around the curve, the place from which Lyles excels like few athletes in the world excel from anywhere. And then his vision evaporated in stunning and alarming fashion. He left the track not celebrating a second gold medal, but breathing heavily while riding in a wheelchair.\n\nIn the aftermath of the race, NBC reported that Lyles tested positive for covid two days ago, citing an interview with Lyles's mother.\n\nLyles fell to third place in his signature race, the 200 meters, losing to 21-year-old Botswanan Letsile Tebogo, who won his country's first gold medal, and fellow American Kenny Bednarek. Lyles crossed in 19.70 seconds, well behind his standard and distant from Tebogo's 19.45-second masterpiece.\n\nAfter he crossed the line, Lyles began breathing heavily and laid down on his back. He slowly rose to sit, and medical personnel attended to him. Lyles unzipped his tracksuit and climbed into the wheelchair, fully conscious and regaining control of his breathing.\n\nLyles suffered from serious asthma as a child, frequently spending nights in the hospital hooked to a nebulizer. He has experienced flares as an adult, but they had never affected him in competition in a major way. Lyles wore a mask in warm-up area. He visited medical personnel after his semifinal, but his coach said he was \"fine.\"\n\nWhen Lyles won the 100 meters Sunday, he captured the event his mother once jokingly christened his \"side chick.\" Thursday, Lyles won only bronze in the race Keisha Caine Bishop considered his \"wife,\" the bread-and-butter event Lyles has dominated on the world stage since he turned professional out T.C. Williams (now Alexandria City) High in Alexandria. His pursuit of three gold medals ended with his second consecutive Olympic bronze.\n\nLyles won every 200 meters race he entered between the Tokyo Olympics final and Wednesday's semifinal, when he started slow and conserved energy on his way to second place. That hiccup could have cost him a preferable lane assignment, but he still started in favored Lane 5.\n\nLyles had declared his intentions -- and brash confidence -- Thursday morning. He borrowed a line from one of his favorite anime stories and posted on social media the Japanese phrase, \"Omae wa-mo shinde iru.\" Translation: You are already dead.\n\nIf Lyles was feeling ill, he didn't show it before the race. Lyles delivered his customary showmanship. As he warmed up, he jogged around the curve and cupped his hand to his ear. As he trotted back around to the blocks, he waved his left arm and asked the crowd for even more noise. When the public addressed introduced him, he charged on to the track, leaped over the barrier and bounded down the track some 25 meters, just like before his 100 victory.\n\nThursday night would not be like his prior triumph. It was another shock result, but not the one anybody wanted.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington {"uri": "2024-08-448214617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:18:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:18:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:58:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.cleveland.com/tv/2024/08/olympic-track-and-field-mens-200m-final-free-stream-today-can-noah-lyles-win-second-gold.html", "title": "Olympic track and field men's 200m final FREE STREAM today: Can Noah Lyles win second gold?", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles will go for his second (hopefully gold) medal of the Paris 2024 Olympics and third overall when he competes in the men's 200m final on Thursday in Paris. The 200m finals start at 1:35 p.m. Eastern on NBC and Peacock.\n\nIf you don't have cable, don't sweat it. Several streaming services will broadcast the event live, and you can watch for free on Fubo and DirecTV Stream, which both offer a free trial to new users. Sling, which has promotional pricing offers, is another option.\n\nPeacock, NBC's streaming service, is also broadcasting all Olympic events. While it does not offer a free trial, fans can sign up for a premium package starting at $7.99/month.\n\nLyles has already won one gold medal this summer in the 100-meter final. He comes into the race with a personal-best time of 19.31 seconds, tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His best time this season is 19.53 seconds set at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nIn addition to his other international competitors, Lyles will also be competing against two fellow Americans - \"Kung Fu\" Kenny Bednarek and Erriyon Knighton.\n\nHere's a further preview of today's race, courtesy of the Associated Press:\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France (AP) -- What was supposed to be the easy half of Noah Lyles' historic Olympic sprint double isn't looking quite so easy anymore.\n\nNewly crowned the Fastest Man Alive after a close-as-can-be win by five thousandths of a second in the 100 meters at the 2024 Games, Lyles was not even the fastest man in his semifinal of the 200 on Wednesday night. He was good enough to make it into that event's final, anyway.\n\nThe 200 is Lyles' preferred, and better, distance -- one at which he had not lost a race in three full years. That streak was snapped at the Stade de France, where Letsile Tebogo of Botswana beat him to the line by crossing in 19.96 seconds, 0.12 faster than runner-up Lyles.\n\nThey'll have a rematch for the gold on Thursday night.\n\nGetting golds in the 100 and 200 at a single Olympics is a rare feat. Usain Bolt accomplished that double at three Olympics in a row -- in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. But until the Jamaican, no man had done it since Carl Lewis at Los Angeles in 1984.\n\nAt his last Games, eight years ago, Bolt was shutting it down late in his 200 semifinal, and suddenly realized Andre De Grasse was running hard. So Bolt dialed his speed back up and wagged a finger at the Canadian. Fast-forward to the final: Bolt won easily.\n\nBefore pulling out his narrow win over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in the 100 final on Sunday night, Lyles didn't finish first in his heat or his semifinal.\n\nAs anyone who pays any attention is well aware, Lyles is a showman who loves the spotlight and enjoys spending time with a microphone.\n\nThat's obvious from his mean-mugging and gesturing on the purple track in Paris before he runs or such statements as the off-hand comparison between track and the NBA that went viral last year: \"The thing that hurts me the most is I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'World Champion' on their head,\" Lyles said. \"World champion of what? The United States?\"\n\nSo it raised some eyebrows when Lyles skipped the interview area after Wednesday's run, and U.S. team officials said he was heading to the medical tent. His coach, Lance Brauman, told The Associated Press: \"He's fine.\"\n\nThat might just add a bit more intrigue in the 24 hours until the medals are at stake.\n\nThere already was plenty.\n\nIs Lyles, a 27-year-old from Florida, at his best? How much did he care about the semifinal, when lane placements are determined but all that truly matters is moving on to the round that determines the medals? Will Lyles find some extra fuel from being outdone in front of a full house of about 80,000?\n\nWas the 21-year-old Tebogo, the 200 bronze medalist at worlds but making his Olympic debut, trying to send a message? Is he ready to challenge for a gold?\n\nAnd what about Kenny Bednarek, Lyles' U.S. teammate and the Tokyo Games silver medalist, who ran in a different semifinal and won it in 20 seconds flat, the evening's second-fastest time? Or Erryion Knighton, a 20-year-old American seen as the next threat, but whose only victories over Lyles came in the opening rounds of the 2021 Olympic trials.\n\nAt the last Olympics, Lyles finished behind Bednarek and champion De Grasse in the 200. On Wednesday, De Grasse was third in Bednarek's heat with a time too slow to reach the final.\n\nAfterward, De Grasse mentioned a hamstring issue that resurfaced. He also was asked about his American coach, Rana Reider, getting kicked out of the Paris Games after the Canadian Olympic Committee said it \"learned of new information about the appropriateness of Mr. Reider remaining accredited.\" Reider was investigated for alleged sexual misconduct by the U.S. Center for SafeSport and placed on a one-year probation that ended in May.\n\n\"I tried to keep my head and stay mentally strong,\" De Grasse said, \"but of course, that's always a tough one, not having your coach out there with you.\"", "source": {"uri": "cleveland.com", "dataType": "news", It was then revealed he had recently been diagnosed with COVID-19.\n\nAfter crossing the line third in the 200 meters for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and eventually sat up to be tended to by medical staff.\n\nIn an interview after the race, Lyles confirmed he had been diagnosed with COVID two days earlier.\n\n\"Yeah, I woke up early about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and, you know, I just was feeling really horrible and I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100. We tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for COVID.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic and I was thinking I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions I felt and we just took it day by day and trying to hydrate as much quarantined off. I definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and, and getting a bronze medal where last Olympics, I was very disappointed.\"\n\nWhile Lyles said he never considered skipping the 200-meter final, he's not sure whether he'll race in the 4x100m relay.\n\n\"At the moment I don't know, I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They're proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me.\"\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the men's 4x100 relay Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said that decision had not been made as of late Thursday.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and a year delay before the Games led to depression that he said hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nMinutes before the men's 200-meter final, Lyles was seen wearing a medical mask on the TV broadcast of the race.\n\nThe athlete, who was named the World's Fastest Man after clinching gold in the 100-meter dash, was spotted with a mask during the semifinal round on Wednesday.\n\nLyles isn't the first Olympian to be impacted by COVID at the Paris Games. claims 200m gold as Noah Lyles takes bronze - NewZimbabwe.com", "body": "Botswana's Letsile Tebogo claimed a surprise Olympic 200m gold medal as Noah Lyles was denied a sprint double at Paris 2024.\n\nTebogo, 21, stormed clear of his rivals to clock an African record of 19.46 seconds and finish ahead of American Kenneth Bednarek, who crossed the line in 19.62.\n\nLyles, crowned the world's fastest man by five-thousandths of a second in a historically quick 100m final on Sunday night, was unable to compete at the head of the race and matched his Tokyo bronze in 19.70.\n\nIt emerged after the race that Lyles had tested positive for Covid and the 27-year-old had to be helped off the track in a wheelchair.\n\nHaving burst out on to the track to huge cheers before the race, Lyles was seeking to become the first man since Usain Bolt in 2016 to complete a 100m and 200m double at an Olympic Games.\n\nBut Tebogo had other ideas.\n\nA world bronze medallist over the distance last year, Tebogo also took 100m silver in Budapest as Lyles completed a golden treble.\n\nThat was a dazzling return for Tebogo at his first senior global championship, but it was nothing compared to his achievement at the Stade de France as he marked his first Olympics with a gold.\n\nTebogo, sixth in the Paris 100m final, lined up with a 200m personal best of 19.50 - notably down on the favourite's 19.31.\n\nShowman Lyles made his entrance to huge excitement, seemingly ready to seize his moment with the eyes of the world fixed upon him, but he remained third throughout following a slow start.\n\nBednarek held out to equal his silver of three years ago in Tokyo - a medal he also won at the 2022 World Championships - but could not overhaul Tebogo, who sprinted clear to win Botswana's It was the first time in Olympic history in which a man from Africa won the 200-meter gold medal. Fellow American Kenny Bednarek won the silver medal.\n\nLyles's personal fastest time in the 200-meter race was 19.31 seconds heading into the Paris Olympics. He hit this time at the 2022 World Athletics Championship. He captured the bronze medal in the 200-meter race at the Tokyo Olympics.\n\nAfter winning a gold medal in the 100-meter final in a fantastic photo finish, Lyles predicted that he would take home another gold medal in this race. This didn't end up being the case, but Lyles still is walking away with another Olympic medal.\n\nLyles completed a personal record in the 100-meter race on Monday with a time of 9.79 seconds.\n\nLyles's Paris journey may not be over yet, as he is set to compete in the 4x100 men's relay final on Friday. After the 200-meter, He did leave the track in a wheelchair after being tended to for an apparent injury, which could be something to watch regarding his availability for the scheduled event.\n\nIf he participates as scheduled, Lyles could add another piece of hardware to his ever-growing collection if the team can place in the top three. {"uri": "2024-08-448507228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:40:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:40:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:39:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.on3.com/news/noah-lyles-reveals-when-he-contracted-covid-19-impact-on-200-meter-final-relay-availability/", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals when he contracted COVID-19, impact on 200-meter final, relay availability", "body": "A stunning upset in the 200-meter dash on Thursday afternoon was followed by an even more surprising sight post-race: American star Noah Lyles in a wheelchair.\n\nAfter collapsing to the ground following the race, which Lyles finished in 19.70 to claim the bronze medal, Lyles was tended to by medical personnel.\n\nHe was placed into a wheelchair, leaving many wondering what was going on.\n\nLyles would reveal less than an hour later that he had previously been diagnosed with COVID-19, but that he never had a real thought of withdrawing from the 200-meter final as he looked to match Carl Lewis' 1984 feat of winning both the 100 and 200.\n\n\"No. No. I didn't,\" Noah Lyles told NBC reporter Lewis Johnson. \"We were just going to try and quarantine as much as possible, stay away. Not trying to pass it off and just, to be honest, give it my all. If I wasn't to make it, somebody definitely would have taken my spot and that would have been my sign that I didn't deserve to be in the final.\"\n\nAs it was, Lyles finished in third, good enough for the bronze medal. He remarked after that he's never been more proud of himself, given the circumstances.\n\nLyles explained when he found out he had COVID-19.\n\n\"Yeah, I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was feeling really horrible then,\" Noah Lyles said. \"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100. We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for COVID.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic. I was thinking I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions I felt and we just took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much, quarantined off. I'd definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympics I was very disappointed, and this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nHowever, Lyles still has some races in the tank. {"uri": "8265964520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:21:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:21:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:19:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.on3.com/pro/news/american-sprinter-noah-lyles-uncertain-about-running-4-by-100-meter-relay-after-covid-diagnosis/", "title": "American sprinter Noah Lyles uncertain about running 4x100 meter relay after Covid diagnosis", "body": "One of the brighter stars for Team USA in Paris for the 2024 Olympics is sprinter Noah Lyles. Already the champion in the 100 meter dash, Lyles was pegged as the favorite to win the 200 meter finals on Thursday.\n\nInstead, a somewhat-disappointing finishing in third place for bronze left Lyles looking physically defeated. He was eventually taken from the track in a wheelchair and would confirm to NBC a report that he had caught Covid-19 a few days prior.\n\nAnd though skipping out on the 200 meter final was never a consideration for Lyles, he admitted being part of the 4\u00d7100 meter relay team might not be tenable.\n\n\"At the moment, I don't know,\" Lyles said on NBC after the 200 meter final. \"Right now I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty they can handle it without me. If that's the case coming off today, then I'm perfectly fine saying, 'Hey, you guys go do your thing. You guys have got more than enough speed to handle it and get the gold medal.'\"\n\nThe men's 4\u00d7100 relay final is slated for around 1:45 p.m. EST on Friday.\n\nSpeaking shortly after the race, Lyles explained his thought process going into Thursday's race and how he didn't consider not running.\n\n\"No. No. I didn't,\" Lyles told NBC reporter Lewis Johnson. \"We were just going to try and quarantine as much as possible, stay away. Not trying to pass it off and just, to be honest, give it my all. If I wasn't to make it, somebody definitely would have taken my spot and that would have been my sign that I didn't deserve to be in the final.\"\n\nAs it was, Lyles finished in third, good enough for the bronze medal. He remarked after that he's never been more proud of himself, given the circumstances.\n\nLyles explained when he found out he had COVID-19.\n\n\"Yeah, I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was feeling really horrible then,\" Lyles said. \"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100. We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for COVID.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic. I was thinking I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions I felt and we just took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much, quarantined off. I'd definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympics I was very disappointed, {"uri": "8264113997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "19:40:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T19:40:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T19:38:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-200m-final-olympics-2024-b2592883.html", "title": "Noah Lyles chases Olympic history in 200m final - but these rivals can stop him", "body": "Breaking news: Noah Lyles just lost a 200m race. Lyles is a double world champion over the distance and had won his last 26 races. But on a still-warm evening at the Stade de France, the American sprint king was beaten to the line in his Olympic semi-final by African champion Letsile Tebogo.\n\nPerhaps it is more accurate to say Lyles finished second, given he comfortably qualified for Thursday night's final. Both men eased up in the final 20m with the finish in sight and energy to conserve. But they were flat out around the bend, where Tebogo burned into the lead, and perhaps it was a sign that Lyles will not have it all his own way.\n\nOnly four men have won the triple of 100m, 200m and 4x100m gold at the Olympic games. After winning the 100m crown by five thousandths of a second on Monday night, Lyles is bidding to join a list of American icons: the great Jesse Owens (1936), Bobby Morrow (1956), who managed to make sprinting look like a light jog in the park, Carl Lewis (1984) and, of course, Usain Bolt (2012 and 2016).\n\nRelays are an unpredictable business, but if USA get the baton round cleanly then they should have too much for the reigning Olympic champions Italy, Canada, Britain and the rest. The question is whether Lyles will be on the startline with two gold medals already around his neck.\n\nNot if Tebogo can help it. The 21-year-old Botswanan has a stack of age-group records including the fastest 200m time ever by a teenager. He was the only man in these three semi-finals to run under 20 seconds, clocking 19.96 sec at a breeze, and his personal best of 19.50 could trouble Lyles, especially if the American gets a sluggish start.\n\nTebogo finished only sixth in the 100m final but the longer distance is about hitting maximum speed and maintaining it, and here Tebogo is in his element. His top speed of 27.92mph was higher than all of the other finalists (Lyles was second with 27.84).\n\nThe most impressive semi-finalist beyond those two was another American, Kenny Bednarek, the 200m specialist who won silver three years ago in Tokyo, ahead of Lyles who took bronze. Bednarek cruised through the line looking very comfortable in his white bandana as he clocked 20.00 sec. He glanced at the screen, shrugged and walked away.\n\nThe third semi-final was one by Erriyon Knighton, another American, who three years ago in Tokyo was being tipped as the future of sprinting when still just 17. He finished fourth in the final there and has since lowered his personal best to 19.49. Knighton is under scrutiny after failing an anti-doping test, only to be cleared after claiming to have ingested contaminated meat.\n\nIf Lyles can beat them he will join esteemed company in the history of American athletics. Although he won't quite match Owens and Lewis, who also found time to win the long jump.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], Fellow American Kenneth Bednarek took silver in 19.62.\n\nLyles said he was proud of his performance given his ill health.\n\n\"We just took it day-by-day trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off,\" {"uri": "2024-08-448533235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:18:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:18:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:14:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.kansas.com/sports/article290890464.html", "title": "Noah Lyles comes up short in Olympic men's 200 meters while battling COVID", "body": "By David Wharton, Los Angeles Times The Tribune Content Agency\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France - After a thrilling, historic victory in the men's 100 meters earlier this week, Noah Lyles was diagnosed with COVID and finished third in the 200-meter final.\n\nOn Thursday night at the 2024 Summer Games, the American sprinter came up short in the 200, thereby ending his hopes for an Olympic sprint triple.\n\nLetsile Tebogo of Botswana took gold in 19.46 seconds, with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62 seconds. Lyles was third across the line in 19.70 seconds.\n\nAfter the race Lyles, who has battled asthma, sat on the track winded and received medical treatment.\n\nMedical personnel wheeled Lyles down a hallway deep beneath the stands at Stade de France. As he was taken by wheelchair for examination, someone asked if he wanted to call his mother. He shook his head.\n\n\"I just needed some time,\" he said. \"So they wheeled me off the track. \"\n\nA minute later, his mother rushed down the hallway after him.\n\nNBC was the first to report his mother confirmed Lyles was diagnosed with COVID two days earlier but still was committed to running.\n\n\"I woke up in the middle of the night [Tuesday] just feeling really chills, aching, sore throat and those are kind of a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting COVID,\" Lyles told reporters while wearing a mask after the race.\n\nHe said he moved to a hotel away from the Athletes Village and took as much Paxlovid as allowed by international track rules. His team did not tell anyone about his test result.\n\nLyles said his team didn't tell anyone about his illness, but took precautions to avoid spreading it. He said felt better Thursday and entered the race at about 90% strength. He told NBC he never considered skipping the 200-meter final\n\n\"To be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out and getting the bronze medal,\" he told reporters.\n\nHe isn't the only athlete who has competed after testing positive for COVID in Paris.\n\nThe COVID safety restrictions that dramatically altered the Tokyo Olympics were abandoned for the Paris Olympics and mask use among athletes has been limited. There are no COVID testing requirements and the disease has been treated like any other respiratory illness. Olympic officials allow athletes and delegations to decide how to handle infections, urging those who feel ill to seek medical treatment. Isolation rooms for those who are ill are available at the Athletes Village.\n\nBritish swimmer Adam Peaty and Australian swimmers Lani Pallister and Zac Stubblety-Cook have all competed with COVID during the Paris Olympics.\n\nLyles chose to join them, lining up for the 200-meter final.\n\nThe last man to accomplish the Olympic triple Lyles sought was Usain Bolt, who did it twice, at London 2012 and Rio 2016.\n\nLyles has another shot at gold in the 4x100 relay Friday, but he told NBC he was leaning against participating in the race.\n\n\"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing,\" Lyles said. \"... {"uri": "8264572601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "04:29:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T04:29:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:28:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.nbcbayarea.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/noah-lyles-sprint-double-200m-final-2024-olympics/3618925/", "title": "How Noah Lyles can make rare Olympic history in the 200m final", "body": "Watch U.S. sprinter Noah Lyles win the men's 100m at the Paris Olympics.\n\nLyles has already earned the title of \"Fastest Man in the World\" at the Paris Games, and he's now on the doorstep of joining very exclusive Olympic company:\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals in Paris.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal time overall behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- will it be in the 200m final?\n\nLyles will look to become just the 10th man to ever pull off the Olympic sprint double when he races in the 200m final on Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET.\n\nThe men's 200m final will be shown on NBC and Peacock. It will also be available to stream here:\n\nLyles enters the 200m final with two Olympic medals: a 200m bronze from the Tokyo Games and a 100m gold from the Paris Games.\n\nHe's also a three-time world champion in the 200m and the reigning world champion in the 100m.\n\nFollowing the 200m final, Lyles is scheduled to next move over to the men's 4x100m relay. The relay event begins with the first round on Thursday followed by the final on Friday.\n\nSo there's a chance Lyles will enter the weekend with an Olympic sprint triple under his belt.", "source": He placed bronze, adding a second medal to his trophy case after winning gold in the 100-meter final on Sunday.\n\nHowever, Lyles dropped to a knee shortly after the 100-meter race ended and was visibly unwell. The sight led the NBC broadcast to reveal the sensational sprinter had tested positive for COVID-19 on Tuesday.\n\nThe Paris Olympics do not have anything resembling strict COVID protocols, so Lyles did not break any rules by particpating in Thursday's race. In fact, he reportedly isn't even the first athlete to participate in the 2024 Games while positive for COVID. But between the news of the diagnosis going public and Lyles' clear struggles after the race, it's natural to wonder if he will be part of his next scheduled event.\n\nLyles is supposed to be part of the 4x100 men's relay team, scheduled to participate in the final on Friday afternoon. Will he participate in light of his COVID diagnosis?\n\nWill Noah Lyles Run in the 4x100 Meter Race at the Olympics?\n\nLyles himself was asked this question by NBC's Lewis Johnson shortly after the conclusion of the 200-meter final.\n\n\"At the moment, I don't know,\" Lyles said. \"Right now I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty they can handle it without me. If that's the case coming off today, then I'm perfectly fine saying, 'Hey, you guys go do your thing. You guys have got more than enough speed to handle it and get the gold medal.'\"\n\nTo Lyles' last point, the 4x100 team had to qualify today without his help. As Lyles prepared for the 200-meter final, Team USA dominated and finished well ahead of any other country in the qualifying heat to reach the final.\n\nRight now, it seems up in the air whether Lyles will be good to go tomorrow. {"uri": "8265909069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:25:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/olympics-2024/524602/noah-lyles-denied-double-gold-after-covid-diagnosis", "title": "Noah Lyles denied double gold after Covid diagnosis", "body": "Botswana's Letsile Tebogo claimed a surprise Olympic 200m gold medal as Noah Lyles was denied a sprint double at Paris 2024.\n\nTebogo, 21, stormed clear of his rivals to clock an African record of 19.46 seconds and finish ahead of American Kenneth Bednarek, who crossed the line in 19.62.\n\nLyles, crowned the world's fastest man by five-thousandths of a second in a historically quick 100m final on Sunday night, was unable to compete at the head of the race and matched his Tokyo bronze in 19.70.\n\nIt emerged after the race that Lyles had tested positive for Covid and the 27-year-old had to be helped off the track in a wheelchair.\n\nHaving burst out on to the track to huge cheers before the race, Lyles was seeking to become the first man since Usain Bolt in 2016 to complete a 100m and 200m double at an Olympic Games.\n\nBut Tebogo had other ideas.\n\nA world bronze medallist over the distance last year, Tebogo also took 100m silver in Budapest as Lyles completed a golden treble.\n\nThat was a dazzling return for Tebogo at his first global championship, but it was nothing compared to his achievement at the Stade de France as he marked his first Olympics with a gold.\n\nTebogo, sixth in the Paris 100m final, lined up with a 200m personal best of 19.50 - notably down on the favourite's 19.31.\n\nShowman Lyles made his entrance to huge excitement, seemingly ready to seize his moment with the eyes of the world fixed upon him, but he remained third throughout following a slow start.\n\nBednarek held out to equal his silver of three years ago in Tokyo - a medal he also won at the 2022 World Championships - but could not overhaul Tebogo.\n\nTebogo dedicated Olympic gold to his mother Seratiwa, who died in May of this year after a brief illness, and held his spikes, displaying her date of birth, up to the camera following his victory.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" Tebogo said.\n\n\"To take her [with me], it gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy.\"\n\nHaving ended Lyles' 26-race winning streak over the distance in the semi-finals, Tebogo announced himself on the global stage as he repeated that victory over the man who has long been tipped as Bolt's heir apparent.\n\nTebogo entered the home straight with an advantage and, as his rivals threatened to pull alongside, he surged away in the closing stages to clinch an emotional - and hugely significant - triumph.\n\nLyles, the fastest man over 200m this year before this race and a three-time reigning world champion over the distance, produced his usual theatrics before the serious business began.\n\nBut this performance in his favoured event was not at his usual world-beating standard and it soon became apparent why as news broke of the American's illness.\n\nBolt, the fastest man in history and winner of eight Olympic gold medals, completed the sprint double at three successive Games in Beijing, London and Rio - and he remains the only man to ever enjoy such a dominant streak.\n\nLyles had targeted a remarkable four golds in Paris, including both the 4x100m and 4x400m relays, but it remains to be seen whether {"uri": "2024-08-448648505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:31:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:31:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:58:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/noah-lyles-olympic-dreams-narrowed-by-covid-19-challenges/", "title": "Noah Lyles' Olympic Dreams Narrowed by Covid-19 Challenges - The Global Herald", "body": "Noah Lyles expressed his pride in securing a bronze medal in the 200 meters, despite the setback of testing positive for Covid-19, which dashed his hopes of achieving an Olympic sprint double, a feat last accomplished by Usain Bolt.\n\nThe American sprinter, aged 27, triumphed in the 100 meters final, winning by a mere five-thousandths of a second. This victory took place on Sunday, marking a historic moment in the competition.\n\nDebilitating Symptoms and Race Results\n\nHowever, just four days post-victory, Lyles was seen being assisted off the track in a wheelchair during the 200 meters final, where Botswana's Letsile Tebogo emerged as the champion. Lyles received the positive Covid-19 test early on Tuesday morning.\n\nLyles commented, \"It definitely affected my performance. I've had to take a lot of breaks,\" conveying the difficulties he faced in managing the illness during the race. He later added, \"I was coughing through the night. I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out here to get a bronze with Covid.\" He described feeling lightheaded, experiencing shortness of breath, and having chest pains following the race. \"I'm a lot better now,\" he reassured.\n\nUnexpected Challenges on a Bright Day\n\nUpon entering the track, Lyles showcased his typical enthusiasm, engaging the crowd as he sought to be among only ten individuals to win both the 100 meters and 200 meters gold medals at one Olympic Games. Following last year's impressive performance, where he won three gold medals at the World Championships, Lyles was optimistic heading into the race.\n\nDuring the final, despite a sluggish start, Lyles found himself unable to catch up with the frontrunners, finishing third behind silver medalist Kenneth Bednarek. It was not until after the race that observers recognized the extent of his struggle, as Lyles showed visible signs of distress.\n\n\"We were trying to keep this close to the chest,\" Lyles noted about his secret Covid diagnosis. He explained, \"The people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mum. We didn't want everybody going into a panic,\" showcasing a competitive mindset aimed at not giving his rivals an advantage.\n\nHealth and Future Competitions\n\nLyles disclosed that he first felt ill early Tuesday morning, suffering symptoms such as chills and sore throat, and subsequently isolated himself with his team in a hotel. They were proactive in providing him with medication to help maintain his racing condition. \"I still wanted to run; it was still possible,\" he explained. As he recovers, he estimates to be at about \"90 to 95%\" of his physical capability.\n\nThe outcome of the 200 meters final interrupted Lyles' ambition for four gold medals in total, having initially aimed to add the 4x400m relay to his achievements from the previous year. His participation in the upcoming relay events remains uncertain, despite the 4x100m final scheduled for Friday, and the 4x400m final set for Saturday.\n\n\"We haven't decided yet; I'm going to talk to the 4x100m crew,\" Lyles said, emphasizing his commitment to communicate openly with coaches regarding his health status and capabilities.\n\nCurrent Covid-19 Protocols in Sports\n\nUnlike the restrictions faced during the Tokyo Games, when athletes competed under strict coronavirus protocols, the current atmosphere in Paris is significantly more relaxed. Covid-19 is now classified as a respiratory illness, absent of rigorous competition restrictions.\n\nThe USA Track and Field organization promptly implemented the necessary protocols to safeguard the health of Lyles and his teammates, allowing Lyles to compete following a thorough medical assessment. They stressed their commitment to athlete safety while enabling competition.\n\nIn another incident earlier in the Games, British swimmer Adam Peaty also tested positive but returned to competition {"uri": "8265921608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:38:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:38:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:37:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.nbclosangeles.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/noah-lyles-taken-off-track-in-wheelchair-moments-after-winning-bronze-at-paris-olympics/3483091/", "title": "Noah Lyles taken off track in wheelchair moments after winning bronze at Paris Olympics", "body": "The Alexandria runner was diagnosed with COVID-19 days before winning bronze in the 200m, but said: \"I've run with worse conditions... We just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off\"\n\nNoah Lyles said he was diagnosed with COVID-19 days before winning bronze in the men's 200m at the Paris Olympics. Moments after finishing third in the race, Lyles left the track in a wheelchair with medical staff, then returned to speak on live TV.\n\nThe Alexandria, Virginia, athlete ran the 200m with a time of 19.70 on Thursday, then lay down on the ground. He continued sitting while medical attendants brought him water. A short time later, he left the track in a wheelchair.\n\n\"It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get a bronze medal,\" Lyles later said. \"Last Olympics I was very disappointed and this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nUSA Track & Field confirmed that Lyles tested positive for COVID-19, and said the organization \"swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\"\n\n\"I've run with worse conditions,\" Lyles later said.\n\nFans were concerned and confused as Lyles took many deep breaths following the race.\n\nLyles' mother first shared news of the COVID diagnosis, NBC's Lewis Johnson reported on the track broadcast.\n\n\"I ran into his mom Keisha Caine Bishop who was distraught trying to find him as well,\" Johnson said. \"We found Noah Lyles in medical, they're being tended to and she did confirm that Noah had been diagnosed with COVID two days ago.\"\n\nSeveral minutes later, Lyles came out and spoke to Johnson during his broadcast and said he started feeling sick a couple of days after winning a gold medal in the 100m race.\n\n\"Yeah I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I just was feeling really horrible. I knew it was more than just being sore from the [100m race]. Woke up the doctors, and we tested, and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for COVID. My first thought was not to panic, thinking, I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions,\" he said.\n\nLyles previously said he has asthma, which the CDC has said can put people \"at increased risk for getting very sick from COVID-19.\"\n\nLyles won gold in the 100m race on Sunday, taking the crown as \"fastest man in the world\" following a dramatic photo finish. He had been open about trying to win gold in both the 200m and 100m races. While the 200m is typically his best event, Lyles wasn't in peak shape while battling COVID.\n\nUSA Track & Field said it was Lyles' choice to compete after he tested positive on Monday.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely,\" the statement said.\n\n\"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory His .005-second victory over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson set up the potential for a historic double-gold in sprinting's two most prestigious events.\n\nMore news: Noah Lyles Wins Men's 100M Final in Photo Finish\n\nJumping and waving his arms prior to Thursday's race, Lyles entered Stade de France with the crowd on his side, well aware of the history at stake.\n\nIn the end, it was Teboco who cruised comfortably at the finish line, flanked by Bednarek on his right and Lyles on his left. Teboco pounded his chest after crossing the finish line after capturing the first Olympic gold medal in his country's history.\n\nLyles won the bronze in the men's 200-meter final at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. {"uri": "2024-08-448537900", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:23:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:23:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:07:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://wgntv.com/2024-olympics/if-noah-lyles-had-covid-why-was-he-allowed-to-compete/", "title": "If Noah Lyles had COVID, why was he allowed to compete?", "body": "(NEXSTAR) - After Noah Lyles competed in the 200-meter final in Paris Thursday, he collapsed to the ground - and it wasn't just from exhaustion. The American sprinter had been diagnosed with COVID-19 two days prior, Lyles told reporters after the race wrapped.\n\nIf Lyles knew he had COVID before the race even started, why was he allowed to compete?\n\nAccording to Scientific American, athletes who test positive for the virus are still allowed to participate in the competition - and several have. As of Wednesday, 19 athletes - many of them British and Australian swimmers - had tested positive.\n\nUnlike the past two Olympics, in Tokyo and Beijing, the Paris Games have no mandatory testing for participating athletes, either, Scientific American reports. Masks are encouraged for those who don't feel well, but they're not required. (Lyles wore a mask when addressing the media after his race, but not in the warm-up or during the event.) There are also single rooms for athletes who are COVID-positive.\n\nWhile there is no overarching COVID policy, some countries have written out their own frameworks for how to tackle the virus at the 2024 Games.\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine. \"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" he added.\n\nAfter Lyles crossed the finish line in third place Thursday, he fell to his back and writhed around in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting into a wheelchair.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to He was taken off the track in a wheelchair.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history. Bednarek, who also won silver in Tokyo, finished in 19.62 and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nSports Roundup\n\nGet the latest D-FW sports news, analysis, scores and more.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nLyles had not been beaten in a 200 since that night in Tokyo, and after his win in the 100, he brought the bronze medal to the press conference, slammed it on the table and said that had been his motivation for three full years.\n\nNow, he'll get another one.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThursday's final marked the second straight night Tebogo beat him to the finish line in the Lyles' favorite race.\n\nIn the semifinal, Lyles finished second and skipped his traditional meeting with reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nThis time, Tebogo was leading as the sprinters reached the curve. {"uri": "8265980974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:37:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:37:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:36:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-wins-bronze-in-200-meters-then-reveals-he-has-covid/", "title": "Noah Lyles Wins Bronze in 200 Meters, Then Reveals He Has Covid", "body": "Almost as soon as he crossed the finish line in the 200-meter dash on Thursday night, Noah Lyles looked winded. He lay on his back on the purple track at Stade de France, after finishing third in a race he had dominated for the last three years, and struggled for breath.\n\nFour days after winning a gold medal in one of the most thrilling endings to an Olympic sprint, Lyles took the bronze in the 200 and considered it, he said afterward, a remarkable achievement. Lyles learned that he had tested positive for the coronavirus around 5 a.m. Paris time on Tuesday, less than 36 hours after he won the 100 in a photo finish that was a stunning start to an Olympic campaign he hoped would position him as the next great American track and field star.\n\nBut on Tuesday, after waking up with chills, aches and a sore throat, symptoms he had experienced during previous exposures, Lyles left the athletes' village to quarantine in a nearby hotel. He said he was taking the antiviral treatment Paxlovid, and that he had not once considered dropping out or revealing his condition in advance of the 200 final. Athletes are not required to test or to report Covid-19 cases.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete,\" Lyles, wearing an N-95 mask, told reporters about 45 minutes after finishing in 19.70 seconds, behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana (19.46), who won his country's first Olympic gold medal in its history, and the American Kenneth Bednarek (19.62). Lyles added: \"And you never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe Paris Olympics are the first to be held without the pandemic-era bubbles of the Tokyo Games in 2021 and the Beijing Games in 2022. In Tokyo, athletes were tested every four days. In Beijing, they were tested daily. When athletes tested positive, they were placed in quarantine. Most were forced to withdraw from the Games entirely.\n\nNational governing bodies have been tasked with creating their own Covid protocols. Few have specific policies, and many have resorted to something that resembles common sense. A positive test has not stopped athletes from competing.\n\nZac Stubblety-Cook, an Australian swimmer, had Covid when he won silver in the 200 backstroke. The British swimmer Adam Peaty learned he had Covid a day after winning silver in the 100 breaststroke. Lani Pallister, another Australian swimmer, tested positive for Covid and decided to race two days later as part of the 4\u00d7200 relay team, which won gold.\n\nFor Lyles, the first clue that he was not at full strength emerged on Wednesday, when Tebogo raced past him in a semifinal heat; Lyles had won the last two world titles in the 200 -- and had not lost in the event since 2021 -- and so it seemed it was likely that he was lagging on purpose, conserving energy before Thursday's final and the upcoming 4\u00d7100 relays.\n\nWhen Lyles was introduced on Thursday night, he darted out of the tunnel, spinning and shouting and pointing to the crowd. The crowd chanted \"U.S.A.! U.S.A.!\" until they were shushed over the arena loudspeakers.\n\nAt the gun, Lyles got off the blocks slower than the seven other finalists. But unlike Sunday, when he trailed for the first 90 meters before edging Kishane Thompson of Jamaica at the end, Lyles lacked endurance and speed, particularly around the bend.\n\nAfterward, Lyles sat near the track, breathing heavily. He got up slowly and called for water, after which medical officials led him to a seat and spoke to him.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team U.S.A. athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" U.S.A. Track and Field, the sport's national governing body, said in a statement on Thursday night. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles entered these Olympics eager to reassert his primacy after floundering at the Tokyo Games, where he finished with a bronze medal in the 200 and opened up about his struggles with his mental health. He called his medal \"boring\" as he spoke through tears to reporters, the only people who were in the stadium.\n\nLyles, 27, thinks of racing as performance art. He loves to race and win, but he loves to race and win in front of a full stadium even more -- the bigger and louder and feistier the crowd, the better.\n\nHe has ripped his speedsuit in triumph after winning world championships, presented anime cards to the camera before and after races, and has become a ubiquitous figure on his Peacock series, YouTube channel and the Netflix docuseries \"Sprint.\"\n\nAt the 2023 world championships in Budapest, he turned in the performance he had long said he was capable of, winning the 100, 200 and the 4\u00d7100 meter relay. He had been eager to go for that trifecta in Paris, too, and perhaps add a gold medal in the 4\u00d7400 to it.\n\nInstead, the rest of Lyles's program is in doubt. He did not win the sprint double, like Usain Bolt or Carl Lewis or Jesse Owens, and it wasn't clear on Thursday whether he would run in any relays.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", The 100-meter final was only the first step.\n\nLyles wants to win the 200-meter gold medal Thursday and win a gold medal in the 4x100-meter relay Friday to put his name alongside some of the greatest Olympic athletes of all time. Only Jesse Owens (1936), Bobby Morrow (1956), Carl Lewis (1984) and Usain Bolt (2012 and 2016) have ever won gold medals in all three of those sprint events at the same Olympics.\n\nNext up on Lyles' list: His signature event.\n\nThe Alexandria, Virginia native is the defending world champion in the 200 meters, but finished second in the 200-meter semifinals on Wednesday -- his first loss since earning a bronze medal at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. He finished with a time of 20.08 seconds.\n\nLyles cruised through his heat Tuesday in 19.31 seconds, two days after he ran the fastest Olympic 100-meter race since Usain Bolt set the Olympic record with a 9.63 in 2012. His time in the 200 on Tuesday was the fastest recorded at the Olympics since Bolt set an Olympic record at the Beijing Games in 2008.\n\nMUST READ: American sprinter Noah Lyles is no longer a meme. He's a stunning redemption story.\n\nLyles also voiced the desire ahead of this week to attempt an unprecedented run at four medals in Paris. He wanted to be included on the United States 4x400 relay team, and the manner in which he publicly campaigned for a spot in the race drew criticism on social media from Quincy Hall, who won the 400-meter gold medal on Wednesday.\n\nLyles ran on Team USA's silver-medal winning 4x400-relay team at the 2024 world indoor track and field championships, but he's not expected to be included at the Olympics.\n\nHe is expected, however, to be a part of the American 4x100-relay team. Lyles anchored the 4x100 team that won a gold medal at the World Athletics Relays in May along with Kenny Bednarek, Courtney Lindsay and Kyree King.\n\nIf all goes as he plans, Lyles will cross the The American sprinter finished third in the men's 200m final, just days after his extremely close win in the 100m final.\n\nLyles sought to become just the tenth person to pull off the double, and the first American to do it since Carl Lewis back in 1984.\n\nUnfortunately, Lyles was unable to win in the 200m - his signature event - as he dealt with COVID.\n\nAfter the race, the typically confident and self-assured Lyles took some time to show a little humility.\n\n\"LETSILE TEBOGO congratulations,\" Lyles said, shouting out the winner of the race from Botswana.\n\n\"Ik you have had a very rough year off the track and despite that you overcame it all!\"\n\nTebogo's gold medal is not only his first, but it's the first for Botswana in its Olympic history. He is also the first African man to win the 200m final, an event typically dominated by American and Caribbean sprinters.\n\nAs Lyles mentioned, Tebogo has had to deal with a lot in the last year, including the death of his mother in May. He wore spikes for the race with her birthday on the side of the shoe.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" Tebogo said about having his mother's birthday on his spikes.\n\n\"To take her [with me], it gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy.\"\n\nLyles' Olympics could be over, depending on his availability for the relay races. He indicated that he could choose to bow out of those races, giving other Americans the chance to win gold as he continues to recover from COVID.\n\nLyles will leave with at least two medals and the title of fastest man alive, but he's certainly disappointed after a third-place finish in his signature event on the track.\n\nRelated: Everyone Has The Same Reaction To Noah Lyles' Illness Lyles finished third in 19.70, and received a code of conduct warning. It was not immediately clear why the warning was issued.\n\nLyles came into the Paris Games with bravado, World Championship golds and claims of being the \"fastest man in the world,\" but was lacking that Olympic gold after earning bronze at the 2020 Tokyo Games. He earned a huge win in the 100-meter final on Aug. 4, but couldn't complete the double in the 200-meter, traditionally his best event.\n\nBednarek, meanwhile, repeated his silver medal in the 200-meter from the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nThis is 21-year-old Tebogo's first Olympic Games. He's previously earned a silver medal in the 100-meter and bronze in the 200-meter at the 2023 World Championships.\n\nLyles was feeling confident after his 100-meter win on Sunday.\n\n\"To be honest, I just believed in myself,\" Lyles told reporters, including PEOPLE, of how he was able to recover from a slower start to win gold. \"That goes to prove that reaction time does not win races.\"\n\nThe Adidas star added to reporters that he knew \"every step of the way it was not 2021,\" referring to his disappointing finish at the Tokyo Games.\n\n\"I'm still constantly moving forward, moving
