{"uri": "8264614784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "05:09:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T05:09:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T05:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/olympics/news/noah-lyles-hometown-high-school-virginia/3b81b9331073c2ad22110d60", "title": "Where is Noah Lyles from? Hometown, high school and more to know about Virginia roots", "body": "The world has a new fastest man, and he comes from the United States.\n\nNoah Lyles' victory in the 100-meter final by the smallest of margins in Paris propelled him into the international spotlight and made him the USA's first Olympic winner of the event in two decades.\n\nFor Lyles, the win was what he had been expecting all along. Even as he posted a pair of second-place finishes in the preliminary rounds of the 100-meter, Lyles kept his confidence high and insisted he wouldn't be beaten when the lights shined the brightest. He started out behind the rest of the pack in the final, but in the end, it was the Star-Spangled Banner that played when the medal ceremony took place.\n\nHere's what you need to know about Lyles' upbringing in the U.S., including his birthplace and high school.\n\nMORE NOAH LYLES: Photo finish explainer | Last US man to win 100m gold | Best photos\n\nLyles was born in Gainesville, Fla., but he was raised in Alexandria, Va. after he and his siblings moved to Virginia following their parents' divorce.\n\nAlexandria is just south of Washington D.C. and has close ties to the colonial era, as it was founded in 1749.\n\nThe north Virginia region was proud of Lyles after his 100-meter win, with his uncle watching the race at an Alexandria restaurant. Another area restaurant actually added a burger in Lyles' name to its menu to celebrate the gold medal.\n\nThe Washington D.C. area can claim more Olympic medals than the vast majority of countries from these Summer Games. Not only is Lyles from the region, but swimmer Torri Huske is from neighboring Arlington, Va. and the legendary Katie Ledecky grew up in Bethesda, Md.\n\nHuske and Ledecky combined for nine swimming medals in Paris, while Lyles has one medal and is expecting a second in the 200-meter. Lyles figures to get a hero's welcome when he returns from Paris, regardless of how the 200-meter final turns out.\n\nLyles attended Alexandria City High School, which was known as T.C. Williams High School at the time.\n\nIf the T.C. Williams name sounds familiar, it's because the famous football film \"Remember The Titans\" is based on the true story of the school's 1971 football team.\n\nLyles first took steps toward stardom during his time in high school, winning a medal at the World Youth Championships when he was just 15 and the Youth Olympic Games when he was 17.\n\nMORE: Who is Noah Lyles dating?\n\nLyles did not go to college, but he interestingly would have gone back to Gainesville if he followed through with a college career. Lyles committed to the University of Florida, setting up a potential homecoming, but he instead turned professional in 2016.\n\nThat commitment paid off, as Lyles first won gold at the World Championships in 2019, winning the 200-meter, and he earned a trip to Tokyo for the Summer Olympics ahead of the delayed 2020 games. Lyles would win bronze in the 200-meter in Tokyo.\n\nLyles only grew more confident in the three years between Tokyo and Paris, and he validated every bit of that confidence by winning the 100-meter final on Sunday. The 200-meter is believed to be an even easier path to gold for Lyles, though he knows now not to underestimate the competition.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8266009709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:09:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:09:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:09:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/08/08/sports/noah-lyles-covid/", "title": "Noah Lyles won an Olympic medal two days after being diagnosed with COVID. Here's what we know. - The Boston Globe", "body": "Lyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana's Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn't lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nThe US track federation released a statement saying it and the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4x100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. {"uri": "8266019386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:19:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:19:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:18:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/08/08/letsile-tebogo-responds-criticism-noah-lyles-faced-running-200m-olympic-final-covid-21390363/", "title": "Tebogo reacts to criticism Lyles has faced for running 200m final with Covid", "body": "Letsile Tebogo has jumped to Noah Lyles' defence after the US athlete faced a wave of criticism for competing in the men's 200m Olympic final, despite testing positive for Covid-19.\n\nLyles looked some way from his best in the 200m semi-finals after being crowned the new 100m Olympic champion, with the American finishing second behind Tebogo on Wednesday to advance to tonight's showpiece in Paris.\n\nAnd it was a familiar sight this evening as an out-of-sorts Lyles had to settle for the bronze medal behind Tebogo and Kenny Bednarek, who claimed gold and silver respectively.\n\nIt subsequently emerged that Lyles had tested positive for Covid-19 two days prior to the final and the 27-year-old has received criticism from some quarters.\n\nLyles was pictured hugging and high-fiving many of his fellow competitors shortly after crossing the finishing line at the Stade de France and BBC host Gabby Logan suggested he had made a 'selfish decision' by competing and putting the other athletes at risk.\n\nMichael Johnson, meanwhile, said he was 'morally' unsure about Lyles' decision to embrace Bednarek, especially given the latter is due to run for the United States in the 4x100m relay on Friday. It remains to be seen if Lyles will be fit enough to participate.\n\n'Personally, I wouldn't say we were at risk because it's not a contact sport,' Tebogo said when asked about Lyles' controversial decision to run in the 200m final.\n\n'So even during the warm-ups and in the call room, he was just there by himself.\n\n'Personally, I wondered why [he was by himself]. I didn't want to make assumptions of what he could be going through.\n\n'But afterwards, all he said - after the 100m final - I thought maybe it was just one of those days when he's not having a great day but I didn't think of Covid or anything else.'\n\nBednarek, the silver medallist, echoed Tebogo's comments and did not feel his compatriot had put others at risk.\n\n'I didn't think I was put at risk at all. I take care of my body so when it comes to getting sick, that's rare for me,' Bednarek said.\n\n'When I found out, it wasn't that big of a deal. He went out there, did his best while being sick.\n\n'I hope he gets better, that's all I can really say.'\n\nSpeaking to NBC shortly after the final, Lyles hinted that he was angling towards pulling out of the 4x100m relay in two days' time.\n\n'At the minute I don't know but I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their own thing,' he said.\n\n'They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me and if that is the case coming off today then I'm perfectly fine to let them go do their thing.\n\n'They have more than enough speed to handle it and get the gold {"uri": "8265808098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "18:53:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T18:53:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T18:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/noah-lyles-bronze-200m-final-no-sprint-double-gold-letsile-tebogo/5685184/", "title": "Noah Lyles falls short in quest for sprint double gold; earns bronze in 200m final", "body": "Noah Lyles, who already earned the title of \"World's Fastest Man\" at the Paris Olympics, fell short Thursday of his goal to become the first American to win gold in the 100m and 200m sprints since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nLyles came in third in the men's 200m final with a time of 19.70 seconds. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold with a time of 19.46 seconds and the USA's Kenneth Bednarek won the silver finishing with a time of 19.62 seconds.\n\nThe 200m is Lyles' premiere, preferred event and he's ranked number one in the world for it. Lyles needed medical attention after the race, but it wasn't clear what was the issue.\n\nLyles had a thrilling triumph in the 100m final on Sunday. The 27-year-old turned on the jets late to win the race by a fraction of a second, capturing his first Olympic gold medal and Team USA's first 100m title in two decades.\n\nLyles is still expected to compete in the men' 4x100m relay final on Friday.\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- will it be in the 200m final?\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double multiple times. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals in Paris.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal time overall behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nLyles already competed in the men's 100m and will be competing in the 4x100m relay as well. Here's what the schedule for that event looks like:\n\nAll of Noah Lyles' medal races will be broadcast live on Peacock and NBCOlympics.com.\n\nLyles' races will also be shown either live or on replay {"uri": "8265960839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:15:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:15:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:15:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/miami/news/paris-olympics-2024-200-meters-noah-lyles-kenny-bednarek-letsile-tebogo/", "title": "Noah Lyles of Team USA wins bronze in 200 meters after testing positive for COVID; Botswana's Letsile Tebogo claims gold", "body": "Noah Lyles sought to follow up his gold medal in the 100 meters with a matching one in the 200 meters. On Thursday, the favorite instead claimed the bronze in the 2024 Paris Olympics -- and revealed that he had been diagnosed with COVID-19 two days earlier.\n\nHe finished behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, who won gold, and fellow American Kenny Bednarek, who garnered the silver.\n\nLyles, a 27-year-old from northern Virginia, said in an interview with NBC after the race that he woke up early Tuesday \"feeling really horrible.\"\n\n\"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100,\" he said. \"Woke up the doctors and we tested, and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for COVID.\"\n\nLyles was seen almost immediately after the race asking for water and going down to one knee. He sat on the side of the track for an extended period of time as medical personnel attended to him. Photographs and video from after the event showed him being taken off the track in a wheelchair.\n\nHe said in the interview, \"It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal.\"\n\nHe said he quarantined as much as possible but never considered skipping the race.\n\nUSA Track & Field said in a statement: \"We can confirm that Noah Lyles tested positive for COVID-19 on Tuesday, August 6th. In response, the USOPC [U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee] and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\"\n\nIt continued, \"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles is scheduled for one more race, the 4x100-meters relay, but he told NBC after the 200 meters he wasn't sure if he would compete in that event.\n\n\"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty they can handle it without me,\" he said. \"If that's the case coming off today, I'm perfectly fine saying, 'Hey, you guys do your thing. You have more than enough speed to handle it and get the gold medal.'\"\n\nOn Sunday, Lyles narrowly edged Kishane Thompson to capture the 100-meter gold, besting the Jamaican by a mere five thousandths of a second. American Fred Kerley rounded out the medals in photo finish, with the top four finishers separated by just .04 seconds and the top seven just .09 -- a literal blink of an eye.\n\nBednarek claimed the silver in the 200 meters in Tokyo but fell behind in the 100 meters in Paris, finishing seventh at the Stade de France.\n\nLyles also took home the bronze in the 200 meters in Tokyo. He added the 100-meter sprint for the Paris Games, which paid off earlier this week.\n\nThe 2024 Summer Games have been good for Team USA, which led the medal count in athletics -- the track and field {"uri": "8265973377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:28:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:28:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:27:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13725495/Noah-Lyles-competed-Olympic-200-COVID-finished-3rd-What-know-illness.html", "title": "Noah Lyles competed in the Olympic 200 with COVID and finished 3rd....", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France (AP) - Noah Lyles said he tested positive for COVID two days before he finished third in the 200-meter final at the Paris Olympics on Thursday night.\n\nHere\u00b4s what we know about the timeline of Lyles\u00b4 illness:\n\nLyles says he quickly got into quarantine after he had tested positive Tuesday morning. He participated in the 200-meter semifinal on Wednesday, where he finished second. Lyles' coach afterward said the sprinter was \"fine.\"\n\nLyles, who usually always takes an opportunity to talk, did not speak to reporters after the semifinal.\n\nThe 100-meter champion said he was feeling better as the 200 final approached. He estimated he was about 90-95 percent when the starting gun went off.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said after Thursday night's race. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, dons a face mask following his men's 200-meters final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Thursday, Aug. 8, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. (AP Photo/Petr David Josek)\n\nLyles was trailing 200-meter champion Botswana\u00b4s Letsile Tebogo as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where the American puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of his race. Before this week, he hadn\u00b4t lost a 200 since his third-place finish in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nThis time, Lyles could not close. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn\u00b4t have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy for today.\"\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThree years ago, at the Tokyo Olympics, a positive COVID test would have put an athlete in immediate isolation, forcing them to a special hotel with no contact with other Olympic participants. Even in 2022 at the Winter Games, daily tests and strict isolation measures were automatic. COVID rules have been changed in much of society, including sports, school and work. The USATF says they followed current policies.\n\nLyles was expected to run the anchor leg of the 4x100 on Friday in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his relay teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I\u00b4m going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nNoah Lyles, of the United States, is treated by medical staff following the men's 200-meters final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Thursday, Aug. 8, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. The 27-year-old was favored in the event and was trying to sweep in both the 100-meter and 200-meter races, which hasn't been done by Team USA since Carl Lewis pulled off the impressive feat 40 years ago.\n\nLyes won the 100-meter title on Aug. 4, but four days later he seemed winded. After crossing the finish line in third place in the 200-meter, Lyles appeared to fall to the ground and gestured for water.\n\nNBC's Lewis Johnson reported shortly after on the broadcast that Lyles was removed from the track in a wheelchair.\n\n\"I ran into his mom, Keisha Caine Bishop, who was distraught trying to find him, as well. {"uri": "8265823826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:07:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:07:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:06:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/2024-olympics-noah-lyles-dealing-with-covid-19-wins-bronze-medal-in-200-meters-kenny-bednarek-takes-silver/", "title": "2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles, dealing with COVID-19, wins bronze medal in 200 meters; Kenny Bednarek takes silver - CBSSports.com", "body": "Lyles not only sought a rare double gold medal but a world record in his signature event Getty Images\n\nThe men's 200 meters did not go to expectation at the 2024 Paris Olympics with Botswana's Letsile Tebogo running away from the field to win the gold medal in 19.46 seconds. Tebogo, 21, became the youngest man to win gold in the 200 meters since the United States' Bobby Morrow in 1956 and the first man from an African nation to do so in Olympic history.\n\nAll eyes entering the event were on United States sprinting sensation Noah Lyles, who won the 100 meters on Sunday and had an eye on setting a world record in the 200 meters. He was looking to become the first American to pull off the 100-200 double since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nInstead, Lyles, who battles asthma and wore a mask backstage before being introduced, looked gassed and needed medical assistance the race. He never came near the lead before ultimately finishing third in 19.70 seconds for a bronze medal\n\nIt was revealed after the race on NBC that Lyles was diagnosed with COVID-19 on Tuesday. He received medical assistance shortly after crossing the finish line and again behind the scenes. The IOC decided to drop previous COVID-19 protocols ahead of the Paris Olympics with the disease instead treated like other respiratory illnesses; athletes and teams were allowed to determine their ability to compete.\n\nLyles' personal best in the 200 meters is 19.31 seconds, an American record set at the 2022 World Championships. His season best was 19.53 seconds set at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June, and it stands to reason he would have been more competitive toward gold had he not been dealing with the illness.\n\nBetween the duo was fellow American Kenny Bednarek, who won a silver medal in 19.62 seconds. Bednarek and Lyles similarly finished in silver and bronze positions at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics three years ago.\n\nPulling off the 100-200 double is extremely difficult as only 10 men have achieved the feat in history. Jamaica's Usain Bolt (2008, 2012, 2016) is the last man to win gold medals in both events during the same Olympic Games. Prior to Bolt came Lewis at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.\n\nCBS Sports will update this developing story shortly.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, Another dog can be seen on a couch and a cat on the floor as the dog bites down and sparks begin to shoot from the battery.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair suffering with what The Associated Press learned was a case of COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and eventually sat up to be tended to by medical staff. A person familiar with Lyles' condition, who did not want to be identified, told AP was diagnosed with COVID two days before the final.\n\nAmerican Kenny Bednarek got silver.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and a year delay before the Games led to depression that he said hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history. {"uri": "8265877107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:57:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:57:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:56:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/american-sprinter-noah-lyles-says-he-tested-positive-for-covid-19-ran-200-meter-race/article_c2719417-1beb-546d-94c1-4eeb737a0b34.html", "title": "American sprinter Noah Lyles says he tested positive for Covid-19, ran 200-meter race anyway", "body": "Saint-Denis, France (CNN) -- American sprinter Noah Lyles has confirmed that he tested positive for Covid-19 earlier this week and ran in Thursday night's 200-meter race anyway.\n\nIn an interview with US Olympic broadcaster NBC, Lyles said he felt really horrible when he woke up Tuesday morning and has been hydrating while in quarantine.\n\n\"I woke up early about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was just feeling really horrible, and I knew it was more than just being sore from the (100-meter race),\" Lyles told NBC. \"I woke up the doctors and we tested, and unfortunately, it came out that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nHe added, \"My first thought was not to panic, you know, I'm thinking I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions, I felt.\"\n\nLyles said he was proud of his performance, despite having Covid.\n\n\"We just took it day-by-day trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off. I definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure,\" he said, \"but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympics I was very disappointed, and this time, I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nThe news of Lyles' positive test came not long after he suffered a stunning defeat in the men's 200-meter race, his signature event. Lyles finished in third, unable to overcome Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and his Team USA compatriot Kenneth Bednarek, who finished in first and second place, respectively.\n\nHowever, the result of the race was quickly bumped from the headlines when Lyles laid down on the track immediately following his crossing the finish line. He was helped off the track by medical personnel in a wheelchair and taken to the medical holding area.\n\nThis is a breaking story and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. What to know about USA sprinter's status after positive COVID test", "body": "Noah Lyles' search for double gold in this year's Olympics came to a swift end on Thursday when the American sprint star -- felled by COVID-19 -- suffered a third-place finish at his signature event, the 200m.\n\nLyles appeared worse for the wear once he sprinted through the finish line, ripping his jersey off and immediately seeking water and medical assistance for his ailment. He was escorted off the track in a wheelchair before appearing on NBC in which he confirmed that he was diagnosed with COVID-19 two days ago.\n\nLyles was far from his best on Thursday, posting a 19.70s finish in the competition, 0.24 seconds slower than that of gold medalist Leslie Tebogo. Entering this year's Games, he appeared likely to take part in three events, not two, with Lyles expected to join the likes of Kenny Bednarek, Christian Coleman, and Fred Kerley on the U.S.'s 4x100m relay team.\n\nLIVE OLYMPICS MEDAL COUNT:\n\nOverall table | Who is winning the Olympics? | Who's won the most gold?\n\nThose plans now appear up in the air. Here's what you need to know about Lyles' COVID-19 diagnosis, as well as the implications it could have on his participation in the 4x100m relay Friday night.\n\nMORE: Noah Lyles ran 200-meter dash with COVID, leaves track in wheelchair\n\nIt's anyone's guess whether Lyles will participate in the men's 4x100m relay on Friday. He said as much during his post-race interview with NBC's Lewis Johnson.\n\n\"At the moment, I don't know,\" Lyles said. \"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me. And if that's the case coming off today, then I'm perfectly fine saying 'Hey, you guys go do your thing. You guys have more than enough speed to be able to handle it and get the gold medal.\"\n\nAt present, it seems as if Lyles is leaning toward not taking part in the 4x100m relay. That's an understandable choice given the amount of pain he appeared to be displaying when the 200m final concluded.\n\nLyles has been open about his experiences with asthma throughout life, outlining his first memories with the condition during a 2020 interview with CNN.\n\n\"So, about 3 to 4, all the way to about 7 years old, I was dealing with asthma and asthma attacks seriously, like in the hospital, maybe every third night; coughing fits, constantly sick because my immune system was weak,\" Lyles said.\n\nMORE: Meet 21-year-old Botswana sprinter who upset USA's Noah Lyles\n\nHe appears to have found a way to manage the chronic illness, claiming four individual world titles to go along with his Olympic medals over the course of his glittering career. Nevertheless, you're never quite sure how COVID-19 will impact one's respiratory system, particularly when the person in question already deals with a respiratory illness.\n\nUSA Track and Field gave Lyles the responsibility of deciding whether he was to compete or not in the 200m. If that decision is any precedent, then it's likely Lyles will then be asked whether he feels capable of participating in the 4x100m. If not, he'll see his spot on the team filled by one of Courtney Lindsey or Kyree King. He wouldn't receive a medal if the U.S. were to finish in the top-three places in that case, as he wouldn't have taken part in either prelims (which took place earlier on Thursday) or finals.\n\nThe U.S. team -- which Bednarek is also expected to join on Friday -- posted a scorching 37.47s time to win the first heat of Thursday's 4x100m relay prelims. {"uri": "8265852225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:32:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/08/08/sports/sports-breaking/botswanas-leslie-tebogo-upsets-noah-lyles-to-win-200m-gold/", "title": "Botswana's Leslie Tebogo upsets Noah Lyles to win 200m gold | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Letsile Tebogo of Botswana wins gold ahead of second place Kenneth Bednarek and third place Noah Lyles of the United States in the men's 200m final at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nPARIS >> Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the men's Olympic 200-meter title today when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 when finishing sixth in the Paris 100m final, produced a dominant last 50 meters and crossed the line in 19.46 seconds beating his chest as he became the fifth-fastest man in history over 200m.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, who had been hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, repeating his Tokyo bronze in 19.67.\n\nIt was the triple world champion's first defeat in a 200m final for three years. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race, U.S. officials said he had COVID, putting his participation in Friday's sprint relay final in serious doubt.\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against his name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box.\n\nLyles might still hog the limelight, but it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three places in the final, Tebogo's place on top of the podium was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old told reporters.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew when the gun went Kenny was going to run away so make sure just to close him down, I have that top-end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"", {"uri": "2024-08-448617393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:26:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:26:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:24:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-covid-health-200-meter-bronze/", "title": "Column | On the night Noah Lyles was to become a legend, he became a reminder", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles, energy personified, collapsed on the track after his double-gold quest ended. He stayed on his back for a disturbing while. He rolled over on his left side. He struggled into a sitting position. As he gasped for air, the man seemingly with caffeine in his veins -- the one who claimed the crown as world's fastest by a whisker-thin margin Sunday -- moved like a snail wearing a weighted vest.\n\nLyles hunched over on his left knee, braced himself with his left hand and lowered his head. He rose eventually and tried to shuffle out of sight. He had finished third in the men's 200 meters Thursday at Stade de France, but there was no way he could take the U.S. flag and parade around the track. There was also no way he could be disappointed about falling short of becoming the 10th man in Olympic history to accomplish the 100-200 double. His only reaction was to ask for help. He gestured for water and fell to the track again as soon as he received it. He needed a wheelchair to exit.\n\nSoon after, we learned why he wore a mask before his signature race, why he seemed mortal during it and why he looked completely depleted afterward: Lyles had covid-19. To reporters, he recalled waking up early Tuesday morning with a sore throat, chills and an aching body. He took a test, and at 5 a.m., he knew the results. Still, he wanted to compete.\n\n\"It's one and done,\" Lyles said. \"There's no holding back.\"\n\nWe thought covid was over. In a sense, the Paris Olympics have been a celebration of global vitality, with athletes and fans living their best lives, shedding the dystopian restrictions that stifled the past two Games staged amid the pandemic. Before competition began, Olympic committees from many nations detailed their covid policies with a shrug. That's all you needed to know.\n\nAnna Meares, the Australia chef de mission, was the most direct. \"I want to stress that we treat covid the same way we treat other viruses like the flu,\" she said. \"This is not Tokyo.\"\n\nBut Thursday felt like those delayed 2021 Tokyo Olympics. It felt all kinds of wrong. The misfortune cost Lyles a better chance at history, though it should be noted that the 19.46 seconds that gold medalist Letsile Tebogo ran to win meant Lyles would've needed to go faster than he has this year.\n\nStill, it was more irksome than just Lyles's legacy bid. Covid may not be regarded as the scary virus that it was four years ago, but for the most part, we have failed to sufficiently confront the proper way to move about the world while ill. Quarantine thresholds have been lowered almost to being personal decisions. In sports, testing is not mandatory. We just witnessed a world-class athlete run the 200 meters in 19.70 seconds with the coronavirus. That's quite a feat -- and a conundrum.\n\n\"I was coughing through the night,\" Lyles said. \"I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out here to get a bronze with covid.\"\n\nBut what if he infected other competitors? He hugged U.S. teammate, Kenny Bednarek, immediately after the race. He wore a mask as the field gathered in tight quarters inside before walking onto the track. There are still two more days track remaining and plenty of medals to be decided. Who else has Lyles been around?\n\n\"I don't care,\" said Bednarek, who won the silver with a time of 19.62 seconds. \"I mean, if I get sick or whatever, like, I'll be fine. If he gets sick ... I don't view those things as a big deal.\"\n\nSaid Tebogo, a 21-year-old from Botswana: \"I don't know he put anyone at risk.\"\n\nThey're too tough to care. They're also Olympians, which means they have one shot every four years. They're not going to blame Lyles for doing something they would've done. And if they get sick and still feel like they can compete, they will.\n\nBeing gritty has never been so icky.\n\nWelcome officially to the post-pandemic sports era, where covid continues to slither about but athletes are back to blind perseverance. Lyles won't be the last to admit he plowed through an event. Toughing it out is back. It was inevitable, but it's still uncomfortable.\n\nCovid impacted a race that was hyped as Lyles's chance to become a transcendent talent. He already was the mouth of the Games, and by 0.005 seconds in Sunday's 100 meters, he backed up his bravado. Now, he aspired to be the face of the Games.\n\nWinning the 100 and 200 meters in the same Olympics turns a fast man into a track deity. Lyles hoped to join a list that includes Jesse Owens, Carl Lewis and Usain Bolt. The 27-year-old, who went to high school in Alexandria, Va., kept his positive test quiet, but he left the Olympic Village and quarantined in a hotel Tuesday. He took \"as much medication as we legally could to make sure my body could keep the momentum going.\"\n\nHe made it through the qualification heats, and when it was time for the 200 final, he tried to shine under the bright stadium lights. He came out with his usual showmanship, skipping, hopping, yelling and spreading his arms wide. The world's fastest man was in the building. He slapped his starting block before getting set.\n\n\"I knew that if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I have from the get-go,\" Lyles said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\"\n\nSo this is what it's like to compete with that insidious virus: Lyles could be only covid's fastest man.\n\nSkip to end of carousel\n\nGet the latest updates on the 2024 Olympics\n\n(Washington Post illustration)\n\nTrack all the Paris Olympic medal counts country by country, and see the breakdown of medals by U.S. athletes. Get live updates from Paris and keep up with the latest by signing up for The Sports Moment: Olympics Edition.\n\nEnd of carousel\n\nWe're left to wonder whether a healthy Lyles, who ran a personal best of 19.31 seconds two years ago, could have done better than Tebogo's 19.46.\n\nEarly in the day, Lyles wrote a social media post making an anime reference: \"Omae wa-m\u014d shinde iru.\" It translated to: \"You are already dead.\" It was easier for him to write smack than talk it.\n\n\"I've had better days, but I'm walking around again,\" Lyles said. \"I was quite lightheaded after that race. Shortness of breath, chest pain, but after a while, I could catch my breath and get my wits about me. I'm a lot better now.\"\n\nHe spoke wearing a thick black mask. On a night that could have transformed Lyles into a legend, he instead became a throwback to a time we've quickly forgotten.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jerry_brewer@washingtonpost.com", "name": "Jerry Brewer", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": became the youngest winner of the event since Bobby Morrow in 1956.\n\nBut attention quickly turned to 100m champion Lyles, who required medical attention immediately after his run.\n\nLyles sat on the track for some time after the race before departing Stade de France in a wheelchair.\n\nHe had been looking to join Usain Bolt as the only winners of the 100-200m double at an Olympics this {"uri": "8265999607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:03:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:03:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:58:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/noah-lyles-did-same-thing-215202924.html", "title": "Noah Lyles did same thing ordinary Americans do every day: He went to work sick", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Given the chance, almost anyone would have done what Noah Lyles did. Probably already have, with far less at stake.\n\nLyles raced the 200 meters Thursday night after being diagnosed with COVID early Tuesday morning. In other words, he went to work sick. Just as countless Americans do every day. Because they can't take time off work. Because they don't want to get behind. Because they don't really feel that bad. Because, because, because.\n\nIn Lyles' case, he had a gold medal to win and history to chase.\n\nHaving already won the 100 meters earlier this week, Lyles wanted to join Carl Lewis and Usain Bolt in that exclusive club of sprinters who won gold in both the 100 and 200 in the same Olympics. The goal has fueled him these last several years, and winning the double at last year's world championships let him know it was within reach.\n\nAnd then he got sick.\n\nLyles said he woke up in the middle of the night Monday with chills, a sore throat and his body aching. He recognized the symptoms, having had COVID before, and a test early Tuesday confirmed he had it. He moved into a hotel so he wouldn't expose others and began taking Paxlovid, an antiviral medication that accelerates recovery.\n\nThe idea of not racing never crossed his mind, even if he didn't have his usual speed. Lyles won the bronze medal, finishing a distant third behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana and fellow American Kenny Bednarek.\n\n\"No, no, no. I was going to compete regardless,\" Lyles said. \"If I didn't make it to the finals, that would've been the sign not to compete.\"\n\nHad this been the Tokyo Olympics, or the Beijing Winter Games, that choice wouldn't have been Lyles' to make. Athletes were required to be vaccinated ahead of both those Games and undergo regular testing. If they tested positive, they were sent to quarantine, Olympic dreams be damned.\n\nBut enough people have either been vaccinated or had COVID, or both, that it's no longer the terrifying threat it once was. People aren't dying by the millions and hospitals aren't being overrun. Thanks to science, and enough people believing in it, we've tamed a devastating pandemic to the point it can now be treated like many other respiratory illnesses.\n\nThere were no vaccination requirements for these Games, either from the International Olympic Committee or U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee. No testing of any kind, either.\n\nThe USOPC says it is following the guidelines of the Centers for Disease Control, which now says someone with COVID can resume normal activities if their symptoms have been improving for at least 24 hours. Lyles says they have been, calling himself \"90 to 95%\"\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the USOPC and USA Track and Field said in a statement. \"We respect his decision and will condition to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles is an asthmatic, which means COVID can be a bigger threat to him than other people. But he's vaccinated. He took precautions to protect others, including wearing a mask before and after his race.\n\nHe's also a grown man who, at 27, can decide for himself whether he should race or not.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" Lyles said. \"But to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything - coming out and getting a bronze medal with COVID, three days ago.\"\n\nLyles is hardly the first to decide being so close to accomplishing a lifelong dream -- whether that's standing atop a medals podium or simply being able to say they competed at the Olympics -- outweighs any health risk.\n\nKerri Strug vaulted on an ankle that was severely sprained and had two torn tendons, and has defended her decision repeatedly. Emil Zatopek won the 5,000-meter, 10,000-meter and marathon golds at the 1952 Olympics after defying his doctor's orders not to compete because of a gland infection. The marathon winner at the 1904 Olympics nearly died because of the extreme heat.\n\nBut ordinary people make similar calculations every day. Sometimes we stay in bed, loading up on chicken soup, orange juice and bad TV until whatever bug we have passes.\n\nSometimes we don't have that luxury, though, and we haul ourselves out of bed and into work or whatever else we have to do. That's what Lyles did.\n\nSometimes Olympians really are like the rest of us.\n\nFollow USA TODAY Sports columnist Nancy Armour on social media @nrarmour.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8265245781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "12:14:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T12:14:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T12:12:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/olympics-2024-noah-lyles-takes-120157024.html", "title": "Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles takes back seat to leave rivals guessing in quest for sprint double", "body": "Well, fair play to Noah Lyles: he always makes things interesting.\n\nAfter the American claimed the tightest of all 100m titles on Saturday, consensus was that the biggest hurdle still to overcome in his hat-trick bid lay in the United States' penchant for stuffing up the sprint relay.\n\nThe 200m, by contrast, looked close to a foregone conclusion. It is Lyles' event, the one in which he made his name, the one in which he has won three straight world titles.\n\nThe one in which the talk pre-Paris was not about whether or not he would win gold, but whether Usain Bolt's world record could go. The complexion, though, has changed a little, after Lyles finished only second in his semi-final, 0.12seconds behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, who qualified fastest for the final.\n\nOn the one hand, there might be little cause for panic: remember, Lyles did not win either his heat or his semi-final en route to gold in the 100m, consoling himself with the idea that others were expending more than was wise when afforded their one shot at the king.\n\nOn the other, this was the first time he had been beaten over half-a-lap since finishing third in the Olympic final in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nLyles did not speak to the media afterwards, instead reported by LetsRun.com to have gone \"straight to medical\", a vague enough phrase to set the rumour mill to work.\n\nWas this the 27-year-old conserving energy in his fifth race in as many days, or is something physically amiss?\n\nEither way, the uncertainty has added a layer of intrigue to the final that would not have been there had Lyles blown the field away while easing down.\n\nTebogo is one threat, but, if Lyles is short of his best, then virtually the entire field is in play, all but one of the eight finalists having broken the 20sec barrier this season.\n\nThe quickest of them is fellow American Kenny Bednarek, who finished just 0.06sec behind Lyles when setting his personal best of 19.59 at the US Olympic trials this year.\n\nBednarek cruised to victory in his semi-final and then was immediately involved in controversy, taking to X, formerly Twitter, to express his fury at his lane allocation for the final.\n\nDespite winning his semi and qualifying second-fastest in a time of 20.00sec, the 25-year-old was initially assigned lane four -- tighter than ideal in the 200m -- while Lyles had the more {"uri": "8264547461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "04:03:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T04:03:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:03:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.nbcsandiego.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/noah-lyles-sprint-double-200m-final-2024-olympics/3591553/", "title": "How Noah Lyles can make rare Olympic history in the 200m final", "body": "Lyles has already earned the title of fastest man in the world at the Paris Games, and he's now on the doorstep of joining very exclusive Olympic company:\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved a combined 11 times by nine athletes in the history of the Olympics.\n\nOlympic legend Usain Bolt was the last man to complete the sprint double -- and he achieved the feat three straight at three straight Games.\n\nThe eight-time gold medalist swept the individual sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, 2012 London Games and 2016 Rio Games, becoming the only man to record an Olympic sprint double twice. Bolt in 2012 also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to ever complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently became the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, doing so in the 2016 Games and pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. Thompson-Herah had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in the history of the Games, with Carl Lewis' 1984 feat standing as the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow and Lewis, along with Bolt in both 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nThe 200m is considered to be Lyles' stronger race compared to the 100m. After earning bronze at the Tokyo Games, Lyles didn't lose a single 200m race until Wednesday's semifinals at the Paris Games.\n\nLyles placed second in his semifinal heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBednarek is the event's reigning Olympic silver medalist. The defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, failed to qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is also the American record of 19.31 seconds, which he tallied at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nUsain Bolt set the 200m world record with a time of 19.19 seconds at the 2009 World Championships. But Lyles has said he believes he'll eventually break Bolt's record mark -- could it be in the 200m final?\n\nLyles will look to become just the 10th man to ever pull off the Olympic sprint double when he races in the 200m final on Thursday, Aug. 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET.\n\nThe men's 200m final will be shown on NBC and Peacock. It will also be available to stream here:\n\nLyles enters the 200m final with two Olympic medals: a 200m bronze from the Tokyo Games and a 100m gold from the Paris Games.\n\nHe's also a three-time world champion in the 200m and the reigning world champion in the 100m.\n\nFollowing the 200m final, Lyles is scheduled to next move over to the men's 4x100m relay. The relay event begins with the first round on Thursday followed by the final on Friday.\n\nSo there's a chance Lyles will enter the weekend with an Olympic sprint triple under his belt.", "source": He lay on his back on the purple track at Stade de France, after finishing third in a race he had dominated for the last three years, and struggled for breath.\n\nFour days after winning a gold medal in one of the most thrilling endings to an Olympic sprint, Lyles took the bronze in the 200 and considered it, he said afterward, a remarkable achievement. Lyles learned that he had tested positive for the coronavirus around 5 a.m. Paris time on Tuesday, less than 36 hours after he won the 100 in a photo finish that was a stunning start to an Olympic campaign he hoped would position him as the next great American track and field star.\n\nBut on Tuesday, after waking up with chills, aches and a sore throat, symptoms he had experienced during previous exposures, Lyles left the athletes' village to quarantine in a nearby hotel. He said he was taking the antiviral treatment Paxlovid, and that he had not once considered dropping out or revealing his condition in advance of the 200 final. Athletes are not required to test or to report Covid-19 cases.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete,\" Lyles, wearing an N-95 mask, told reporters about 45 minutes after finishing in 19.70 seconds, behind Letsile Tebogo of Botswana (19.46), who won his country's first Olympic gold medal in its history, and the American Kenneth Bednarek (19.62). {"uri": "8265832930", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:15:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:15:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:14:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/13313807/noah-lyles-usain-bolt-paris-olympics-200m-100m/", "title": "Lyles collapses to floor and put in wheelchair after being denied sprint double", "body": "COVID-STRICKEN Noah Lyles was yellow carded and taken out in a wheelchair as he missed out on an epic Olympic sprint double.\n\nJamaica legend Usain Bolt won 100m and 200m gold at Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016.\n\nAnd Lyles, 27, was aiming to follow in his footsteps with another thrilling victory in Paris.\n\nBut in truth, he was always trailing Letsile Tebogo, who claimed Botswana's first-ever Olympic gold medal in a staggering 19.46 seconds - five days after Julien Alfred secured Saint Lucia's maiden gold in the women's 100m final.\n\nThat was also the fifth-fastest time ever recorded in history - behind only Usain Bolt, Yohan Blake, Lyles and Michael Johnson.\n\nAfter his stunning 100m victory on Sunday - winning by 0.005 seconds in a dramatic photo finish - American Lyles only qualified as third fastest for the 200m final.\n\nHis 20.08 seconds time was beaten by both Tebogo (19.96) and Bednarek (20.00).\n\nBut many expected the ultimate showman Lyles to turn on the style when it mattered most.\n\nThe 200m world champion came bounding out once again, jumping up and down along the track before settling into his blocks in lane five - but only after kicking them, earning himself a yellow card for \"improper conduct\".\n\nLyles got a quick start however Tebogo, 21, flew out of the blocks and never looked in trouble.\n\nOLYMPICS FREE BETS - SIGN UP OFFERS AND DEAL FOR PARIS 2024\n\nLyles did his best to chase down Bednarak down the home straight but the gap was too much as the superstar American crossed in 19.70 seconds and settled for another bronze in the 200m - just like in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nHe looked sluggish in the closing stages and collapsed on the track afterwards clearly struggling to breathe as medics came to his aid, pulling him away in a wheelchair.\n\nIt then transpired he had Covid - despite hugging compatriot Bednarek at the end.\n\nFour-time Olympic gold medallist Michael Johnson insisted that Lyles was not carrying an injury due to the time he still managed to achieve.\n\nSpeaking on the BBC, he said: \"He certainly isn't carrying an injury because you can't do this with an injury, you can't run 19.70.\n\n\"If there's anything, there's some sort of illness that has zapped his energy from the ability to actually carry that speed all the way through.\n\n\"[The medics] would've given him the OK to race, he's probably not in danger of anything by racing other than being 100 percent and able to perform the way that he would want to.\"\n\nTebogo's mum died in May and the champ had her date of birth on his trainers and said: \"It was really a beautiful race for me.\n\nMum is watching up there, and she's really, really happy. {"uri": "8266047306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:55:32", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:55:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:54:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.myjoyonline.com/paris-2024-tebogo-becomes-botswanas-first-olympic-champion-with-200m-win/", "title": "Paris 2024: Tebogo becomes Botswana's first Olympic champion with 200m win - MyJoyOnline", "body": "Letsile Tebogo made history for Botswana at the Paris 2024 Games on Thursday (8), winning the first Olympic gold medal for his nation in any sport.\n\nStorming to the 200m title, he held off USA's Kenny Bednarek and 100m champion Noah Lyles with an African record of 19.46 - a time that moves the 21-year-old to fifth on the world all-time list.\n\nBednarek got silver in 19.62 and Lyles bronze in 19.70 - the fastest ever time for third place in any race - as the pair repeated their medal-winning positions from Tokyo three years ago.\n\nTheir US teammate Erriyon Knighton, a two-time world medallist, finished fourth in 19.99, as Dominican Republic's Alexander Ogando was fifth. Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba finished sixth and eighth respectively for Zimbabwe, the first time the nation has had two sprinters in an Olympic 200m final. They were separated by Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh in seventh.\n\nTebogo looked focused as he walked out on to the track, while Bednarek encouraged cheers from the crowd and Lyles bounded out, jumping up and down.\n\nTebogo lined up in lane seven, with Bednarek to his right and Knighton, then Lyles, to his left. As they blasted out of the blocks and then reached the curve, Tebogo was slightly ahead of his US rivals. He continued to pull away and had time to celebrate on his approach to the finish line, looking up at the screen and then thumping his chest.\n\nFollowing the race, with his national flag draped over his shoulders, Tebogo took off his spike and held it up to the camera. Dedicating his win to his mother Seratiwa, who died in May, the shoe featured her date of birth in tribute.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" he said. \"She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy. I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.\n\n\"It was really a beautiful race for me,\" he added. \"When we made it to the final, my coach just told me: 'Now my job is done, it's up to you to see what you can do. Whether it's a medal or not, just finish the race healthy.' That's all I could have wished for. I'm happy I finished the race healthier than before.\"\n\nHis time was a PB by 0.04, improving his own African record set in London last year.\n\nFour days on from his 100m victory in Paris, Lyles wasn't able to immediately celebrate his second medal as he was helped off the track in a wheelchair. USATF later confirmed that Lyles had tested positive for Covid on Tuesday but still wanted to compete.\n\nSix-time world champion Lyles had started Paris 2024 with a 200m win streak that dated back to the Tokyo Olympic Games. But after the 27-year-old won his heat, Tebogo handed him his first defeat after 26 consecutive victories, beating him in the semifinals.\n\nHe repeated the feat in the final, becoming the first African man to win the Olympic 200m title and claiming his nation's third ever Olympic medal, a maiden gold.\n\nTebogo, who finished sixth in the 100m final, adds his Olympic gold to the two world medals - 100m silver and 200m bronze - he claimed in Budapest last year. That senior success followed the four medals he gained at the past two editions of the World U20 Championships, as he claimed 100m gold and 200m silver in both 2021 and 2022.", "source": {"uri": Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles said he had COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" he said.\n\nAn hour after that shock, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThe hurdler expected to challenger her hardest, Femke Bol, finished third, behind American Anna Cockrell, who finished 1.5 seconds behind McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nInterim superintendent of St. Louis Public Schools left previous job under fire Letter: If Biden's age was so concerning, why isn't Trump's age? He said that decision had not been made as of late Thursday.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time -- nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\n\"To be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. He celebrated very enthusiastically after that finish.\n\nOn Thursday, Lyles limped away from the finish line and collapsed on the track of the Stade de France, showing obvious signs of exhaustion. Trainers tended to the track star, giving him water and getting him a wheelchair, before he left the area.\n\n\"I woke up early about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was just feeling really horrible,\" Lyles told NBC. \"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100. I went to doctor's and we tested, and unfortunately it came back that I was positive with COVID.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic. I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions. We took it day-by-day, trying to hydrate as much [as possible] and quarantined off.\n\n\"It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get the bronze medal.\"\n\nLyles, who wore a mask during his interview on NBC, said he never considering withdrawing from the 200-meter final. He also was seen wearing a mask before the race, but was not wearing one earlier this week during a news conference or in other media interviews.\n\nUnlike the previous Olympics, athletes are not required to undergo daily COVID-19 testing in Paris.\n\n\"I just said we were just going to try and quarantine as much as possible, stay away, not try to pass it off and just give it my all,\" Lyles said. \"If I wasn't to make it and somebody would have taken my spot, that would have been my sign that I didn't deserve to be in the final.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100-meter relay final is scheduled for 1:47 p.m. EDT Friday in Saint-Denis. Lyles said he didn't know if he would compete.\n\n\"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing,\" Lyles said. \"They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me.\n\n\"If that's the case, coming off of today, then I'm perfectly fine saying 'do your thing. {"uri": "8265906438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:23:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:23:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:22:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.outkick.com/sports/noah-lyles-takes-bronze-200m-after-testing-positive-covid", "title": "Noah Lyles Takes Bronze In 200m After Testing Positive For COVID", "body": "Noah Lyles was crowned the World's Fastest Man last week at the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris in one of the closest races in Olympic history.\n\nREAD: Noah Lyles Captures Olympic Gold Medal For USA In Unreal Photo Finish During 100M Race\n\nBut the 200meter event was a different story. Lyles didn't get off to a great start, but picked up the pace in the middle part of the race. He wasn't able to catch up to Letsile Tebogo from Botswana however, and finished a disappointing third.\n\nAfter the race though, he had an explanation for his underwhelming performance: he has COVID. Except...his entrance to the 200meter event sure didn't seem like he was suffering too many ill effects.\n\nSeemingly overwhelmed by the 20 seconds of exertion though, Lyles was then taken off the track in a wheelchair.\n\nStill, the media's obsessive assertions that coming down with COVID required strict isolation and would clearly hamper performances took a major hit Thursday. As it has for the entire Olympics.\n\nREAD: Is COVID Officially Over? Olympians Have Tested Positive And Still Competed, As They Should\n\nAfter the race, Lyles spoke to NBC, while dutifully and pointlessly wearing a mask, and discussed when he found out and how he dealt with it.\n\n\"I woke up early, about 5am on Tuesday morning and I just was feeling really horrible,\" Lyles said on the broadcast. \"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100. I woke up the doctors, and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for COVID. And my first thought was not to panic. I was thinking 'I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions, I felt.' We just took it day by day. I tried to hydrate as much. Quarantine. It's taken its toll for sure. I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get a bronze medal.\"\n\nWhen asked if he'd considered not running in the 200 meter event, he said, \"No. No. I didn't.\"\n\nAs far as the running the 4x100 relay, Lyles wasn't sure, but seemed to be leaning towards sitting it out.\n\n\"At the moment I don't know,\" Lyles said. \"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty they can handle it without me. And if that's the case coming off of today, I'm perfectly fine, saying 'you guys go do your thing. You guys have more than enough speed to be able to handle it and get the gold medal.'\"\n\nIt does seem a bit odd that Lyles would be jumping around before the race, if he felt that bad, and that he'd still secure a bronze medal in a very competitive race. With the 4x100 final on Friday, he won't have much time to get better. And shortly after that, he was also seen being wheeled out in a wheelchair with Olympic medical staff surrounding him.\n\nAs it turns out, Lyles has COVID.\n\nThat certainly throws quite a wrench into things. Here's everything we know about the track star's diagnoses so far.\n\nWait, Noah Lyles has COVID-19?\n\nYes, apparently so. He was diagnosed with COVID two days ago. He confirmed his diagnosis with reporters after the race.\n\nHe said he kept it \"close to the vest\" and didn't want competitors to know he was ill. The signs were there. Lyles had been wearing a mask and quarantining leading up to the race.\n\nHow in the world was he still allowed to race?\n\nTechnically, there is no COVID protocol for the 2024 Paris Olympics. Athletes are not being barred from competing if they get the virus.\n\nChief medical officer of the Olympics, Jon Finnoff, said Team USA is following the CDC guidelines for all infectious disease protocols, USA Today's Carrie McDonald reports.\n\nIf a Team USA athlete experiences symptoms of any kind, Finnoff reiterated the USOPC is \"going to follow the CDC guidelines for all of infectious disease protocols.\"\n\n\"It doesn't mean [infected athletes] can't train or compete,\" Finnoff said. \"We'll do that based on their symptoms and how they feel, but we do want to prevent [them] from infecting those around them, and we'll also provide prophylaxis based on what is recommended by CDC guidelines.\"\n\nLyles isn't the only athlete at the Games with COVID. At least 40 athletes have tested positive so far, according to Yahoo! Sports.\n\nWell, is Lyles OK?\n\nHe definitely didn't look it after the race. He immediately fell to the ground after the race and then was put in a wheelchair after.\n\nHe addressed the media after, but the immediate aftermath of the race was certainly concerning.\n\nWill Lyles be available for the 4\u00d7100?\n\nThe answer is probably not at this point. Lyles said after the race that he's leaning toward not participating.\n\n\"At the moment I don't know. I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. {"uri": "2024-08-448527323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:10:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:10:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:26:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/olympic-games/track-and-field/2024/08/08/66b51b0022601d15078b45d9.html", "title": "What happened to Noah Lyles? U.S. Track & Field star has COVID", "body": "Despite the setback, Lyles bravely took to the track, determined to give it his all. He burst out of the blocks and navigated the bend with his trademark speed and grace. But as the race reached its climax, the effects of the virus began to take their toll, and Lyles couldn't maintain his pace. Botswana's Letsile Tebogo seized the opportunity, pulling away in the final 50 meters to cross the line in a blistering time of 19.46 seconds, setting a new African record.\n\nLyles' US teammate, Kenneth Bednarek, made a late surge to claim the silver medal, relegating Lyles to third place. Immediately after the race, Lyles was seen sitting in a chair and being wheeled off the track, raising concerns about his physical condition.\n\nFormer US Olympic great Michael Johnson, who was providing commentary for the BBC, offered his analysis, saying, \"He certainly isn't carrying an injury because you can't do this with an injury, you can't run 19.70.\" Johnson suggested that Lyles' performance was likely affected by some form of illness that had \"zapped his energy.\"\n\nLyles' performance affected by illness, not injury\n\nShortly after the race, the news broke that Lyles had indeed tested positive for COVID-19 prior to the event. His decision to compete despite the illness was a testament to his determination and competitive spirit, but it also highlighted the challenges athletes face when dealing with the lingering effects of the virus.\n\nTebogo's historic victory made him the first African to win the 200m title, and in doing so, he secured Botswana's first-ever Olympic gold medal. The young sprinter's dominant performance cemented his status as one of the rising stars in the sport, clocking the fifth-fastest time in history over the distance.\n\nBednarek's silver medal was a testament to his own consistency and resilience, as he claimed his second successive silver in the 200m event. For Lyles, the disappointment of missing out on the sprint double was tempered by the knowledge that he had given his all, despite the obstacles he faced.", "source": {"uri": "marca.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8264484536", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "02:52:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T02:52:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T02:51:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/article-paris-olympics-noah-lyles-might-be-the-fastest-man-alive-but-he-wasnt/", "title": "Paris Olympics: Noah Lyles might be the Fastest Man Alive, but he wasn't even fastest in his Olympic 200 semi-final", "body": "What was supposed to be the easy half of Noah Lyles's historic Olympic sprint double isn't looking quite so easy any more.\n\nNewly crowned the Fastest Man Alive after a close-as-can-be win by five thousandths of a second in the 100 meters at the 2024 Games, Lyles was not even the fastest man in his semi-final of the 200 on Wednesday night. He was good enough to make it into that event's final, anyway.\n\nThe 200 is Lyles' preferred, and better, distance - one at which he had not lost a race in three full years. That streak was snapped at the Stade de France, where Letsile Tebogo of Botswana beat him to the line by crossing in 19.96 seconds, 0.12 faster than runner-up Lyles.\n\nThey'll have a rematch for the gold on Thursday night.\n\nGetting golds in the 100 and 200 at a single Olympics is a rare feat. Usain Bolt accomplished that double at three Olympics in a row - in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. But until the Jamaican, no man had done it since Carl Lewis at Los Angeles in 1984.\n\nAt his last Games, eight years ago, Bolt was shutting it down late in his 200 semi-final, and suddenly realized Andre De Grasse was running hard. So Bolt dialled his speed back up and wagged a finger at the Canadian. Fast-forward to the final: Bolt won easily.\n\nBefore pulling out his narrow win over Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in the 100 final on Sunday night, Lyles didn't finish first in his heat or his semi-final.\n\nAs anyone who pays any attention is well aware, Lyles is a showman who loves the spotlight and enjoys spending time with a microphone.\n\nThat's obvious from his mean-mugging and gesturing on the purple track in Paris before he runs or such statements as the offhand comparison between track and the NBA that went viral last year: \"The thing that hurts me the most is I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'World Champion' on their head,\" Lyles said. \"World champion of what? The United States?\"\n\nSo it raised some eyebrows when Lyles skipped the interview area after Wednesday's run, and U.S. team officials said he was heading to the medical tent. His coach, Lance Brauman, told The Associated Press: \"He's fine.\"\n\nThat might just add a bit more intrigue in the 24 hours until the medals are at stake.\n\nThere already was plenty.\n\nIs Lyles, a 27-year-old from Florida, at his best? How much did he care about the semi-final, when lane placements are determined but all that truly matters is moving on to the round that determines the medals? Will Lyles find some extra fuel from being outdone in front of a full house of about 80,000?\n\nWas the 21-year-old Tebogo, the 200 bronze medalist at worlds but making his Olympic debut, trying to send a message? Is he ready to challenge for a gold?\n\nAnd what about Kenny Bednarek, Lyles's U.S. teammate and the Tokyo Games silver medalist, who ran in a different semi-final and won it in 20 seconds flat, the evening's second-fastest time? Or Erryion Knighton, a 20-year-old American seen as the next threat, but whose only victories over Lyles came in the opening rounds of the 2021 Olympic trials.", "source": {"uri":
