{"uri": "2024-08-448943585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "07:38:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T07:38:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/sports/olympics/story/2024-08-08/noah-lyles-does-not-win-paris-200-meters/", "title": "Noah Lyles comes up short in Olympic men's 200 meters while battling COVID", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- Minutes after Noah Lyles collapsed on the track, medical personnel wheeled him down a long hallway, deep beneath the stands at Stade de France.\n\nSomeone asked if he wanted to call his mother. Lyles shook his head.\n\n\"I just needed some time,\" he said. \"So they wheeled me off the track.\"\n\nThe world's fastest man, it seemed, had been slowed by COVID.\n\nDays after winning gold in a thrilling, historic 100 meters, a weakened Lyles struggled to finish third in his specialty, the 200, at the 2024 Summer Olympics. Letsile Tebogo of Botswana won his country's first-ever gold medal with a time of 19.46 and Kenny Bednarek of the U.S. was second.\n\nThe 21-year-old Tebogo, a rising star in track, slapped his chest as he crossed the finish line.\n\n\"It was really a beautiful race for me,\" said Tebogo, who recently lost his mother and had written her birth date on his shoes. \"We had our ups and downs, but we just made sure that we pulled through and made it to the Olympics.\"\n\nThe result ended Lyles' quest to win the 100, 200 and 400 relay -- the coveted sprint triple last achieved by the legendary Usain Bolt. Unbeknownst to almost everyone, Lyle's chances had taken a serious hit days beforehand.\n\nThe trouble arose early Tuesday morning, about 36 hours after his 100 victory.\n\n\"I woke up in the middle of the night just feeling really chills, aching, sore throat,\" he said. \"And those are kind of a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting COVID.\"\n\nA test came back positive and U.S. officials quietly moved him to a hotel outside the athletes village where he remained, taking Paxlovid, for the next few days. Only his coach and family knew the nature of his absence.\n\n\"Why would you want to tell your competitors you're sick?\" said Lyles, who joined British swimmer Adam Peaty and Australian swimmers Lani Pallister and Zac Stubblety-Cook among athletes who competed with COVID during the Olympics. \"Why would you want to give them an edge over you?\"\n\nBecause of relaxed health protocols at the Games, Lyles was allowed to continue training and competing in the early rounds of the 200. If he looked a bit off, that wasn't too unusual -- his 100 prelims had been lackluster.\n\nThough his girlfriend -- Jamaican runner Junelle Bromfield -- told him that he had been coughing all night, the symptoms seemed to fade by Thursday morning.\n\nDuring introductions for the 200, Lyles burst onto the track like always, jumping up and down, pumping his fists. When the race began, he gambled on a fast start but could not muster the kind of finish that has carried him to victories in the past.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" he said of the illness, estimating that he felt \"like 90 percent to 95 percent\" of full strength.\n\nTebogo, meanwhile, came off the curve looking strong. After seeing Lyles' victory at the world championships last year, he had trained hard on that aspect of his race and was able to generate momentum to carry him down the home stretch.\n\nBednarek, wearing a trademark headband tied at the back, tried to follow but could not close the gap, repeating his silver-medal finish from three years ago in Tokyo.\n\n\"This race wasn't what I wanted,\" the American said, \"but I'm happy to be back on the podium.\"\n\nMoments after the finish, Lyles sank down and lay on the track, fighting shortness of breath and chest pains. Medical staff brought him water and helped him to his feet before eventually taking him away in a wheelchair. His mother came down from the stands, chasing after him down that hallway.\n\nAlmost an hour later, the sprinter appeared before reporters wearing a black face mask. Withdrawing from the 200 had never crossed his mind, he said. As for running the relay on Friday, he would leave that decision to his coaches and teammates.\n\nConsidering his rough night, Lyles sounded surprisingly upbeat.\n\n\"To be honest,\" he said, \"I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\n\u00a92024 Los Angeles Times. first African to win Olympic 200m", "body": "Paris (AFP) - Botswana's Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the Olympic 200 metres on Thursday as he upstaged Noah Lyles' plans for a sprint double in Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, was able to ease up at the end and still clocked an African record of 19.46sec for gold with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62sec and Lyles fading to bronze in 19.70sec.\n\nThe sole African to have won a short sprint title at an Olympic Games is South African Reggie Walker, over 100m at the 1908 Games in London.\n\nThe final lacked the pre-race hype of the 100m, falling mid-session at a packed Stade de France.\n\nLyles was given a huge reception when introduced as cameras showed him up on the big screens at either end of the stadium.\n\nThe newly crowned 100m champion was drawn in lane five, outside Alexander Ogando and inside American teammate Erriyon Knighton, while Tebogo was in seven.\n\nThe American bounded into the stadium, as he had done before the 100m final, cupping his ear to the crowd.\n\nTebogo, however, walked quietly on and went straight to his blocks.\n\nAfter the gun went for the start, Lyles was quickly up on Ogando.\n\nHe, Tebogo and Bednarek all rounded the bend well, but coming into the home straight, Lyles was in third spot.\n\nTebogo looked in total control, even relaxing as he went through the finish line, making a brushing-off gesture with his hand on his sky blue vest.\n\nBednarek held on for silver, with Lyles prone on the track after being unable to replicate his gold medal showing in the In a press conference ahead of the 200m, Lyles was discussing his objective for the race before stopping himself and saying while laughing: 'I'll be winning.'\n\nAmerican teammate Fred Kerley then said while sat next to him: 'Talk your s**t'. Lyles responded: 'That man ain't winning, none of them is winning. When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.'\n\nAfter his words came back to bite him on Thursday, fans took to social media to mock the Olympian for predicting that his competitors would be left 'depressed' when he came round the bend. One said on X: 'Guess Noah Lyles [is] the only person depressed after the turn'. Another commented: 'Saw a video of Noah Lyles saying at the bend his competitors will be depressed. Guess who is now'.\n\n'Noah Lyles said everyone was gonna be depressed when they hit that turn.... Wellllllll,' wrote a third. A fourth put: 'Noah Lyles is definitely the depressed one now - loud mouth'. A fifth posted: 'Noah Lyles was talking about how these guy's will be depressed only to lose. There's a fine line between confidence and arrogance.'\n\nWhile another said: 'Talked that s**t and didn't back it up this time'. Following his third-place finish, the disappointment soon gave way to a frightful scene as Lyles was wheeled away from the track by medics.\n\nIt has since been claimed that the 100m champion ran Thursday's 200m with Covid, which may well explain his slow start. NBC said they spoke to his mom, who confirmed he had the virus but still decided to run at the Olympics.\n\nLyles was plagued by a slow start Thursday and was unable to catch Bednarek, who had been the top runner in the 200 throughout the ongoing Paris Olympics. He now has two bronze medals in the 200, following his third-place finish at the 2020 Tokyo Games.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? at Olympic sprint double in 200m", "body": "American Noah Lyles has the chance to become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete an Olympic sprint double after qualifying for the 200m final at Paris 2024.\n\nLyles won 100m gold by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish on Sunday.\n\nThe 27-year-old, winner of three golds at last year's World Championships, finished second in his 200m semi-final in 20.08 seconds to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nWorld 100m silver and 200m bronze medallist Tebogo set the fastest time of the round at Stade de France on Wednesday evening, clocking 19.96 seconds.\n\nThe Olympic men's 200m final takes place on Friday at 6.30am NZT.\n\nKenneth Bednarek, of the United States, also set a faster time than Lyles, in 20.00, while compatriot Erriyon Knighton, who upgraded to world 200m silver last year, also safely progressed.\n\nBut Canada's Andre de Grasse will not defend his title in the final after finishing third in his race (20.41).\n\nThe Olympic 200m bronze winner three years ago, Lyles claimed world 100m, 200m and 4x100m gold in Budapest last year.\n\nFollowing that achievement, when he became the first man since Bolt in 2015 to complete a 100m and 200m world double, he claimed he could look to add the 4x400m relay title to that treble haul in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint legend Bolt completed individual sprint doubles at three successive Olympic Games among his eight titles, adding relay gold in 2012 and 2016.\n\nOnly nine men have achieved that double in the history of the Games.\n\nLyles became the first American to win an Olympic 100m title for 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in 2004, with his narrow triumph.\n\nA three-time reigning world 200m champion, he will line up as favourite as he looks to further assert himself as the dominant male sprinter of the current generation.", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": This is the second consecutive Olympics where the virus has played a significant role in Lyles' journey. In the Tokyo Olympics, he also won bronze and faced mental challenges due to the pandemic's impacts.\n\nNoah Lyles faced a formidable challenge at the Olympic 200 meters, ultimately losing out to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo. After securing third place, Lyles was seen lying on the track and then sitting up to receive medical attention. The Associated Press learned that he had been diagnosed with COVID two days before the final event.\n\nThis marks the second consecutive Olympics where the virus has severely affected Lyles' performance. In Tokyo, he also took home the bronze, with the pandemic influencing his preparation and mental health, leading to a journey marked by depression and a delay in the Games. This experience motivated his path to the current competition in Paris.\n\nDespite the setbacks, Lyles' story is one of resilience and determination in the face of ongoing global health challenges. {"uri": "8265956305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:12:56", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:12:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:11:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/covid-noah-lyles-reveals-positive-210222200.html", "title": "'I do have Covid': Noah Lyles reveals positive test after taking 200m bronze", "body": "Noah Lyles revealed he tested positive for Covid on Tuesday morning, in the aftermath of a men's 200m final where the American was removed from the track in a wheelchair having finished third in 19.70sec.\n\nLyles appeared for media duties wearing a mask, flanked by members of the US team's medical department, but claimed he never had any thought about withdrawing from the event. USA Track & Field had made clear it was Lyles's decision to participate in Thursday night's final.\n\nRelated: Lyles wins 200m bronze before Covid diagnosis revealed as Tebogo takes gold\n\nLyles, the freshly crowned Olympic 100m champion, was unable to keep pace with the gold medallist, \u00adBotswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.46) or his US teammate \u00adKenneth Bednarek (19.62), who took silver. Lyles's appearance in a wheelchair immediately drew speculation about his medical condition.\n\nThe 27-year-old soon clarified his situation. \"I do have Covid,\" Lyles said. \"I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday. I woke up feeling chills, aching, sore throat. Those were a lot of the symptoms I have had before getting Covid. I was like: 'I need to test this one.' It came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and they got me on as much medication as they legally could to make sure my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, they said it was still possible so we stayed away from everybody and took it round by round. I have definitely had better days but I am walking around again. I was quite light headed after that race and the chest pain was definitely active. After a while I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me. I am feeling a lot better now. It definitely affected my performance.\"\n\nIn a statement, USA Track & Field said: \"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough \u00admedical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe Paris Olympics has no mandatory rules relating to Covid and participation, meaning Lyles was within his rights to take to the start line. Covid has been a lingering feature of the Games, having affected Australian water polo players and swimmers from various nations, including \u00adBritain's Adam Peaty.\n\nLyles answered a firm \"no\" when asked whether withdrawing from the 200m was ever a consideration. \"I was going to compete regardless,\" he added. \"If I didn't make the final, that would have been the sign not to compete.\"\n\nStill, Lyles's attitude will raise eyebrows. His girlfriend is the Jamaican athlete Junelle Bromfield, with whom he admitted sharing a bed while in the hotel. \"Junelle said I was coughing through the night last night,\" Lyles said. \"I thought I had a good sleep but she said she had to keep moving me through the night to make sure I would stop coughing. I am more proud of myself than \u00adanything. Coming out and winning the bronze medal after three days with Covid ... it has been a wild Olympics.\"\n\nNo other members of the US team had been informed of Lyles's diagnosis before the 200m final. \"The only people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mum and my family,\" said Lyles.\n\n\"We tried to keep this as close to the chest as possible. We didn't want everybody going into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete. You also never want to tell your competitors you are sick. Why would you give them an advantage over you?\"\n\nBednarek, who hugged Lyles after the final, seemed to have no worries about any danger attached to that. \"I don't care,\" said the silver \u00admedallist. \"I don't view those things as a big deal. I am healthy and do \u00adeverything to ensure my body is healthy. It doesn't bother me at all. I don't get sick easily.\"\n\nLyles still has to make a call over whether to compete in the 4x100m men's relay. \"I am going to talk to the 4x100 crew,\" Lyles said. \"I am going to be very honest and transparent with them, I will let them make the decision. {"uri": "2024-08-448681962", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:46:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:46:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:41:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/noah-lyles-declares-that-his-participation-in-the-2024-paris-olympics-has-come-to-an-end-due-to-a-confirmed-covid-diagnosis-stating-he-will-return-for-another-opportunity-in-the-future/", "title": "Noah Lyles declares that his participation in the 2024 Paris Olympics has come to an end due to a confirmed COVID diagnosis, stating he will return for another opportunity in the future. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Noah Lyles has revealed that he's likely done competing in the Paris Olympics after the American sprinter battled through COVID to finish third in the 200m final on Thursday.\n\nLyles, who picked up a gold in the 100m earlier in the Games, looked set to compete in the 4x100m relay on Friday but has seemingly ruled himself out.\n\nHe wrote on Instagram, '...I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics. It is not the Olympic I dreamed of but it has left me with so much Joy in my heart. I hope everyone enjoyed the show. Whether you were rooting for me or against me, you have to admit you watched, didn't you? See you next time.'\n\nLyles used the earlier portion of his post to thank fans for their support and congratulate Letsile Tebogo and USA teammate Kenny Bednarek on their gold and silver medal wins respectively.\n\n'First I want to thank God for getting me through this entire Olympics! Second I want to congratulate @tebogo_letsile_ , @kenny_bednarek and everyone else on an amazing Olympic 200m final,' he wrote.\n\n'Finally I want to thank everyone for the supportive messages.'\n\nLyles' post was met with more messages of support as American tennis star Coco Gauff commented 'unreal' with a gold medal emoji.\n\nTeam USA fencer Miles Chamley-Watson also commented 'keep being a [star] bruv.'\n\nEarlier in the evening, Lyles had at least left the door open to competing in the 4\u00d7100 relay, but admitted he was leaning towards sitting out.\n\n'At the moment I don't know, I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing,' he said. 'They have proven they can handle it without me.'\n\nLyles labored to a third-place finish in Thursday's 200m final before it was revealed that he was battling COVID.\n\nThe American sprinter was placed in a wheelchair and looked visibly out of breath following the race.\n\nHe later explained to NBC that he woke up on Tuesday morning 'feeling really horrible.'\n\n'I knew it was more than being sore from the 100,' he continued. 'My first thought was not to panic, I've been in worse situations, I've been in worse conditions.\n\n'I took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much. It would say it has taken its toll, for sure, but I have never been more proud of myself coming out here and getting a bronze.'\n\nTrack legend Michael Johnson questioned Lyles' decision to compete with COVID, saying on the BBC: 'Very bizarre, Covid is still a dangerous disease. It is just bizarre, the whole thing is really weird.\n\n'There is going to be all of this thing with the Noah haters out there - and he set himself up for it - there are going to be people out there saying it's not real and he's faking or whatever.\n\n'But putting that aside, having Covid and still coming out here and being in close proximity with other people - I know there probably is not a policy I guess at these Games for that - but morally I'm not sure about it.'\n\nNotably, Lyles later said that the other competitors were unaware of his diagnosis: 'We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mom knew.\n\n'We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick. Why would you give them an edge?'\n\nOn Friday, Lyles' foes now won't have to worry about him during the 4\u00d7100 relay, as Team USA looks to add to its gold medal tally.\n\nThrough Thursday, the United States is leading the Games in both total medals and golds, with 103 overall medals and 30 first-place finishes.\n\nChina are just behind in that second category, with 29 golds, while Australia are third with an impressive 18.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8266020941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:21:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:21:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:20:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.thezimbabwemail.com/sports/letsile-tebogo-makes-history-as-first-african-to-win-olympic-mens-200m-gold-end-for-zimbabwes-two-boys/", "title": "Letsile Tebogo Makes History as First African to Win Olympic Men's 200m Gold, end for Zimbabwe's two boys", "body": "PARIS, - Letsile Tebogo etched his name in the history books on Thursday, becoming the first African athlete to win the men's Olympic 200 meters title.\n\nThe 21-year-old from Botswana powered past American sprinters Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles to secure his country's first-ever Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who had earlier set a national record of 9.86 seconds in the 100m final, surged ahead in the last 50 meters of the 200m race, crossing the finish line in an impressive 19.46 seconds. His victory not only earned him the gold but also made him the fifth-fastest man in history over the 200m distance.\n\nKenny Bednarek, who took silver in the event at the Tokyo Olympics, repeated the feat, finishing in 19.62 seconds. Noah Lyles, the triple world champion who had been aiming to become the first American to achieve the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, settled for bronze with a time of 19.67 seconds. Lyles' performance marked his first defeat in a 200m final in three years.\n\nThe U.S. team revealed that Lyles had tested positive for COVID-19 on Tuesday, just two days after winning gold in the 100 meters. Despite the diagnosis, Lyles chose to compete, and U.S. officials implemented all necessary health protocols to ensure the safety of all athletes.\n\nAdding to the drama, Lyles received a yellow card for a misconduct violation after damaging his lane box before the race began, further complicating his night.\n\nA Historic Night for Africa\n\nWhile much of the attention was on Lyles, it was undoubtedly Tebogo's night, symbolizing a monumental moment for African athletics. Traditionally dominant in middle and long-distance events, this was the first time in Olympic history that four African sprinters competed in a 200m final. Though three of them finished in the last three positions, Tebogo's record-breaking win marked a significant leap forward for the continent.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion -- it's something I have never seen in my life or even dreamt of. It is an amazing moment,\" Tebogo said after the race. \"I knew Kenny was going to run away, so I made sure to close him down. I have that top-end speed that allows me to finish the race strong. When I saw Kenny fade, I knew Noah was far behind us, and that's when I realized I was the Olympic champion.\"\n\nTebogo's triumph is more than just a personal achievement; it represents a milestone for Botswana, Africa, and his family.\n\nFor Bednarek, who ran a strong race from lane eight, the result was bittersweet. \"I don't think I put my best race down. It was really tight at the end,\" he said. \"This year, I'm finally healthy. I can build off this. There's also the world championships next year. I'm going to be dangerous. I expect big things in the next four years.\"\n\nTebogo's victory is a testament to the growing prowess of African athletes in sprinting, and it sets the stage for even greater achievements in the Lyles - who entered as a massive favorite for gold - has claimed bronze for the second time. Lyles' time of 19.70 seconds is nearly a full 0.40 seconds below his personal best of 19.31.\n\nFor Lyles, the defeat in his signature event means he'll fall short of his goal to become the first American man since Carl Lewis in 1984 to complete the 100m-200m Olympic double. Only nine men in history have achieved that feat, and the number will stay there until at least 2028.\n\nWhen Bednarek booked his spot on the U.S. Olympic team in June, he teased his Paris goals in his post-race interview.\n\n\"I'm gonna get him next time,\" Bednarek said, staring Lyles down as he spoke.\n\nOn Thursday in Paris, Bednarek did just that, eclipsing his U.S. teammate by .08 seconds for silver.\n\nWith this gold medal, the young Botswanan Tebogo has elevated himself to the elite level of his sport. {"uri": "8265863795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:44:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:44:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:44:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/08/08/gabby-logan-suggests-noah-lyles-made-selfish-decision-competing-200m-final-21389906/", "title": "Gabby Logan suggests Noah Lyles made 'selfish decision' competing in 200m final", "body": "BBC host Gabby Logan has suggested Noah Lyles made a 'selfish decision' to compete in the men's 200m final at the Paris Olympics if he was aware that he had Covid-19 before the race.\n\nAfter being crowned the new men's 100m champion, Lyles had to settle for the bronze medal in the longer distance, with Botswana's Letsile Tebogo storming home in an African-record time of 19.46 seconds.\n\nLyles' fellow countryman Kenny Bednarek came home in third place to claim silver at a rapturous Stade de France.\n\nBut just moments after the athletes crossed the finish line, it came to light that Lyles had tested positive for Covid-19 and the American was pictured being taken off the track in a wheelchair in the French capital.\n\n'Just hearing... we've been told by US Track and Field that Noah Lyles has got Covid,' BBC presenter Logan told a shocked Jessica Ennis-Hill, Michael Johnson and Denise Lewis in the track-side studio.\n\n'A decision to race is one thing when you have something like that but also the introductions [stadium entrances]...\n\n'Really interesting, that that's a waste of energy.'\n\nLogan believes there will be many people questioning Lyles' decision to go ahead and compete given the American would likely have been mixing with his fellow athletes and rivals prior to the final.\n\n'There's also, I imagine, some people thinking, \"Hang on, you're with people in a small space, there's a potential to give other people Covid\",' she added.\n\n'It would seem to be quite a selfish decision.'\n\nLater in the programme, the BBC showed images of Lyles wearing a mask in the call room prior to the race, with Logan going on to question the American's decision to hug Bednarek after the final.\n\n'Noah Lyles in the call room with a face mask on... so, obviously, that backs up the Covid story that has emerged,' she said.\n\n'But also in the call room and then you've [Johnson] just shown me a picture on social media of him cuddling Kenny Bednarek after the race.'\n\nIn response, Johnson said he was 'morally' unsure about Lyles decision to embrace Bednarek if he knew he had Covid.\n\n'Very bizarre because Covid is still a dangerous disease and Kenny Bednarek is a member of the 4x100m relay team so it's just bizarre. The whole thing is really weird,' Johnson said.\n\n'There's gonna be all this sort of thing about there being Noah Lyles haters out there and he's set himself up for that.\n\n'There's going to be people saying it's not real and he's faking or whatever, but putting that aside... having Covid and being out here in close proximity with other people... I know there's probably not a policy I guess at these Games. But still, morally I'm not sure about it.'\n\nAccording to Johnson, there had been rumours of Lyles coming down with an illness on the eve of the 200m final.\n\n'They said he went to a medical yesterday and that was a rumour going around, that he was sick or maybe had an illness or there was something going around in the village,' the former 200m and 400m world-record holder continued.\n\n'They didn't say Covid but they said something so I would imagine they would have known that yesterday.'\n\nMORE : American sprinter accuses Olympic organisers of 'favouritism' ahead of "https://metro.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2024/08/comp-1723146112.png?crop=0px%2C23px%2C2000px%2C1051px&resize=1200%2C630", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792855", "eventUri": "eng-9792855", {"uri": "8266058509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:07:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:07:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:06:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/2024-olympics-sydney-mclaughlin-levrones-gold-adds-to-her-glory-while-covid-robs-noah-lyles-of-his-story/", "title": "2024 Olympics: Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone's gold adds to her glory, while COVID robs Noah Lyles of his story - CBSSports.com", "body": "Two Americans at the peak of their primes had very different outcomes on the track Thursday Getty Images\n\nThe most unbeatable track athlete in the world -- and one of the best athletes in the world, period -- represents the United States and her name is Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone.\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone isn't just the best 400-meter hurdler in women's history. When you see her go, you understand how her specialty is unique. Most other runners just don't make it look this easy, because they can't make it look this easy. Her form is perfect. Every time. You know how we see these world records get broken with every Olympics and the times are wildly improved from athletes two generations prior? That's what it's like watching McLaughlin-Levrone, only she's doing it against contemporaries.\n\nIt's like she beamed back from the future. That's how much better she is than the field.\n\nGiven the way she has separated from her competition and redefined the boundaries of what's physically possible in women's hurdling, she can fairly be called the greatest hurdler of all time.\n\nAnd on Thursday, the sports world bore witness once again to her transcendent dominance.\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone set her sixth world record in the 400 hurdles, easily winning gold by running and hurdling the big purple oval at Stade de France in 50.37 seconds. (Her time was so good it would've nearly landed McLaughlin-Levrone in the 400-meter finals -- the race without the hurdles.)\n\nThe win gives McLaughlin-Levrone an astonishing reality: She is the only woman to ever win back-to-back gold medals in the 400m hurdles. What a phenomenal Olympian. McLaughlin-Levrone can claim supremacy over her sport like Simone Biles and Katie Ledecky do in theirs. It is a joy to watch her so effortlessly gallup past so-called competitors. It makes the pre-race chatter even more hilarious after the fact. Prior to Thursday's run there was faint curiosity if this event would wind up being the scene of yet another upset in track at these Olympics. After all, they'd been popping up with regularity; we even saw it materialize in the men's 200-meter final. (More on that in just a moment.)\n\nWould Femke Bol of the Netherlands run the race of her life and out-do McLaughlin-Levrone? Turns out she couldn't even out-do Anna Cockrell. Cockrell, an American, took silver (51.87) behind McLaughlin-Levrone, while Bol had to settle for bronze (52.15).\n\nAt 25 years old, these Games represent the true star turn for McLaughlin-Levrone. She burst onto the scene in Tokyo, and, yes, in the track and field world she's been the envy of most for years. But in showing out so definitively in front of fans on the Paris stages, McLaughlin-Levrone upped her profile to the highest tier for an American Olympian, especially when you factor in how she hasn't lost in the 400m hurdles in five years.\n\nShe's expected to run again in 2028 at the Los Angeles Games, and it's there and then when she could opt to go supernova status. Her talent is so obvious, the temptation to expand her program and run the 400 (sans hurdles), or the 200-meter dash, or basically any race she wants, will be there.\n\nThe hype will be earned and widespread. McLaughlin-Levrone has already cemented her reputation among the all-time great American Olympians. In 2028, she goes for pantheon status. We'll all be waiting, eagerly, to see her chase it.\n\nAnd speaking of pantheon status ...\n\nNoah Lyles' bid for the double halted by COVID\n\nNoah Lyles had something rarely attainable available to him at these Games. The 2024 Olympics were set up to catapult the gifted track speedster to American superstardom, to be the face of American track. In order to truly break through to all-time status, Lyles -- an elite sprinter -- would need to clear two massive hurdles in order to get there.\n\nHe had to pull off the grueling, ever-coveted double: win gold in both the 100- and 200-meter dashes.\n\nCarl Lewis is the only American to ever do that. Lyles got halfway there on Sunday night when he roared from behind to barely beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in one of the most dramatic 100-meter finals in history. Lyles' chest beat Thompson's torso by five one-thousandths of a second: 9.784 to 9.789 seconds.\n\nThen, a conspicuous thing in the past two days. Lyles was seen wearing a medical face mask prior to stepping into the open air of Stade de France. Was it precautionary?\n\nNo. It was COVID. We now know that, because Lyles confirmed as much on Thursday after he failed in his quest to take the double. This also explains why Lyles didn't even finish first in his semifinal heat on Wednesday.\n\n\"I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning, and I just was feeling really horrible, and I knew that it was more than being sore from the 100\" Lyles said on NBC. \"My first thought was not to panic. I was thinking I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions, I felt, and we just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off.\"\n\nLyles, whose competitive spirit is as evident as any athlete at these Olympics, said he never debated not running in the 200. (If you weren't aware, it's been official Olympics policy to allow athletes to compete while having COVID, in essence treating it like other common respiratory illnesses.)\n\nRunning sick, Lyles still managed to earn a bronze, but he was clearly not himself. He was beaten by his Team USA comrade, Kenny Bednarek, who took silver, and was downright dusted by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, who won the gold after running the fifth-fastest 200 in history.\n\nTebogo sprinted to first in 19.46 seconds. Bednarek reached the line in 19.62, while Lyles was well off his personal-best time of 19.31 that he set two years ago.\n\nDown (but not out) with disease, Lyles would've needed to run something borderline alien in order to win gold. Tebogo won the first gold for Africa ever in the 200. It was also the first gold for Botswana in any Olympic event.\n\n\"It's taken its toll for sure,\" Lyles said on NBC after the race. \"But I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here, and getting a bronze medal, where last Olympics I was very disappointed. This time, I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nLyles' outspoken nature has led to him be something of a polarizing athlete. He infamously took aim at NBA players for proclaiming \"world champion\" status despite competing only on North American soil. So the loss was a moment for his critics to crow.\n\nExcept, peer into the race through his eyes. Work for four years, and not run in the 200? It was policy to allow him to compete with COVID. Obviously he was going to give it a go. When Lyles -- who has long battled asthma, remember -- says he's proud of winning bronze, I believe him. It's understandable how we expect U.S. athletes to win gold and can feel let down when they fall short of that. But the Olympics hand out three prizes for a reason.\n\nSometimes, just making it to the podium can feel like a victory. Lyles got the 100. Ironically, his best event is where his body failed him, through little fault of his own.\n\nHe leaves Paris with at least two medals. And now we wonder: Is Lyles' Olympics over? He was on pace to run the anchor leg in the 4x100 relay, but Lyles indicated he wasn't likely to run in it when asked by Lewis Johnson on NBC on Thursday. So, we'll wait and see there.\n\nThat's the tricky thing about these races. No matter how we think they're gonna go, the ending is never guaranteed.\n\nUnless your name is Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS {"uri": "2024-08-448630171", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:52:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:52:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:46:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.miamiherald.com/sports/olympics/article290897514.html", "title": "Don't Blame COVID-19 for Noah Lyles's Olympic Bronze in the 200 Meters", "body": "PARIS - Excuses? Nah. Noah Lyles's positive test for COVID-19 is not an excuse for his surprising third-place performance in the men's 200-meter final on Thursday night. But it was a factor-and there is a big difference, in sports, between factors and excuses.\n\nClaiming he lost because he's never run on a purple track would be an excuse. Blaming refs is almost always an excuse. Complaining that your hotel-room pillow was too soft, your bus driver drove too slow, or your socks were too tight: Excuse, excuse, excuse.\n\nWhat happened to Lyles is just part of sports, which are designed, in the most basic sense, to measure which humans perform specific tasks best at a specific time on a specific day. Sometimes you tweak your ankle, sometimes you're distracted by something happening in your personal life, and sometimes you're an asthmatic who gets COVID-19 in the most important week of your career. If the International Olympic Committee insisted that all participants be at their mental and physical best at the moment of competition, no event would ever take place.\n\nSo congrats to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, whose time of 19.46 seconds was more than worthy of gold. Congrats to American Kenny Bednarek for grabbing silver and congrats to Lyles for somehow running a 200 in 19.70 seconds, just two days after he-his words-\"woke up in the middle of the night just feeling, really, chills, aching, sore throat.\" Lyles bounced into the stadium like he always does. But by the end of the race, he appeared to be laboring.\n\n\"This is by far the best day I felt out of the last three days,\" he said. \"I still wouldn't say I'm 100%, but I'd definitely say I'm closer to like 90 to 95 percent ... I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out and [getting] the bronze medal.\"\n\nHe should be proud. He should also rest up, see if he feels strong enough to run in the 4X100 relay Friday, and definitely not read the next paragraph.\n\nBednarek and Lyles have faced each other in the 200-meter dash 13 times. Lyles has finished ahead of Bednarek in 11 of them. The other two were in the Olympics.\n\nLyles thrives on showmanship, and at the Tokyo Olympics, there were no fans and therefore no show. The atmosphere in Paris was much more to his liking. He won the 100 meters by one sixteenth of a goose bump. The 200 figured to be the easier race for him; after the 100, he had promised he would win. (Or at least he promised that everybody else in the final would be unhappy with the result, which I took as a promise he would win.)\n\nLyles did not announce he tested positive until after the race. His coaches, his doctors, his family and his girlfriend, Junelle Bromfield-a Jamaican sprinter who is also competing in Paris-knew about his diagnosis. But they also knew that the 200 would happen whether he ran or not. Lyles said he never considered withdrawing.\n\nWhen a reporter asked if his COVID-19 medication was PAXLOVID, Lyles paused, said \"I can't remember the name of it,\" and laughed at the absurdity of it. An official near him confirmed it was PAXLOVID.\n\n\"Even Junelle was saying that I was coughing through the night last night,\" Lyles said. \"I thought I had a good night's sleep, but she said she had to keep moving me through the night to make sure that I would stop coughing.\"\n\nBecause Lyles basically guaranteed a victory and ended up getting bronze, there will inevitably be whispers that COVID-19 was a convenient excuse. The theory makes sense until you think about it for, oh, two seconds.\n\nQuickly now: Lyles's asthma has been well-documented. COVID-19 symptoms can be especially severe for patients with asthma. Lyles left the Olympic Village, stayed in a hotel, changed his preparatory regimen before the biggest 200 of his career-and then, after he finished, he fell to the track and was taken out of the stadium in a wheelchair. He put on a mask and told reporters if he wasn't healthy enough to run in the 4X100 relay Friday, he would tell the coaches.\n\nOf course he was sick, and of course it affected him-and of course it doesn't really matter. They held the men's 200 at the Olympics this week, Noah Lyles was the third-fastest man in the final and that's that.\n\nThis article was originally published on www.si.com as Don't Blame COVID-19 for Only people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mom, my family. We didn't want everybody to go into a panic.\n\n\"We wanted them to be able to compete. {"uri": "8264757067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "07:04:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T07:04:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T07:03:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/olympics/news/noah-lyles-mental-health-depression-anxiety-olympics/a0e8206ef019af1257d0b61d", "title": "Noah Lyles mental health: How USA sprinter overcame depression, anxiety on Olympics gold medal run", "body": "One of the biggest global stars in track and field, Noah Lyles is seeking to add to his 100-meter dash gold medal this week as he competes in two more events before the conclusion of the 2024 Paris Games.\n\nThe 27-year-old sprinter is notorious for being himself -- speaking out, loud and proud, and never shying away from the spotlight. He wasn't always like that, however.\n\nAfter winning the 100-meter race at the Stade de France, Lyles posted an inspiring message on social media. He wrote: \"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\"\n\nLyles has been open about the obstacles he's faced throughout his career. Here's everything you need to know about his mental health journey, including how the USA sprinter overcame depression and anxiety on the way to an Olympic gold medal.\n\nUSA OLYMPICS MEDAL COUNT: Overall table | U.S. medal tracker | Who has won gold?\n\nSince he began taking track seriously after watching the 2012 Olympics, the sport has been Lyles' refuge. When he was sprinting, he didn't have to worry about anything else.\n\nThat didn't mean it was always easy. After having struggled with asthma, bullying and learning difficulties because of his ADD and dyslexia at a young age, Lyles and his brother, Josephus, turned professional in 2016, forgoing collegiate careers.\n\nLyles began to struggle mentally before his first outdoor world championships in Doha in 2019. After living out of hotel rooms in Europe for some time during the season, he was growing homesick -- even winning the 200m race at worlds that year didn't fully improve his mood.\n\nThen, the pandemic hit and Lyles lost his \"twinkle,\" his therapist told TIME. He struggled to talk, experiencing constant fatigue and difficulty breathing. He was depressed, and the murder of George Floyd in May 2020 only drove him into a deeper hole.\n\nMORE: Best Noah Lyles 100m photos\n\nLyles began taking antidepressants that summer but ended up tapering them down before beginning his next track season. Feeling a bit better, Lyles qualified in the 200-meter race for the postponed 2021 Tokyo Olympics and entered the Games as the favorite for gold.\n\nUnfortunately, Josephus did not qualify with him, nixing a dream the two brothers had. Without the crowd to rile him on and Josephus at his side, Lyles struggled in the 200-meter final and only captured bronze. It was immediately after this race that Lyles broke down publicly for the first time and expressed his struggles with mental health.\n\n\"I knew there was a lot of people out there like me who's scared to say something or to even start that journey,\" he said. \"I want you to know that it's OK to not feel good, and you can go out and talk to somebody professionally, or even get on medication, because this is a serious issue and you don't want to wake up one day and just think, you know, 'I don't want to be here anymore.'\n\n\"This wasn't even my dream,\" Lyles continued as he sobbed to reporters after the race. \"I just wanted to tag along because I loved my brother, and I wanted to do this together. And it's taken us so far, and I feel like he should be here.\"\n\nSince then, Lyles has defied the odds and overcome his struggles, continuing to cement himself as one of the greatest American {"uri": "8265962656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:18:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:18:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:17:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/others/242069/tebogo-upstages-covid-hit-lyles-to-become-first-african-to-win-olympic-200m", "title": "Tebogo upstages Covid-hit Lyles to become first African to win Olympic 200m", "body": "Botswana's Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the Olympic 200 metres on Thursday as he -- and Covid --upstaged Noah Lyles' plans for a sprint double in Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, was able to ease up at the end and still clocked an African record of 19.46sec for gold, with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62sec and Lyles fading to bronze in 19.70sec.\n\nLyles, who was pictured in the warm-up area wearing a mask, admitted after the race he had Covid.\n\n'I've had better days,' the American said. 'I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5:00 am on Tuesday morning.\n\n'I woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat.\n\n'I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100. We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for Covid.'\n\nCovid woes aside, the night belonged to the ground-breaking Tebogo.\n\nThe sole African previously to have won a short sprint title at an Olympic Games is South African Reggie Walker, over 100m at the 1908 Games in London.\n\nTebogo's time saw him leapfrog American Erriyon Knighton to go fifth fastest in the all-time list. The gold was also Botswana's first ever at an Olympics.\n\n'It was really a beautiful race for me,' Tebogo said. 'When we made it to the final, my coach just told me, 'Now my job is done, it's up to you to see what you can do. Whether it's a medal or not, just finish the race healthy'.\n\n'That's all I could've wished for. I'm happy I finished the race healthier than before.'\n\nTebogo's gold is even more impressive given that he lost his mother Seratiwa in May. His running shoes bear his late mother's date of birth.\n\n'It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,' said the sprinter, who took a month off training and competition after her death.\n\n'It gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy. I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.'\n\nTebogo added: 'I'm really grateful for the team around me. They really pushed me through thick and thin.\n\n'We had our ups and downs, but we just made sure that we pulled through and made it to the Olympics.'\n\nThe final lacked the pre-race hype of the 100m, falling mid-session at a packed Stade de France.\n\nLyles was given a huge reception when introduced as cameras showed him up on the big screens at either end of the stadium.\n\nThe newly crowned 100m champion was drawn in lane five, outside Alexander Ogando and inside American teammate Knighton, while Tebogo was in seven inside Bednarek.\n\nThe American bounded into the stadium, as he had done before the 100m final, cupping his ear to the crowd, but his exuberant showboating saw him yellow-carded for breaking the starting block.\n\nTebogo, however, was an image of calmness, walking quietly on and going straight to his blocks.\n\nAfter the gun went for the start, Lyles was quickly up on Ogando.\n\nHe, Tebogo and Bednarek all rounded the bend well, but coming into the home straight, Lyles was in third spot.\n\nBut Tebogo looked in total control, even relaxing as he went through the finish line, making a brushing-off gesture to the rest of the field.\n\nBednarek held on for silver, with Lyles prone on the track after being unable to replicate his gold medal showing in the 100m.\n\n'I came out here wanting to win, but I have to settle for silver again,' said Bednarek, who was also second at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\n'I didn't put the best race down, but Tebogo ran a really good race.'", "source": {"uri": "newagebd.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100 metres and 200 metres titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100 metres gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the {"uri": "8266029483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:34:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:34:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:31:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/olympics/news/15234/13193563/covid-stricken-lyles-misses-out-on-olympic-double-in-200m", "title": "Olympics 2024: Noah Lyles misses out on double gold after falling short in men's 200m final", "body": "Covid-stricken Noah Lyles missed out on an Olympic sprint double after falling short in the men's 200m final in Paris, with Letsile Tebogo of Botswana taking gold and American Kenny Bednarek snapping up silver.\n\nThe world champion at the distance was hoping become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100m and 200m titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100m gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nAfter the race Lyles fell to his back after the loss and eventually sat up to be tended to by medics who rushed out onto the track.\n\nHe was placed in a wheelchair with Lyles later revealing he tested positive for Covid on Tuesday morning and woke up in the middle of the night \"with chills\".\n\nLyles said he quickly quarantined in a hotel, but insisted on competing in the final, although the 27-year-old said the illness had affected his performance.\n\nHe said: \"I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nTebogo led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old Tebogo said.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew when the gun went Kenny was going to run away so make sure just to close him down, I have that top end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"\n\nBednarek, who also won silver in Tokyo, finished in 19.62 and Lyles, four nights after winning an epic 100m, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20m mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120m mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nLyles, who was also issued a yellow card for breaking his starting block, was whisked away to a medical consultation after the race.\n\nIn other news, American Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone broke the women's 400m hurdles world record with a time of 50.37 seconds to retain her Olympic title.\n\nAnna Cockrell of the United States took silver and Dutchwoman Femke Bol claimed bronze.\n\nArshad Nadeem clinched Pakistan's first Olympic medal in athletics in the men's javelin, beating defending champion Neeraj Chopra of India.\n\nNadeem broke the Olympic record on his second throw with a stunning 92.97 metres - the best in the world this year.\n\nChopra, favourite to win, looked off his best form, and 89.45 was also his only valid attempt as he fouled on his five other attempts.\n\nGrenada's Anderson Peters won bronze with 88.54, a redemptive moment for the two-time world champion after he failed to make it to the final at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\nKeep up to date with the action from the Paris 2024 Olympics across Sky Sports digital platforms and Sky Sports News every day between now and Sunday August 11.\n\nAlongside live news blogs and updates as records are broken and medals won on skysports.com and the Sky Sports app, Sky Sports News will also have dedicated reporters on the scene in Paris during the Games to gather the latest news both inside and outside the arenas in France as well as reaction to the big moments from medal winners, coaches, relatives and pundits.", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-448581687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:28:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:28:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:20:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.sfgate.com/olympics/article/noah-lyles-covid-olympics-200-meters-19629286.php", "title": "Noah Lyles' last Olympics race in Paris was a COVID-related spectacle", "body": "All eyes were on the brash American sprinter Noah Lyles as the eight men competing in the Olympic 200-meter final lined up at the start. A little more than 20 seconds later, international focus quickly shifted from the result on Thursday to something that had happened on Tuesday: a positive COVID test.\n\nImmediately after crossing the finish line, Lyles made his way to an area just outside the track and then slowly got on the ground. He had difficulty breathing, and trainers eventually took him to a medical tent in a wheelchair for medical treatment. Within moments of his treatment, it came out that Lyles ran his specialty race with COVID.\n\nNews of the positive COVID test first became public through the BBC, which got confirmation from USA Track and Field and announced it on the network's post-race analysis show. A few minutes later, NBC also reported the positive COVID test after reporter Lewis Johnson ran down to the track in search of answers and spoke to Lyles' mother.\n\nWhile not every COVID diagnosis is the same -- the CDC's guidelines for isolation are to only wait for symptom to improve, and asymptomatic positive tests do happen -- Lyles' illness was reportedly on the more severe side. Speaking with Johnson after finishing treatment, Lyles said that he felt \"really horrible\" early Tuesday and woke up his doctors to get tested. He did not clarify whether his symptoms improved in time for the race, but he did say that while the symptoms affected him, he downplayed what he was going through.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic,\" Lyles said. \"Thinking, 'I've been in worse situations.' I've run with worse conditions, I felt. And we just took it day by day -- trying to hydrate as much [as possible], quarantined off.\"\n\nLyles, beaming with pride at his performance, said he never considered skipping the 200-meter final. The 4x100 meter relay, however, is another story. The 100-meter gold medalist initially told NBC \"I don't know\" when asked if he will compete in the relay, but then added that he was \"feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me.\"\n\nAs with all things COVID, a conspiracy theory emerged almost immediately in the replies to the BBC's social media post announcing the diagnosis. It also doesn't help that Lyles is a lightning rod of online anger because of his outgoing personality, and his infamous \"world champion of what?\" comment after the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\n\"Don't look like he had covid there,\" wrote one Twitter user who posted a video of Lyles jumping around during his pre-race entrance, not realizing there's a difference between jumping for joy and racing against the fastest men on the planet.\n\nWhile it's not clear exactly how Lyles' diagnosis went unknown for two days -- or why the International Olympic Committee or USA Track & Field allowed an asthmatic to race with COVID and expose others to the virus -- it's probably safe to say it's not an elaborate ruse to justify him standing a little lower than expected on the {"uri": "8266093326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:54:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:54:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T23:54:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/article-paris-olympics-us-sprinter-lyles-says-his-paris-run-is-over/", "title": "Paris Olympics: U.S. sprinter Lyles says his Paris run is over", "body": "American Noah Lyles said that his Paris Games are over, hours after he needed medical attention following his shock third-place finish in the 200 metres, when it was revealed he tested positive for COIVD.\n\nLyles turned up the positive test on Tuesday, officials said, two days after he won the 100 metres, and appeared to be in physical distress after Thursday's final in the longer sprint.\n\n\"I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics. It is not the Olympics I dreamed of but it has left me with so much joy in my heart,\" he wrote on Instagram.\n\nParis Olympics: COVID-stricken Noah Lyles finishes third in 200 metres\n\nParis Olympics: Letsile Tebogo wins 200 metres for Botswana's first gold\n\nLyles leaves an Olympic champion but the abrupt end to his campaign was almost certainly a bitter pill to swallow, as he had set the ambitious goal of winning four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay and the 4x400m relay.\n\nIt also marked the triple 200 world champion's first defeat in a 200m final for three years.\n\nThe star of the Netflix docuseries \"SPRINT\" congratulated gold medallist Letsile Tebogo of Botswana and compatriot Kenny Bednarek, who finished second in the 200, and thanked his fans for the messages of support.\n\n\"I hope everyone enjoyed the show,\" Lyles wrote. \"Whether you were rooting for me or against me, you have to admit you watched, didn't you?\"", "source": {"uri": He bested Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by 0.005 seconds in a photo finish to earn \"The Fastest Man in the World\" title and achieve one of his biggest Olympic dreams.\n\nNext up, Lyles will aim for another, as he seeks a gold medal in the 200m race.\n\nThe 200-meter dash may be Lyles' best event. The sprinter has top-tier short-distance speed, but his ability to continue accelerating beyond the first 100 meters makes him an ideal fit for the slightly longer 200-meter race.\n\nIf Lyles can capitalize on his success in the event and win gold during the final, he will write himself into the USA record books. Why? Because he would be one of the only United States runners to ever win \"the double.\"\n\nHere's what to know about \"the double\" and the exclusive list of American men who have earned the world's top honors on the track.\n\n2024 PARIS OLYMPICS\n\nFull Olympics schedule | How to watch in USA | Meet NBC's broadcasters\n\nThe double in track occurs when a runner wins the 100-meter and 200-meter dashes at the same Olympics.\n\nLyles has long established his goal is to earn as many medals as possible at the 2024 Olympics.\n\n\"We're coming after everything,\" Lyles said in February, per NBCOlympics.com. \"All the Olympic medals. I don't care who wants it. It's mine.\"\n\nEven so, the 27-year-old stp knows that winning the 100-meter and 200-meter dashes won't come easily.\n\n\"It's hard to do it once,\" Lyles said of winning a gold medal, per NBC. \"It's incredibly hard to do it twice. If I can do it three times, even four, we're talking about legacy no one would be able to touch, to forever be cemented as a great athlete.\"\n\nLyles has already accomplished half of his goal by winning the 100-meter dash. Now, fans will wait and see if he can show similarly great speed in the 200-meter race, which Lyles has referred to as his \"baby.\"\n\nIf he can win, Lyles would become the first American man to win the Olympic double since 1984.\n\nMORE: How Noah Lyles overcame anxiety, depression to become Olympic gold medalist\n\nCarl Lewis was the last American man to win the double. He did so at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, blazing a 9.99-second 100-meter dash to defeat silver medalist Sam Graddy, who finished 0.2 seconds behind him.\n\nLewis earned four gold medals at the 1984 Summer Games: one in the 100-meter dash, one in the 200-meter dash, one in the 4x400 relay and one from the long jump. He has 10 Olympic medals to his name, including nine gold.\n\nThat makes Lewis one of the most decorated male track stars in the Olympics' century-long history. He's tied with Finland's Paavo Nurmi with the most Olympic gold medals for a male track athlete with nine and trails the Fin by just two medals in the total count overall.\n\nIn total, nine different sprinters have won the double at the Olympics. Only one athlete has achieved the feat since Lewis in 1984. That would be Usain Bolt, the only sprinter to win the event more than once.\n\nBelow is a full breakdown of the Olympic double winners, which dates back to Archie Hahn's two race wins in the 1904 Olympics.\n\nIf Lyles can achieve the double, he will cement himself as one of Team USA's most successful sprinters of all time.\n\nHe may also have a chance to tie the mark for the most gold medals won by a track athlete at a single Olympics, a record that is currently shared by several top USA stars like Lewis and Jesse Owens.\n\nBEST U.S. OLYMPIANS\n\nTop 33 rankings | Simone Biles | Katie Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles said he had COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed around in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLetsile Tebogo, of Botswana, second left, wins the men's 200-meters final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Thursday, Aug. 8, 2024, in Saint-Denis, France. (AP Photo/Martin Meissner)\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time - nothing. {"uri": "8265882045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:03:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:03:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:01:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.news18.com/olympics/paris-2024-botswana-sprinter-letsile-tebogo-scripts-history-with-200m-gold-kenny-bednarek-second-noah-lyles-third-9001741.html", "title": "Paris 2024: Botswana Sprinter Letsile Tebogo Scripts History With 200m Gold, Kenny Bednarek Second, Noah Lyles Third - News18", "body": "Tebogo clocked an African record of 19.46sec to pick up the yellow metal, and was followed home by American Bednarek for a silver in 19.62sec. Newly crowned 100m champion Lyles came in third with a time of 19.70sec to bag the bronze medal.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the Olympic 200 metres on Thursday as he upstaged Noah Lyles' plans for a sprint double in Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, was able to ease up at the end and still clocked an African record of 19.46sec for gold with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62sec and Lyles fading to bronze in 19.70sec.\n\nThe sole African to have won a short sprint title at an Olympic Games is South African Reggie Walker, over 100m at the 1908 Games in London.\n\nHis time saw him leapfrog American Erriyon Knighton to go fifth fastest in the all-time list. The gold was also Botswana's first ever at an Olympics.\n\n\"It was really a beautiful race for me,\" Tebogo said. \"When we made it to the final, my coach just told me, 'Now my job is done, it's up to you to see what you can do. Whether it's a medal or not, just finish the race healthy'.\n\n\"That's all I could've wished for. I'm happy I finished the race healthier than before.\"\n\nTebogo's gold is even more impressive given that he lost his mother Seratiwa in May. His running shoes bear his late mother's date of birth.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" said the sprinter, who took a month off training and competition after her death.\n\n\"It gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy. I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.\"\n\nTebogo added: \"I'm really grateful for the team around me. They really pushed me through thick and thin.\n\n\"We had our ups and downs, but we just made sure that we pulled through and made it to the Olympics.\"\n\nThe final lacked the pre-race hype of the 100m, falling mid-session at a packed Stade de France.\n\nLyles was given a huge reception when introduced as cameras showed him up on the big screens at either end of the stadium.\n\nThe newly crowned 100m champion was drawn in lane five, outside Alexander Ogando and inside American teammate Erriyon Knighton, while Tebogo was in seven.\n\nThe American bounded into the stadium, as he had done before the 100m final, cupping his ear to the crowd, but his exuberant showboating saw him yellow-carded for breaking the starting block.\n\nTebogo, however, walked quietly on and went straight to his blocks.\n\nAfter the gun went for the start, Lyles was quickly up on Ogando.\n\nHe, Tebogo and Bednarek all rounded the bend well, but coming into the home straight, Lyles was in third spot.\n\nBut Tebogo looked in total control, even relaxing as he went through the finish line, making a brushing-off gesture to the rest of the field.\n\nBednarek held on for silver, with Lyles prone on the track after being unable to replicate his gold medal showing in the 100m.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448227394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:32:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:32:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:31:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.sacbee.com/sports/article290872284.html", "title": "Noah Lyles targets 200M gold to complete rare sprint double", "body": "Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Noah Lyles will make his attempt at history Thursday, lining up for the 200-meter final, where he can become just the 10th male Olympian to complete a sprint double.\n\nLyles completed the first leg of the feat by becoming the first American man to win the 100-meter final in 20 years Sunday in Saint-Denis, France. He will aim for his second gold at 2:30 p.m. EDT Thursday at the Stade de France.\n\nThe men's 200-meter final will air on NBC and stream on Peacock and NBCOlympics.com. Lyles remains confident that he will beat the field.\n\n\"None of them are winning,\" Lyles told reporters this week in Saint-Denis. \"When I come off the turn, they will be depressed.\"\n\nArchie Hahn was the first man to complete the double, winning the 100- and 200-meter finals in 1904. Ralph Craig (1912), Eddie Tolan (1932), Jesse Owens (1936), Bobby Morrow (1956) and Carl Lewis (1984) are the other Americans to accomplish the feat. Canada's Percy Williams (1928) and Soviet Valeriy Borzov (1972) also completed Olympic doubles.\n\nJamaican Usain Bolt, widely recognized as the best sprinter in history, completed the double three-consecutive times (2008, 2012, 2016). Owens, Morrow and Lewis also won the 4x100-meter relay finals the same years they completed their doubles. Bolt earned gold in the 4x100 alongside his doubles in 2012 and 2016.\n\nLyles won the 100-meter final by the narrowest of margins, but is a heavy favorite to win the 200 -- his best event.\n\nHis best time in the 200 is an American-record 19.31 seconds, which he posted at the 2022 World Championships. Letsile Tebogo of Botswana and Americans Kenneth Bednarek and Erriyon Knighton are among the other expected contenders in Thursday's Olympic final.\n\nTebogo posted the fastest time (19.96) in the semifinal round for the 200. Bednarek (20.00) and Lyles (20.08) clocked the respective second and third fastest semifinal times. Bednarek also clocked a 19.96 in the first round of qualifying.\n\nCanada's Andre De Grasse, who failed to qualify for Thursday's final, won the event with a time of 19.62 at Tokyo 2020. {"uri": "8265869544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:51:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:51:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:50:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/08/08/2024/tebogo-upstages-lyles-to-become-first-african-to-win-olympic-200m", "title": "Tebogo upstages Lyles to become first African to win Olympic 200m", "body": "Paris: Botswana's Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the Olympic 200 metres on Thursday as he upstaged US's Noah Lyles' plans for a sprint double in Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, was able to ease up at the end and still clocked an African record of 19.46sec for gold with American Kenny Bednarek taking silver in 19.62sec and Lyles fading to bronze in 19.70sec.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo crosses the finish line to win the men's 200m final of the athletics event at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at Stade de France in Saint-Denis, north of Paris, on August 8, 2024. (Photo by Odd Andersen / AFP)\n\nThe sole African to have won a short sprint title at an Olympic Games is South African Reggie Walker, over 100m at the 1908 Games in London.\n\nThe final lacked the pre-race hype of the 100m, falling mid-session at a packed Stade de France.\n\nLyles was given a huge reception when introduced as cameras showed him up on the big screens at either end of the stadium.\n\nThe newly crowned 100m champion was drawn in lane five, outside Alexander Ogando and inside American teammate Erriyon Knighton, while Tebogo was in seven.\n\nGold medallist Botswana's Letsile Tebogo holds his shoe reading the date of birth of his late mother as he celebrates after wining the men's 200m final of the athletics event at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at Stade de France in Saint-Denis, north of Paris, on August 8, 2024. (Photo by Jewel Samad / AFP)\n\nThe American bounded into the stadium, as he had done before the 100m final, cupping his ear to the crowd.\n\nTebogo, however, walked quietly on and went straight to his blocks.\n\nAfter the gun went for the start, Lyles was quickly up on Ogando.\n\nHe, Tebogo and Bednarek all rounded the bend well, but coming into the home straight, Lyles was in third spot.\n\nTebogo looked in total control, even relaxing as he went through the finish line, making a brushing-off gesture with his hand on his sky blue vest.\n\nBednarek held on for silver, with Lyles prone on the track after being unable to replicate his gold medal showing in the 100m.", "source": {"uri": "thepeninsulaqatar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Peninsula"}, "authors": [],
