{"uri": "8265906198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:23:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:23:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:22:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://cbs58.com/news/american-sprinter-noah-lyles-says-he-tested-positive-for-covid-19-ran-200-meter-race-anyway", "title": "American sprinter Noah Lyles says he tested positive for Covid-19, ran 200-meter race anyway", "body": "By David Close, Kyle Feldscher and Amanda Davies, CNN\n\nSaint-Denis, France (CNN) -- American sprinter Noah Lyles has confirmed that he tested positive for Covid-19 earlier this week and ran in Thursday night's 200-meter race anyway.\n\nIn an interview with US Olympic broadcaster NBC, Lyles said he felt really horrible when he woke up Tuesday morning and has been hydrating while in quarantine.\n\n\"I woke up early about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was just feeling really horrible, and I knew it was more than just being sore from the (100-meter race),\" Lyles told NBC. \"I woke up the doctors and we tested, and unfortunately, it came out that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nHe added, \"My first thought was not to panic, you know, I'm thinking I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions, I felt.\"\n\nLyles said he was proud of his performance, despite having Covid.\n\n\"We just took it day-by-day trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off. I definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure,\" he said, \"but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympics I was very disappointed, and this time, I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nThe news of Lyles' positive test came not long after he suffered a stunning defeat in the men's 200-meter race, his signature event. Lyles finished in third, unable to overcome Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and his Team USA compatriot Kenneth Bednarek, who finished in first and second place, respectively.\n\nHowever, the result of the race was quickly bumped from the headlines when Lyles laid down on the track immediately following his crossing the finish line. He was helped off the track by medical personnel in a wheelchair and taken to the medical holding area.\n\n\"I've had better days, but I'm walking around again,\" Lyles told reporters afterward. \"I was quite light-headed after that race. Shortness of breath, chest pain, but after a while, I could catch my breath and get my wits about me. I'm a lot better now.\"\n\nIt's a truly shocking turn of events for Lyles, who was hoping to win at least three gold medals at these Olympics. He took the 100-meter race on Sunday by the thinnest of margins and expressed nothing but confidence in his ability to deliver in the 200m and later on in the team relay.\n\nHe appeared to be full of his usual energy when he made his entrance for the race, bounding out of the tunnel to pump up the crowd and jumping around the track.\n\n\"I already had a bunch of energy. This is by far the best day I've felt out of the last three days. Still not 100%, but closer to 90 to 95%. That only works for one shot. I got to settle down for a while. It's one and done, there's no holding back.\"\n\nHe said that he felt like the infection affected his performance, saying, \"I've had to take a lot of breaks. ... I was coughing through the night. I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out here to get a bronze with Covid.\"\n\nKate Hartman, the chief external affairs officer for the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee, said in a statement that the group supports Lyles' decision to compete.\n\nAfter Lyles' positive test, she said, \"The USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nLyles told reporters that few people were aware of his diagnosis.\n\n\"We were trying to keep this close to the chest. The people who knew were the medical staff, coach, my mom,\" he said. \"We didn't want everybody going into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete. We wanted to make this as free as possible. I'm competitive. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nHe added that it is unclear if he'll participate as planned in the men's 4x100m on Saturday.\n\n\"We haven't decided yet, I'm going to talk to the 4x100m crew,\" he said. \"I'm going to be very honest and transparent with the coaches, and I'll let them make the decision. No matter what happens, this 4x100m team can handle everything. I've been with them in practice, I know they can come out with a win, break as many records as they put their mind to.\"\n\nCovid-19 has still made its unfortunate presence known at these Paris Games as Lyles is far from the only athlete to test positive for the virus during the Olympics.\n\nFive players on Australia's women's water polo team and Team GB swimmer Adam Peaty tested positive for Covid-19 last week.\n\nAlthough the world is no longer under a public health emergency due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the Olympic Games come as a wave of Covid-19 infections has hit the United States; even President Joe Biden recently tested positive for the disease.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that, if you test positive for Covid-19, you stay home until you are fever-free without the help of fever-reducing medications for at least 24 hours and your symptoms have been improving for 24 hours. It then recommends wearing a mask around other people for the next five days.\n\nSeparate public health guidance for travelers attending the 2024 Summer Olympic and Paralympic Games was released last week by the World Health Organization, the French Ministry of Health and Prevention, Sant\u00e9 publique France and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.\n\nThe guidance recommends checking your vaccination status against common infectious diseases including measles, whooping cough, polio and Covid-19.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "2024-08-448619623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:29:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:29:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:52:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/not-meant-to-be/article_a00588cd-117b-5dad-b6ce-14440890e949.html", "title": "Not meant to be", "body": "Letsile Tebogo, of Botswana, second left, wins the men's 200-meter final in Saint-Denis, France.\n\nASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask, Lyles told reporters he had COVID but decided to compete anyway.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed on the ground trying to catch his breath. He got to one knee and stayed there for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely was an effect,\" Lyles said. \"But I mean, to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything for coming out and getting the bronze medal with COVID.\"\n\nLyles said he tested positive early Tuesday morning and quickly got into quarantine.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" he said. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nWaterloo residents have more than 1,000 signatures on petition to put high school plan on the ballot Teen charged in vape purchase gone wrong after attacking store clerk Man charged after trade-in vehicle in truck sale repossessed Downtown Waterloo bridges opening delayed until fall, no pedestrian use until 2025 Autistic man accused of breaking into co-worker's home to plant letter, smear boyfriend Pablo's Mexican Grill marking 20 years on Main Street in downtown Cedar Falls Clear Lake teen dies in two-vehicle crash Monday afternoon Man sentenced to prison in shooting that paralyzed robbery victim Lawsuit by man paralyzed in Waterloo officer-involved shooting thrown out Waterloo cleaning woman sentenced to probation for burglary, forgery Group effort: Cedar Valley Woodworkers build 17-foot desk for Waterloo library 2024 Courier Male Athlete of the Year: Jesup's Jack Miller Helicopter crashed near Nashua after striking powerlines, killing pilot Cedar Falls City Council to consider items related to more planned roundabouts STEVE CORBIN: Economists say Trump poses a threat to US economy\n\nThe U.S. track federation released a statement saying it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" the statement said. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nThe men's 4x100 relay is set for Friday, and Lyles was expected to run the anchor leg in what many thought would be a quest for a third gold medal in Paris. He said he would talk to his teammates and come to a decision.\n\n\"I want to be very honest and transparent, and I'm going to let them make the decision,\" Lyles said, describing himself as being at around 90 or 95%.\n\nIn the 200, Tebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine.\n\nIt became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nMore gold\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters on her fourth jump to capture the gold medal and join the likes of Tiana Bartoletta, Brittney Reese and the great Jackie Joyner-Kersee as Americans to win that event.\n\nGrant Holloway of the U.S. cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss. He won the world championship in 2019, 2022 and 2023. American teammate Daniel Roberts took silver.\n\nA javelin gold for Pakistan, and silver for India\n\nPakistan's Arshad Nadeem put together the best meet of his life in winning the men's javelin at Stade de France.\n\nNadeem set a new Olympic record in winning gold. His throw of 92.97 meters in his second attempt smashed the old mark of 90.57 set by Andreas Thorkildsen of Norway in 2008.\n\nIndia's Neeraj Chopra, the 2020 Olympic champion, took silver at 89.45 meters, a season best.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that And shortly after that, he was also seen being wheeled out in a wheelchair with Olympic medical staff surrounding him.\n\nAs it turns out, Lyles has COVID.\n\nThat certainly throws quite a wrench into things. Here's everything we know about the track star's diagnoses so far.\n\nYes, apparently so. He was diagnosed with COVID two days ago. He confirmed his diagnosis with reporters after the race.\n\nHe said he kept it \"close to the vest\" and didn't want competitors to know he was ill. The signs were there. Lyles had been wearing a mask and quarantining leading up to the race.\n\nTechnically, there is no COVID protocol for the 2024 Paris Olympics. Athletes are not being barred from competing if they get the virus.\n\nChief medical officer of the Olympics, Jon Finnoff, said Team USA is following the CDC guidelines for all infectious disease protocols, USA Today's Carrie McDonald reports.\n\nLyles isn't the only athlete at the Games with COVID. At least 40 athletes have tested positive so far, according to Yahoo! Sports.\n\nHe definitely didn't look it after the race. Photograph: Fabrizio Bensch/Reuters\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo set the fastest time in the men's Olympic 200 metres semi-finals on Wednesday, proving his intent to upset American Noah Lyles's quest for a sprint double.\n\nTebogo, last year's World Championships bronze medallist, overtook the American 100 metres champion on the bend and cruised the rest of the way unchallenged to finish in 19.96 seconds.\n\nThe 27-year-old Lyles had to work hard to finish second in 20.08s.\n\nAmericans Kenny Bednarek, Olympic silver medallist in Tokyo, and Erriyon Knighton each won their semi-finals, Bednarek clocking 20.00 and the 20-year-old Knighton crossing in 20.09.\n\nRounding out the field for Thursday's final are Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic, Joseph Fahnbulleh of Liberia, and Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba.\n\nLyles, the three-times reigning World champion over what has always been his stronger event, has not lost over the distance since he had to settle for bronze at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nHis run on Wednesday, however, was reminiscent of his sluggish 100m semi-final after which he reached out to his therapist for guidance. He came out two hours later and electrified the crowd by winning the most competitive men's 100m in Olympic history.\n\nIMAGE: Noah Lyles reacts after finishing behind Letsile Tebogo in second place. Photograph: Sarah Meyssonnier/Reuters\n\nLyles did not stop to speak to reporters, heading straight to see medical experts, a USA Track and Field spokesperson said.\n\nHe is looking to become the first American in four decades to win the Olympic sprint double and is aiming for potentially four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay, and -- if he is selected in the squad -- the 4x400m relay.\n\nCanada's defending champion Andre de Grasse, the last man to beat Lyles in a competitive race over the distance, did not advance to the final.\n\n\"I reactivated a lingering issue in my hamstring,\" De Grasse said. \"It was going to be tough today. I knew I had to go out there and try to do my best and see what I can come up with.\n\n\"It's tough. It's been a tough 24, 48 hours. {"uri": "8265838266", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:25:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:25:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:19:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13725087/Olympics-Athletics-Tebogo-wins-200-metres-Botswanas-gold.html", "title": "Olympics-Athletics-Botswana's Tebogo becomes Africa's first 200m...", "body": "Tebogo takes historic gold for Africa\n\n*\n\nDouble-chasing Lyles settles for bronze again\n\n*\n\nBednarek takes second successive silver\n\n(Adds detail, quotes)\n\nBy Mitch Phillips\n\nPARIS, Aug 8 (Reuters) -\n\nLetsile Tebogo became the first African to win the men's Olympic 200 metres title on Thursday when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 when finishing sixth in the Paris 100m final, produced a dominant last 50 metres and crossed the line in 19.46 seconds beating his chest as he become the fifth-fastest man in history over 200m.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, who had been hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, repeating his Tokyo bronze in 19.67.\n\nIt was the triple world champion's first defeat in a 200m final for three years. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race, U.S. officials said he had COVID, putting his participation in Friday's sprint relay final in serious doubt.\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against his name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box.\n\nLyles might still hog the limelight, but it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three places in the final, Tebogo\u00b4s place on top of the podium was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old told reporters.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew when the gun went Kenny was going to run away so make sure just to close him down, I have that top end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"\n\n(Reporting by Mitch Phillips, editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448652547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "23:38:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T23:38:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://omaha.com/ap/sports/paris-olympics-day-13-covid-hit-lyles-misses-out-on-a-double-us-team-breaks/article_d4581fe1-3d74-54dd-b103-f821f87e06c2.html", "title": "Paris Olympics Day 13: COVID-hit Lyles misses out on a double, US team breaks 100-medal mark", "body": "PARIS (AP) --\n\nhe first sign of trouble Thursday night came when Noah Lyles started rounding the curve in the Olympic final of the 200 meters -- the sprint that has always been his best race.\n\nNormally at the curve, Lyles starts making up ground, then pulling away from what have been, for the last three years, game but overmatched contenders.\n\nThis time, his momentum stalled. Instead of Lyles reeling in the runner two lanes to his right, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, Tebogo pulled farther way. The American favorite, who had gone three years without losing in the 200, labored into the finish and ended up in third.\n\nThe insidious specter of COVID, the killer virus that upended the globe four years ago and made the last Olympics part of its collateral damage, struck at the Paris Games, too.\n\nIn a bracing reminder that the virus is still very much a factor, even if its deadly fingerprint has been blunted, the world's marquee sprinter racing on the world's biggest sports stage revealed he had tested positive two days before his shocking, but now not-inexplicable, bronze-medal finish in the 200.\n\n\"I still wanted to run,\" Lyles said, wearing a mask, as he spoke to reporters, whose mere congregation in a jam-packed scrum underneath the stadium was unthinkable three years ago. \"They said it was possible.\"\n\nWith the blessing of officials at USA Track and Field and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee, who said they followed protocol, Lyles did run.\n\nHe finished in 19.70 -- .39 off his personal-best, and .24 behind the 21-year-old Tebogo. Lyles' U.S. teammate Kenny Bednarek finished second, marking the second straight Olympics in which he and Lyles finished 2-3.\n\n\"When I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far, far away behind us,\" Tebogo said. \"So that means I'm the Olympic champion.\"\n\nIt was Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone vs her own world record\n\nAn hour after that shock, Americans Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone lowered her world record for the sixth time, finishing the 400-meter hurdles in 50.37 seconds for another Olympic blowout.\n\nThat was one of three gold medals and eight overall the U.S. won on a night filled with big events.\n\nTara Davis-Woodhall jumped 7.10 meters to capture the long jump and get in the Olympic win column next to some greats, including Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Brittney Reese.\n\nGrant Holloway cruised to gold in the 110 hurdles, claiming the Olympic title that eluded him three years ago in his only major-championship loss.\n\nxxxxxxxxxxxxxx\n\nSprinter Noah Lyles revealed he had COVID-19 after missing out on another gold medal for the United States at the Paris Olympics on Thursday.\n\nElsewhere, French basketball star Victor Wembanyama moved closer to his dream of a first gold after helping Les Bleus beat Germany to set up a dream final against the U.S. team after the Americans edged Serbia 95-91.\n\nOn the same Stade de France track where he won the historically close 100 meters by five thousandths of a second, Lyles was third behind gold medalist Letsile Tebogo of Botswana and U.S. teammate Kenneth Bednarek.\n\nMedics tended to a tired-looking Lyles and took him off in a wheelchair. Wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles later said he had COVID.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" said Lyles, adding that he tested positive early Tuesday morning but was cleared to compete. The U.S. track federation said it and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee adhered to all Olympic and Centers for Disease Control guidelines.\n\nOver at Bercy Arena, with former NBA stars Dirk Nowitzki and Tony Parker watching their respective countrymen, France held on to win 73-69.\n\nWembanyama, the NBA rookie of the year, clenched his fists at the buzzer and teammate Evan Fournier jubilantly threw the ball into the crowd.\n\nThe 20-year-old star didn't play three years ago in Tokyo, when the French lost the final to the U.S. They meet again Saturday, when Wembanyama hopes to give France its first Olympic gold in men's or women's basketball.\n\nHighlights of what happened on Day 13 of the Paris Olympics:\n\nCurry leads semifinal fightback against Serbia\n\nThey scored six points in two seconds. And just like that, against what looked like overwhelming odds, the U.S. Olympic men's basketball team was on its way.\n\nTo a comeback. To a win. And to another Olympic gold medal game.\n\nStephen Curry scored 36 points, including a go-ahead 3-pointer with 2:16 left, and the U.S. will play for gold in the Paris Olympics on Saturday night after beating Serbia 95-91. LeBron James had the fourth triple-double in Olympic history for the U.S., which trailed by 17 points in the first half and faced an 11-point halftime deficit -- the biggest one successfully overcome by an American team since NBA players were added to the Olympic mix in 1992.\n\n\"I've seen a lot of Team USA basketball,\" Curry said. \"And that was a special one.\"\n\nSerbia led by 11 with 7:19 left. The rest of the way, it was all U.S. The Americans won a game where they led for 3 minutes, 25 seconds. Serbia led for 35:12 -- nearly 90% of the game.\n\nBut it'll be the U.S. against host France for gold in a dream matchup for the host nation on Saturday, while Serbia will face Germany earlier Saturday for bronze. The gold-medal game is a rematch from the Tokyo Games three years ago, where the Americans prevailed 87-82.\n\n\"I'm really humbled to have been a part of this game,\" U.S. coach Steve Kerr said, tipping his hat multiple times to Serbia. \"It's one of the greatest basketball games I've ever been a part of. They were perfect. They played a perfect game. Our coaches were saying, Villanova-Georgetown, for all of our older readers and viewers out there.\n\n\"But they played the perfect game, and they forced us to reach the highest level of competition that we could find. And our guys were incredible in that fourth quarter, and they got it done.\"\n\nJoel Embiid scored 19 points on 8 for 11 shooting and James added 16 points, 12 rebounds and 10 assists for the U.S., which is now assured of its 20th medal in 20 Olympic appearances.\n\n\"Joel was everything,\" said James, who has two of the four triple-doubles in Olympic men's history; he also had one in 2012, while the Soviet Union's Aleksander Belov in 1976 and Slovenia's Luka Doncic in 2021 had the others. \"Made every big shot.\"\n\nBogdan Bogdanovic scored 20 points for Serbia, which got 17 from Nikola Jokic and 15 from Aleksa Avramovic. The Serbians were 0-3 against the U.S. this summer, getting blown out in the first two meetings and then looking poised for a win of their own on Thursday.\n\nThe whole game changed in the fourth after a wild sequence saw the U.S. score six points in two seconds. Kevin Durant made a 3-pointer while Anthony Davis was getting fouled. The U.S. got another possession, and off the inbounds Devin Booker made another 3-pointer.\n\nJust like that, a 78-67 lead for Serbia was down to 78-73. The comeback was on, and Curry's 3 put the U.S. up for good. He added a pair of free throws with 8.2 seconds left to make it a two-possession game and the Americans escaped.\n\nCurry's 36 points were the second-most in a game by a U.S. men's player in Olympic history, one shy of Carmelo Anthony's record 37 against Nigeria in 2012. And Anthony, sitting courtside, was Curry's biggest cheerleader. When the Americans tied it with about 3:35 left, Curry gave Anthony a big smile. When the go-ahead 3 rattled home, Anthony leaped from his seat. And when it was over, the two shared a long embrace.\n\n\"That was a godlike performance,\" Durant said of Curry.\n\nSerbia coach Svetislav Petic kept saying the same thing all summer, that the team the U.S. put together for the Paris Games was better than any in Olympic history. Even the Dream Team, he insisted. His mind wasn't changed after this one.\n\n\"They're that good,\" he said.\n\nA barrage of Serbian 3-pointers had the Americans squarely on the ropes, until the game changed in the fourth. But in the end, the U.S. improved to 144-6 all-time in Olympic play, 63-4 since NBA players were added to the Olympics in 1992.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Perseverance, hard work dedication, Chef Curry and Joel 'Process' Embiid,\" James said. \"Big-time win for us. We knew we were going to be challenged. We knew it was going to be the toughest game to date. Total effort.\"\n\nThe comeback kept Durant's hopes of becoming the first four-time Olympic men's gold medalist very much alive, and gave the U.S. a chance to return to the international basketball mountaintop. The Americans were fourth at the World Cup last summer, a result that spurred some NBA stars like James and Curry to be part of this team.\n\nAnd of all the U.S. semifinal moments, this was like few others. The four-point final margin was the second closest in American history in the Olympic semifinals; the U.S. beat Lithuania by two in the 2000 semifinals in Sydney, on the way to gold there.\n\nThey're one win away from another.\n\n\"I'm 39 years old, going into my 22nd season, I don't know how many opportunities and moments I'm going to get like this to compete for something, compete for something big and play in big games,\" James said. \"And tonight was a big game.\"\n\nUS team gets a world record, breaks the 100-medal mark\n\nThe United States now has more golds and more overall medals than any other nation.\n\nWith three days left of competition, American athletes total 30 golds for 103 medals overall.\n\nThe U.S. went 1-2 in the women's 400 hurdles with Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone breaking her own world record in a time of 50.37 seconds, and Anna Cockrell taking the silver.\n\nGrant Holloway followed up with gold in the men's 110 hurdles in 12.99, beating countryman Daniel Roberts.\n\nAlso, Long jumper Tara Davis-Woodhall won the women's long jump with Jasmine Moore taking the bronze behind Germany's Malaika Mihambo.\n\nChina's diving double ends with tears\n\nChina claimed its sixth gold medal in diving at the Paris Games with defending champion Xie Siyi winning the 3-meter springboard.\n\nThe Chinese made it a podium 1-2 as Wang Zongyuan took the silver ahead of Mexico's Osmar Olvera Ibarra.\n\nWang was in tears afterward.\n\nHe hadn't lost a major diving competition in the event since finishing behind teammate Xie at the Tokyo Olympics. After that silver, Wang won three straight world championship titles.\n\n\"It is regrettable I lost,\" Wang said through an interpreter. \"I must learn to accept any failure and my response is to make a greater effort to improve myself.\"\n\nAnother world record but no gold\n\nAmerican Sam Watson left the Games with another world record to his name but didn't get the gold medal.\n\nThe 18-year-old Watson broke sport climbing's speed world record on Thursday for the second time at the Paris Games, but that came in the fight for bronze.\n\nVeddriq Leonardo of Indonesia won gold in 4.75 seconds in the final.\n\nCharron lifts for another medal\n\nMaude Charron raised Canada's flag at the opening ceremony for the Paris Games and lifted up another medal in weightlifting.\n\nCharron took the silver medal in the 59-kilogram category to add to her gold in the 64-kilogram competition at the Tokyo Games.\n\nRahimi stars as Morocco gets bronze\n\nSoccer-mad Morocco fans finally have an Olympic medal to celebrate after routing African rival Egypt 6-0 for the bronze.\n\nSoufiane Rahimi scored twice and the Casablanca-born striker will surely become a household name back home after netting an impressive eight goals in the tournament.\n\nHe was comfortably the leading scorer ahead of Friday's final between Spain and 1984 Olympic champion France.\n\nMorocco won the African Cup of Nations title in 1976.\n\nDutch end long wait for gold in men's field hockey\n\nDuco Telgenkamp scored the golden goal in the shootout to give the Netherlands a 2-1 victory over Germany.\n\nIt was the Netherlands' first gold in men's hockey at the Olympics since 2000 and third in the country's history.\n\nCaptain Harmanpreet Singh scored both goals as India beat Spain 2-1 for a second straight bronze, after beating Germany at the Tokyo Games.\n\nFrench get gold, Portugal a rare medal\n\nTrack cyclist Benjamin Thomas overcame a crash in the men's omnium race to give France its 14th gold medal of the Paris Games.\n\nThomas held off I\u00fari Leit\u00e3o, whose silver medal was only Portugal's second medal so far -- compared to 54 for the French.\n\nAlso, world champion Ellesse Andrews of New Zealand won the Olympic title in the women's keirin.\n\nNadeem gets Pakistan's first medal with an Olympic record\n\nArshad Nadeem got Pakistan's first medal of the Paris Games in style by setting an Olympic record in javelin.\n\nNadeem's throw of 92.97 meters beat Norwegian Andreas Thorkildsen's mark of 90.57 from the 2008 Games in Beijing.\n\nPlain sailing for Austria\n\nIn the southern port city of Marseille, Lara Vadlau and Lukas Maehr of Austria won gold in a tight race in the mixed-gender dinghy.\n\nThe sport became a new sailing category at these Games.\n\nAP Olympics: The 27-year-old Lyles had to work hard to finish second in 20.08.\n\nAmericans Kenny Bednarek, Olympic silver medallist in Tokyo, and Erriyon Knighton each won their semi-finals, Bednarek clocking 20.00 and the 20-year-old Knighton crossing in 20.09.\n\nRounding out the field for Thursday's final are Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic, Joseph Fahnbulleh of Liberia, and Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba.\n\nLyles, the three-time reigning world champion over what has always been his stronger event, has not lost over the distance since he had to settle for bronze at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nHis run on Wednesday, however, was reminiscent of his sluggish 100m semi-final after which he reached out to his therapist for guidance. He came out two hours later and electrified the crowd by winning the most competitive men's 100m in Olympic history.\n\nLyles is looking to become the first American in four decades to win the Olympic sprint double. He is aiming for potentially four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay, and -- if he is selected in the squad -- the 4x400m relay.\n\nCanada's defending champion Andre de Grasse, the last man to beat Lyles in a competitive race over the distance, did not advance to the final. 2008, 2012 and 2016 Olympics.\n\nBut Lyles, who clocked the third-fastest 200m time with a sizzling 19.31 second sprint, is bullish about his chances.\n\n\"I know that I'm going to break it,\" Lyles said in an interview in 2023.\n\n\"The second-most popular, favourite hobby of humans - {"uri": "8265865740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:58:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:58:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:46:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://keyt.com/sports/national-sports/cnn-sports/2024/08/08/american-sprinter-noah-lyles-says-he-tested-positive-for-covid-19-ran-200-meter-race-anyway/", "title": "American sprinter Noah Lyles says he tested positive for Covid-19, ran 200-meter race anyway", "body": "By David Close, Kyle Feldscher and Amanda Davies, CNN\n\nSaint-Denis, France (CNN) -- American sprinter Noah Lyles has confirmed that he tested positive for Covid-19 earlier this week and ran in Thursday night's 200-meter race anyway.\n\nIn an interview with US Olympic broadcaster NBC, Lyles said he felt really horrible when he woke up Tuesday morning and has been hydrating while in quarantine.\n\n\"I woke up early about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was just feeling really horrible, and I knew it was more than just being sore from the (100-meter race),\" Lyles told NBC. \"I woke up the doctors and we tested, and unfortunately, it came out that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nHe added, \"My first thought was not to panic, you know, I'm thinking I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions, I felt.\"\n\nLyles said he was proud of his performance, despite having Covid.\n\n\"We just took it day-by-day trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off. I definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure,\" he said, \"but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympics I was very disappointed, and this time, I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nThe news of Lyles' positive test came not long after he suffered a stunning defeat in the men's 200-meter race, his signature event. Lyles finished in third, unable to overcome Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and his Team USA compatriot Kenneth Bednarek, who finished in first and second place, respectively.\n\nHowever, the result of the race was quickly bumped from the headlines when Lyles laid down on the track immediately following his crossing the finish line. He was helped off the track by medical personnel in a wheelchair and taken to the medical holding area.\n\nIt's a truly shocking turn of events for Lyles, who was hoping to win at least three gold medals at these Olympics. He took the 100-meter race on Sunday by the thinnest of margins and expressed nothing but confidence in his ability to deliver in the 200m and later on in the team relay.\n\nKate Hartman, the chief external affairs officer for the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee, said in a statement that the group supports Lyles' decision to compete.\n\nAfter Lyles' positive test, she said, \"The USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nCovid-19 has still made its unfortunate presence known at these Paris Games as Lyles is far from the only athlete to test positive for the virus during the Olympics.\n\nFive players on Australia's women's water polo team and Team GB swimmer Adam Peaty tested positive for Covid-19 last week.\n\nAlthough the world is no longer under a public health emergency due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the Olympic Games come as a wave of Covid-19 infections has hit the United States; even President Joe Biden recently tested positive for the disease.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that, if you test positive for Covid-19, you stay home until you are fever-free without the help of fever-reducing medications for at least 24 hours and your symptoms have been improving for 24 hours. It then recommends wearing a mask around other people for the next five days.\n\nSeparate public health guidance for travelers attending the 2024 Summer Olympic and Paralympic Games was released last week by the World Health Organization, the French Ministry of Health and Prevention, Sant\u00e9 publique France and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.\n\nThe guidance recommends checking your vaccination status against common infectious diseases including measles, whooping cough, polio and Covid-19.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8261114813", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "04:40:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T04:40:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T04:39:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/olympics/story/paris-olympics-2024-athletics-noah-lyles-sprint-double-bid-continues-eases-through-200m-heat-2577555-2024-08-06", "title": "Paris Olympics: Noah Lyles sprint double bid continues, eases through 200m heat", "body": "Lyles finished 200m heat in 20.19 secondsLyles said he felt good being on the trackLyles is aiming to win both 100 m and 200 m golds in Paris\n\nLess than 24 hours after clinching gold in the 100 meters, Noah Lyles continued his pursuit of the prestigious Olympic sprint double by effortlessly advancing through his 200m heat on Monday with a time of 20.19 seconds. The American sprinter, who excels in the 200m, remains unbeaten in 25 races over this distance since earning bronze at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. Lyles has also secured the last three world titles in the event.\n\nLyles aims to achieve an ambitious goal of winning four gold medals in Paris, targeting the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay, and possibly the 4x400m relay. Such a feat would place him alongside legendary compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who each won four golds in a single Games, though their fourth medals came in the long jump rather than the longer relay.\n\nParis Olympics 2024: India Schedule | Full Coverage | Medal Tally\n\n\"It feels good to be out here,\" Lyles told reporters. \"It was in my head win the 120, win the 150, check around, win the heat.\"\n\nDefending champion Andre de Grasse of Canada, the last sprinter to beat Lyles, followed closely behind, finishing in 20.30 seconds. American Kenny Bednarek, who secured silver ahead of Lyles in Tokyo and was runner-up to him at the 2022 World Championships, posted the fastest time of the heats with 19.96 seconds despite easing up before the finish. Bednarek also competed in Sunday's 100m final, where his time of 9.88 seconds placed him seventh.\n\nErriyon Knighton, who has previously won world championship silver and bronze medals as a teenager, ensured a strong American presence in the semi-finals by winning his heat in 19.99 seconds, the only other sub-20 time of the evening. Now 20, Knighton is eager to make his mark on the Olympic stage after years of being touted as the next big star.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 seconds while finishing sixth in Sunday's 100m final and claimed bronze in the 200m at last year's World Championships, comfortably won his heat in 20.10 seconds. Wayde van Niekerk, the 400m world record holder and former world championship silver medallist in the 200m, advanced as the third automatic qualifier from the first heat with a time of 20.42 seconds, {"uri": "8265903855", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:22:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:22:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:20:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.nbcdfw.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/olympian-noah-lyles-leaves-track-in-wheelchair-after-covid-diagnosis-heres-what-we-know/3616326/", "title": "Team USA's Noah Lyles leaves track in wheelchair after winning bronze", "body": "Lyles' mother said her son has COVID-19 but opted to compete anyway.\n\n\"Fastest man in the world\" Noah Lyles was taken from the track in a wheelchair Thursday after winning a bronze medal in the men's 200-meter final at the 2024 Olympics in Paris.\n\nLyles was diagnosed with COVID-19 two days prior, but opted to run anyway.\n\nAfter securing a bronze medal, the Olympian was struggling to walk so he laid down on the track where he appeared to be breathing heavily. He left the arena in a wheelchair and received medical attention before returning the track and speaking with reporters.\n\nAccording to Lyles' mother, he was diagnosed with COVID on Tuesday, Aug. 6.\n\nNBC Olympics' Lewis Johnson reported on the track broadcast that Lyles' mother confirmed the COVID diagnosis.\n\n\"I ran into his mom Keisha Caine Bishop who was distraught trying to find him as well,\" Johnson said. \"We found Noah Lyles in medical, they're being tended to and she did confirm that Noah had been diagnosed with COVID two days ago.\"\n\nSeveral minutes later, Lyles spoke to Johnson during his broadcast.\n\n\"Yeah, I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I just was feeling really horrible. I knew it was more than just being sore from the [100m race]. Woke up the doctor's, and we tested, and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for COVID. My first thought was not to panic, thinking, 'I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions,'\" he said.\n\nLyles previously said he has asthma, which the CDC has said can put people \"at increased risk for getting very sick from COVID-19.\n\nWhile it is still to be determined if he'll return to the competition, Lyles is slated to run in the men's 4x100m relay race on Friday.\n\nSo far, at least 40 athletes have tested positive for COVID at the Paris Olympics, according to a report from the TODAY Show.\n\nThe U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee told TODAY.com that it has the following protocols in place to reduce the risk of COVID among Team USA athletes:\n\n\"We implemented an infection prevention program prior to the Games ('Don't let a cold keep you from the gold') that encouraged athletes to wash their hands, wear face masks when indoors during their travel from the US to Paris, etc.\n\n\"If they have an infectious disease, we will set them up with the indicated treatment/medications, and provide them with a private room so they don't have to worry about getting their roommate sick.\n\n\"We will help with transportation so they aren't in a bus with other athletes, and we will deliver their meals.\n\n\"We will have them wear a mask anytime they are inside and around other people.\n\n\"We will allow them to train and compete as long as they feel up to it.\"\n\nThe CDC issued the following statement on its website regarding the 2024 Olympics:\n\n\"Mass gatherings are associated with unique health risks, including an increased risk for respiratory illnesses. {"uri": "8265934058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:54:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:54:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:50:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13725431/USAs-gold-medal-favorite-collapses-taking-bronze-200m.html", "title": "USA's gold medal favorite collapses after taking bronze in 200m", "body": "Noah Lyles ran the men's 200m final with Covid and needed to be wheeled out of the Stade de France after finishing third in the race - but said afterwards that he has never been prouder of himself. NBC said they spoke to Lyles' mom, who confirmed he had the virus before the athlete himself spoke out. He said he had no regrets over competing, despite the inevitable risk of spreading the virus to other athletes, who he hugged and shook hands with after the race.\n\nThe USA star told NBC, masked up: 'I woke up early about 5am Tuesday morning, feeling really horrible. I knew it was more than being sore from the 100. My first thought was not to panic, I've ben in worse situations, I've been in worse conditions. 'I took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much. It would say it has taken its toll, for sure, but I have never been more proud of myself coming out here and getting a bronze.' He was asked by Lewis Johnson if he considered withdrawing and gave an emphatic response: 'No. No. We just said we were going to quarantine as much as possible and not try and pass it on.'\n\nLyles did admit the virus could force him out of USA's 4x100m relay on Friday. 'At the moment I don't know, I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing,' he said. 'They have proven they can handle it without me.' Michael Johnson questioned Lyles' decision to go ahead and compete, saying on the BBC: 'Very bizarre, Covid is still a dangerous disease. It is just bizarre, the whole thing is really weird. 'There is going to be all of this thing with the Noah haters out there - and he set himself up for it - there are going to be people out there saying it's not real and he's faking or whatever.\n\n'But putting that aside, having Covid and still coming out here and being in close proximity with other people - I know there probably is not a policy I guess at these Games for that - but morally I'm not sure about it.' There are no rules that force athletes to withdraw from events, with all Covid protocols dropped for the Paris Games. Moments earlier, NBC's Johnson revealed Lyles' condition: 'We saw Noah being taken off there in a wheelchair. I ran into his mom who was distraught.'\n\n'She did confirm that Noah had been diagnosed with Covid two days ago but he decided he was going to run anyway. 'I ran down underneath the stadium to try and find where he was. We found Noah Lyles in medical being tended to. 'Obviously what he has there may have affected how he performed. He is now with medical people but that is the issue. Noah has Covid.'\n\nThe USA star made his trademark theatrical entrance to the race, leaping into the stadium as his name was announced and screaming at the crowd for the race that many had him as the big favorite for.\n\nBut after being left behind by Letsile Tebogo, who won gold, and fellow American Kenny Bednarek, Lyles was seen strewn on the track and struggling for breath after congratulating his fellow competitors. Moments later, he was pictured needing a wheelchair to make his way off the track. He arrived for the race wearing a mask.\n\nLyles tweeted earlier this week - after winning gold in 100m - that he is asthmatic, saying: 'I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. 'But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!' He also took to X to offer Tebogo his congratulations on winning gold, saying: 'LETSILE TEBOGO congratulations. Ik (I know) you have had a very rough year off the track and despite that you overcame it all!'\n\nLyles was seen shaking hands and hugging his fellow competitors before he dropped to the ground. Earlier this week, it was reported that over 40 athletes had tested positive for the virus. British swimmer Adam Peaty tested positive a day after winning silver in the 100m breaststroke when he had not felt well, his team said. Australian medal hope Lani Pallister pulled out of the women's 1500m freestyle after falling ill.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? Lyles, who won the 100m in a photo-finish from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, topped his 200m heat in 20.19sec. The triple world 200m champion had a slow start but as soon as he hit the bend he looked in total control. The semi-finals are scheduled for 1802 GMT on Wednesday, with the final set for 1830 on Thursday.\n\n\"I was up by seven. My dang body got this clock that wakes up at seven because that's when I practise every day,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"So that's when I naturally wake up. But throughout the day it's kind of just been meandering, trying to get my body jump-started.\n\n\"I saw my physio and chiro at about 10, saw them till 12. Then I got some food, took a nap and woke up about 3.30. And here we are.\"\n\nLyles, who will also chase gold in the 4x100m relay, said the 200m remained his \"favourite race because I feel it shows all my abilities\".\n\n\"I spent years working on the 100m, but the 200 is where it's at. This is where I get to show my speed and endurance and my top-end speed.\n\n\"This is where I get to show I'm stronger than everybody else.\"\n\nLyles' Jamaican partner Junelle Bromfield qualified for the semi-finals of the women's 400m, on the couple's two-year anniversary.\n\n\"I watched it on TV while I was getting treatment,\" Lyles said of Bromfield, who was a one-time training partner of Thompson, who was edged into 100m silver on Sunday by just five-thousandths of a second.\n\nHe added: \"We've been dating for two years now - it goes by fast. I've got pretty big plans for celebrations. I'm trying to give her a little more time.\n\n\"Last year we kind of went on a Noah Lyles campaign and unfortunately that cut into a lot of our vacation time.\"\n\nAlso going through into the 200m semis as heat winners were fellow 100m finalists Letsile Tebogo of Botswana (20.10sec) and American Kenny Bednarek (19.96).\n\nTebogo finished sixth in the 100m in a national record of 9.86sec, one ahead of Bednarek, and the Botswanan admitted it had been something he had had to \"digest quickly and live for another day\".\n\n\"It doesn't mean it's the end of the world even if you didn't make it in the 100m,\" he said.\n\n\"A lot of people didn't make it in the final, so I was grateful that I made it into the final.\"\n\nThe 200m, he argued, was a more sympathetic event than the 100m.\n\n\"The 100m is more of a tactical race. You have to get everything correct from the block, to your running, even timing your dip. It's a lot of tactics.\n\n\"In the 200m, you know you've got 200m to go, where you can correct a silly mistake along the way,\" said Tebogo\n\nA third American, Erriyon Knighton, a silver and bronze {"uri": "8265525704", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "15:14:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T15:14:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:13:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/sports/how-noah-lyles-can-make-rare-olympic-history-200m-final-912586", "title": "How Noah Lyles can make rare Olympic history in the 200m final", "body": "Having already earned the title of \"Fastest Man in the World\" at the Paris Games, Lyles stands on the brink of joining an elite group in Olympic history.\n\nNoah Lyles is poised to sprint into Olympic history at the 2024 Paris Games. The Team USA star will compete in the men's 200m final on Thursday, aiming for a rare sprint double after his thrilling victory in the 100m final on Sunday. The 27-year-old Lyles won his first Olympic gold medal and secured Team USA's first 100m title in two decades with a late surge that clinched the race by a narrow margin.\n\nHaving already earned the title of \"Fastest Man in the World\" at the Paris Games, Lyles stands on the brink of joining an elite group in Olympic history:\n\nThe men's sprint double -- where an athlete wins both the 100m and 200m dashes at the same Games -- has been achieved 11 times by nine athletes throughout Olympic history.\n\nThe last athlete to complete the sprint double was the legendary Usain Bolt, who accomplished this feat at three consecutive Games. The eight-time gold medalist swept the 100m and 200m sprints at the 2008 Beijing Games, the 2012 London Games, and the 2016 Rio Games, making him the only man to achieve the Olympic sprint double multiple times. In 2012, he also became the first athlete -- male or female -- to complete the sprint double at consecutive Games.\n\nFellow Jamaican Elaine Thompson-Herah recently made history as the first woman to win both the 100m and 200m races at consecutive Olympics, achieving this in the 2016 Games and the pandemic-delayed 2020 Tokyo Games. She had previously become the first woman to complete the sprint double since American Florence Griffith-Joyner at the 1988 Seoul Games.\n\nHere's a look at every men's sprint double in Olympic history, with Carl Lewis' achievement in 1984 being the most recent by an American:\n\nOwens, Morrow, and Lewis, along with Bolt in 2012 and 2016, expanded their sprint doubles into triples by winning the 4x100m relay as well.\n\nThe 200m is considered Lyles' stronger event compared to the 100m. After earning a bronze medal at the Tokyo Games, Lyles remained undefeated in 200m races until the semifinals in Paris, where he placed second in his heat with a time of 20.08 seconds, finishing behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo (19.96). Lyles posted the third-best semifinal time overall, behind Tebogo and fellow American Kenny Bednarek (20.00). Bednarek is the reigning Olympic silver medalist, while the defending Olympic champion, Canada's Andre De Grasse, did not qualify for the final.\n\nLyles' personal-best time in the 200m is the American record of 19.31 seconds, achieved at the 2022 World Championships. His season-best time of 19.53 seconds came at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.", "source": {"uri": "tbsnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Business Standard"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-08-447396051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "21:42:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T21:42:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T21:41:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.star-telegram.com/sports/olympics/article290856039.html", "title": "Noah Lyles qualifies second, behind Letsile Tebogo, in 200-meter dash", "body": "PARIS -- Botswana's Letsile Tebogo set the fastest time in the men's Olympic 200 meters semifinals on Wednesday, proving his intent to upset American Noah Lyles' quest for a sprint double.\n\nTebogo, last year's world championship bronze medalist, overtook the American 100-meter champion on the bend and cruised the rest of the way unchallenged to finish in 19.96 seconds. The 27-year-old Lyles had to push to finish second in 20.08.\n\nAmericans Kenny Bednarek, Olympic silver medalist in Tokyo, and Erriyon Knighton each won their semifinals, Bednarek clocking 20.00 and the 20-year-old Knighton crossing in 20.09.\n\nRounding out the field for Thursday's final are Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic, Joseph Fahnbulleh of Liberia, and Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba.\n\nLyles, the three-time reigning world champion over what has always been his stronger event, has not lost over the distance since he had to settle for bronze at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nHis run on Wednesday, however, was reminiscent of his sluggish 100 semifinal after which he reached out to his therapist for guidance. He came out two hours later and electrified the crowd by winning the most competitive men's 100-meter dash in Olympic history.\n\nLyles did not stop to speak to reporters, heading straight to see medical experts, a USA Track and Field spokesperson said.\n\nHe is looking to become the first American in four decades to win the Olympic sprint double and is aiming for potentially four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay, and -- if he is selected in the squad -- the 4x400m relay.\n\nCanada's defending champion Andre de Grasse, the last man to beat Lyles in a competitive race over the distance, did not advance to the final.\n\n\"I reactivated a lingering issue in my hamstring,\" De Grasse said. \"It was going to be tough today. {"uri": "2024-08-448534570", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:17:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:17:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:12:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/noah-lyles-races-in-the-200m-event-with-covid-19-doesnt-regret-it-even-after-winning-only-bronze-being-helped-off-the-track-in-paris-and-embracing-his-competitors/", "title": "Noah Lyles races in the 200m event with COVID-19, doesn't regret it even after winning only bronze, being helped off the track in Paris, and embracing his competitors. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Noah Lyles ran the men's 200m final with Covid and needed to be wheeled out of the Stade de France after finishing third in the race - but said afterwards that he has never been prouder of himself.\n\nNBC said they spoke to Lyles' mom, who confirmed he had the virus before the athlete himself spoke out. He said he had no regrets over competing, despite the inevitable risk of spreading the virus to other athletes, who he hugged and shook hands with after the race.\n\nThe USA star told NBC, masked up: 'I woke up early about 5am Tuesday morning, feeling really horrible. I knew it was more than being sore from the 100. My first thought was not to panic, I've ben in worse situations, I've been in worse conditions.\n\n'I took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much. It would say it has taken its toll, for sure, but I have never been more proud of myself coming out here and getting a bronze.'\n\nHe was asked by Lewis Johnson if he considered withdrawing and gave an emphatic response: 'No. No. We just said we were going to quarantine as much as possible and not try and pass it on.'\n\nLyles did admit the virus could force him out of USA's 4x100m relay on Friday.\n\n'At the moment I don't know, I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing,' he said. 'They have proven they can handle it without me.'\n\nMoments earlier, NBC's Johnson revealed Lyles' condition: 'We saw Noah being taken off there in a wheelchair. I ran into his mom who was distraught.\n\n'She did confirm that Noah had been diagnosed with Covid two days ago but he decided he was going to run anyway.\n\n'I ran down underneath the stadium to try and find where he was. We found Noah Lyles in medical being tended to.\n\n'Obviously what he has there may have affected how he performed. He is now with medical people but that is the issue. Noah has Covid.'\n\nThe USA star made his trademark theatrical entrance to the race, leaping into the stadium as his name was announced and screaming at the crowd for the race that many had him as the big favorite for.\n\nBut after being left behind by Letsile Tebogo, who won gold, and fellow American Kenny Bednarek, Lyles was seen strewn on the track and struggling for breath after congratulating his fellow competitors.\n\nMoments later, he was pictured needing a wheelchair to make his way off the track. He arrived for the race wearing a mask.\n\nLyles tweeted earlier this week - after winning gold in 100m - that he is asthmatic, saying: 'I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!'\n\nMichael Johnson questioned Lyles' decision to go ahead and compete, saying on the BBC: 'Very bizarre, Covid is still a dangerous disease. It is just bizarre, the whole thing is really weird.\n\n'There is going to be all of this thing with the Noah haters out there - and he set himself up for it - there are going to be people out there saying it's not real and he's faking or whatever.\n\n'But putting that aside, having Covid and still coming out here and being in close proximity with other people - I know there probably is not a policy I guess at these Games for that - but morally I'm not sure about it.'\n\nThere are, however, no rules that force athletes to withdraw from events with all Covid protocols dropped for the Paris Games.\n\nLyles was seen shaking hands and hugging his fellow competitors before he dropped to the ground.\n\nEarlier this week, it was reported that over 40 athletes had tested positive for the {"uri": "8265934414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:51:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:51:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:51:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://dailyvoice.com/virginia/alexandria/alexandria-native-noah-lyles-wins-bronze-in-200-meter-final-while-battling-covid-19-reports/", "title": "Alexandria Native Noah Lyles Wins Bronze In 200-Meter Final While Battling COVID-19: Reports", "body": "Virginia native Noah Lyles sprinted his way to a bronze medal in his signature race and was wheeled out after revealing a COVID-19 diagnosis.\n\nLyles earned the medal in the 200-meter race before laying on the track and motioning for water on Thursday after the race.\n\nThe Alexandria resident - who notoriously suffers from asthma - then had to be helped off the track in a makeshift wheelchair.\n\nHe later revealed that he tested positive for the virus two days earlier and has been hydrating and quarantining until the race.\n\nLyles finished the race milliseconds after gold medalist Letsile Tebogo, of Botswana, and fellow American Kenny Bednarek with a time of 19.70, despite having to fend off COVID-19 and the other athletes vying for his spot on the podium.\n\n\"I woke up early about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning and I was feeling really horrible. I knew it was more than being sore from the 100,\" Lyles said after the race to NBC.\n\n\"Woke up the doctors and we tested and it came back as positive for COVID. My first thought was not to panic. I'm thinking I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions, I felt, and we just took it day by day, tried to hydrate as much, quarantined.\n\n\"It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself to be able to come out here and getting a bronze medal.\"\n\nHe said he never considered not running in the final.\n\n\"No. I didn't,\" he said. \"We were just gonna try to quarantine as much as possible and stay away, not try to pass it off and just to give it my all.\n\n\"If I weren't to make it then someone else would take my spot.\"\n\nLyles will still come home happy after winning the gold in the 100-meter. He was also qualified to participate in the 4\u00d7100-meter relay for the Americans, though it is unclear if he or another sprinter will fill that spot.\n\n\"At the moment I don't know. I'm feeling more on the side of letting team USA do their thing,\" Lyles said. \"They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me.\n\n\"And if thats the case, I'm perfectly fine to say 'hey go do your thing' ... You have more than enough speed to get that gold medal.\"\n\nWant breaking news in the DMV as it happens, or want to contribute? {"uri": "8266111960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:20:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:20:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:17:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.democraticunderground.com/120494685", "title": "COVID derails Noah Lyles' bid for sprint double: 'I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics'", "body": "SAINT-DENIS, France -- At 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning, Noah Lyles woke up with a wicked sore throat, an aching body and the chills.\n\n-snip-\n\nThe test came back positive, throwing Lyles' historic pursuit of an Olympic sprint double into chaos two days before Thursday night's men's 200 final. Lyles quarantined in a hotel near the Olympic Village, tried to get as much rest and fluids as he could and took any medication he could without violating anti-doping rules.\n\nThe idea of not competing in the 200 never was something that Lyles seriously considered, especially after he managed to advance to the final by gutting out a second-place finish in his semifinal heat on Wednesday. Lyles explained that he \"still wanted to run\" and that doctors gave him permission to try.\n\nRight from the start of Thursday's final, it was obvious that the world's most unbeatable 200 runner didn't have his usual burst. The American fell behind early and struggled to make up ground after rounding the turn, leaving himself too far back of Letsile Tebogo of Botswana and fellow American Kenny Bednarek to overtake either of them before they reached the finish line.\n\nhttps://sports.yahoo.com/covid-derails-noah-lyles-bid-for-sprint-double-i-believe-this-will-be-the-end-of-my-2024-olympics-183515628.html", "source": {"uri": "2024-08-448584810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:31:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:31:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:31:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.kidderminstershuttle.co.uk/sport/national/24507311.noah-lyles-reveals-covid-chose-compete-200-metres-final/", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals he had Covid but chose to compete in 200 metres final", "body": "Noah Lyles revealed he had Covid after collecting Olympic 200 metres bronze on Thursday night.\n\nThe American sprinter said he tested positive around five o'clock on Tuesday morning and woke up in the middle of the night \"with chills\".\n\nLyles, the Olympic 100m champion, said he quickly quarantined in a hotel but insisted on competing in the final won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLater, Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone defended her 400 metres hurdles gold in world record time.\n\nLyles, who was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt to win both Olympic sprint titles, said the illness had affected his performance.\n\nHe said: \"I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100 metres and 200 metres titles.\n\nThe 27-year-old had managed to bounce back to win 100 metres gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20-metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo, 21, became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last May.\n\nIt is a second 200m bronze for Lyles, who had also hoped to compete in the men's 4x100m and 4x400m relays in Paris, though the latter was a long shot if he were in a position to secure four Olympic golds in one Games - a feat Bolt never achieved.\n\nLyles admitted he was feeling \"quite light-headed\" and experienced chest pain following the 200m final.\n\nHe said: \"This is by far the best day I've felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I am 100 per cent but I am closer to 90 or 95.\n\n\"I only had one shot and then I will be down for a while. Me and my therapist said 'it's one and done, there is no holding back'.\n\n\"We haven't decided on the relay yet.\n\n\"I'll talk to the coaches and to be honest, I'm gonna be very honest and transparent with them, and I'm gonna let them make the decision.\n\n\"I believe that no matter what happens this four by one team can handle anything and everything. I've been with them in practice. They are more than capable to come out with a win and even break as many records as they take their mind to.\"\n\nA USA Track and Field statement read: \"We can confirm that Noah Lyles tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday, August 6th. In response, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\n\n\"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nAs the Lyles situation was unfolding, athletes and audience alike were preparing for one of the most anticipated events of these Games - the women's 400m hurdles.\n\nIt was billed as a showdown between the Netherlands' Femke Bol, the reigning world champion, and American McLaughlin-Levrone, out to defend her Olympic title from Tokyo.\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone dominated from the gun, taking an instant lead and powering to the finish to lower her own world record, set in June in Eugene, to 50.37 seconds.\n\nThe 25-year-old's US team-mate Anna Cockrell came second in a personal best 51.87, Bol collecting bronze for a second straight Games in front of a large Dutch contingent in 52.15.\n\nMcLaughlin-Levrone said: \"I wasn't looking at the clock to be honest with you. I mean, across the line I was definitely grateful for that time.\"", "source": {"uri": "kidderminstershuttle.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Kidderminster Shuttle"}, "authors": [], "concepts": I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible Noah Lyles\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100 metres and 200 metres titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100 metres gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nUSA\u00b4s Noah Lyles (right) congratulates Botswana\u00b4s Letsile Tebogo on winning the men\u00b4s 200 metres final at the Paris Olympics (Martin Rickett/PA).\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo, 21, became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last May.\n\nIt is a second 200 metres bronze for Lyles, who had also hoped to compete in the men's 4\u00d7100 metres and 4\u00d7400 metres relays in Paris, though the latter was a long-shot if he were in a position to secure four Olympic golds in one Games - a feat Bolt never achieved.\n\nLyles admitted he was feeling \"quite lightheaded\" and experienced chest pain following the 200 metres final, which he finished in 19.70 seconds.\n\nHe said: \"This is by far the best day I've felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I am 100 per cent but I am closer to 90 or 95.\n\nUSA\u00b4s Noah Lyles finishes third in the men\u00b4s 200 metres final (Martin Rickett/PA).\n\n\"I only had one shot and then I will be down for a while. Me and my therapist said 'it's one and done, there is no holding back'.\n\n\"We haven't decided on the (4\u00d7100 metres) relay yet.\n\n\" I'll talk to the coaches and to be honest, I'm gonna be very honest and transparent with them, and I'm gonna let them make the decision.\n\n\"I believe that no matter what happens this four by one team can handle anything and everything. I've been with them in practice. They are more than capable to come out with a win and even break as many records as they take their mind to.\"\n\nA USA Track and Field statement read: \"We can confirm that Noah Lyles tested positive for COVID-19 on Tuesday, August 6th. In response, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\n\n\"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent {"uri": "8265933278", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:50:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:50:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:49:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/covid-positive-noah-lyles-wheeled-off-the-track-after-winning-bronze-in-200-meters", "title": "COVID-Positive Noah Lyles Wheeled Off the Track After Winning Bronze", "body": "The American athlete did not break any protocols by participating in the 200-meter event after testing positive for COVID-19 a few days ago.\n\nAmerican sprinter Noah Lyles revealed he ran in Thursday's 200-meter Olympic race -- and placed third -- despite testing positive for COVID-19 earlier this week.\n\nAfter crossing the finish line behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo and Team USA's Kenneth Bednarek, Lyles immediately laid down on the track. The 27-year-old athlete, who remained fully conscious, had to be helped off the track in a wheelchair by medical personnel, and was taken to a medical holding area.\n\nWearing a black medical mask, he told Olympic broadcaster NBC News that he was \"quite lightheaded after that race, and shortness of breath and chest pains were definitely active.\n\n\"But after a while underneath [the stands], I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me. So I'm feeling a lot better now.\"\n\nLyles told reporters that he first tested positive after waking up \"feeling horrible\" around 5 a.m. on Tuesday. \"I knew it was more than just being sore from the [100-meter race],\" he said. \"I woke up the doctors and we tested, and unfortunately, it came out that I was positive for COVID.\"\n\nThe runner moved out of Paris' Athletes Village and into a hotel to isolate, taking \"as much medication as we legally could,\" including Paxlovid, under observation by USA Track & Field's medical team.\n\nStill, there was no question that Lyles would compete in the 200-meter, his signature event. On Wednesday, still feeling the effects of the virus, he finished second in his semi-final heat with a time of 20.08. His final time was 19.70, as compared to Tebogo's 19.46 and Bednarek's 19.62.\n\n\"I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go,\" he said. \"I didn't have any time to save energy, so that was kind of the strategy for today,\" he added. \"This is by far the best day I felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I'm 100 percent but I would definitely say I'm closer to like, 90 to 95 percent.\"\n\nThe northern Virginia native did not break any Olympics protocols by competing in the race. While the 2020 Tokyo Summer Olympics and 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics instituted strict rules regarding testing and masking, the 2024 Paris Games allow COVID-positive athletes to compete at their discretion. At least 19 athletes have tested positive over the past two weeks, according to Scientific American.\n\nLyles has been adamant about his intention to compete in the men's 4x100 team relay on Friday night, but added Thursday that he would let his coaches decide.\n\nUSA Track & Field said it supported Lyles' decision to continue competing. After his positive COVID test, a spokesperson said that officials \"swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nPrior to his test, Lyles was having an exceptional Games, clinching the gold medal in Sunday's 100-meter dash, which he ran in 9.79 seconds, a personal best.
