{"uri": "8261154006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "05:17:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T05:17:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T05:16:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.ewn.co.za/2024/08/06/wayde-van-niekerk-finishes-3rd-in-200m-heat-progressing-to-semi-finals-thursday-802-pm", "title": "Wayde van Niekerk finishes 3rd in 200m heat, progressing to semi-finals (Wednesday, 8.02 pm)", "body": "South Africa's 400m world record holder and gold medallist in Rio, Wayde van Niekerk, went through after finishing third in his heat on Monday, won by Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh.\n\nNoah Lyles, fresh from winning Olympic 100m gold in Paris, cruised his 200m heat at the Stade de France to keep his bid for a sprint treble alive.\n\nLyles, who won the 100m in a photo-finish from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, topped his 200m heat in 20.19sec.\n\nThe triple world 200m champion had a slow start but as soon as he hit the bend he looked in total control.\n\nThe semi-finals are scheduled for 1802 GMT on Wednesday, with the final set for 1830 on Thursday.\n\n\"I was up by seven. My dang body got this clock that wakes up at seven because that's when I practise every day,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"So that's when I naturally wake up. But throughout the day it's kind of just been meandering, trying to get my body jump-started.\n\n\"I saw my physio and chiro at about 10, saw them till 12. Then I got some food, took a nap and woke up at about 3.30. And here we are.\"\n\nLyles, who will also chase gold in the 4x100m relay, said the 200m remained his \"favourite race because I feel it shows all my abilities\".\n\n\"I spent years working on the 100m, but the 200 is where it's at. This is where I get to show my speed and endurance and my top-end speed.\n\n\"This is where I get to show I'm stronger than everybody else.\"\n\nLyles' Jamaican partner Junelle Bromfield qualified for the semi-finals of the women's 400m, on the couple's second anniversary.\n\n\"I watched it on TV while I was getting treatment,\" Lyles said of Bromfield, who was a one-time training partner of Thompson, who was edged into 100m silver on Sunday by just five-thousandths of a second.\n\nHe added: \"We've been dating for two years now - it goes by fast. I've got pretty big plans for celebrations. I'm trying to give her a little more time.\n\n\"Last year we kind of went on a Noah Lyles campaign and unfortunately that cut into a lot of our vacation time.\"\n\nAlso going through into the 200m semis as heat winners were fellow 100m finalists Letsile Tebogo of Botswana (20.10sec) and American Kenny Bednarek (19.96).\n\nTebogo finished sixth in the 100m in a national record of 9.86sec, one ahead of Bednarek, and the Botswanan admitted it had been something he had had to \"digest quickly and live for another day\".\n\n\"It doesn't mean it's the end of the world even if you didn't make it in the 100m,\" he said.\n\n\"A lot of people didn't make it in the final, so I was grateful that I made it into the final.\"\n\nThe 200m, he argued, was a more sympathetic event than the 100m.\n\n\"The 100m is more of a tactical race. You have to get everything correct from the block to your running, even timing your dip. It's a lot of tactics.\n\n\"In the 200m, you know you've got 200m to go, where you can correct a silly mistake along the way,\" said Tebogo.\n\nA third American, Erriyon Knighton, a silver and bronze We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nLyles later told reporters that his illness \"definitely affected my performance\".\n\n\"But to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything,\" he added. \"Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep this as close to the chest. Only people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mom, my family. We didn't want everybody to go into a panic.\n\n\"We wanted them to be able to compete. But a loaded schedule that featured a historic run for gold in the 100m on Sunday clearly appeared to take its toll.\n\nQuestions of his health also came into question as he was seen wearing a mask in recent days. Those only strengthened when he went down following the race and was in need of medical attention.\n\nThe 27-year-old Alexandria, VA was attempting to become just the 10th Olympian ever to win the 100m and 200m at the same Games and the first American to do so in 40 years.\n\nBut it never looked as though he was going to challenge for gold, especially considering he had the slowest reaction time off the blocks (0.173 seconds) amongst the field of eight runners.\n\nFrom Lane 5, he managed to make up the slow start and get into third, but could not catch Bednarek, who ran a 19.62-second race, and Tebogo, who set an African record of 19.46 seconds.\n\nLyles took the mantle of fastest man alive on Sunday when he narrowly defeated Jamaica's Krishane Thompson by a razor-thin 0.005 (five-one-thousandths of a second). Those were a lot of the symptoms I've had right before getting Covid. I [knew] I needed to test this one and ... it came back positive.\"\n\nLyles, who won 100m gold last Sunday, revealed he promptly transferred from the Olympic Village, where a number of athletes have contracted Covid during the Games, to isolate at a nearby hotel.\n\n\"We were trying to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure my body was able to keep the momentum going,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, [doctors] said it was possible.\"\n\nExplaining the decision to conceal it, he said: \"We were trying to keep this close to our chests ... my coach didn't want everybody [in the US team] to go into a panic ... and you never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nLyles ran his 200m heat on Monday. In Wednesday's semi-finals, following his diagnosis, Lyles was beaten by Tebogo, his first defeat over the distance in 27 races.\n\nHe said the final left him feeling \"quite light-headed, [with] shortness of breath and chest pain\".\n\nLyles said the illness \"definitely affected my performance\", but insisted he was \"90 to 95 per cent\" healthy.\n\nOnly medical staff and his coach, mum and family knew Lyles had tested positive. I rarely get sick,\" Bednarek said. \"I'm just going to give him a hug, regardless of whether he's sick or not. The whole thing is really weird.\"\n\nHe added: \"There's going to be all the Noah haters out there who say it's not real and he's faking it or whatever. And, with a staff in hand, pound it three times. It's called Les Trois Coups, meaning three ground strikes, and it's designed to kick off the venue's events with a thunderous rhythm.\n\nThursday, at Stade de France, the honors went to Carl Lewis. It was an homage to Noah Lyles, the 100-meter champion and the world's best at 200 meters. He was on the cusp of a feat not done by an American since Lewis in 1984.\n\nBut what was revealed to Lyles was just how difficult the task is, no matter how easy Jamaican Usain Bolt, the greatest of all time, made it look.\n\nLyles was not only beaten by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo's 19.46 -- the same man who beat him in his semifinal heat. But Lyles was also beaten by teammate Kenny Bednarek's 19.62 -- the same man who Lyles, after his 100-meter win, said would not win.\n\nLyles was humbled. He ran a decent time of 19.70. But he was never really a threat to win it.\n\nAfter all his verbal taunts, after declaring himself a legend in the making and talking about transcending the sport, Lyles mostly backed it up. Especially after his thrilling 100-meter final, he silenced everyone who was turned off by his arrogance.\n\nThursday, at Stade de France, finally, Noahstradamus never looked more wrong. After the race, Lyles went straight to the medical area, further fueling speculation about his condition.\n\nLyles did not wear a mask before his 100m final but wore one before the 200m event, sparking speculation about a possible illness. Many fans have expressed their worries on social media, noting that his performance in the semifinal was unusual.\n\nHis decision to wear a mask aligns with other athletes taking extra precautions during the games. Mask-wearing has become common in crowded areas and during travel to reduce infection risk. This practice helps athletes compete without health concerns.\n\nDespite finishing second in the semifinal, Lyles remains a top contender for the gold medal in the 200m race, his stronger event. The men's 200m final is scheduled for Thursday, August 8 at 2:30 p.m. ET. His race time of 20.08 was third-fastest overall among the semifinal heats.\n\nNoah Lyles' proactive approach to health and safety is evident in his use of a mask before the 200m final. {"uri": "8265037311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:09:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:09:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T10:06:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/noah-lyles-cried-tokyo-why-100243684.html", "title": "Noah Lyles cried in Tokyo. Here's why he's smiling so big in Paris.", "body": "An ironclad rule of sports journalism is that there's no cheering in the press box. Sports journalists are to always exhibit neutrality. We're human, though, and at times it's impossible not to become a fan of individual athletes. And I'll admit that when the men in the 200-meter final settle into their starting blocks Thursday, I'll be in my living room, ready to cheer American Noah Lyles to victory.\n\nAlready the 100-meter gold medalist after a thrilling, photo-finish race Sunday night, Lyles will be running to secure his second gold medal in Paris in the event that put him on the path to track and field greatness.\n\nOn Aug. 4, 2021, in Tokyo, he won a bronze medal in the 200 meters, behind Canada's Andre DeGrasse and American Kenny Bednarek. Lyles' loss was one of the surprises of the meet, perhaps behind only Italy's Marcell Jacobs' shocking the hell out of the world with his 100-meter win. After that race, in the thick humidity of the mix zone under Tokyo Olympic Stadium, I became a fan.\n\nLyles was spent. He was talking to print and online reporters after he'd already endured more than a dozen television and radio interviews. His initial aloofness gave way to a torrent of emotion, his disappointment at not winning. He cried. He apologized for crying. He expressed his sorrow that his younger brother, Josephus, the one he'd followed into track as a kid so they could be together, wasn't in Tokyo competing. \"This should be him,\" he said.\n\nHe shared more about his nearly lifelong journey with anxiety and depression and how the year leading into those Olympics had been the hardest of his life physically and mentally.\n\nA U.S.A. Track & Field media official offered to cut things short. He didn't take the out.\n\n\"Having a place where you can actually be OK with letting go of your fears and saying, 'I am scared,' because I've definitely said that quite a few times this year,\" Lyles said. \"It's OK, you know?\n\n\"I want other people to know that there's a better way.\"\n\nAfter Lyles won the 100-meter race in Paris on Sunday, he posted a message on social media: \"I have Asthma, allergies, dyslexia, ADD, anxiety, and Depression. But I will tell you that what you have does not define what you can become. Why Not You!\"\n\nTalking to us reporters under the stadium in Tokyo three years ago, Lyles was raw and vulnerable, in a way we've rarely seen from those in the public eye, in a way that we, for far too long, have told athletes, particularly male athletes, isn't allowed. Thankfully, led in part by Lyles and gymnastics icon Simone Biles, that stigma seems to be melting away.\n\nIf his tears over not winning the 200 in Tokyo were Lyles' low point, everything since has propelled him higher and higher.\n\nHe has made it his mission to make track and field more popular in the States, in part by making the stadium walk-in photo opportunity, now common in other professional sports, a thing in his sport, too. He's used it as a time to show off some personality and his fashion sense before showing out when the competition begins. With his big talk and his painted nails, he relishes the pre-meet meetings with media, sometimes poking at his competitors and even athletes outside his sport. He got the attention of NBA stars when he said last year at the world championships that it bothers him to hear the NBA's title-winning team called world champions when 29 of the 30 teams are in the U.S. (the 30th is in Canada).\n\nWhile he is raising his own profile and chasing Jamaica's Usain Bolt in the record book, other American track standouts could reap the benefits of the increased exposure.\n\nMore than the walk-in photo-ops and the entertaining news conferences, however, Lyles knew that the real way to make himself a household name was to win what counts as the marquee event at every Olympics and perhaps across all sports: the men's 100-meter gold and the accompanying title of \"world's fastest man.\"\n\nLyles had always included 100-meter races on his schedule (he has called the race his mistress, while the 200 meters is his wife), and he ran an impressive 9.86 at a Diamond League race in China in 2018. But he failed to secure a spot in the 100 meters when he finished seventh of eight runners in the final at the U.S. Olympic Trials in 2021. He announced last year that he would become world champion in both the 200 and the 100 meters in Budapest, Hungary.\n\nGiven that his biggest liability in the 100 meters was -- and remains -- his block starts, it was a lofty goal. The 27-year-old, one of the rare track and field athletes to jump from high school to the pros, met that first goal: He won three golds in Budapest, surprising the field with his 10-meter victory, getting his third consecutive 200-meter world championship and joining with Christian Coleman, Fred Kerley and Brandon Carnes to win the 4x100-meter relay.\n\nThe success only fueled him to match the feat at the Olympics. He got that 100-meter gold by the smallest of margins and still has his signature event on deck. The Americans are also the favorite in the relay, but after the disaster of Tokyo, where they didn't even qualify for the medal race, the latest in a comedy of errors that hasn't seen the U.S. win a medal in the men's 4x100 since 2004 or a gold since 2000, it might not be a given.\n\nBut from what we've seen of Lyles since that night in Tokyo, when he was despondent and bared his soul to a cadre of socially distanced strangers, it will be hard to bet against them. And hard not to cheer for him.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_journalism", "type": {"uri": "8265838793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:22:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:22:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:20:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/botswanas-tebogo-becomes-africas-first-200m-champion-4536486", "title": "Botswana's Tebogo becomes Africa's first 200m champion", "body": "PARIS :Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the men's Olympic 200 metres title on Thursday when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 when finishing sixth in the Paris 100m final, produced a dominant last 50 metres and crossed the line in 19.46 seconds beating his chest as he become the fifth-fastest man in history over 200m.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, who had been hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, repeating his Tokyo bronze in 19.67.\n\nIt was the triple world champion's first defeat in a 200m final for three years. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race, U.S. officials said he had COVID, putting his participation in Friday's sprint relay final in serious doubt.\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against his name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box.\n\nLyles might still hog the limelight, but it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three places in the final, Tebogo's place on top of the podium was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old told reporters.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew when the gun went Kenny was going to run away so make sure just to close him down, I have that top end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"", quarantine", "body": "USA track star Noah Lyles revealed he felt awful before testing positive for Covid this week.\n\nLyles, 27, finished third in the 200m Thursday night in Paris as he failed to add to his 100m crown.\n\nThe Team USA superstar collapsed to the floor after his bronze medal run and needed a wheelchair to help him off the track.\n\nSeconds after the race, US track and field confirmed Lyles ran with Covid.\n\nHe was seen wearing a mask in the call room before the race, and had the mask on during his interview with NBC afterwards.\n\nLyles revealed, \"I woke up about 5am on Tuesday morning and was feeling really horrible.\n\n\"I knew it was more than being sore from the 100m.\n\n\"We woke up the doctors and tested, and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for Covid.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic - I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions I've felt.\n\n\"We just took it day by day, tried to hydrate, quarantined off and I would definitely say it's taken it's toll for sure.\n\n\"But I've never been more proud of myself to come out here and get a bronze medal.\n\n\"Last Olympics I was very disappointed and this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nLyles was adamant there was never a thought of not running in the 200m - his favored event.\n\nThe 27-year-old was targeting at least three gold medals in Paris having won the 100m Sunday night.\n\nBut he cast doubt over whether he would be back for the 4x100m relay final.\n\nUSA won their heat without him Thursday morning.\n\n\"We were just going to try and quarantine as much as possible, stay away, not pass it off and give it my all,\" Lyles insisted.\n\n\"If I wasn't to make it and somebody was able to take my spot, that would've been my sign that I didn't deserve to be in the final.\n\n\"At the moment, I don't know about the relay.\n\n\"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing.\n\n\"They're proven with great certainty that they can handle it {"uri": "8264619081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "05:13:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T05:13:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T05:12:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/08/08/sports/tebogo-beats-lyles-to-clock-fastest-200m-semi-time/", "title": "Tebogo beats Lyles to clock fastest 200m semi time - Stabroek News", "body": "(Reuters) - Botswana's Letsile Tebogo set the fastest time in the men's Olympic 200 metres semi-finals yesterday, proving his intent to upset American Noah Lyles' quest for a sprint double.\n\nTebogo, last year's world championship bronze medallist, overtook the American 100 metres champion on the bend and cruised the rest of the way unchallenged to finish in 19.96 seconds. The 27-year-old Lyles had to work hard to finish second in 20.08.\n\nAmericans Kenny Bednarek, Olympic silver medallist in Tokyo, and Erriyon Knighton each won their semi-finals, Bednarek clocking 20.00 and the 20-year-old Knighton crossing in 20.09.\n\nRounding out the field for today's final are Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic, Joseph Fahnbulleh of Liberia, and Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba.\n\nLyles, the three-times reigning world champion over what has always been his stronger event, has not lost over the distance since he had to settle for bronze at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nHis run yesterday, however, was reminiscent of his sluggish 100m semi-final after which he reached out to his therapist for guidance. He came out two hours later and electrified the crowd by winning the most competitive men's 100m in Olympic history.\n\nLyles did not stop to speak to reporters, heading straight to see medical experts, a USA Track and Field spokesperson said.\n\nHe is looking to become the first American in four decades to win the Olympic sprint double and is aiming for potentially four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay, and -- if he is selected in the squad -- the 4x400m relay.\n\nCanada's defending champion Andre de Grasse, the last man to beat Lyles in a competitive race over the distance, did not advance to the final.\n\n\"I reactivated a lingering issue in my hamstring,\" De Grasse said. \"It was going to be tough today. I knew I had to go out there and try to do my best and see what I can come up with.\n\n\"It's tough. It's been a tough 24, 48 hours. I've just got to try to keep the head, try to see how I can support my team in any way with the 4x100m relay.\"", "source": {"uri": "stabroeknews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Stabroek News"}, {"uri": "2024-08-448578430", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:21:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:21:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:21:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.wmur.com/article/noah-lyles-covid-paris-olympics/61829864", "title": "What are the rules about competing at the Olympics with COVID?", "body": "In Paris on Aug. 7, after 200-meter world champion and American record-holder Noah Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat of the 200 meters, he did not stop to talk to the media in the mixed zone. That was unusual for Lyles -- he isn't one to pass up the opportunity to speak. Instead, he was reported to be seeking medical treatment. And one day later, after the final of the 200 meters, the world knows why. Lyles tested positive for COVID on Tuesday morning, he told trackside reporter Lewis Johnson of NBC after the final. Letsile Tebogo of Botswana won in 19.46, Kenny Bednarek of the United States was second in 19.62, and Lyles was third in 19.70. Lyles left the track in a wheelchair, but he went through the mixed zone, the subterranean room at Stade de France where athletes talk to the media, on foot. He was masked as he answered questions from reporters. He said he started to feel poorly at about 5 a.m. on August 6, with a fever, chills and a sore throat. A test revealed COVID. But Lyles said it was \"never a thought\" not to compete and he said by the 200 meters on Thursday, he was at about 90 to 95 percent health. Lyles is taking Paxlovid. He kept his diagnosis very private, so as not to give an advantage to his competitors. All this begs the question: What are the rules about competing at the Olympics with COVID? Short answer: It's up to the athlete. \"Scientific American\" reported that the Paris Games are treating COVID like any other respiratory illness. There are single rooms in the Olympic Village for athletes who have COVID. And athletes who are sick are encouraged to wear masks, wash their hands frequently, and avoid contact with others. Lani Pallister, an Australian swimmer who contracted COVID, withdrew from the 1500 meters in order to save energy for a later race. An unnamed Australian water polo player was isolated after getting sick, but Anna Meares, the head of the Australian Olympic delegation, said in an article on the Olympic news service, \"I need to emphasize that we are treating COVID no differently to other bugs like the flu. This is not Tokyo.\"Athletes who have talked to reporters in the track's mixed zone said illnesses was circulating through the athletes at the Olympic Village. Jakob Ingebrigtsen spoke to media after the 1500 meters wearing a mask, thought to be a precaution. Grant Fisher, who won bronze in the 10,000 meters, was not staying in the village and in fact went back to altitude in St. Moritz, Switzerland, before the start of the 5,000 meters. It has not yet been determined whether Lyles, who won the 100 meters, will compete on the 4 x 100-meter relay team for the U.S. \"I'm going to be honest and transparent with them and let them make the decision,\" Lyles said. \"I believe that no matter what happens, this 4 x 100 team can handle anything.\"USA Track & Field did not immediately respond to questions from \"Runner's World.\" As previously reported in \"Runner's World,\" rushing back to running and exercise after you've had COVID isn't always the best idea.\n\nIn Paris on Aug. 7, after 200-meter world champion and American record-holder Noah Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat of the 200 meters, he did not stop to talk to the media in the mixed zone.\n\nThat was unusual for Lyles -- he isn't one to pass up the opportunity to speak. He was masked as he answered questions from reporters.\n\nHe said he started to feel poorly at about 5 a.m. on August 6, with a fever, chills and a sore throat. A test revealed COVID. Lyles is taking Paxlovid.\n\nHe kept his diagnosis very private, so as not to give an advantage to his competitors.\n\nAll this begs the question: What are the rules about competing at the Olympics with COVID?\n\nShort answer: It's up to the athlete.\n\n\"Scientific American\" reported that the Paris Games are treating COVID like any other respiratory illness. There are single rooms in the Olympic Village for athletes who have COVID. And athletes who are sick are encouraged to wear masks, wash their hands frequently, and avoid contact with others.\n\nLani Pallister, an Australian swimmer who contracted COVID, withdrew from the 1500 meters in order to save energy for a later race. {"uri": "8265893314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:12:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:12:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:11:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://thewillnews.com/tebogo-takes-gold-as-first-african-to-win-olympic-200m-title/", "title": "Tebogo Takes Gold As First African To Win Olympic 200m Title", "body": "August 08, (THEWILL) -Letsile Tebogo, the rising star from Botswana, made history on Thursday by becoming the first African to win the Olympic 200 metres title. The 19-year-old produced a dominant performance, clocking a time of 19.46 seconds to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who had won bronze at the World Championships last year and set a national record of 9.86 seconds in the 100m final in Paris, powered clear of the American duo of Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles to secure the coveted title. Bednarek took the silver medal with a time of 19.62 seconds, while Lyles, who was hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, had to settle for bronze in 19.67 seconds.\n\nThe race was not without its drama, as U.S. officials revealed that Lyles had tested positive for COVID-19 prior to the final. A yellow card was also displayed against his name in the official results, further adding to the intrigue of the event.\n\nTebogo's victory is a significant moment for African athletics, as the continent has traditionally struggled to make its mark in the sprinting events at the highest level. The young Botswanan's triumph will undoubtedly inspire a new generation of athletes across Africa and beyond.\n\nWith his impressive performance, Tebogo has cemented his place among the elite sprinters in the world, becoming the fifth-fastest man in history over the 200m distance. His dominant display, which comes two months after his mother's death, is a testament to his dedication, hard work and the growing talent pool in Botswana's athletics programme.", "source": {"uri": Medical personnel came to his aid, and Lyles left the track at Stade de France in a wheelchair shortly after.\u00c2\n\nNBC\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s track and field reporter Lewis Johnson said Lyles was diagnosed with COVID two days ago in his post-event report, and Lyles himself confirmed the diagnosis after the race.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning, and I was feeling really horrible,\u00e2\u20ac Lyles said. \u00e2\u20ac\u0153I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100, woke up the doctors, and we tested, and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for COVID. My first thought was not to panic, thinking I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122ve been in worse situations, I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122ve run with worse conditions, and we just took it day by day, trying to hydrate, quarantined off. It\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s taken its toll for sure, but I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122ve never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get a bronze medal.\u00e2\u20ac\n\nLyles has been vocal about his lifelong struggles with asthma, which along with his COVID diagnosis could have factored into his condition Thursday. He was seen wearing a mask before the race as well.\n\nLyles previously won gold in the men\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s 100-meter final in the Paris Games and will have another chance to win a gold medal in the men\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s 4x100 relay on Friday, should he participate.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153At the moment, I don\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t know,\u00e2\u20ac Lyles said of his relay availability. "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/sport/athletics/lyles-eyes-sprint-double-after-booking-200m-final-slot-c-15629093", "title": "Lyles eyes sprint double after booking 200m final slot", "body": "Lyles eyes sprint double after booking 200m final slotStaff WritersAAPThu, 8 August 2024 3:56AM\n\nNoah Lyles has taken one step closer to his dream of achieving an individual Olympic sprint double in Paris after securing his spot in the 200m final at the Stade de France.\n\nTo add to American delight, another United States pace merchant, Quincy Hall, came from nowhere to grab victory in an electrifying finish to the 400m.\n\nLyles claimed 100m gold by five one thousandths of a second on Sunday night, and needed to finish in the top two from semi-final heat two to automatically book his place in Thursday night's showdown.\n\nLyles crossed his fingers with a tongue-out grin as the camera cut toward him on the big screen.\n\nLike that 100m final, Lyles got out to the slowest start of the eight-man field, but made up for it when he crossed the line in 20.08 sec for second spot behind Botswanan Letsile Tebogo in 19.96.\n\nLyles' time was still good enough for third-fastest of the semi-finalists behind Tebogo, the only man to clock a sub-20 time in the semis.\n\nSecond quickest was Lyles' American team-mate Kenny Bednarek, the 2022 world and Tokyo 2020 silver medallist, who made easy work of the first semi-final in exactly 20 seconds.\n\nDominican Alexander Ogando and a third American, Erriyon Knighton, rounded out the top five while Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh and Zimbabwe duo Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba also qualified.\n\nmedal tallyGame On ParisLoading...Full Medal TallyOlympics Coverage\n\nShortly afterwards, Hall produced a sensational finish to win Olympic 400m gold which denied Britain a first gold in the event in a century.\n\nHall, the world championship bronze medallist, trailed into the home stretch but then exploded and caught the leading Matthew Hudson-Smith right on the line for victory in a personal best 43.40.\n\nHall is the first American since LaShawn Merritt in 2008 to capture gold in the one-lap race. His victory came an evening after American Cole Hocker came from far behind late to beat the favourites in the men's 1500m.\n\nHudson-Smith lowered his European record to 43.44 but it was only good enough for silver. He had been bidding to become the first British man to win the 400m since Eric Liddell in 1924, also in Paris.\n\nThe bronze went to Zambia's Muzala Samukonga in 43.74 as five men dipped below 44 seconds They included Grenada's Kirani James who had won gold in 2012, silver in 2016 and bronze at Tokyo 2020 before coming fifth.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up {"uri": "2024-08-448475133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "18:57:13", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T18:57:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T18:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/2024-olympics-noah-lyles-gassed-falling-short-with-bronze-medal-in-200-meters-as-kenny-bednarek-wins-silver/", "title": "2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles gassed falling short with bronze medal in 200 meters as Kenny Bednarek wins silver", "body": "The men's 200 meters did not go to expectation at the 2024 Paris Olympics with Botswana's Letsile Tebogo running away from the field to win the gold medal in 19.46 seconds. Tebogo, 21, became the youngest man to win gold in the 200 meters since the United States' Bobby Morrow in 1956 and the first man from an African nation to do so in Olympic history.\n\nAll eyes entering the event were on United States sprinting sensation Noah Lyles, who won the 100 meters on Sunday and had an eye on setting a world record in the 200 meters. He was looking to become the first American to pull off the 100-200 double since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nInstead, Lyles, who battles asthma and wore a mask backstage before being introduced, looked gassed after the race. He never came near the lead before ultimately finishing third in 19.70 seconds for a bronze medal.\n\nHis personal best in the 200 meters is 19.31 seconds, an American record set at the 2022 World Championships, and his season best was 19.53 seconds set at the U.S. Olympic Trials in June.\n\nBetween the duo was fellow American Kenny Bednarek, who won a silver medal in 19.62 seconds. Bednarek and Lyles similarly finished in silver and bronze positions at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics three years ago.\n\nPulling off the 100-200 double is extremely difficult as only 10 men have achieved the feat in history. Jamaica's Usain Bolt (2008, 2012, 2016) is the last man to win gold medals in both events during the same Olympic Games. Prior to Bolt came Lewis at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.\n\nCBS Sports will update this developing story shortly.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, {"uri": "8266100366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:06:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:06:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:03:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.inforum.com/sports/pro/tebogo-powers-to-victory-in-200-bednarek-nabs-silver", "title": "Tebogo powers to victory in 200; Bednarek nabs silver", "body": "PARIS -- Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the men's Olympic 200-meter title on Thursday when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and a COVID-hit Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 when he finished sixth in the 100-meter final, produced a dominant last 50 meter and crossed the line in 19.46 seconds, beating his chest as he become the fifth-fastest man in history over 200 meters.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, who had been hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, repeating his Tokyo bronze in 19.67.\n\nIt was the triple world champion's first defeat in a 200-meter final for three years. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race U.S. officials said he had tested positive for COVID on Tuesday, two days after he won the 100-meter gold.\n\n\"In response (to the test, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors,\" USATF said in a statement.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against Lyle's name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box before the race start.\n\nThe Lyles show might still hog much of the limelight, but on the track it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three positions, Tebogo's place on top of the podium in an African record was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of -- it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old told reporters. \"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew Kenny was going to run away so made sure just to close him down, I have that top-end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"\n\nBednarek, the man in the middle again, ran a fantastic bend in lane eight and finished strongly, but not just quite fast enough.\n\n\"I don't think I put my best race down, it was really tight at the end,\" he said.\n\n\"This year I'm finally healthy. I can build off this. There's also the world championships next year. I'm going to be dangerous. {"uri": "8265988270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:45:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:45:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:44:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/08/08/sports/olympics-noah-lyles-200-meters-covid-bronze/", "title": "For COVID-stricken Noah Lyles, just being in the race was a victory. The bronze medal was a bonus. - The Boston Globe", "body": "So he moved out of the Olympic village and into a nearby hotel to get some distance from teammates, took all the medications allowable, wore a mask through race trials, and pushed himself back out there for Thursday's final.\n\nHis 19.70 finish wouldn't prove to be enough for a win. That went to 21-year-old Letsile Tebogo of Botswana, who ran a 19.46. American Kenneth Bednarek won silver, repeating, like Lyles, the same finish he'd had in Tokyo in 2021.\n\nBut as much as the postrace story was about Lyles's illness, it was even more about his ability to deal with the setback. Unlike his Tokyo experience, when he was so full of anxiety and so absent of joy that he was unable to perform at his best, the Lyles who fell to the track after Thursday's race and could barely get up, the one who had get the assistance of race officials with a wheelchair to make it back to the medical team, wasn't going to beat himself up the way he did three years ago.\n\nHe has grown enough to understand that being out there was the win itself; the bronze medal was a bonus. He was able to give himself grace for something happening that was beyond his control, to lean into the support from his girlfriend, Jamaican sprinter Junelle Bromfield, as well as his personal therapist, and do the best he could under difficult, unexpected circumstances.\n\n\"I'm more proud of myself than anything coming out and getting the bronze medal with getting COVID three days ago,\" Lyles said. \"It definitely affected my performance. I've had to take a lot of breaks, lots of fluids.\n\n\"Even Janelle was saying that I was coughing through the night last night. I thought I had a good night's sleep but she said she had to keep moving me throughout the night to make sure that I would stop coughing.\"\n\nIt was clear as soon as the race was over that Lyles wasn't quite right. He dropped to the ground just outside the track's first curve, just steps beyond the finish line, and lay on his back. He was there as Tebogo celebrated, as Bednarek gathered his American flag and found family in the stands, as the results were officially announced and the track began resetting for the next race.\n\nEventually Lyles rolled sideways and got his torso off the ground, but even the effort to get to his knees proved too much. Eventually, he was helped off in the wheelchair.\n\nInitially, it appeared that the extraordinary mental and physical effort that went into his 100 win had taken a toll. But as Lyles explained later, his gas tank was empty for another, more serious reason.\n\n\"I tested positive around 5 a.m. Tuesday morning,\" he said. \"I woke up in the middle of the night just feeling the chills, aching, sore throat. And those were kind of a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting COVID and I was just like, I need to test this one. We tested it and you know, came back positive.\n\n\"I still wanted to run the final. It was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and just tried to take it round by round and, you know, to be honest, I knew if I wanted to come out here I would have to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. So that was kind of the strategy.\"\n\nLyles was unable to say whether he'd run in Friday night's 4x100 relay, where the US men are favored for gold. Again, with the benefit of growth, perspective, and maturity, he was able to accept how much of this is out of his hands.\n\n\"I'll talk to the coaches,\" he said. \"I've been very honest and transparent with them, and I'm going to let them make the decision.\n\n\"I believe that no matter what's happened, this four-by-one team is very capable, they can handle anything and everything. I've been with them in practice. They are more than capable to come out with a win and even break as many records as they stick their mind to.\"\n\nLyle was soon ushered away by Team USA officials, walking slowly by their sides as he exited the mixed zone. But unlike three years ago, the lack of a bounce in his step did not signify sadness, anxiety, or depression. He knew he'd done his best, and that was enough.\n\nAs he told NBC, \"My first thought was not to panic, thinking I've been in worse situations. {"uri": "8265938663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:55:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:55:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:54:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/covid-positive-noah-lyles-leaves-191158761.html", "title": "Noah Lyles tested positive for Covid but kept it secret from his 200m rivals", "body": "Noah Lyles revealed that he tested positive for Covid on Tuesday but kept it secret from his competitors following his failed attempt to emulate Usain Bolt's 100m-200m Olympic sprint double.\n\nThe American, who had won the 100m by just 0.005sec on Sunday, said that he woke in the early hours of Tuesday with a sore throat, chills and aches but still lined up in the 200m final, before slumping at the side of the track after an emphatic defeat by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nLyles did still run 19.70sec to emulate his Olympic bronze medal of 2021 but said that his performance was impacted and that he felt light-headed and experienced chest pain immediately following the race. He required medical treatment trackside and, after being briefly placed in a wheelchair, recovered to speak with media from behind a mask.\n\n\"I do have Covid,\" he said. \"I tested positive at around 5am on Tuesday morning. There were a lot of symptoms. We tested it and it came back positive. We quickly quarantined to a hotel near the village to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure my body was able to just keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I was going to compete regardless. We just stayed away from everybody and took it round by round. This is the best I've felt out of the last three days. I'm not 100 per cent - but 90 to 95 per cent.\"\n\nAsked if his competitors, including American team-mate Kenny Bednarek, and those he raced in Wednesday night's semi-final, had known, Lyles admitted that he had largely kept his virus secret.\n\n\"We tried to keep this as close to my chest, most of the people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mom and my family,\" he said. \"We didn't want everybody going into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it as discreet as possible.\n\n\"You never want to tell your competitors you are sick - why would you give them an edge over you? It definitely affected my performance. I was coughing through the night last night. I'm more proud of myself than anything - to come out and get the bronze medal with Covid.\"\n\nTebogo, who began celebrating Bolt-style some metres before the finish, would still have taken some beating. Lyles's personal best is 19.31sec and Tebogo dominated the race from start to finish, producing the fifth-fastest 200m in history to run 19.46sec and win his country's first Olympic gold.\n\nThe 21-year-old's closest challenge was Bednarek, who beat Lyles to repeat the silver medal he had won in Tokyo with a time of 19.62sec.\n\nLyles said that the USA team will decide on Friday whether he {"uri": "2024-08-448546409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:34:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:34:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:21:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.cubaheadlines.com/articles/286566", "title": "Noah Lyles Overcomes COVID-19 to Secure Bronze in 200 Meters", "body": "Noah Lyles, the stellar American sprinter and favorite to win the gold medal in the 200 meters at Paris 2024, faced unforeseen circumstances on Thursday, ending up with the bronze medal despite competing while infected with COVID-19.\n\nAccording to CBS Sports, Lyles, the reigning Olympic champion in the 100 meters, saw his performance significantly impaired due to the illness, which was diagnosed last Tuesday. The 2023 world titleholder in the 200 meters suffers from asthma and, according to various sources, was seen wearing a mask before the race and showed considerable signs of exhaustion afterward.\n\nIn fact, he was never a serious contender for the top spot against the champion Letsile Tebogo from Botswana, who covered the distance in a phenomenal 19.46 seconds, setting an African record and ranking among the best times ever. Another respected American sprinter, Kenny Bednarek, finished in second place with 19.62 seconds. The fatigued Lyles followed in third with a time of 19.70, requiring medical assistance on the track and later being attended to backstage.\n\nIt is worth noting that the International Olympic {"uri": "8265815571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:01:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:01:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T18:59:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.insidesport.in/chak-de-india/paris-2024-botswana-letsile-tebogo-becomes-first-african-man-to-win-200m-olympics-gold-stuns-noah-lyles-in-final/", "title": "Letsile Tebogo becomes first African man to win 200m Olympics Gold, stuns Noah Lyles in final - Inside Sport India", "body": "This race, one of the most memorable in recent Olympic history, showcased the depth of talent emerging from Africa, with Tebogo now firmly establishing himself as one of the brightest stars in global athletics.\n\nIn a historic and electrifying final at the 2024 Paris Olympics, Letsile Tebogo of Botswana stunned the athletics world by becoming the first African man to win the gold medal in the 200m event. Tebogo's remarkable performance not only secured him the top spot on the podium but also left world champion and 100m Olympic champion Noah Lyles in disbelief as he settled for bronze.\n\nThe men's 200m final was highly anticipated, especially with Noah Lyles chasing a potential quadruple gold haul.\n\nNoah Lyles, running in lane five, was widely expected to dominate, with fierce competition from Erriyon Knighton in lane six, Tebogo in lane seven, Kenny Bednarek in lane eight, and Joseph Fahnbulleh in lane nine. The tension was palpable as the athletes lined up, with the crowd's excitement needing to be hushed before the start.\n\nFrom the start, Lyles seemed to be in control, getting off to a powerful beginning alongside Bednarek. However, as they approached the curve, it was Tebogo who emerged as the surprise contender. The Botswana sprinter, running with extraordinary speed and determination, surged ahead in the final stretch. As the finish line approached, it became clear that Tebogo was going to make history.\n\nCrossing the line in an African record time of 19.46 seconds, Tebogo claimed the gold, leaving Bednarek to take silver with a time of 19.62 seconds. Noah Lyles, the reigning world champion and heavy favourite, could only manage bronze, finishing in 19.70 seconds.\n\nLetsile Tebogo's victory is not just a personal achievement but a monumental moment for African athletics. His win marks the first time an African man has ever won the 200m gold at the Olympics, a milestone that will inspire future generations of athletes across the continent.\n\nThis race, one of the most memorable in recent Olympic history, showcased the depth of talent emerging from Africa, with Tebogo now firmly establishing himself as one of the brightest stars in global athletics. {"uri": "8266141787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:57:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:57:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:57:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/2024-olympics-noah-lyles-says-i-believe-this-will-be-the-end-of-my-2024-olympics-as-he-battles-covid-19/", "title": "2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles says 'I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics' as he battles COVID-19 - CBSSports.com", "body": "The Team USA track star took bronze in the men's 200 meter on Thursday Getty Images\n\nNoah Lyles' dream start to the 2024 Olympics came crashing down thanks to COVID-19, and now the illness is threatening to cut his time in Paris short, too.\n\nTeam USA's star sprinter posted on Instagram, with part of his caption reading, \"I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics. It is not the Olympic I dreamed of but it has left me with so much Joy in my heart. I hope everyone enjoyed the show. Whether you were rooting for me or against me, you have to admit you watched, didn't you?\"\n\nThe post came shortly after Lyles finished a disappointing third in the men's 200 meters, his signature event. He received medical assistance following the race and was wheeled off of the track.\n\nLyles, who also suffers from asthma, awoke Tuesday with a sore throat, aches and chills, telltale signs to him that he had COVID-19 according to Yahoo! Sports. After a test came back positive, he quarantined in a local hotel, rested, got fluids and loaded up on medicine that wouldn't violate anti-doping rules. He finished second in a preliminary run Wednesday before Thursday's bronze.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" Lyles said after running a 19.70 seconds, nearly four-tenths slower than his personal best.\n\nHe added he did not consider skipping the race, and there are no rules in place prohibiting COVID-positive athletes from competing. Instead, the call is up to the teams and athletes themselves. Lyles was seen wearing a surgical mask prior to the races Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" a statement from USA Track & Field read. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely. As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nLyles was hoping to complete the coveted 100-200 double after winning the 100 meters on Sunday, two days before he started feeling symptoms. He was also expected to compete on the men's 4x100 relay, though his Instagram post certainly puts that in doubt.\n\n\"I'll talk to the coaches,\" Lyles said. \"To be honest, I want to be very honest and transparent with them. leg of a 4x400m relay would be a waste as he didn't see him as a starter.\n\nGoing further to imply that he didn't believe Hall's talents would be well optimised in any leg of the relay.\n\n'The only reason I wouldn't use the current U.S. champion is that I just don't think he'd be a starter,\" Lyles said.\n\n'Using him on the first leg would almost be like a waste of his talents.'\n\nThe slight diss warranted a response from Hall who took offence to the exclusion.\n\nHe responded on 'X' with a tweet of his own which read 'Noah Lyles, I don't bother nobody, but my blocks ready anytime you {"uri": "8265964151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:19:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:19:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:18:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/us-olympic-sprint-star-lyles-tests-positive-for-covid/article_faf00fec-ed95-5691-9f8c-9dcc1dc48769.html", "title": "US Olympic sprint star Lyles tests positive for Covid", "body": "Olympic 100m champion Noah Lyles revealed he tested positive two days before finishing third to take bronze in Thursday's 200m final.\n\nLyles, who had been bidding to complete a 100m-200m double in Paris, was taken off the track in a wheelchair following the race, won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nThe 27-year-old Lyles, who has suffered from asthma in the past, had been seen wearing a surgical mask shortly before Thursday's 200m final.\n\nHowever, there had been no sign of illness when the American was introduced to the crowd before the race, bounding onto the track and gesticulating with his arms to pump up the crowd.\n\nIn an interview with NBC, Lyles said: \"I woke up early, about 5:00am on Tuesday morning and I was feeling really horrible.\n\n\"I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100 (metres). We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nLyles later told reporters that his illness \"definitely affected my performance\".\n\n\"But to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything,\" he added. \"Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\nMore from this section Dutch PM risks early ejection from fire hazard office US in 'around-the-clock' push against Mideast war Drug Approved to Fight Rare Cancer That Hits Young Adults\n\n\"We tried to keep this as close to the chest. Only people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mom, my family. We didn't want everybody to go into a panic.\n\n\"We wanted them to be able to compete. And you don't really want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give an edge over you?\"\n\nUSA Track and Field said in a statement that US team officials had \"enacted all necessary protocols to prioritise his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors\" following Lyles' positive test on Tuesday.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" the statement said.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. {"uri": "8260615314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:02:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:02:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:01:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/newsletter/fos-pm-lyles-ready-to-capitalize/", "title": "FOS PM: Lyles Ready to Capitalize - Front Office Sports", "body": "Noah Lyles's Paris Olympics saga is far from over. The 27-year-old is still looking for gold in the 200-meter sprint, which would make him the first man since Usain Bolt in the 2016 Rio Games to win both the 100-meter and 200-meter races, or what's known as the \"double.\"\n\nLyles is the heavy favorite to win the event -- his odds are at -460 on FanDuel Sportsbook -- as he's significantly more experienced in the 200-meter than in the 100-meter. His 200-meter accolades encompass three world championships, including the last two titles, and a bronze medal from the 2021 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nOn Monday, Lyles won his Round 1 heat and qualified for the 200-meter semifinals, slowing in the final stretch when he had clearly won the race.\n\n\"The 200 is my wife, and the 100 is my mistress,\" Lyles said on the Netflix docuseries \"Sprint\" before winning the double in the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\nDouble or not, Lyles's win in the 100-meter, the most prestigious track event, solidifies his title as the fastest man in the world.\n\nComparisons between Bolt and Lyles are inevitable, and the American has declared that he wants to challenge Bolt's world-record times.\n\n\"He's the fastest man to ever do it, and soon it'll be me,\" Lyles told CNN in March.\n\nBut, like Bolt, Lyles also wants to impact the sport beyond the track. Bolt's dominance and longevity made him the face of the sport, but his bravado, which includes a signature pose, made him one of the world's most marketable athletes.\n\nLyles, from his shots at NBA players to showing Yu-Gi-Oh! cards before big races, has already shown the swagger to become a media focal point. The question now is how high he can go in a sport that only receives significant international fanfare every four years during the Olympics.\n\nAfter winning the 100-meter race on Sunday, Lyles, an Adidas athlete since 2016, told reporters that he wants his own signature shoe, particularly a training shoe and not a track-and-field spike.\n\n\"I want my own shoe. I want my own trainer. Dead serious. I want a sneaker, ain't no money in spikes. There's money in sneakers,\" Lyles said.\n\nIt may not be a coincidence that Lyles made his statement the day after Bolt launched a signature lifestyle shoe with Puma.\n\nAthletic brands often reserve their signature shoes for athletes in more accessible and marketable sports, particularly basketball. There are some other athletes with their own signature lines that come with lifestyle and training shoes, such as On with Roger Federer and Adidas with Patrick Mahomes.\n\nThose are two of the greatest athletes in their sport's history, so a shoe or clothing line would cement Lyles as the face of track and field.\n\n\"With today's win, and everything he has achieved in his career so far, Noah has cemented his greatness and place as one of the leading athletes in the world. We're proud to have been able to support him on every step of his journey since our partnership began in 2016,\" said Alberto Uncini Manganelli, Adidas's general manager of running and credibility I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100,\" Lyles told NBC Olympics' Lewis Johnson. \"You know, woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for Covid. My first thought was not to panic. I'm thinking, you know, I've been in worse situations, you know i've run with, you know, worse conditions i've felt. And we just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off.\"\n\nAre athletes who tested positive for Covid able to compete in the Olympics?\n\nThe U.S. Olympic Paralympic Committee told TODAY.com athletes are encouraged to follow safety protocols, including washing hands, wearing face masks during travel, and seeking out medical staff if you feel sick. If an athlete tests positive, the USOPC said it will help set them up with individual housing and transportation.\n\n\"We will allow them to train and compete as long as they feel up to it,\" the USOPC said to TODAY.com. Infected athletes will be required to wear masks indoors and around other people, according to the USOPC.\n\nUSA Track & Field released a statement supporting Lyles' decision to compete:\n\n\"We can confirm that Noah Lyles tested positive for COVID-19 on Tuesday, August 6th. In response, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\n\n\"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nThe International Olympic Committee did not immediately respond to a request from NBC News on Thursday about Covid policies and the number of cases among its athletes.\n\nNBC New York reached out to the Paris 2024 Organizing Committee for comment.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo won the gold in the men's 200m denying Lyles his chance at a 100m-200m double sprint gold, a feat not accomplished by an American since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nLyles later congratulated Tebogo on social media after the race.\n\n\"LETSILE TEBOGO congratulations [champagne emoji.] ik you have had a very rough year off the track and despite that you overcame it all!,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"Heal up. {"uri": "2024-08-448557279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:51:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:51:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:49:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-alexandria-watch-party/", "title": "In Alexandria, fans cheer Noah Lyles, their hometown hero", "body": "Sorry, a summary is not available for this article at this time. Please try again later.\n\nThe world knows him as Noah Lyles, Olympic gold medalist and now two-time bronze medalist, world champion and one of the fastest men in the world.\n\nBut to many Alexandrians, he's long been a hometown hero. The Olympian graduated from Alexandria City High School in 2016, then known as T.C. Williams, and was a standout on the track along with his brother, Josephus.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, ahead of Lyles' 200-meter race, about 400 people gathered for a watch party in Alexandria City's gymnasium, hosted by the city of Alexandria, the Lyles Brothers Sports foundation and Alexandria City's public school system.\n\nSpotty showers didn't stop them from filling the auditorium. Red, white and blue balloon garlands were on full display as guests entered, greeted by red and blue pompoms ruffling together nonstop. Guests showed off their American pride, donning blue glow-in-the-dark glasses, bracelets and necklaces.\n\nBefore the race started, attendees passed around a blue canvas where they wrote notes of encouragement and congratulations for Lyles. The idea came from Romona Williams, a 57-year-old Alexandria resident who brought the canvas and wanted to document the event.\n\n\"We're here to capture the history of everybody coming together, unity in Alexandria City,\" said Williams, a mother of two Alexandria City graduates. \"They're showing love and writing good things. It doesn't take just his family to support [Lyles], this is a USA thing going on here.\"\n\nThe Lyles Brothers Sports foundation, which promotes health and wellness in Alexandria, kept the crowd entertained ahead of the race. They hosted a round of trivia, asking questions only true Lyles fans would know, for a grand prize of a Team Lyles hat. The fans delivered and answered all of the questions right, even down to his best record in a 200-meter race, birthday and first track event at Alexandria City: not the 200 meter but the high jump.\n\nAt 2:30 p.m., Lyles took off, and the crowd roared. As the runners got closer to the 200-meter mark, fans rose, hoping Lyles would inch closer to take the lead. When he crossed the finish line and ended in third place -- not the outcome many had hoped for -- a mix of groans and sighs of disappointment filled the auditorium.\n\nBut shortly after, the moment of defeat turned into pride. The Alexandria City marching band played their fight song as fans remained standing.\n\n\"We love you, Noah!\" they chanted.\n\nThe stream at the auditorium ended before guests could see Lyles leaving the field in a wheelchair. His covid infection came as news to close family and friends at the watch party, who said they were waiting on confirmation from Lyles's mother, Keisha Caine Bishop.\n\nBishop called Lori Hawkins, special events coordinator of the Lyles Brothers Sports Foundation, about an hour after the race confirming Lyles had covid.\n\n\"It wasn't going to stop him,\" Hawkins said. \"He still wanted to go out to do his best in the 200, and he came away with a bronze. So, we are so proud of him, and he's a proud of himself. He did it.\"\n\nFor Delano Frazer, Lyles's older brother, proud was an understatement. The 34-year-old made it to the watch party just in time to watch his brother race. Although Lyles didn't get the gold, Frazer said placing in the Olympics is enough of an achievement he can carry with pride forever.\n\n\"It's still surreal that my brother's up there,\" Frazer said. \"You already won the 100, still to say you're the fastest man in the world. You have that title, run with it, and you come back with a bronze in the 200.\"\n\nGetting the gold may have been the goal, but to see Lyles place in the Olympics was enough for Sharon Hennessee, assistant events coordinator at the Lyles Brothers Sports foundation.\n\n\"I'm always just proud to see Noah out there doing the best that he can -- win, lose, draw, however -- just watching him out there because you can't get to the level that he's at without doing a lot of work to get there. ... I know that the family is proud of him, no matter where he places,\" Hennessee said.\n\nIt's unclear whether Lyles will compete in more races, such as the 100-meter relay. But Alexandrians will have other ways to celebrate their hero: At local restaurant Holy Cow, fans can order a burger named after the athlete. Like Lyles, it's got the full package: angus beef, cheddar, bacon, sweet bread and butter pickles, lettuce, tomato and ranch on a brioche bun.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jordan_d_brown@washingtonpost.com", "name": "Jordan D. something he perceived to be a disadvantage.\n\n'Never seen favoritism like this on a global scale,' he wrote on X.\n\nBednarek has since issued a protest with officials and has been moved to lane 8 - something that could help him to return to the podium.\n\nAmerican sprinter Kenny Bednarek has received a new lane assignment since this post on X\n\nKenny Bednarek (right) is pictured alongside his teammate and rival, Noah Lyles (left)\n\nRead More Noah Lyles comes from behind to win 200 meters at Olympic trials with fastest time of 2024\n\nBednarek won a silver medal in the 200 at the 2020 Tokyo Games by racing in lane 7, narrowly edging teammate and Olympic rival Noah Lyles, who was in the third lane.\n\nThis time Lyles, the 100-meter champion, will be racing the 200 in lane 4.\n\nThe 200 is Lyles' preferred, and better, distance - one at which he had not lost in three full years.\n\nThat streak was snapped in the semifinals at the Stade de France, where Letsile Tebogo of Botswana beat him to the line by crossing in 19.96 seconds, 0.12 faster than runner-up Lyles.\n\nThey'll have a rematch for the gold on Thursday night with Bednarek and 20-year-old phenom Erryion Knighton on hand.\n\nGetting golds in the 100 and 200 at a single Olympics is a rare feat.\n\nUsain Bolt accomplished that double at three Olympics in a row - in Beijing in 2008, London in 2012 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. But until the Jamaican, no man had done it since Carl Lewis at Los Angeles in 1984.\n\nAt his last Games, eight years ago, Bolt was shutting it down late in his 200 semifinal, and suddenly realized Andre De Grasse was running hard. {"uri": "8265558621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "15:38:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T15:38:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T15:36:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/olympics/news/noah-lyles-necklace-usa-sprinter-diamond-chain-link-olympics/6cbfa9acf8661bb391a6a63f", "title": "Noah Lyles necklace, explained: Why USA sprinter wears diamond chain link during Olympics and how much it costs", "body": "When Noah Lyles wins on the track, he does so in style.\n\nThe American sprinter is making waves in Paris at the 2024 Olympics. The Florida native already claimed gold once, winning the 100-meter dash in dramatic fashion, narrowly defeating the field in a photo finish.\n\nNow Lyles has a chance at winning double gold when he hits the track at Stade de France on Thursday, aiming to win the 200-meter race. He owns the world's third-fastest time in the event and is viewed as the favorite to take the sprint.\n\nLyles does not lack any confidence in himself -- a key component of why he is an Olympic gold medalist and six-time world champion. That belief he has in himself flows over into his appearance as well. Lyles paints his fingernails before races, joining a select list of high-end athletes who do so.\n\nHe also wears a thick necklace around his neck that seemingly does not hold him back when it comes to the races.\n\nHere is more to know about Lyles' necklace and where it is from.\n\nUSA OLYMPICS MEDAL COUNT: Overall table | U.S. medal tracker | Who has won gold?\n\nWhen Lyles won the 100-meter race earlier in the Olympics, a necklace made of white metal with mariner links was seen around his neck.\n\nFor those who have been following Lyles' track and field career, it may not come as a surprise to see it. He previously wore the chain at other competitions, including the 2023 World Athletics Championships where he swept the 100-meter and 200-meter events.\n\nLooking at the necklace, it appears to be made out of three different metals, alternating between white, yellow and silver gemstones that appear to be diamonds.\n\nMORE: How Noah Lyles overcame depression, anxiety to make Olympics run\n\nIt's unclear who makes the necklace. Lyles has not discussed the piece of jewelry much at all in his career, so the creator and cost of the necklace are not known.\n\nIt is possible that the necklace is the product of The Village Jeweler, a jewelry company based out of Gainesville, Fla., -- Lyles' hometown. The company previously posted on Facebook in 2021 that it appeared to create a ring for Lyles, consisting of rose gold accents and gemstones that represented the five Olympic rings.\n\nIn addition, The Village Jeweler also posted a 2021 TikTok video of Lyles discussing a custom rose gold and diamond necklace he bought from the company.\n\nEither way, like the painted fingernails, the necklace {"uri": "8265930197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:46:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:46:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/08/08/olympic-roundup-noah-lyles-comes-up-short-in-200-meters-while-battling-covid/", "title": "Olympic roundup: Noah Lyles comes up short in 200 meters while battling COVID", "body": "Noah Lyles, of the United States, is taken from the track in a wheelchair following the men's 200-meters final at the 2024 Summer Olympics on Thursday. Petr David Josek/Associated Press\n\nSAINT-DENIS, France -- Noah Lyles lost the Olympic 200 meters Thursday, falling to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo, then being tended to by medics who carted him off the track in a wheelchair. Later, wearing a mask as he spoke with reporters, Lyles said he had COVID.\n\nAfter crossing the line third for the second straight Olympics, Lyles fell to his back and writhed around in pain, staying down for nearly 30 seconds before getting up, asking for water and getting to the wheelchair.\n\nIt's the second straight Olympics the virus has played a major role in Lyles' trip to the Games. He also won the bronze in the Tokyo Olympics, and he has said the empty stands and the year-long delay before the Games led to depression that hampered his performance and inspired his road to Paris.\n\nTebogo, 21, led wire-to-wire and won in 19.46 seconds, the fourth-fastest time in history, but .15 slower than Lyles' top time. Kenny Bednarek finished in 19.62 for his second straight silver, and Lyles, four nights after winning a close-as-can-be 100, ran the curve in 19.70.\n\nThe first sign something might be wrong came a night earlier when Lyles finished second in a lackluster semifinal, then left the track without talking to reporters to head to the medical tent. His coach said he was fine. It became clear he was not when Tebogo and Bednarek reached the curve in the final.\n\nLyles was trailing as they headed into the homestretch, which is usually where he puts on a trademark closing finish that has always been the best part of this race. This time - nothing. Only a desperate push to the line then a collapse onto the purple track.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWATER POLO: The U.S. women's water polo team was eliminated by Australia in the semifinals of the Paris Olympics on Thursday night, ending its run for a fourth consecutive gold medal.\n\nAustralia went 6 for 6 in a penalty shootout and goalkeeper Gabi Palm denied Maddie Musselman on the last attempt of the tiebreaker, sending the Aussies into the final. It was Australia's third win of the Paris Games via penalty shootout.\n\nNext up for Australia is Spain, which advanced with a 19-18 victory over the Netherlands in a penalty shootout. The gold-medal match is on Saturday at Paris La Defense Arena.\n\nThe U.S. blew a 5-2 halftime lead in its second loss of the Paris Games and third loss at the Olympics overall since it dropped the 2008 final against the Netherlands. It went 5-0-1 in London, 6-0 in Rio de Janeiro and 6-1 in Tokyo.\n\nNo team - men's or women's - has won four straight water polo titles at the Olympics.\n\nMEN'S FIELD HOCKEY: A sprinkler inexplicably went off and delayed play for a couple of minutes. A dramatic shootout victory set off a wild celebration that was interrupted briefly when a scuffle almost broke out.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe men's Olympic field hockey final had a little bit of everything. And now the Netherlands has gold for the first time in more than two decades.\n\nDuco Telgenkamp scored the golden goal in the shootout to give the Dutch the title at the Paris Games with a 2-1 victory over Germany. It's the Netherlands' first gold in men's hockey at the Olympics since 2000 and third in the country's history.\n\nAs Dutch players piled on each other in the corner to celebrate, Germany's Niklas Wellen took exception and began shoving a rival, leading officials to separate the teams.\n\nThe tensions were much different than the confusion nearly an hour earlier when water began spraying the sideline and field 3:28 into the third quarter. Workers ran over to stop the shower, and the crowd at Yves-du-Manoir Stadium cheered when the water went off after about two minutes.\n\nCYCLING: World champion Ellesse Andrews of New Zealand won the Olympic title in the women's keirin at the Paris Games on Thursday night, holding off Dutch rider Hetty van de Wouw and Britain's Emma Finucane in a sprint to the finish line.\n\nIn the men's omnium, Benjamin Thomas of France overcame a crash in the concluding points race to hold off Portugal's I\u00fari Leit\u00e3o for gold. He finished with 164 points, Leit\u00e3o had 153 and Fabio van den Bossche of Belgium took bronze with 131.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe keirin is a sprint race involving six riders who begin by pacing for three laps behind a motorized scooter. When it pulls off, the riders are left with three laps to conduct an elbow-to-elbow, high-speed dash to the finish.\n\nSPORT CLIMBING: Sam Watson leaves the Paris Games with another world record in speed sport climbing but without the Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe American broke the speed world record on Thursday for the second time at the 2024 Paris Olympics, but the feat came in the fight for the bronze after he was eliminated in the semifinals.\n\nThe 18-year-old Watson, the heavy favorite for the gold, lost to Wu Peng of China in the semifinals before setting a record of 4.74 seconds in the third-place heat. Leonardo Veddriq of Indonesia won the gold with a time of 4.75 in the final. Wu ended with 4.77.\n\nWOMEN'S GOLF: Morgane Metraux had eight 3s on her card on the front nine - an 8-under 28 - until getting slowed by the wind and a bad shot at the wrong time. She still had a 6-under 66, giving her a one-shot lead over Ruoning Yin of China at the halfway point of the women's golf competition.\n\nWRESTLING: Vinesh Phogat, the Indian woman who qualified for the Olympic final at 50 kilograms and then was disqualified for barely missing weight, announced her retirement on social media on Thursday.\n\nIn a post translated from Hindi, Phogat said: \"My courage is broken, I don't have any more strength now. Goodbye Wrestling, 2001-2024.\"\n\nUnited World Wrestling, the sport's governing body, disqualified Phogat on Wednesday morning. Team India said she was 100 grams - about a fifth of a pound - over the weight limit. Instead of becoming India's first woman to compete in an Olympic final, she went home empty-handed.\n\nCYCLING: A longtime stalwart of the U.S. women's pursuit squad, Chloe Dygert teamed with newly minted Olympic road race champion Kristen Faulkner, Jennifer Valente and Lily Williams to beat New Zealand in the finals. And in doing so, Dygert was able to finally hear her nation's anthem while standing on the top step of the podium.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nRelated Stories
