final slot", "body": "Noah Lyles has taken one step closer to his dream of achieving an individual Olympic sprint double in Paris after securing his spot in the 200m final at the Stade de France.\n\nTo add to American delight, another United States pace merchant, Quincy Hall, came from nowhere to grab victory in an electrifying finish to the 400m.\n\nLyles claimed 100m gold by five one thousandths of a second on Sunday night, and needed to finish in the top two from semi-final heat two to automatically book his place in Thursday night's showdown.\n\nLyles crossed his fingers with a tongue-out grin as the camera cut toward him on the big screen.\n\nLike that 100m final, Lyles got out to the slowest start of the eight-man field, but made up for it when he crossed the line in 20.08 semis.\n\nSecond quickest was Lyles' American team-mate Kenny Bednarek, the 2022 world and Tokyo 2020 silver medallist, who made easy work of the first semi-final in exactly 20 seconds.\n\nDominican Alexander Ogando and a third American, Erriyon Knighton, rounded out the top five while Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh and Zimbabwe duo Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba also qualified.\n\nShortly afterwards, Hall produced a sensational finish to win Olympic 400m gold which denied Britain a first gold in the event in a century.\n\nHall, the world championship bronze medallist, trailed into the home stretch but then exploded and caught the leading Matthew Hudson-Smith right on the line for victory in a personal best 43.40.\n\nHall is the first American since LaShawn Merritt in 2008 to capture gold in the one-lap race. His victory came an evening after American Cole Hocker came from far behind late to beat the favourites in the men's 1500m.\n\nHudson-Smith lowered his European record to 43.44 but it was only good enough for silver. He had been bidding to become the first British man to win the 400m since Eric Liddell in 1924, also in Paris.\n\nThe bronze went to Zambia's Muzala Samukonga in 43.74 as five men dipped below 44 We woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for Covid.\"\n\nLyles later told reporters that his illness \"definitely affected my performance\".\n\n\"But to be honest, I'm more proud of myself than anything,\" he added. \"Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep this as close to the chest. Only people who knew were the medical staff, my coach, my mom, my family. We didn't want everybody to go into a panic.\n\n\"We wanted them to be able to compete. And you don't really want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give an edge over you?\"\n\nUSA Track and Field said in a statement that US team officials had \"enacted all necessary protocols to prioritise his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors\" following Lyles' positive test on Tuesday.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" the statement said.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. {"uri": "8265989001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:46:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:46:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:45:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/noah-lyles-swept-200m-final-214101575.html", "title": "Noah Lyles swept into 200m final like a whirlwind and shuffled away in a wheelchair", "body": "For a man stricken with Covid, Noah Lyles had lost none of his gift for choreography. This born showman swept into this 200 metres final like a whirlwind and shuffled away from it in a wheelchair.\n\nIn between, he saw his dream of becoming the first American man since Carl Lewis to win the Olympic sprint double dashed by a young Botswanan fuelled by pure emotion. Letsile Tebogo, who lost his mother only two months ago, stole Lyles's thunder by seizing gold with the fifth-fastest time in history, making 19.46sec look so easy that he could afford to drop his arms and thump his chest before the finish line.\n\nIt is all part of Lyles's thespian exuberance that he can be the central figure in the drama even in defeat. While it seemed at first as if this bronze medal - a huge downgrade on the Olympic title he had targeted for three years - was the product of poor strategy, he revealed in the bitter aftermath that it had all come down to him feeling poorly. All his meticulous preparation had come undone when, 24 hours before this race, he tested positive for Covid, leaving him unable to hit the blistering top speed that could have reeled in Tebogo.\n\nIn truth, even a peak-condition Lyles would have struggled to live with the 21-year-old in this mood. Tebogo was astounding, so blisteringly quick that he could afford to indulge in a premature celebration. The scene was reminiscent of Usain Bolt in that unforgettable 100m final at Beijing 2008, when, with the Jamaican the same age then as Tebogo is now, he shut down with 20 to spare and still ran 9.69. Oh for the fearlessness of youth. Lyles, at 27, is a relative veteran, encumbered by the vast expectations he heaps on himself.\n\nParis, he had long told anybody who would listen, was his stage. Lyles had orchestrated all the Netflix cameras and ostentatious headgear for this very moment, when he intended to deliver the double that would cement all those comparisons with Bolt. The longer sprint is by far his favourite event, where his best of 19.31 stands above even Michael Johnson's epochal run in Atlanta 28 years ago. There was even talk of hunting down Bolt's world record of 19.19, one of the finest in the book. But the onset of illness soon punctured these delusions of grandeur.\n\nLyles described how he knew as early as Tuesday morning, 36 hours after his 100m gold, that he was in trouble, \"feeling really horrible\". Sure enough, he tested positive for Covid, but tried desperately not to panic. He had run in worse predicaments, he said, and tried to stave off the worst effects by staying hydrated. And yet the 200m is a discipline that punishes even the slightest sign of ill health. Perhaps his sluggish semi-final time of 20.08 should have been a warning. For when it came to the final, he lacked his customary acceleration off the curve, trailing in behind Tebogo and US compatriot Kenny Bednarek in a result that no one had foretold.\n\nThe timing is desperately unfortunate. For all that Lyles can grate with his look-at-me excesses, and his stated aim to emulate Michael Jordan by launching his own range of trainers, he is the carnival act that athletics sorely needs. Where Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone, the superstar of the night with her 50.37 world record in the 400m hurdles, gives precious little away in interviews, Lyles is unabashedly an open book, happy to talk about everything from his music collection to his nail polish. He adores the limelight to such an extent that he even gatecrashed a Mondo Duplantis interview after the Swede's giddying 6.25m pole vault, shrieking \"All-star, let's go!\"\n\nThis time he was a touch more muted, knowing how rare an opportunity had passed him by. Only nine men in history have doubled up at the Olympics over 100 and 200, and Lyles fully intended to be the 10th. But he was upstaged by a brilliant Botswanan sprinter on a single-minded quest. His mother died on May 19, and he left little doubt that he was still in profound grief, crossing the line with his hand on his heart.\n\n\"It wasn't really clicking for me that she's really gone,\" Tebogo explained. \"I have to find the reason why I started my athletics journey and why I should continue going on.\" The spikes that he brought here to Paris were also marked with her date of birth to honour her. \"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field. To take her with me, it gives me a lot of motivation. She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy. I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.\"\n\nLittle in this Paris sprint programme has unfolded as predicted. Champions have sprung from the unlikeliest places: first came Julien Alfred from St Lucia, and now Tebogo from Botswana, both grasping their countries' first gold medals in Olympic history. It has been a stirring reflection of this sport's universal appeal.\n\nLyles, however, has been left cursing his luck. He arrived here with designs only on being the history man. Instead, he has been reduced to the unfortunate invalid.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8266105348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:12:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:12:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:10:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/fans-dont-believe-noah-lyles-has-covid-after-missing-gold-in-200m/article_e607576f-3ebe-528f-8d81-964c139131f9.html", "title": "Fans Don't Believe Noah Lyles Has COVID After Missing Gold In 200m", "body": "Fans were shocked to see Noah Lyles lose the 200-meter race in the 2024 Paris Olympics on Thursday.\n\nHe was the odds-on favorite to win the race but got bronze. After the race, he revealed that he was diagnosed with COVID-19 two days ago but still wanted to compete anyway.\n\nLyles had to be taken off the track in a wheelchair following the race.\n\nDespite getting bronze, some fans think Lyles doesn't actually have COVID-19 and are trying to tear him down for losing.\n\n\"already with the excuses,\" one tweet read.\n\n\"he had the excuse ready,\" another tweet read.\n\n\"Bet he wouldn't have had COVID if he won,\" another fan tweeted.\n\n\"He needs a wheelchair? Wtf? This is embarrassing and ridiculous,\" another tweet read.\n\nObviously, these fans are dead wrong because it was confirmed that he tested positive for the virus before he chose to participate in the race.\n\nLyles was trying to become just the tenth person to pull off winning the 100-meter final and 200-meter final, and the first American to do it since Carl Lewis did back in 1984.\n\nHe'll leave {"uri": "8262268120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "18:06:26", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T18:06:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:05:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://andscape.com/features/noah-lyles-sneaker-demand-is-bigger-than-just-shoes/", "title": "Noah Lyles' signature sneaker demand is bigger than just shoes", "body": "Olympic gold medalist is thinking beyond his sport, even if the odds of a deal aren't in his favor\n\nWhat does being the fastest man in the world get you? Besides a gold medal and bragging rights, sprinter Noah Lyles hopes the distinction comes with a signature sneaker.\n\n\"I want my own shoe. I want my own trainer. I'm dead serious,\" said Lyles after his victory Sunday in the men's 100 meters at the Paris 2024 Olympics. \"I want a sneaker, ain't no money in [track] spikes. There's money in sneakers and even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. I feel like for how many medals [track athletes] bring back, for all the notoriety [track athletes] get, the fact that that hasn't happened yet is crazy to me.\"\n\nIt's a point of order, but Johnson got a signature sneaker, the Nike Zoom JST, in 1998. The shoe didn't sell particularly well, and that might be part of a more significant hurdle that even the best track star might find too high. Usain Bolt, the world's fastest man ever, also received the signature treatment during his track career. In June 2012, Bolt's longtime endorser, Puma, released the evoSpeed Runner Usain Bolt ahead of the London Olympics, where he won gold in the 100-meter final with a still-standing record time of 9.63 seconds. Puma also delivered the signature Bolt evoSpeed cleat, which he wore in his final Olympics appearance in 2016.\n\nFor all the well-deserved notoriety people such as Lyles, Sha'Carri Richardson, Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, and Allyson Felix bring to their sport every four years, it's still just every four years. Track and field remains a niche sport that airs on television in spots not quite ready for prime time. The sport isn't seeing the commas the NBA and WNBA just saw in their landmark broadcast deals. Occupying that more minor part of the media landscape means less recognizable faces. The unfortunate reality is that runners stay in the limelight when their names appear in a scandal. And that's even if they have a couple of medals to their name. While Lyles' point about track competitors facing world-class competition is valid, along with his beliefs about their athletic ability, those facts alone don't move the needle much.\n\nIt's easy to understand why Lyles wants this for himself and, more importantly, for the sport he loves. Even without squinting, it's not impossible to see his vision. The Virginia native ruffled a few feathers at the world championships in 2023 when he compared track and the NBA, questioning the legitimacy of the league calling itself \"world champions.\" While the comments went viral, the context of his words fell on deaf ears. Lyles made a more significant point about attracting attention to the sport. Winning medals is his first, second, and third goal. Still, he never stopped thinking about how to leverage that success for a larger platform.\n\n\"After you get the medals, more and more people gain interest. You can go into fashion, you can go into music. You can start collaborating with people and start meeting bigger and better athletes. From athletes, you go to artists and from artists, you go to the world. And now you have connections,\" Lyles said.\n\nLyles makes those connections by transforming himself into an undeniable brand. Skills alone no longer pay the bills. But combining one's ability with a gift of gab and a flair for the dramatic usually equals set for life. And Lyles is halfway there.\n\nSimilarly to Richardson, Felix, Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, and track legends such as sprinters Usain Bolt, Gail Devers, and Florence Griffith Joyner, the world's fastest man stands out. Lyles wore a striking pair of Adidas Adizero Y-3 spikes created by Paris-based Japanese designer Yohji Yamamoto. He runs in chain-link necklaces covered in diamonds. The man also rocks a Speedmaster watch by Omega, the official timekeeper of the Olympics, and Lyles is a brand ambassador. Anyone can call themselves an icon, but few have the confidence to paint different designs and messages on their nails like the Alexandria, Virginia, native did for the Olympics. To Lyles' point about making connections, retired NBA guard Dwyane Wade noticed the nails and gave the gold medalist his props, as did NBA legend Magic Johnson. Besides Johnson's humble brag about watching the Olympics on a yacht, these looks can ensure Lyles' name rings bells in places that matter. It helps that he has the personality to match the jewelry and colorful digits.\n\nHe calls his shots and basks in the spotlight whenever it comes his way, especially if he can use it to his advantage. It didn't bother him when NBA players attacked him for those comments in 2023. For Lyles, the fact that they responded was a testament to his status.\n\n\"When I got the title of world's fastest man, now all of a sudden people perk up their ears like, 'The world's fastest man said that? I can't believe you would say something like that,' \" Lyles said.\n\nEven Bolt, the man Lyles wants to overtake in the record books, said the 27-year-old's personality and attitude are exactly what the sport needs. That same charisma Bolt sees is one reason Lyles is featured in the Netflix docuseries Sprint and is the subject of the upcoming Peacock series Untitled: The Noah Lyles Project. If success is about preparation, opportunity, and timing, the stars look aligned for Lyles, who has an endorsement deal with Adidas.\n\nConvincing Adidas to give him his patented sneaker is still easier said than done. A signature shoe deal usually pays the athlete 5% or 6% royalty sales of every shoe. The number of shoes sold should be enough to justify the millions invested in the athlete and help the company's bottom line. Suppose the typical deal pays a base salary between $5 million and $15 million annually and comes with a 5% royalty check for every shoe sold. In that case, that's an enormous bet that the company and the star must work in their favor. NBA players are on TV screens almost every night from October to June. Even if it's a game that does not feature someone with branded kicks, there's a good chance another player will wear a pair, given the relationship multiple players have with Nike, Adidas, and Under Armor. Lyles would need more close moments with audiences more often and find enough running buddies in and outside his sport willing to put his name on their feet.\n\nIt's a long shot, but what else is new for the man who earned America's first gold medal in the 100-meter dash in 20 years? Lyles is an asthmatic who runs faster than any man on the planet. He has attention deficit disorder, dyslexia, depression and anxiety. He wears those ailments as proudly as his love of Dragon Ball Z and Yu Gi Oh! It's easy for observers to side-eye his demand for his branded kicks. All it takes is one person and one moment to change everything. Lyles understands social media, wears his emotions on his sleeves, shows off with the best of them, and ensures all eyes stay on him.", "source": {"uri": "andscape.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8266098966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:03:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:03:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:02:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://thesun.my/sport/2024-paris-olympics/athletics-botswana-s-tebogo-becomes-africa-s-first-200m-champion-II12836538", "title": "Athletics-Botswana's Tebogo becomes Africa's first 200m champion", "body": "PARIS: Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the men's Olympic 200 metres title on Thursday when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and a COVID-hit Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 when finishing sixth in 100m final, produced a dominant last 50 metres and crossed the line in 19.46 seconds, beating his chest as he become the fifth-fastest man in history over 200m.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, who had been hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, repeating his Tokyo bronze in 19.67.\n\nIt was the triple world champion's first defeat in a 200m final for three years. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race U.S. officials said he had tested positive for COVID on Tuesday, two days after he won the 100 metres gold.\n\n\"In response (to the test, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritise his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors,\" USATF said in a statement.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against Lyle's name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box before the race start.\n\nAFRICA'S NIGHT\n\nThe Lyles show might still hog much of the limelight, but on the track it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three positions, Tebogo's place on top of the podium in an African record was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old told reporters.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew Kenny was going to run away so made sure just to close him down, I have that top-end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"\n\nBednarek, the man in the middle again, ran a fantastic bend in lane eight and finished strongly, but not just quite fast enough.\n\n\"I don't think I put my best race down, it was really tight at the end,\" he said.\n\n\"This year I'm finally healthy. I can build off this. There's also the world championships next year. I'm going to be dangerous. {"uri": "8265966842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:22:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:22:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:21:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/tebogo-pride-africa-wearing-shoes-his-mum-4536741", "title": "Tebogo is pride of Africa wearing shoes for his mum", "body": "PARIS : Botswana's Letsile Tebogo was the toast of Africa after winning the Olympic 200 metres gold on Thursday but his immediate thoughts were much closer to home as he dedicated his victory to his mother who died in May.\n\nTebogo became the first African to win the event when he ran 19.46 seconds to beat Americans Kenny Bednarek and a COVID-hit Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal and become the fifth-fastest man in history over the half-lap.\n\nHe did it wearing spikes bearing his mother's date of birth.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take,\" Tebego told reporters. \"Me, to take her, it gives me a lot of motivation.\n\n\"I didn't want to put the date of her death, because I'll get emotional.\n\n\"I took about a month without doing anything. It wasn't really clicking for me that she's really gone. For me, I have to find the reason why I started my athletics journey and why I should continue going on.\n\n\"(If she were here) I believe she could be one of the happiest people on the planet because she believed in me when I doubted myself.\"\n\nIt was an historic day for Africa with the continent having four athletes in the final for the first time, after also providing two in the 100m final, where Tebogo came sixth and South Africa's Akani Simbine was fourth.\n\nAsked if his breakthrough performance could help him follow in the footsteps of Usain Bolt as the sport's biggest name, he quietly shook his head.\n\n\"I can't be the face of athletics as I'm not a loud or arrogant person like Noah,\" he said.\n\nLyles was a hot topic in the post-race press conference, from which he was absent, after U.S. officials revealed that he had tested positive for COVID on Tuesday, two days after winning the 100 metres.\n\nLyles wore a face mask in the call room before the race and though Tebogo wondered why, he said he did not want to make assumptions.\n\nBednarek, who repeated his silver from Tokyo, was also asked about the COVID situation.\n\n\"I don't think I was put at risk,\" he said.\n\n\"When I found out, it wasn't that big of a deal. He went out there and did his best while he was sick and I hope he gets better.\"\n\nBoth men were originally expected to run in Friday's 4x100m relay final after the U.S. qualified without them on {"uri": "8265863209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:44:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:44:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:43:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/olympics/news/letsile-tebogo-botswana-noah-lyles-200m-olympics/0f494214db43e2dbae727ecc", "title": "Who is Letsile Tebogo? Meet 21-year-old Botswana sprinter who upset USA star Noah Lyles in 200m final at Olympics", "body": "All eyes were on Noah Lyles in the 200-meter final, but the United States star couldn't capture the coveted \"double\" at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nInstead, it was Letsile Tebogo who ran away with the gold medal in Thursday's final.\n\nThe Botswanan sprinter finished in 19.46, clearing the rest of the competition with ease. He set a new African record as well as becoming the first person from Botswana to win an Olympic gold medal. Kenneth Bednarek and Lyles finished in second and third, respectively.\n\nTebogo dedicated his gold medal to his late mother who died in May 2024 due to an illness.\n\n\"I believe there is a medal in these legs and it only needs the determination and the willpower to do it,\" Tebogo said earlier during the 2024 Olympics. \"I've had such a huge blow that affected me deeply so I'm still trying to get the confidence back into the body. It's not about injuries, it is all about my mum.\"\n\nHere is everything you need to know about Tebogo's background.\n\nMORE: Full results, highlights from 200-meter final at 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nTebogo is a 21-year-old sprinter from Botswana. He won the gold medal in the 200-meter final at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nTebogo raced out to a 19.46 time, easily beating the pack for first place. Bednarek placed second with a time of 19.62 while Lyles finished third in 19.70.\n\nMORE: How many medals does Noah Lyles have?\n\nThe 19.46 time was an African record for the 21-year-old. Tebogo is making his Olympic debut in Paris. He also ran in the 100-meter final a few days ago, placing sixth with a time of 9.86.\n\nIt's the first Olympic medal of Tebogo's career, and he's only been a full-time track and field athlete since 2019. He played soccer as a teenager before realizing track and field would allow him to compete around the world.\n\n\"With athletics, I was going abroad and that was when I took that decision to transform from being a footballer to being an athlete,\" Tebogo told BBC in January.\n\nTebogo is from Botswana, which is located in the southern portion of Africa. The country has an approximate population of 2.53 million, according to worldometers.com.\n\nIt's the first gold medal for any African sprinter in the 200-meter, and first Olympic gold medal for any athlete from Botswana. Tebogo stands alone atop the leaderboard, making history for his home country and continent.\n\nThe 21-year-old is one of many African athletes at the 2024 Paris Olympics, and his 200-meter gold medal shines a brighter light on the continent and Botswana specifically.\n\n\"It's more like a surprise to me,\" Tebogo told BBC in January. \"I think I'm taking it well. {"uri": "8264102773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "19:28:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T19:28:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T19:27:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/articles/clyn29v1j70o", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles sets up shot at Olympic sprint double", "body": "American Noah Lyles has the chance to become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete an Olympic sprint double after qualifying for the 200m final at Paris 2024.\n\nLyles won 100m gold by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish on Sunday.\n\nThe 27-year-old, winner of three golds at last year's World Championships, finished second in his semi-final in 20.08 seconds to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nWorld 100m silver and 200m bronze medallist Tebogo set the fastest time of the round at Stade de France on Wednesday evening, clocking 19.96secs.\n\nThe Olympic men's 200m final takes place on Thursday at 19:30 BST.\n\nKenneth Bednarek, of the United States, also set a faster time than Lyles, in 20.00, while compatriot Erriyon Knighton, who upgraded to world 200m silver last year, also safely progressed.\n\nBut Canada's Andre de Grasse will not defend his title in the final after finishing third in his race (20.41).\n\nThe Olympic 200m bronze winner three years ago, Lyles claimed world 100m, 200m and 4x100m gold in Budapest last year.\n\nFollowing that achievement, when he became the first man since Bolt in 2015 to complete a 100m and 200m world double, he claimed he could look to add the 4x400m relay title to that treble haul in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint legend Bolt completed individual sprint doubles at three successive Olympic Games among his eight titles, adding relay gold in 2012 and 2016.\n\nOnly nine men have achieved that double in the history of the Games.\n\nLyles became the first American to win an Olympic 100m title for 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in 2004, with his narrow 100m triumph.\n\nA three-time reigning world 200m champion, he will line up as favourite as he looks to further assert himself as the dominant male sprinter of the current generation.\n\nElsewhere during Wednesday's evening session, Great Britain's Amber Anning reached the final of the women's 400m.\n\nOlympic debutant Anning, 23, finished second in her semi-final in a personal best of 49.47.\n\nHowever, team-mates Laviai Nielsen (50.69) and Victoria Ohuruogu (51.14) missed out.\n\nIreland's Rhasidat Adeleke was among the other qualifiers for that final, which takes place on Friday at 19:00.\n\nTeam GB's Alastair Chalmers exited the men's 400m hurdles after suffering a fall in his semi-final.\n\nNorway's world record holder Karsten Warholm qualified fastest for the final in 47.67.\n\nTade Ojora was unable to reach the men's 110m hurdles final, finishing seventh in his heat.\n\nAmerican three-time world champion Grant {"uri": "8265699881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "17:21:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T17:21:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T17:21:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/noah-lyles-has-4-word-warning-for-everyone-before-the-200m-final/article_95c842fb-9b53-52ff-bf81-c3e140009167.html", "title": "Noah Lyles Has 4-Word Warning For Everyone Before The 200m Final", "body": "We're merely hours away from the men's 200m final in the Summer Olympics and Noah Lyles hopes to join a handful of Olympic legends as winners of both the 100m and the 200m in a single Olympic Games.\n\nAhead of the games, Lyles had a four-word warning that only some fans were likely to understand:\n\n\"Omae wa-mo shindeiru,\" Lyles wrote.\n\nWhile that may seem like nonsense words, it's actually Japanese for \"You are already dead\" - a reference from the iconic anime Fist of the North Star. The scene depicts the protagonist Kenshiro having defeated an enemy without them having even realized it yet.\n\nLyles has made it known for a long time that he's a diehard anime fan. During the Olympic qualifying events he frequently showed off some of his prized and most powerful Yu-Gi-Oh cards to signify his dominance all en route to winning his signature events.\n\nHaving already won the gold medal in the 100m dash, Lyles now has a chance to become just the 10th athlete in history to win both the 100m and the 200m in a single Olympics. He would join the likes of Jesse Owens, Bobby Morrow, Carl Lewis and Usain Bolt in that distinguished category.\n\nLyles only narrowly won the 100m, but the 200m is where he really excels. {"uri": "8265940446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:58:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:58:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:56:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.runnersworld.com/news/a61829128/noah-lyles-covid-paris-olympics/", "title": "Should Noah Lyles Have Been Allowed to Compete in the 200 Meters With COVID?", "body": "We earn a commission for products purchased through some links in this article. Why Trust Us?\n\nIn Paris on August 7, after 200-meter world champion and American record-holder Noah Lyles finished second in his semifinal heat of the 200 meters, he did not stop to talk to media in the mixed zone.\n\nThat was unusual for Lyles -- he isn't one to pass up the opportunity to speak. Instead, he was reported to be seeking medical treatment.\n\nAnd one day later, after the final of the 200 meters, the world knows why. Lyles tested positive for COVID on Tuesday morning, he told trackside reporter Lewis Johnson of NBC after the final. Letsile Tebogo of Botswana won in 19.46, Kenny Bednarek of the United States was second in 19.62, and Lyles was third in 19.70.\n\nLyles left the track in a wheelchair, but he went through the mixed zone, the subterranean room at Stade de France where athletes talk to the media, on foot. He was masked as he answered questions from reporters.\n\nHe said he started to feel poorly at about 5 a.m. on August 6, with a fever, chills and a sore throat. A test revealed COVID. But Lyles said it was \"never a thought\" not to compete and he said by the 200 meters on Thursday, he was at about 90 to 95 percent health. Lyles is taking Paxlovid.\n\nHe kept his diagnosis very private, so as not to give an advantage to his competitors.\n\nAll this begs the question: What are the rules about competing at the Olympics with COVID?\n\nShort answer: It's up to the athlete.\n\nScientific American reported that the Paris Games are treating COVID like any other respiratory illness. There are single rooms in the Olympic Village for athletes who have COVID. And athletes who are sick are encouraged to wear masks, wash their hands frequently, and avoid contact with others.\n\nLani Pallister, an Australian swimmer who contracted COVID, withdrew from the 1500 meters in order to save energy for a later race. An unnamed Australian water polo player was isolating after getting sick, but Anna Meares, the head of the Australian Olympic delegation, said in an article on the Olympic news service, \"I need to emphasize that we are treating COVID no differently to other bugs like the flu. This is not Tokyo.\"\n\nAthletes who have talked to reporters in the track's mixed zone said illnesses was circulating through the athletes at the Olympic Village. Jakob Ingebrigtsen spoke to media after the 1500 meters wearing a mask, thought to be a precaution. Grant Fisher, who won bronze in the 10,000 meters, was not staying in the village and in fact went back to altitude in St. Moritz, Switzerland, before the start of the 5,000 meters.\n\nIt has not yet been determined whether Lyles, who won the 100 meters, will compete on the 4 x 100-meter relay team for the U.S. \"I'm going to be honest and transparent with them and let them make the decision,\" Lyles said. \"I believe that no matter what happens, this 4 x 100 team can handle anything.\"\n\nUSA Track & Field did not immediately respond to questions from Runner's World.\n\nKenny Bednarek, silver medalist in the 200 from the U.S., said he hadn't noticed a lot of cases of COVID going around the Olympic Village in Paris. He added he didn't know that Lyles had COVID before the race and that it doesn't really bother him.\n\n\"Sometimes I'm just carefree and minding my own business,\" Bednarek said. \"There was a message that there was something going around, but I haven't seen anything.\"\n\nAs previously reported in Runner's World, rushing back to running and exercise after you've had COVID isn't always the best idea.\n\nIn May 2023, researchers published a literature review in Frontiers in Physiology to determine if high-intensity activity could be dangerous for someone with COVID infection. While intense exercise does come with benefits -- such as improved cardiovascular function and metabolic health -- they concluded that during and after a COVID infection, intense exercise influences the levels of stress hormones (adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine), which may make COVID symptoms more severe.", "source": {"uri": "runnersworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Runner's The American runner experienced both success and disappointment while also leaving in a wheelchair. So what happened?\n\nHeading into the game, the track and field star didn't hold his tongue as he spoke his mind about his intent to win multiple gold medals in Paris. He even hopped onto The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon to say as much. He backed up his words by winning the 100-meter finals albeit by a hair -- almost literally. Then, he used the post-race press conference to claim he will win the 200-meter and that his competitors will be depressed when he comes off that turn during the race. He even directed his attention to his teammates, saying they won't win, including Kenny Bednarek.\n\nWell, despite always speaking his mind, he didn't quite back up his words this time, as Bednarek finished ahead of him, taking silver, and Letsile Twnogo from Botswana won gold. It forced Lyles to settle for bronze, which is something he has not bragged about but should certainly be happy about.\n\nHowever, immediately after the race, Lyles was seen struggling on the track, asking for water, and very clearly out of breath as if he had just run a marathon, causing people to speculate if he was sick and -- if he was -- why was he so extremely hyper before the race. In retrospect, it's incredibly odd to see him waste that energy, especially in a situation where he clearly needed it. He was then taken off the track on a wheelchair.\n\nLater on, he gave an interview while wearing a black mask and said he woke up feeling horrible two days before the race, then tested positive for Covid. \"We took it day by day,\" he said. \"It's taken its toll for sure.\"\n\nHowever, he refused to use it as an excuse, saying \"I ran in worse conditions.\" Since he was deemed sick, he was asked if he considered not running in the race, to which he answered, \"No.\" Lyles was expected to run in the 4x400m relay this weekend, but noted that he wasn't sure if he would because of his condition. {"uri": "2024-08-448534675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:17:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:17:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:13:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/sports/20240808-tebogo-races-into-legend-as-first-african-man-to-claim-olympic-200m-title", "title": "Tebogo races into legend as first African man to claim Olympic 200m title", "body": "Letsile Tebogo from Botswana entered legend on Thursday night when he became the first man from Africa to win the 200m at an Olymp\u00eec Games.\n\nThe 21-year-old scorched home in 19.46 seconds. He beat the American duo of Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles into second and third place respectively.\n\nThe men's 200m has been a feature of the Olympic Games since the second edition in 1900.\n\nSince then, 17 of the winners have come from the United States. Jamaica, courtesy of Don Quarrie and Usain Bolt's hat trick, boasts four.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion,\" said Tebogo. \"It's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push throughh and when I made it to the final my coach told me: 'Now it's your race.'\"\n\nTebogo said his tactic was to keep Bednarek in his sights.\n\n\"I knew that when the gun went Kenny was going to run away so I needed to make sure just to close him down.\n\n\"I have that top end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\"\n\nTebogo finished in the fifth fastest time over the distance.\n\nThe joy comes as he mourns his mother who died in May.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family,\" Tebogo added.\n\nLyles, who was attempting {"uri": "8265939597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:57:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:57:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:55:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-confirms-he-raced-200m-final-with-covid-after-claiming-bronze-as-letsile-tebogo-takes-gold/a574322592.html", "title": "Noah Lyles confirms he raced 200m final with Covid after claiming bronze as Letsile Tebogo takes gold", "body": "Noah Lyles revealed he had Covid after collecting Olympic 200 metres bronze on Thursday night.\n\nThe American sprinter said he tested positive around five o'clock on Tuesday morning and woke up in the middle of the night \"with chills\".\n\nLyles, the Olympic 100 metres champion said he quickly quarantined in a hotel, but insisted on competing in the final won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nThe 27-year-old, who was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt to win both Olympic sprint titles, said the illness had affected his performance.\n\nHe said: \"I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100 metres and 200 metres titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100 metres gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo, 21, became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last May.\n\nIt is a second 200 metres bronze for Lyles, who had also hoped to compete in the men's 4\u00d7100 metres and 4\u00d7400 metres relays in Paris, though the latter was a long-shot if he were in a position to secure four Olympic golds in one Games - a feat Bolt never achieved.\n\nLyles admitted he was feeling \"quite lightheaded\" and experienced chest pain following the 200 metres final, which he finished in 19.70 seconds.\n\nHe said: \"This is by far the best day I've felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I am 100 per cent but I am closer to 90 or 95.\n\n\"I only had one shot and then I will be down for a while. Me and my therapist said 'it's one and done, there is no holding back'.\n\n\"We haven't decided on the (4\u00d7100 metres) relay yet.\n\n\" I'll talk to the coaches and to be honest, I'm gonna be very honest and transparent with them, and I'm gonna let them make the decision.\n\n\"I believe that no matter what happens this four by one team can handle anything and everything. I've been with them in practice. They are more than capable to come out with a win and even break as many records as they take their mind to.\"\n\nA USA Track and Field statement read: \"We can confirm that Noah Lyles tested positive for COVID-19 on Tuesday, August 6th. In response, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\n\n\"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [], It is not the Olympics I dreamed of but it has left me with so much joy in my heart,\" he wrote on Instagram.\n\nLyles leaves an Olympic champion but the abrupt end to his campaign was almost certainly a bitter pill to swallow, as he had set the ambitious goal of winning four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay and the 4x400m relay.\n\nIt also marked the triple 200 world Chronicle", "body": "AMERICAN Noah Lyles has the chance to become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete an Olympic sprint double after qualifying for the 200m final at Paris 2024.\n\nLyles won 100m gold by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish on Sunday.\n\nThe 27-year-old, winner of three golds at last year's World Championships, finished second in his 200m semi-final in 20.08 seconds to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nWorld 100m silver and 200m bronze medallist Tebogo set the fastest time of the round at Stade de France on Wednesday evening, clocking 19.96secs.\n\nThe Olympic men's 200m final takes place today at 19:30 BST.\n\nKenneth Bednarek, of the United States, also set a faster time than Lyles, in 20.00, while compatriot Erriyon Knighton, who upgraded to world 200m silver last year, also safely progressed.\n\nBut Canada's Andre de Grasse will not defend his title in the final after finishing third in his race (20.41).\n\nThe Olympic 200m bronze winner three years ago, Lyles claimed world 100m, 200m and 4x100m gold in Budapest last year.\n\nFollowing that achievement, when he became the first man since Bolt in 2015 to complete a 100m and 200m world double, he claimed he could look to add the 4x400m relay title to that treble haul in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint legend Bolt completed individual sprint doubles at three successive Olympic Games among his eight titles, adding relay gold in 2012 and 2016.\n\nOnly nine men have achieved that double in the history of the Games.\n\nLyles became the first American to win an Olympic 100m title for 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in 2004, with his narrow triumph.\n\nA three-time reigning world 200m champion, he will line up as favourite as he looks to further assert himself as the dominant male sprinter of the current generation\n\nElsewhere during Wednesday's evening session, Great Britain's Amber Anning reached the final of the women's 400m.\n\nOlympic debutante Anning, 23, finished second in her semi-final in a personal best of 49.47.\n\nHowever, team-mates Laviai Nielsen (50.69) and Victoria Ohuruogu (51.14) missed out.\n\nIreland's Rhasidat Adeleke was among the other qualifiers for that final, which takes place on Friday at 19:00hrs.\n\nTeam GB's Alastair Chalmers exited the men's 400m hurdles after suffering a fall in his semi-final.\n\nNorway's world record holder Karsten Warholm qualified fastest for the final in 47.67.\n\nTade Ojora was unable to reach the men's 110m hurdles final, finishing seventh in his heat.\n\nAmerican three-time world champion Grant Holloway recorded the fastest time in 12.98 as he seeks to upgrade his Tokyo silver.(BBC Sport)", "source": {"uri": "guyanachronicle.com", I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo, 21, became the first man from his Tebogo. The 21-year-old Gaborone native ran 200 meters in 19.50 seconds at the World Athletics Diamond League meet in London in 2023.\n\nTebogo won two medals at the world championships in Budapest in 2023, taking silver in the 100-meter race and bronze in the 200-meter race.\n\nPreviously, Botswana-one of the most sparsely populated countries on Earth-had only two Olympic medals to its name. Both were athletics medals, in the men's 800-meter race in London in 2012 and in the men's 4-by-400-meter relay in Tokyo in 2021.\n\nGiven his young age, it appears likely that Tebogo will be a factor {"uri": "2024-08-448579733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:24:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:24:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:55:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/sports/olympics/athletics-botswanas-tebogo-wins-mens-200-metres-gold-2024-08-08/", "title": "Athletics-Botswana's Tebogo becomes Africa's first 200m champion", "body": "PARIS, Aug 8 (Reuters) - Letsile Tebogo became the first African to win the men's Olympic 200 metres title on Thursday when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and a COVID-hit Noah Lyles to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who set a national record of 9.86 when finishing sixth in 100m final, produced a dominant last 50 metres and crossed the line in 19.46 seconds, beating his chest as he become the fifth-fastest man in history over 200m.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, who had been hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, repeating his Tokyo bronze in 19.67.\n\nIt was the triple world champion's first defeat in a 200m final for three years. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race U.S. officials said he had tested positive for COVID on Tuesday, two days after he won the 100 metres gold.\n\n\"In response (to the test, the USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritise his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors,\" USATF said in a statement.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against Lyle's name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box before the race start.\n\nAFRICA'S NIGHT\n\nThe Lyles show might still hog much of the limelight, but on the track it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three positions, Tebogo's place on top of the podium in an African record was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing moment,\" the 21-year-old told reporters.\n\n\"I just came here with the little that I had in me to push through because yesterday we made it to the final, my coach told me 'now it's your race'.\n\n\"I knew Kenny was going to run away so made sure just to close him down, I have that top-end speed that will allow me to finish the race without getting tired, so that's what I did, and when I saw Kenny fade I knew Noah was far, far away behind us so that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It means a lot for everybody, the country, the continent and my family.\"\n\nBednarek, the man in the middle again, ran a fantastic bend in lane eight and finished strongly, but not just quite fast enough.\n\n\"I don't think I put my best race down, it was really tight at the end,\" he said.\n\n\"This year I'm finally healthy. I can build off this. There's also the world championships next year. I'm going to be dangerous. I expect big things in the next four years.\"\n\nReporting by Mitch Phillips, editing by Ed Osmond\n\nOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8265925928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:42:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:42:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:41:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/olympics-2024/noah-lyles-reveals-he-had-covid-but-chose-to-compete-in-200-metres-final-1659444.html", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals he had Covid but chose to compete in 200 metres final | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Noah Lyles revealed he had Covid after collecting Olympic 200m bronze on Thursday night.\n\nThe American sprinter said he tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning and woke up in the middle of the night \"with chills\".\n\nLyles, the Olympic 100m champion, said he quickly quarantined in a hotel, but insisted on competing in the final won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nThe 27-year-old, who was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt to win both Olympic sprint titles, said the illness had affected his performance.\n\nHe said: I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100m and 200m titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100m gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo (21) became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last May.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8265888761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:10:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:10:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:07:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/letsile-tebogo-botswana-runner-won-200127846.html", "title": "Who is Letsile Tebogo, the Botswana runner who won 200m over Noah Lyles at Paris Olympics?", "body": "Letsile Tebogo started pounding the \"Botswana\" on his jersey in celebration before even crossing the finish line. He had stunned the world at the 2024 Paris Olympics, winning the 200m and earning the gold medal over heavy favorite Noah Lyles of the United States.\n\nTebogo made all sorts of history by beating Lyles, who settled for the bronze medal, and silver medalist Kenny Bednarek. But for track and field enthusiasts, Tebogo's emergence wasn't completely unexpected.\n\nHe has been a rising star for a few years, even drawing comparisons to Usain Bolt prior to his introduction to an international audience on Thursday. He also beat Lyles Wednesday in the 200m semifinals - the first race Lyles had lost in the 200m since the Tokyo Olympics - in a precursor to what Tebogo pulled off in the final.\n\nHere's what else you should know about Tebogo now that he's known for dethroning Lyles in his signature event:\n\nTebogo was born in Kanye, Botswana, a village in the southern portion of the country. He moved to Botswana's capital city, Gaborone, in the seventh grade.\n\nBy winning the gold medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics, Tebogo became the first Olympic gold medal winner from Botswana and the first runner from Africa to win the 200m final at the Olympic Games. In 2023, he became the first African to win a medal in the 100m at the world championships.\n\n\"Africans can be sprinters, too,\" Tebogo declared to NBCSports.com in an interview before the Paris Games.\n\nTebogo's mother, Seratiwa, died in May from an illness and Tebogo said he dedicated his 200m gold medal win to her. Tebogo held up his shoe to the camera after the race, and it featured his mother's birthdate on it. He also painted her initials on his nails.\n\n\"I always think about her but I just try not to let it get into me that much and then just block it out and move forward,\" Tebogo said last week. \"I believe there is a medal in these legs and it only needs the determination and the willpower to do it. I've had such a huge blow that affected me deeply so I'm still trying to get the confidence back into the body. It's not about injuries, it is all about my mum.\"\n\nIn 2022, at the U20 world championships in Columbia, Tebogo set a world junior record in winning the 100m gold medal in 9.91 seconds. He was far enough ahead in the final stretch that he turned around and smiled at his nearest competitors. Tebogo later explained it was a tribute to Bolt as opposed to showboating.\n\n\"If somebody took it as disrespect, I'm really sorry,\" Tebogo said at the time, according to Reuters. \"(It was so) everybody watching at home can enjoy the race - to remind them a little bit about what Usain Bolt did back in the day. He's my idol - the person I look up to.\"\n\nThe display quickly drew comparisons to Bolt on social media and Bolt even retweeted a post featuring Tebogo's finish.\n\n\"I used to train without shoes,\" Tebogo told NBCSports.com. \"Shoes were more expensive and we couldn't afford that because we lived with our extended family, so it was difficult for us to get things. [If you did], it would be as if you were the favored child, so things had to be equal. So I used to train without shoes in both football and athletics. I would wear a pair of old pants that one of my uncles used to wear back when he was in school. It was just a generational thing.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_metres", {"uri": "8264703461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "06:23:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T06:23:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T06:22:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://realnewsmagazine.net/lyles-sets-up-shot-at-olympic-sprint-double-in-200m/", "title": "Lyles sets up shot at Olympic sprint double in 200m - Realnews Magazine", "body": "AMERICAN Noah Lyles has the chance to become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete an Olympic sprint double after qualifying for the 200m final at Paris 2024.\n\nLyles won 100m gold by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish on Sunday.\n\nThe 27-year-old, winner of three golds at last year's World Championships, finished second in his 200m semi-final in 20.08 seconds to Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nWorld 100m silver and 200m bronze medallist Tebogo set the fastest time of the round at Stade de France on Wednesday evening, clocking 19.96secs.\n\nThe Olympic men's 200m final takes place on Thursday at 19:30 BST.\n\nKenneth Bednarek, of the United States, also set a faster time than Lyles, in 20.00, while compatriot Erriyon Knighton, who upgraded to world 200m silver last year, also safely progressed.\n\nBut Canada's Andre de Grasse will not defend his title in the final after finishing third in his race (20.41).\n\nThe Olympic 200m bronze winner three years ago, Lyles claimed world 100m, 200m and 4x100m gold in Budapest last year.\n\nFollowing that achievement, when he became the first man since Bolt in 2015 to complete a 100m and 200m world double, he claimed he could look to add the 4x400m relay title to that treble haul in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint legend Bolt completed individual sprint doubles at three successive Olympic Games among his eight titles, adding relay gold in 2012 and 2016.\n\nOnly nine men have achieved that double in the history of the Games.\n\nLyles became the first American to win an Olympic 100m title for 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in 2004, with his narrow triumph.\n\nA three-time reigning world 200m champion, he will line up as favourite as he looks to further assert himself as the dominant male sprinter of the current generation.Media caption,\n\nGB's Anning makes final\n\nElsewhere during Wednesday's evening session, Great Britain's Amber Anning reached the final of the women's 400m.\n\nOlympic debutant Anning, 23, finished second in her semi-final in a personal best of 49.47.\n\nHowever, team-mates Laviai Nielsen (50.69) and Victoria Ohuruogu (51.14) missed out.\n\nIreland's Rhasidat Adeleke was among the other qualifiers for that final, which takes place on Friday at 19:00.\n\nTeam GB's Alastair Chalmers exited the men's 400m hurdles after suffering a fall in his semi-final.\n\nNorway's world record holder Karsten Warholm qualified fastest for the final in 47.67.\n\nTade Ojora was unable to reach the men's 110m hurdles final, finishing seventh in his heat.\n\nAmerican three-time world champion Grant Holloway recorded the fastest time in 12.98 as he seeks to upgrade his Tokyo silver. - bbcsport", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8260991417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "02:21:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T02:21:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T02:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/paris-2024-olympics-noah-lyles-eases-through-200m-heats-athletics-track-and-field-results-standings/article68491079.ece", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles eases through 200m heat in bid for sprint double", "body": "Less than 24 hours after winning 100 metres gold, Noah Lyles began his quest for the prestigious Olympic sprint double by cruising through his 200m heat on Monday in 20.19 seconds.\n\nThe American has always been stronger over the longer distance, where he is unbeaten in 25 races dating back to the Tokyo Olympics in 2021 when he came third, and he has won the last three world titles.\n\nLyles is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay. That would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with a long jump instead of the longer relay.\n\n\"It feels good to be out here,\" Lyles told reporters. \"It was in my head win the 120, win the 150, check around, win the heat.\"\n\nAsked what life had been like since his photo-finish victory, he said: \"I've been trying to get some sleep with my phone going off constantly. Right now I've got to rush over and get my medal.\"\n\nFollowing him home in 20.30 was defending champion Andre de Grasse of Canada, the last man to beat him.\n\nAmerican Kenny Bednarek, silver medallist ahead of Lyles in Tokyo and runner-up to him at the 2022 worlds, shut down early but still clocked the fastest time with 19.96.\n\nHe too went well in Sunday's 100m final, though his 9.88 was good enough only for seventh.\n\n\"I'm on a mission for this 200,\" he said. \"What happened yesterday happened. I'm taking it day by day.\"\n\nALSO READ | Paris 2024: Faith Kipyegon's 5000m silver medal reinstated after appeal\n\nErriyon Knighton, world championship silver and bronze medallist as a teenager, made sure there would be three Americans in the semi-finals by winning his heat in 19.99, the only other sub-20 time on a warm Paris evening.\n\nNow 20, Knighton will seek to deliver on the biggest stage after seemingly being the next big thing for years but never quite reaching the top step.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo, sixth in Sunday's 100m final in a national record 9.86 and a bronze medallist over 200m in last year's world championships, cruised his heat in 20.10.\n\nWayde van Niekerk, the 400m world record holder and former world championship silver medallist over 200m, made it as the third automatic qualifier from the first heat in 20.42 having opted the skip the one-lap event in Paris.\n\n\"The decision (to run only the 200) was purely based on getting back to a space of enjoying the sport,\" said the South African. \"Finding peace in a sport that has helped me so much.\n\n\"If I look at my performance so far, I'm obviously well off the top-tier guys. I'm going to have to pull a rabbit out of the hat to get among the top three.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarParis 2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles eases through 200m heat in bid for sprint double ReutersParis {"uri": "8260789461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "22:03:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T22:03:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T21:59:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/cfb-nfl/noah-lyles-declares-bold-ambition-after-winning-gold-in-100m-dash-at-paris-olympics/article_5be75e34-7325-5cbd-af25-73d685306aac.html", "title": "Noah Lyles Declares Bold Ambition After Winning Gold in 100m Dash at Paris Olympics", "body": "Noah Lyles, fresh off his electrifying gold medal win in the 100-meter sprint at the Paris Olympics, is now aiming for a different kind of victory -- one in the world of sports marketing. The 27-year-old American sprinter, known for both his speed and his swagger, has voiced a bold new ambition: securing his own signature sneaker.\n\nLyles' victory on Sunday was a nail-biter, as he edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by just five-thousandths of a second. This win not only underscores his status as the world's fastest man but also sets the stage for his push into the commercial spotlight.\n\nAlready sponsored by Adidas, Lyles has captured attention with his on-track performances and charismatic personality. His latest triumph, coupled with a substantial $50,000 prize and a lucrative endorsement deal -- the richest for a sprinter since Usain Bolt -- puts him in a prime position to demand more.\n\n\"I want my own shoe. I want my own trainer. I'm dead serious,\" Lyles said, while at the Paris 2024 Olympics press conference. \"I want a sneaker; ain't no money in spikes. There's money in sneakers. Even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. I feel like for how many medals we bring back, for the notoriety we get, the fact that that hasn't happened is crazy to me. I was like, 'Yeah, that needs to happen.'\"\n\nLyles' call for a signature shoe highlights a broader issue within not just the track and field community, but Olympic athletes in general. By advocating for his own sneaker, Lyles is seeking personal gain but he's also aiming to pave the way for future Olympic stars, particularly in his own sport.\n\nAs he prepares to return to the track for the 200-meter race, Lyles is eyeing another milestone. He has the chance to become the first sprinter since Usain Bolt in 2016 to win both the 100-meter and 200-meter events at the same Olympics, a feat known as the \"double.\" This ambition follows his first double victory at the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\nLyles' quest for a signature sneaker could revolutionize how track and field athletes are marketed and compensated. If successful, it would mark a significant shift, recognizing the commercial potential and star power of track athletes in a way that hasn't been fully realized before.\n\nAs Lyles continues to break records and push boundaries, his determination to secure a signature sneaker symbolizes his broader vision: transforming his athletic success into a lasting legacy both on and off the track.", {"uri": "8260487250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:05:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:05:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:04:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/noah-lyles-is-chasing-usain-bolt-on-and-off-the-track/", "title": "Noah Lyles Is Chasing Usain Bolt On and Off the Track", "body": "The Adidas athlete could also become the most marketable track star since Bolt.\n\nNoah Lyles's Paris Olympics saga is far from over. The 27-year-old is still looking for gold in the 200-meter sprint, which would make him the first man since Usain Bolt in the 2016 Rio Games to win both the 100-meter and 200-meter races, or what's known as the \"double.\"\n\nLyles is the heavy favorite to win the event -- his odds are at -460 on FanDuel Sportsbook -- as he's significantly more experienced in the 200-meter than in the 100-meter. His 200-meter accolades include three world championships, including the last two, and a bronze medal in the 2021 Tokyo Olympics.\n\n\"The 200 is my wife, and the 100 is my mistress,\" Lyles said on the Netflix docuseries \"Sprint\" before winning the double in the 2023 World Athletics Championships.\n\nDouble or not, Lyles's win in the 100-meter, the most prestigious track event, solidifies his title as the fastest man in the world.\n\nComparisons between Bolt and Lyles are inevitable, and the American has declared that he wants to challenge Bolt's world-record times.\n\n\"He's the fastest man to ever do it, and soon it'll be me,\" Lyles told CNN in March.\n\nBut, like Bolt, Lyles also wants to impact the sport beyond the track. Bolt's dominance and longevity made him the face of the sport, but his bravado, which includes a signature pose, made him one of the world's most marketable athletes.\n\nLyles, from his shots at NBA players to showing Yu-Gi-Oh! cards before big races, has already shown the swagger to become a media focal point. The question now is how high he can go in a sport that only receives significant international fanfare every four years during the Olympics.\n\nAfter winning the 100-meter race on Sunday, Lyles, an Adidas athlete since 2016, told reporters that he wants his own signature shoe, particularly a training shoe and not a track-and-field spike.\n\n\"I want my own shoe. I want my own trainer. Dead serious. I want a sneaker, ain't no money in spikes. There's money in sneakers,\" Lyles said.\n\nIt may not be a coincidence that Lyles made his statement the day after Bolt launched a signature lifestyle shoe with Puma.\n\nAthletic brands often reserve their signature shoes for athletes in more accessible and marketable sports, particularly basketball. There are some other athletes with their own signature lines that come with lifestyle and training shoes, such as On with Roger Federer and Adidas with Patrick Mahomes.\n\nThose are two of the greatest athletes in their sport's history, so a shoe or clothing line would cement Lyles as the face of track and field.\n\n\"With today's win, and everything he has achieved in his career so far, Noah has cemented his greatness and place as one of the leading athletes in the world. {"uri": "8265965737", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:20:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:20:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:20:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://deadline.com/2024/08/noah-lyles-catches-covid-still-manages-bronze-medal-1236035093/", "title": "Team USA's Noah Lyles Catches Covid, Still Manages A Bronze Medal In Men's 200-Meter Race", "body": "Billy Bean Dies: Second MLB Player To Come Out, Who Later Led Diversity Efforts, Was 60\n\nThe reigning world's fastest human was almost defeated by a microscopic bug.\n\nSprinter Noah Lyles woke up sore Tuesday morning, fresh off his gold medal effort Sunday in the Men's 100-meter race, where he became the first Team USA member to win gold in that event in 20 years.\n\nFeeling drained, he contacted team doctors, and discovered a positive COVID-19 test. He was scheduled for the 200-meter final Thursday, where he was a heavy favorite for the gold medal.\n\nHe decided to run, and wound up with a bronze medal.\n\n\"My first thought was not to panic, thinking I've been in worse situations,\" he told NBC after the race while wearing a mask. \"I've run with worse conditions, I felt. We just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off, and I'd definitely say that it's taken its toll for sure but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal. Last Olympics, I was very disappointed, and this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nAfter the race, Lyles fell to the track in exhaustion, and got pushed off in a wheelchair at Stade de France.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo was the upset winner of the gold at 19.46, and Team USA's Kenneth Bednarek copped the silver at 19.62.\n\nLyle's condition was known to officials before the race.\n\nKate Hartman, the chief external affairs officer for the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee, said in a statement that the group supports Lyles' decision to compete.\n\nAfter Lyles' positive test, she said, \"The USOPC and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the well-being of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors. Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete. After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight.
