{"uri": "2024-08-448540562", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:28:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:28:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:10:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/08/08/letsile-tebogo-200m-noah-lyles-2024-paris-olympics-gold-medal/74725838007/", "title": "Who is Letsile Tebogo, the Botswana runner who won 200m over Noah Lyles at Paris Olympics?", "body": "Letsile Tebogo started pounding the \"Botswana\" on his jersey in celebration before even crossing the finish line. He had stunned the world at the 2024 Paris Olympics, winning the 200m and earning the gold medal over heavy favorite Noah Lyles of the United States.\n\nTebogo made all sorts of history by beating Lyles, who settled for the bronze medal, and silver medalist Kenny Bednarek. But for track and field enthusiasts, Tebogo's emergence wasn't completely unexpected.\n\nHe has been a rising star for a few years, even drawing comparisons to Usain Bolt prior to his introduction to an international audience on Thursday. He also beat Lyles Wednesday in the 200m semifinals - the first race Lyles had lost in the 200m since the Tokyo Olympics - in a precursor to what Tebogo pulled off in the final.\n\nHere's what else you should know about Tebogo now that he's known for dethroning Lyles in his signature event:\n\nTebogo was born in Kanye, Botswana, a village in the southern portion of the country. He moved to Botswana's capital city, Gaborone, in the seventh grade.\n\nLetsile Tebogo 200m history\n\nBy winning the gold medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics, Tebogo became the first Olympic gold medal winner from Botswana and the first runner from Africa to win the 200m final at the Olympic Games. In 2023, he became the first African to win a medal in the 100m at the world championships.\n\n\"Africans can be sprinters, too,\" Tebogo declared to NBCSports.com in an interview before the Paris Games.\n\nLetsile Tebogo dedicated 2024 Paris Olympics to his mother\n\nTebogo's mother, Seratiwa, died in May from an illness and Tebogo said he dedicated his 200m gold medal win to her. Tebogo held up his shoe to the camera after the race, and it featured his mother's birthdate on it. He also painted her initials on his nails.\n\n\"I always think about her but I just try not to let it get into me that much and then just block it out and move forward,\" Tebogo said last week.\n\n\"I believe there is a medal in these legs and it only needs the determination and the willpower to do it,\" he added. \"I've had such a huge blow that affected me deeply so I'm still trying to get the confidence back into the body. It's not about injuries, it is all about my mum.\"\n\nLetsile Tebogo-Usain Bolt comparison, explained\n\nIn 2022, at the U20 world championships in Columbia, Tebogo set a world junior record in winning the 100m gold medal in 9.91 seconds. He was far enough ahead in the final stretch that he turned around to gesture and smile at his nearest competitors. Tebogo later explained it was a tribute to Bolt as opposed to showboating.\n\n\"If somebody took it as disrespect, I'm really sorry,\" Tebogo said at the time, according to Reuters. \"(It was so) everybody watching at home can enjoy the race - to remind them a little bit about what Usain Bolt did back in the day. He's my idol - the person I look up to.\"\n\nThe display quickly drew comparisons to Bolt on social media and Bolt even retweeted a post featuring Tebogo's finish.\n\nLetsile Tebogo used to train without shoes\n\n\"I used to train without shoes,\" Tebogo told NBCSports.com. \"Shoes were more expensive and we couldn't afford that because we lived with our extended family, so it was difficult for us to get things. [If you did], it would be as if you were the favored child, so things had to be equal. So I used to train without shoes in both football and athletics. I would wear a pair of old pants that one of my uncles used to wear back when he was in school. It was just a generational thing.\"", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letsile_Tebogo", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Letsile Tebogo"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Lyles", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Noah Lyles"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/200_metres", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "200 metres"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gold_medal", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Gold medal"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": I knew it was more than just being sore from the 100,\" a masked Lyles told NBC. \"Woke up the doctors and we tested and unfortunately it came up that I was positive for COVID.\"\n\nLyles, who added that he concealed his diagnosis to maintain an advantage over opponents, quarantined at a nearby hotel ahead of the race, though the Paris games have dropped any official requirements for COVID testing or mitigation strategies.\n\n\"You never want to tell your competitors you're sick,\" Lyles said. \"Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nAs Scientific American noted, Paris athletes are no longer required to mask or avoid contact with others if ill, and many have opted to proceed as normal, despite infectious disease doctor Peter Chin-Hong's assessment that the games provide \"picture-perfect ways to spread\" the virus.\n\nOutside of the Olympic Village, COVID-19 infection levels have reached recent highs, with wastewater tests putting many U.S. states in the \"high\" infections category. {"uri": "8265940344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:58:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:58:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:56:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/08/08/noah-lyles-reveals-he-had-covid-but-chose-to-compete-in-200m-final/", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals he had Covid but chose to compete in 200m final | Meath Chronicle", "body": "Noah Lyles reveals he had Covid but chose to compete in 200m final RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 8 Aug 2024, 9:34 PM Last updated: Thu 8 Aug 2024, 9:51 PM\n\nBy Rachel Steinberg, PA, Paris\n\nNoah Lyles revealed he had Covid after collecting Olympic 200m bronze on Thursday night.\n\nThe American sprinter said he tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning and woke up in the middle of the night \"with chills\".\n\nLyles, the Olympic 100m champion, said he quickly quarantined in a hotel, but insisted on competing in the final won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nThe 27-year-old, who was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt to win both Olympic sprint titles, said the illness had affected his performance.\n\nHe said: I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100m and 200m titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100m gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo (21) became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last May.\n\nRSS Syndicated {"uri": "2024-08-448538491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:23:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:23:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:18:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.star-telegram.com/sports/olympics/article290890804.html", "title": "Noah Lyles Explains Why He Raced Despite Positive COVID Test", "body": "Noah Lyles, a favorite to win gold at the 200-meter final at the Paris Games, came in third, securing bronze. His place on the podium was a shock, until shortly after the race he was seen being tended to by medical staff and taken off in a wheelchair. The first thought was that he may have run through an injury, but the reality was he ran while ill from COVID.\n\nLyles tested positive a few days ago and described attempting to quarantine to the best of his ability leading up to the 200-meter. He did not break any Olympic protocols by participating in the event. Teams and individuals are able to participate at their discretion even if COVID positive in 2024 after restrictions for the past two Games.\n\nThe main reason Lyles opted to race, despite the illness, was resilience. He spoke after the race about how he was proud of being able to come out to participate despite the circumstances.\n\n\"My first thought [after testing positive] was not to panic, thinking I've been in worse situations, I've run with worse conditions, and we just took it day by day, trying to hydrate, quarantined off. It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get a bronze medal.\"\n\nHis medal, the same one he achieved last Olympics, feels much different this time around:\n\n\"It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympic I was very disappointed, and this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nAsked if he ever considered not running, he said: \"No. No, I didn't. I just said we was just going to quarantine as much as possible, stay away, not trying to, you know, pass it off and, just to be honest, give it my all.\"\n\nThis article was originally published on {"uri": "8265922823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:40:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:40:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:38:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.con-telegraph.ie/2024/08/08/letsile-tebogo-wins-200m-for-botswanas-first-gold/", "title": "Letsile Tebogo wins 200m for Botswana's first gold | Connaught Telegraph", "body": "Letsile Tebogo wins 200m for Botswana's first gold RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 8 Aug 2024, 8:03 PM Last updated: Thu 8 Aug 2024, 9:36 PM\n\nBy Mitch Phillips\n\nLetsile Tebogo became the first African to win the Olympic 200m title on Thursday when he powered clear of American duo Kenny Bednarek and Noah Lyles in 19.46 seconds to claim Botswana's first Olympic gold medal.\n\nTebogo, who won bronze at the world championships last year and set a national record of 9.86 when finishing sixth in the Paris 100m final, produced a dominant run to become the fifth-fastest man in history over 200m.\n\nBednarek chased him all the way to take a second successive silver in 19.62 seconds, with Lyles, hoping to become the first American to complete the sprint double since Carl Lewis 40 years ago, third in 19.67.\n\nImmediately after the race, US officials said Lyles had Covid and a yellow card appeared against his name in the official results.\n\nRSS {"uri": "8266099936", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-09", "time": "00:04:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-09T00:04:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-09T00:03:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.thewrap.com/noah-lyles-200-meter-final-covid-olympics/", "title": "Noah Lyles Never Considered Bowing Out of 200-Meter Final After COVID Diagnosis: 'I've Run With Worse Conditions' | Video", "body": "\"I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics,\" the athlete says after winning bronze Thursday night in Paris\n\nAfter Noah Lyles won bronze in the 200-meter final Thursday night at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, he revealed that he ran the race after testing positive for COVID.\n\nHe explained to commentator Lewis Johnson that he \"never considered\" bowing out of the race, despite receiving the diagnosis two days ago.\n\n\"I woke up early, about 5 a.m. on Tuesday morning, and I just was feeling really horrible again, and I knew it was more than just being sore from [running] the 100,\" the masked athlete told Johnson.\n\n\"I woke up the doctors, and we tested, and unfortunately, it came up that I was positive for COVID. My first thought was not to panic, thinking, you know, I've been in worse situations. I've run with worse conditions I felt, and we just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much [as possible] and stay quarantined,\" Lyles continued.\n\nHe admitted that the virus \"has taken its toll,\" but that he's \"never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal.\"\n\nLyles won Sunday's 100m race in a photo finish that was later measured to be a mere five-thousandths of a second. However, he has said he is likely out of the 4 x 100m relay.\n\n\"At the moment, I don't know, I'm feeling more on the side of you know, letting Team USA do their thing,\" he told Johnson. \"They've proven with a great certainty that they can handle it without me. And if that's the case, coming off today, then I'm perfectly fine saying, 'Hey, you guys, go do your thing. You guys have more than enough speed to be able to handle it. Get the gold medal, right?'\"\n\n\"I believe this will be the end of my 2024 Olympics. It is not the Olympic I dreamed of but it has left me with so much Joy in my heart. {"uri": "8264061767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "18:51:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T18:51:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T18:50:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/national/24504635.noah-lyles-keeps-sprint-double-bid-course-booking-200-metres-final-spot/", "title": "Noah Lyles keeps sprint double bid on course by booking 200 metres final spot", "body": "Noah Lyles took one step closer to his dream of achieving an individual Olympic sprint double in Paris after securing his spot in the 200 metres final at the Stade de France.\n\nThe American claimed 100 metres gold by five one thousandths of a second on Sunday night, and needed to finish in the top two from semi-final heat two to automatically book his place in Thursday night's showdown.\n\nLyles crossed his fingers with a tongue-out grin as the camera cut toward him on the big screen.\n\nLike that 100m final, Lyles got out to the slowest start of the eight-man field, but made up for it when he crossed the line in 20.08 seconds for second spot behind Botswanan Letsile Tebogo in 19.96.\n\nLyles' time was still good enough for third-fastest of the semi-finalists behind Tebogo, the only man to clock a sub-20 time in the semis.\n\nSecond quickest was Lyles' American team-mate Kenny Bednarek, the 2022 world and Tokyo 2020 silver medallist, who made easy work of the first semi-final in exactly 20 seconds.\n\nDominican Alexander Ogando and a third American, Erriyon Knighton, rounded out the top five while Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh and Zimbabwe duo Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba also qualified.\n\nEarlier, Guernsey hurdler Alastair Chalmers' evening came to an unfortunate end when he fell at the final bend of his 400 metres hurdles semi-final.\n\nHe said: \"Honestly I'm actually quite fine, I'm happy to make the semi-final and had a good heat the other day.\n\n\"To be in front of this crowd and racing these kinds of athletes is a dream. I just lost a bit of concentration between six and seven. It's a bit frustrating I guess, but I'm happy with how I set the race up, I attacked it and I'm honestly not that upset or disappointed.\n\nNorway's defending Olympic champion Karsten Warholm, who set a world and Olympic record 45.94 seconds at Tokyo 2020, was the fastest of the semi-finalists in 47.67.\n\nGreat Britain's Tade Ojora lined up in heat two of the men's 110 metres semi-finals but did not advance after finishing seventh.\n\nHe said: \"It was a great experience. Obviously I hoped to do better and expected to do better, I wish I'd done better, I let myself down but that's the emotions. I'm sure in a couple of days, maybe a couple of hours I'll be able to look back on that Olympic experience. {"uri": "8265679743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "17:07:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T17:07:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T17:06:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/lego-fashion-romance-inside-real-29703866", "title": "Real life of Paris Olympics 100m gold medallist Noah Lyles", "body": "Noah Lyles is aiming to become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete an Olympic sprint double after qualifying for the 200m final at Paris 2024\n\nNewly crowned Olympic 100m champion Noah Lyles has already made history in Paris and he's aiming to complete a very special double on Thursday night. The 27-year-old American could become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete an Olympic sprint double if he picks up gold in the 200m final.\n\nHe won 100m gold by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson in a dramatic photo finish on Sunday. The 27-year-old, winner of three golds at last year's World Championships, became the first American to win an Olympic 100m title for 20 years, since Justin Gatlin in 2004.\n\nAlong with the medal, he'll also be aiming to smash Bolt's long-standing 200m world record of 19.19 seconds - further cementing his name in the history books.\n\nREAD MORE: Team GB star Keely Hodgkinson's tumour battle, not being a 'one-hit wonder' and dreaming of gold\n\nLyles is also expected to participate in the men's 4\u00d7100 metres relay final, and has openly advocated for a spot on the men's 4\u00d7400 team as well, in a bid to achieve something Bolt never did by winning four golds in one Games.\n\nRead on to find out more about the star.\n\nEarly life in Florida and track success\n\nNoah Lyles was born on July 18, 1997 in Gainesville, Florida to parents Kevin Lyles and Keisha Caine. He has a sister called Abby and a brother called Josephus, who is also an athlete.\n\nHe was a gymnast in his youth and started track and field at age 12, first taking up the high jump before switching to sprints. He's said of his sporting prowess: \"I was born into this sport. Me and my younger brother Josephus got into it together through our parents who used to run.\n\n\"We have always been surrounded by track. Track was what I loved from the start. If I can be on a track, then I can be happy. It always saved me.\"\n\nSince turning professional in July 2016, he has notched up an impressive string of accolades, including Olympic bronze, six world titles, and four Diamond League Final trophies. At the 2023 World Championship in Budapest he retained his 200m crown from 2019 and 2022.\n\nIn the process, he claimed a rare sprint treble, winning gold in the 100m, 200m, and the 4x100m relay - the first man to do so since Usain Bolt in 2015.\n\nMental health struggles\n\nLyles has been open with his struggles with mental health - a subject that other athletes have previously been reluctant to open up about. In August 2020, he said in a tweet that he had started to take antidepressant medication.\n\nHe later shared that his struggles began during a two-month stay in Europe for training and competition before the 2019 World Championships in Doha, Qatar - the prolonged period away from home leading to homesickness and depression. He said he was reluctant to continue training and family members noticed signs of distress during a Christmas visit.\n\nHe's said of this time in his life: \"So that's when I started ringing my personal therapist on a regular basis, and it was going well for a time, but once coronavirus hit and the Black Lives Matter movement started happening, it created the perfect storm. I didn't feel like it was very hard to share, as I'm constantly talking about mental health.\"\n\nLyles flew to the Tokyo 2020 Olympics with the 2019 world 200m title under his belt and was the favourite to become the first American to claim gold in that event since 2004. Instead, he finished third in a stadium that was near-empty stadium as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about his lifelong battle with anxiety and depression and the difficulty of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nBefore heading to Paris he said: \"I get to finally say, I'm showing up to an Olympic Games not depressed and it feels amazing. It's a lot of joy, a lot of joy, even though there's hard times in the moment I can always think back to the last Olympics and be like, 'no, this one is not the same'. This one is way better and I'm ready to show it.\n\n\"If I lose this time, it's not going to be because I beat myself, it's just gonna be that they had to be that much better. But to be honest, when Noah Lyles is being Noah Lyles - nobody (can).\"\n\nDealing with superstardom in Paris\n\nLyles has not shied away from courting attention, declaring his intent on recently-released Netflix documentary Sprint to become the face of his sport and elevate athletics' appeal in the process. He freely admits he's showman who performs better in front of a full house.\n\nHe said he remembers the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\", but instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted\".\n\nHe says that \"the line between confidence and cocky can be so blurred\" but brushes off anyone who might not fully understand his \"vision\", his signature bravado mitigated by memories of being the dyslexic kid with asthma, who struggled in school and was told he would never achieve his athletic ambitions.\n\nIn Paris he is one of the most recognisable faces in the Olympic athletes' village and has spoken about the difficulties of managing his mental health with his new echelon of fame.\n\nHe said: \"I've become kind of popular in the village. Unfortunately, that has come with its own set of challenges in being able to find my own space whether that's eating or training in the gym. I know some athletes like to leave the village and have their own hotels but I like to enjoy the whole Olympic event, being with other athletes and stuff like that, but it has come with its own challenge of, you know, finding my own safe place.\n\n\"It's been kind of hard for me to find that within the village and I don't want to leave. It's definitely something I feel like after this Olympics, I'm gonna have to have conversations higher up than me, and whoever is in charge of that, making that more available or just more aware, because I'm not even the most popular person in the village.\n\n\"I know I'm not the only one who's had to deal with situations like this, and I just talked about that to bring that to people's attention. We might be superstars in your eyes, we still are human beings, and we do want to be able to have our space and our time.\"\n\nFashion, love for LEGO and life outside sport\n\nThe sports star's official Paris Olympics profile notes that his hobbies include \"painting (especially shoes), watching anime, making music and building complex LEGO creations\". The fashion-forward star has walked the runway at Paris and Milan Fashion Weeks and likes to paint his nails to mark the big occasions and wears themed necklaces to match his hair.\n\nIn an interview in 2018, ahead of the Birmingham Diamond League, he said: \"I have a lot of interests and art is my biggest love. Lego is another one. I have a whole Lego city that I'm building piece by piece and brick by brick and box by box and people actually like it.\"\n\nBut when asked if there was anything he couldn't do, Lyles admitted: \"I'm not actually that good at traditional learning. Or math or writing. I actually have dyslexia, which actually makes things hard for me and people see in my tweets that I spell things wrong.\"\n\nHe said he uses an app to help him get his spelling right but added: \"There's different words so I might end up putting a wrong word so the grammar is off. I do have my limits.\"\n\nStar wants his own shoe\n\nAsked what he wants next, Lyles told interviewers: \"I want my own shoe\". He added: \"I want my own trainer -- I'm dead serious. There ain't no money in spikes, it's in sneakers.\n\n\"And even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker. I feel like for how many medals we bring back, for the notoriety we get ... the fact that that hasn't happened, that's crazy to me. I was like, 'Yeah, that needs to happen.' \"\n\nThe new Usain Bolt?\n\nLyles has long been an admirer of retired sprint superstar Usain Bolt but has expressed his desire to break the Jamaican's longstanding records in the 100m and 200m events.\n\nHe said last year: \"I've always known that I'm the fastest man in the world. Well, in my head, I think I'm going to break it. I'm planning to break it.\"\n\nHis profile is on track to be as big as Bolt's- with a beaming smile and personality to match - but Lyles is adamant that he isn't the next Bolt. The two stars met after a race in Bolt's homeland of Jamaica last year, with Lyles saying the star was nothing but encouraging to him.\n\nHe said: \"Bolt coming down and giving me his respects and me giving him my respects, it was kind of like, 'Wow', He said, 'Just keep doing what you are doing'.\"\n\nHowever Lyles is firmly his own man, saying: \"I am the new Noah Lyles.\"\n\nPersonal life and romance\n\nNoah Lyles' girlfriend is Jamaican track star Junelle Bloomfield, who's also an Olympian. The couple, who are both representing their countries at the Paris Olympics 2024, celebrated their second anniversary during the Games.\n\nThey first met through social media in 2017 but did not pursue their relationship after sparks failed to fly on their first date. According to Cosmopolitan, Bromfield originally reached out to Lyles via Instagram in 2017.\n\nLyles then contacted Bromfield again and asked for a second chance and they went Instagram official in December 2022. They now live together in Florida.\n\nThe men's 200m final will take place at the Saint Denis stadium at 7.30pm on Thursday night. It will be broadcast live on BBC One.\n\nThis year, the Olympics runs from July 26 to August 11. As usual, a number of events are being screened across the BBC - whilst the schedule will be further rolled out through streaming platform Discovery+.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8265908157", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:25:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:25:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:24:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/sport/national/24507311.noah-lyles-reveals-covid-chose-compete-200-metres-final/", "title": "Noah Lyles reveals he had Covid but chose to compete in 200 metres final", "body": "Noah Lyles revealed he had Covid after collecting Olympic 200 metres bronze on Thursday night.\n\nThe American sprinter said he tested positive around five o'clock on Tuesday morning and woke up in the middle of the night \"with chills\".\n\nLyles, the Olympic 100 metres champion said he quickly quarantined in a hotel, but insisted on competing in the final won by Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nThe 27-year-old, who was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt to win both Olympic sprint titles, said the illness had affected his performance.\n\nHe said: I do have Covid. I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting Covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with Covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100 metres and 200 metres titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100 metres gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo, 21, became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last {"uri": "8264548896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "04:05:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T04:05:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T04:04:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/b4d928a7-e1e3-4012-b300-f77a375ac1c8", "title": "Noah Lyles targets Olympic sprint double with 200-metre win", "body": "Noah Lyles, the world's fastest competing athlete, is aiming to become the first man since Usain Bolt to achieve an Olympic sprint double.\n\nThursday's 200-metre final in Paris will be a fitting stage for the Olympian to show off his two best skills -- sprinting and hyping himself up. After winning gold in Sunday's 100 metres in the tightest of photo finishes, the highly confident Lyles has backed himself to finish first again.\n\n\"None of them is winning,\" he said of his competitors. \"When I come off the turn, they're gonna be depressed.\"\n\nLyles, 27, has long been a 200-metre specialist, winning gold in the Youth Olympics a decade ago. His personal best of 19.31 seconds, recorded in 2022 when he won his second of three golds in the World Athletics Championships, is the third-fastest time ever, and more than a tenth of a second faster than any of his Paris rivals.\n\nBolt, the retired Jamaican sprinter, set the 200-metre world record of 19.19 seconds in 2009 -- and Lyles has been clear about his intention to break it. After making the US team in June, he said he had set himself two goals: \"Grabbing an Olympic gold, and then\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009grabbing a world record. It's on the list.\"\n\nLyles has overcome adversity in his return to prominence on track and field's biggest stages. He struggled with depression during the early months of the coronavirus pandemic and finished third in the 200 metres at the 2021 Tokyo Games.\n\nHe has since been on a mission to re-establish himself as the world's best sprinter, while also leaning into his role of pot-stirrer in an effort to boost athletics' media profile and the prize money on offer as a new crop of investors vies to reshape the sport.\n\nA star of the recent Netflix documentary series Sprint, Lyles has taken aim at US stars in sports such as basketball who proclaim themselves \"world champions\" for winning domestic league titles.\n\n\"You know what hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on their head. World champion of what? The United States?\" he said after winning the sprint double at the 2023 World Championships. \"I love the US, at times, but that is not the world.\"\n\nA win for Lyles in the 200-metre final would offer him a bigger platform to air his views. Rivals include his compatriot Erriyon Knighton, who has a personal best of 19.49 seconds, and Botswana's Letsile Tebogo with 19.50.\n\nIn Lyles's dramatic photo-finish victory in the 100-metre race, he edged out Jamaica's Kishane Thompson by a mere five-thousandths of a second.\n\nJamaica, which has become a sprinting powerhouse in recent decades with the rise of Bolt and other athletes, has had a disappointing Games -- winning only one athletics gold so far, in men's discus. Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce and Shericka Jackson withdrew from the 100-metre and 200-metre women's races respectively, the latter having already pulled out of the shorter-distance event before the Games began.\n\nUS sprinter Gabby Thomas won the women's 200 metres on Tuesday. Reflecting Lyles's motivational qualities, Thomas said she was partly inspired by her male counterpart's performance in the 100 metres.\n\n\"Hearing Noah go after what he wanted and take it, I knew that if I were in any position in this race, I could still go after it and take [the gold],\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "ft.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Financial Times News"}, "authors": {"uri": "8264069340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "18:58:27", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T18:58:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T18:57:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/noah-lyles-eyes-historic-olympic-double-iconic-signature-shoe/", "title": "Noah Lyles Eyes Historic Olympic 'Double,' Iconic Signature Shoe", "body": "Noah Lyles (above) is headed to the finals of the 200-meter sprint after placing second in his semifinals heat.\n\nDespite not winning his heat, he is still the heavy favorite to win the 200-meter sprint in Paris since he is a three-time world champion in the event. Lyles also placed second in his semifinal heat in the 100-meter event before taking home the gold in the final.\n\nWith a win Thursday, the U.S. track star can become the first sprinter since Usain Bolt in 2016 to take gold in both the 100 and 200-meter races, known as the prestigious \"double.\"\n\nLyles solidified his spot as one of the most marketable Olympians after winning the 100-meter sprint Sunday. But the Adidas-backed sprinter declared he wants a signature shoe, an accomplishment saved for some of the top athletes in major sports, including Bolt. Achieving the \"double\" would improve Lyles's case, especially given his marketable, albeit polarizing, personality.\n\n\"I want my own shoe. I want my own trainer. I'm dead serious.\" Lyles told reporters in Paris. \"I want a sneaker. There ain't no money in spikes. There's money in sneakers. And even Michael Johnson didn't have his own sneaker.\"\n\nLyles was direct about his desire for a signature shoe, but he never once mentioned Adidas during his press conference.\n\nWhile athletes are allowed to secure personal sponsorships anytime during the Games, the IOC's Rule 40 severely limits the amount of public interaction Olympic athletes can have with any non-Olympic partners, like Adidas.\n\nAn example of how granular Rule 40 can be is that an athlete can thank each personal sponsor only once during the entirety of the Games.\n\n\"During the Games Period, you may provide one simple 'thank-you' message to each of your Non-Olympic Partner personal sponsors,\" the Rule 40 FAQ states.\n\nNike is also the national team sponsor for the U.S., which is why Lyles sports the Swoosh on his tracksuit despite wearing Adidas racers.\n\nA signature shoe would be another step in Lyles's journey to grow and transcend the sport.\n\nLyles was the main subject of the Netflix docuseries Sprint, released last month, and said it was \"amazing\" in giving fans a deeper look into the track and field. But he hopes the sport can amass attention beyond the Olympics.\n\n\"I want to see a continuation of the ability to take advantage of moments for our sport,\" Lyles said in Paris. \"This needs to be {"uri": "2024-08-448588791", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:37:07", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:37:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:35:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-proud-200m-bronze-covid-positive-3217858", "title": "Noah Lyles 'proud' to win 200m Olympic bronze after testing positive for Covid", "body": "Tebogo, 21, claimed Botswana's first Olympic gold medal in 19.46 seconds, making him the fifth fastest man in history over the distance.\n\nLyles, the 100m champion in the closest race in history only four days ago, was hoping to become the first American since Carl Lewis, watching from the stands, to win both sprint events at the same Games.\n\nBut instead Lyles was not even the fastest American on the night, beaten into second by Kenny Bednarek, who claimed Olympic 200m silver for the second consecutive Games.\n\n\"I've been in worse situations and I've run with worse conditions,\" said Lyles, who was taken off the track in a wheelchair..\n\n\"We just took it day by day, trying to hydrate as much, quarantined off. I'd definitely say it's taken its toll, for sure.\n\n\"But I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get a bronze medal.\"\n\n\"I didn't [consider not running]. I was set. We were going to try and quarantine as much has possible, stay away, not try to pass it on, and give it my all.\n\n\"This is by far the best day I felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I'm 100 per cent but I would definitely say I'm closer to 90 to 95 per cent.\n\n\"We were trying to keep this as close to the chest as possible.\n\n\"You never want to tell your competitors you're sick; why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nThere are no specific rules at Paris 2024 regarding protocols for athletes who tested positive.\n\nLast week, British swimming superstar Adam Peaty tested positive and was separated from the rest of the team, but swam in the relay six days later.\n\nThere had been rumours of Lyles receiving medical treatment during the week, but few people seemed to know the whole truth, and when Lyles exploded out onto the track, the last man introduced to the crowd, it seemed he was more than confident of repeating his feat from the World Championships last year.\n\nBut he had been wearing a medical mask in the call room, where the athletes wait to go to the track, and by the final 20 metres it became clear that all was not well with Lyles.\n\nUsually the quickest over the second 100 metres of the race, he failed to make any indent on the lead of Tebogo and USA teammate Bednarek.\n\n\"I don't care [if he had Covid],\" Bednarek said.\n\n\"If I get sick or whatever, I'm fine. If it's a cold or... I don't view those things as a big deal.\"\n\nBoth men were due to be involved in the 4x100m relay final this weekend, although Lyles hinted he may sit it out.\n\n\"At the moment I don't know,\" Lyles added.\n\n\"I'm feeling more on the side of letting Team USA do their thing. They've proven with great certainty that they can handle it without me.\"\n\nEllie Aldridge was only too happy to rescue the Olympic regatta for Team GB by soaring to gold in the inaugural women's kite event on an up-and-down Thursday in France.\n\nThe 27-year-old beat Lauriane Nolot to top spot after the French favourite fell off her board in the early stages of the final in Marseille.\n\nNolot won gold and Aldridge silver at the last two World Championships and at the Test Event, but the Dorset native delivered at the big dance and took the first-ever kite title, with her rival settling for second place.\n\n\"I knew that if I had the right week I could win but it was going to need everything to align,\" said Aldridge.\n\n\"I felt like at the beginning of the week I didn't have great luck, but I feel like my luck came around a bit.\n\n\"We haven't had the easiest conditions but it's been really cool and I hope everyone watching on TV thinks the same thing. It's been incredible.\"\n\nThe sigh of relief breathed by British sailing bosses when Aldridge crossed the line first was almost audible from Paris.\n\nBefore her dramatic victory, the Games had only yielded one medal for Team GB in the shape of bronze for Emma Wilson.\n\nEven then Wilson was disconsolate at the colour of her medal after she dominated the event, winning eight of 14 races, before scores were wiped and she finished third in the final.\n\nBoth Micky Beckett and the pairing of John Gimson and Anna Burnet had podium chances heading into their final races, but crashed and burned in the double-points contest.\n\nAt the athletics track, Katarina Johnson-Thompson hailed her \"best day in a long time\" after surging to the women's heptathlon summit in pursuit of her maiden Olympic medal.\n\nThe 31-year-old added more than 50cm to her shot put lifetime best and recorded her best high jump performance since 2019 to hold the overnight lead ahead of reigning champion Nafi Thiam.\n\nThe pair are separated by just 48 points heading into Friday's conclusion, with long jump and javelin taking place in the morning before the 800m rounds things off from 7.15pm.\n\nAlso at Stade de France, Laura Muir and Georgia Bell made it through to the women's 1500m final.\n\nAt the velodrome, Emma Finucane added keirin bronze to her team sprint gold as the cycling medals continued to flow.\n\nRacing alongside fellow team sprint gold medallist Katy Marchant, Finucane tried to go from a long way out to surprise reigning world champion Ellesse Andrews of New Zealand.\n\nBut the Kiwi has made this most unpredictable of events her forte, and was too strong for Finucane, with the Netherlands' Hetty van de Wouw pipping Finucane to silver.\n\nAt the Grand Palais, Jade Jones denied ever taking performance-enhancing drugs just months after she was cleared to compete at the Olympics despite a missed doping test.\n\nThe double gold medallist was suspended pending further investigation earlier this year after failing to provide a sample to a doping control officer on 1 December.\n\nA missed test is normally treated the same as a failed one but Jones escaped sanction after being found to having committed a no-fault doping violation on confidential medical grounds.\n\nShe lost in the first round here, while teammate Bradly Sinden had to pull out of his bronze medal match due to a knee injury he suffered in his quarter-final bout.\n\nThe 68kg fighter, who won Olympic silver in Tokyo three years ago, fears he has torn the medial cruciate ligament in his left knee and was unable to take on China's Liang Yushuai in the third-place play-off.\n\nMeanwhile, there was disappointment for divers Jack Laugher and Jordan Houlden in the men's 3m springboard {"uri": "8265675675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "17:04:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T17:04:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T17:03:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/what-time-mens-200m-final-29703608", "title": "What time is the men's 200m final at the Paris Olympics tonight", "body": "Noah Lyles is making his bid for double Olympic sprint gold after taking the 100 metre title on Sunday\n\nThe men's 200m sprint final will take on Thursday night (August 8) as the Paris Olympics nears its end. Breakout star Noah Lyles will be in the spotlight again as he bids to add to the 100m gold he's already secured.\n\n.The 27-year-old American claimed 100 metres gold by five one thousandths of a second on Sunday night. He needed to finish in the top two from semi-final heat two to automatically book his place in the 200m final - crossing the line in 20.08 seconds for second spot behind Botswanan Letsile Tebogo in 19.96.\n\nTeam GB won't be represented in the final but Lyles will face compatriots Erriyon Knighton and Kenneth Bednarek. The rest of the field is Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba (both of Zimbabwe), Alexander Ogando (Dominican Republic), Letsile Tobogo (Botswana) and Joseph Fahnbulleh (Liberia).\n\nREAD MORE: Team GB star Keely Hodgkinson's tumour battle, not being a 'one-hit wonder' and dreaming of gold\n\nLyles is also expected to participate in the men's 4\u00d7100 metres relay, and has openly advocated for a spot on the men's 4\u00d7400 team as well, in a bid to achieve something Jamaican eight-time Olympic champion Usain Bolt never did by winning four golds in one Games.\n\nHe is in Paris with a point to prove after becoming embroiled in a debate before the Games about who was currently fastest man on the planet. The world 100m and 200m champion's 100m triumph came three summers after he entered the postponed Tokyo 2020 Olympics as the 200m favourite and world champion - but only claimed bronze.\n\nAfterwards, he opened up about a lifelong battle with depression and the challenges of balancing the benefits of antidepressant medication with side effects that led to weight gain and affected his ability to perform - ultimately electing to wean off the treatment before those Games.\n\nHe has since acknowledged that he performs better in front of a full house, remembering the moment on the start line in Tokyo when he would usually say to himself \"it's showtime\". He said he instead found himself thinking \"this is not it. This is not fun. This is not cool. This is not what I wanted.\"\n\nThe men's 200m final will take place at the Saint Denis stadium at 7.30pm on Thursday night. It will be broadcast live on BBC One.\n\nThis year, the Olympics runs from July 26 to August 11. "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles cruises into 200m final in pursuit of treble", "body": "Noah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five-thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, finished second in his semifinal behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nAmerica's Kenny Bednaraek, the second-fastest in the world this year over the distance, clocked 20.00sec to edge out Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic in the first semi-final.\n\nErriyon Knighton of the US, a silver and bronze medallist over 200m at the past two world championships, qualified first from the third semi-final, clocking 20.09, ahead of Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Makanakaishe Charamba and compatriot Tapiwanashe Makarawu, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and his compatriot Makanakaishe Charamba, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify after a season in which the Canadian has struggled for form.\n\nTreble-chasing Lyles has the chance to be the standout star of the athletics programme in Paris.\n\nALSO READ | Paris 2024: United States win women's team pursuit gold\n\nJamaican sprint star Shericka Jackson withdrew from the women's 100m and then pulled out of her 200m heat.\n\nSt Lucia's Julien Alfred, pursuing the women's sprint double, came second behind Gabby Thomas in the 200m after winning the shorter sprint.\n\nLyles, the Tokyo 2020 bronze medallist, has been dominant in his preferred 200m, winning the past three world titles.\n\nHe is the third-fastest half-lap runner in history, with his mark of 19.31sec set at the world championships in Oregon in 2022 ranking behind only Jamaica's Yohan Blake and Bolt's world record of 19.19sec.\n\nRetired Jamaican sprint superstar Bolt did the 100m-200m sprint double at three consecutive Games -- Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016, adding the 4x100m gold in London and Rio.\n\nThe first round of the sprint relay is on Thursday morning but Lyles is likely to be rested following his 200m semi-final.\n\nLatest on SportstarParis 2024 Olympics: Noah Lyles cruises into Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nAmerica's Kenny Bednaraek, the second-fastest in the world this year over the distance, clocked 20.00sec to edge out Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic in the first semi-final.\n\nErriyon Knighton of the US, a silver and Zimbabwe's Makanakaishe Charamba and compatriot Tapiwanashe Makarawu, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's form.\n\nTreble-chasing Lyles has the chance to be the standout star of the athletics programme in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint star Shericka Jackson withdrew from the women's 100m and then pulled out of her 200m heat.\n\nSt Lucia's Julien Alfred, pursuing the women's sprint double, came second behind Gabby Thomas in the 200m after winning the shorter sprint.\n\nLyles, the Tokyo 2020 bronze medallist, has been dominant in his preferred 200m, winning the past three world titles.\n\nHe is the third-fastest half-lap runner in history, with his mark of 19.31sec set at the world championships in Oregon in 2022 ranking behind only Jamaica's Yohan Blake and Bolt's world record of 19.19sec.\n\nRetired Jamaican sprint superstar Bolt did the 100m-200m sprint double at three consecutive Games -- Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016, adding the 4x100m gold in London and Rio.\n\nThe first round of the sprint relay is on Thursday morning but Lyles is likely to be rested following his 200m Text \"Alerts\" to (201) 335-0739 or sign up here.\n\nWhile athletes who competed in Tokyo in 2021 experienced strict COVID-19 protocols -- including mandatory tests, mandatory masking when not competing or training, quarantining and the banning of all spectators -- Paris was seemingly the opposite. There are no strict protocols or restrictions for COVID-19 in Paris, though Anne Descamps, Paris 2024 chief communications director, told Reuters \"any athlete that has tested positive has to wear a mask.\" She also said they \"remind everyone to follow best practices but in terms of monitoring COVID, cases are quite low in France.\" Scientific American also reported officials in Paris dropped past Olympic protocols and were \"approaching the disease like other respiratory illnesses,\" adding officials were letting athletes and teams determine how best to prevent or respond to infection.\n\n\"I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here,\" Lyles told NBC after the race. \"And, getting a bronze medal, where last Olympics I was very disappointed ... this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nLyles had been seeking the gold in the 200 meter to be the first American male to complete the Olympic Double -- winning gold in both the 100 and 200 meter dash -- since 1984.\n\nLyles, 27, made his Olympic debut in Tokyo, where he earned a bronze medal in the 200 meter race. He was named the world champion in the event in 2019, and won it again in 2022 when he broke Michael Johnson's 26-year-old record. In addition to his various medals and championships at world competitions, he is only the second man ever to receive the Jesse Owens Award for USA Track & Field's male athlete of the year three times (2018, 2022, 2023). He is from Gainesville, Florida, and had committed to run track at the University of Florida, but decided to go professional at the last minute and signed an eight-year contract with Adidas in 2016.\n\nLyles' availability for the 4x100 meter relay. {"uri": "2024-08-447929974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:14:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:14:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:59:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/08/08/sport/noah-lyles-nba-players-beef-explained-spt/index.html", "title": "The Noah Lyles-NBA players beef, explained", "body": "Noah Lyles celebrates winning the gold medal in the men's 100m final on day nine of the 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nNoah Lyles is a charismatic, boisterous athlete who is not afraid to say what's on his mind in his effort to push track and field's profile higher in the sporting world. Last year, however, that put him at odds with some of the most high-profile basketball players in the NBA.\n\nAt last year's world championships, Lyles won the 100-meter and 200-meter races - a double he's trying to repeat in the Olympics on Thursday night after winning the 100m on Sunday - and wasn't shy about comparing his accomplishments to those of his professional basketball counterparts back in the US.\n\nWhen speaking to reporters at the World Championships in Budapest, Lyles was asked about what he wanted to do for track and field and what he'd like to see to improve the sport's profile.\n\nLyles said the medals he wins are the first step to raising track's awareness in the public's eye and that he wants more former world champions to be present at high-profile meets. And then he took a turn into taking a shot at the NBA.\n\n\"You know the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on they head. World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong, I love the US - at times - but that ain't the world,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"We are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving, putting on their flag to show they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\nLyles' comment hit on something that sports fans in the rest of the world often mock about US sports culture. In almost every major American sport, the champion of the league is referred to as the world champion, even though those teams only play against other franchises that are based in either the US or Canada.\n\nBut the US' distinct sporting culture means that the four major American sports - football, basketball, baseball and hockey - are head and shoulders above those sports' domestic leagues in other nations. Most of the best players from around the world in those sports end up playing for American teams, hence the claim to the title of world champion: case and point, the last six NBA MVP awards went to players who were born abroad.\n\nLyles' comment was not welcomed by the American NBA players who he had called out.\n\nTwo-time NBA champion and 2014 MVP Kevin Durant, who has also been named Finals MVP twice in his illustrious career, led the charge.\n\n\"Somebody help this brother,\" he wrote on Instagram, responding to an ESPN post.\n\nFour-time NBA champion Draymond Green also got involved, writing on Instagram, \"When being smart goes wrong\" with the face-palm emoji. Devin Booker, who plays on Team USA in these Olympics and the Phoenix Suns, just simply posted a facepalm emoji.\n\nSo if Lyles ends up winning the 100m-200m double, don't expect very many American Both are in today's final. While the price for Lyles to win is prohibitively short, odds on the other two Americans to medal -- Bednarek and Erriyon Knighton could present value. {"uri": "8265914796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:31:57", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:31:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:31:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/other-sports/athletics/letsile-tebogo-mother-olympic-gold-33426471", "title": "New Olympic 200m champion sends emotional message to mum who died in May at 44", "body": "Letsile Tebogo lost his mother earlier this year, and the sprinter gave an emotional interview after winning Botswana's first ever Olympic gold medal with a 200m victory\n\nLestile Tebogo knew his 200m Olympic victory would have meant a lot to his mother, who died in May aged just 44.\n\nThe Botswanan athlete won his country's first ever Olympic gold, setting a new African record of 19.46 seconds. Kenny Bednarek took silver, while 100m champion Noah Lyles finished third as US Track & Field confirmed he had been suffering from Covid.\n\nBotswana only had two previous medals of any colour. Nijel Amos won silver in the 800m in London in 2012, while the African nation secured bronze in the 4x400m relay in Tokyo.\n\nTebogo's sister was in the stands at the Stade de France to watch the 21-year-old come home in first place. And, after posting the fastest time in the world in 2024, he spoke about his family's loss.\n\n\"It's basically me carrying her through every stride that I take inside the field,\" he said. \"She's watching up there, and she's really, really happy.\"\n\nTebogo also posted a national record in the 100m final, but his time of 9.86 was only enough for sixth on that occasion. He was the fastest man in the 200m semis, though, and made sure in the final.\n\n\"My coach has told me just now, 'now it's your race, you can do whatever you want. It's either a medal or not, I don't care - you made it through after all you have been through, making it to the final, I'm the happiest coach ever',\" Tebogo told Eurosport. \"So for me this is a really amazing moment for myself.\n\nHow impressed were you with Letsile Tebogo's win? Let us know in the comments section\n\n\"Before the race, when I was walking to the call room, he just told me 'I think it's now best we just do what we did in London when we ran the African record',\" Tebogo added. \"When the gun went, I knew Kenny was going to run away so make sure, just close him down, because I have that top-end speed that will allow me to be in the race without getting tired.\n\n\"So that's what I did, and when I saw [Bednarek] fade I knew Noah was far away behind us. So that means I'm the Olympic champion.\n\n\"It really means a lot to my late mum because she always dreamt of making it here. I think my little sister is in the stands, I don't know where she's sitting but I believe she's happy, she's representing her while she's here. So it means a lot for everybody - the country, the continent, and my family at large.\"\n\nIt later emerged that bronze medalist Lyles had been suffering with Covid after waking up with chills on Tuesday morning US Track and field said in a statement that it - along with the US Olympic and Paralymic Committee, had \"enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\n\n\"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete,\" the USTF's statement continued. \"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\n\n\"As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOpc, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nKeep up with the latest Olympic coverage with Mirror Sport's live blog\n\nThis article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. "American sprinter slams Noah Lyles 'favouritism' at Paris Games", "body": "Controversy has erupted between American teammates over perceived 'favouritism' in a glamour Paris Olympics event.\n\nAmerican sprinter Kenny Bednarek, who is known by the moniker above, is hoping to dethrone superstar compatriot Noah Lyles in the men's 200m final at the Paris Olympics.\n\nBut Bednarek has thrown an accusation of \"favouritism\" towards Games organisers over the starting positions for the blue ribbon race at the Paris track.\n\nWhile Lyles, who took out the 100m earlier at the Games and is aiming for the sprint double, has been handed a favourable lane 5 for the race, Bednarek was initially listed in the far outside lane 9.\n\nThe middle lanes 5-8 are considered the preferred positions for the quarter-lap event, as the inside and outside lanes have issues with visibility around the bend.\n\nBednarek, the silver medallist in the event from the Tokyo Olympics and the world's second-ranked 200m runner behind Lyles, didn't hold back on social media.\n\n\"Never seen favouritism like this on a global scale,\" the 25-year-old wrote on X to his 20,000 followers.\n\nThe post had received 2,500 likes at the time of writing and over 130 comments, before one comment stated the starting positions had changed and Bednarek had been shifted to lane 8.\n\nIt appears the shift was made after Bednarek lodged a complaint, with the sprinter replying to the post showing the new lane positions: \"I protested!\"\n\nBednarek, Erriyon Knighton and Letsile Tebogo all won their semi-final races, with the latter two given lanes six and seven respectively.\n\nLyles finished second to Tebogo in their semi-final.\n\nThe situation, and Bednarek's accusation, drew mixed responses on X.\n\n\"(The protest) was unnecessary ... now that he did that I want him beaten like in the 100m. ... ridiculous lane assignments,\" suggested another.\n\n\"See this is the kind of stuff that makes you lose focus, you're always looking at next man, you aren't focused on you ... you need to lock in, you got this man,\" wrote a fourth.\n\n\"I mean if you're the best you should be able to win from any lane, it's the same distance lol,\" declared another.\n\nIt all adds some extra spice to the {"uri": "8265688521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "17:13:35", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T17:13:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T17:12:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/08/08/american-sprinter-accuses-olympic-organisers-favouritism-ahead-200m-final-21389259/", "title": "American sprinter accuses Olympic organisers of 'favouritism' before 200m final", "body": "American sprinter Kenny Bednarek accused Paris Olympic organisers of 'favouritism' after the initial lane assignments for today's men's 200m final.\n\nBednarek, who won 200m silver at the Tokyo Olympics and 2022 World Championships, punched his ticket into Thursday's final after winning his semi-final with a time of 20.00.\n\nHowever, despite his performance, the American found himself initially placed in lane four for the final, a somewhat unfavourable position for runners looking to navigate the bend.\n\nFellow countrymen Erriyon Knighton and Noah Lyles as well as Botswanan's Letsile Tebogo and Dominican Republic's Alexander Ogando were instead given slots in lanes 5-8 which are the preferred lanes.\n\nAfter protesting, Bednarek eventually had his lane switched with Ogando, who he beat in the semis, but the American still wanted to make his feelings known about the situation.\n\n'Never seen favoritism like this on a global scale,' the 25-year-old said in a post on X.\n\nLyles, meanwhile, who won 100m gold earlier in the week, will still race in lane five despite failing to win his semi-final and running a slower time than Bednarak.\n\nThe 100m gold medallist will fancy his chances of winning his second gold in Paris, with the 200m his preferred distance.\n\nLyles is twice a world champion over the distance and had won his last 26 races prior to the semi-final defeat.\n\nHe also lost both his heat and semi-final in the 100m before claiming a narrow photo-finish victory in the final.\n\nAfter winning 100m {"uri": "8264210304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "21:09:28", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T21:09:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T21:08:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.newagebd.net/post/others/241974/lyles-cruises-into-200m-final-in-pursuit-of-olympic-treble", "title": "Lyles cruises into 200m final in pursuit of Olympic treble", "body": "Noah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79sec, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow against Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nAmerica's Kenny Bednaraek, the second-fastest in the world this year over the distance, clocked 20.00sec to edge out Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic in the first semi-final.\n\nErriyon Knighton of the US, the 20-year-old who has been a silver and bronze medallist over 200m at the past two world championships, qualified first from the third semi-final, clocking 20.09sec, ahead of Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and his compatriot Makanakaishe Charamba, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify after a season in which the Canadian has been beset by injuries.\n\nDe Grasse said he knew it would be tough after he hurt his hamstring.\n\n'After the 100m semis I didn't realise that when I came back the next day after the 200m first round I kind of re-aggravated a lingering issue that I have in my hamstring,' he said.\n\n'They gave me some meds for the pain, and so I just tried to come out here today and see what I could do. But it was going to be really tough to try to come away with a fast time, because of course these guys are running the Olympics.'\n\nSouth Africa's Wayde van Niekerk, the 400m Olympic champion at the 2016 Rio Games and world record holder at the distance, missed out on the 200m final, with his decision to step down to the shorter sprint failing to pay off.\n\n'I'm a competitor, I won medals and I'm not happy with where I am at the moment,' said Van Niekerk, 32.\n\nTreble-chasing Lyles has the chance to be the standout star of the athletics programme in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint star Shericka Jackson withdrew from the women's 100m and then pulled out of her 200m heat.\n\nSt Lucia's Julien Alfred, pursuing the women's sprint double, came second behind Gabby Thomas in the 200m after winning the shorter sprint.\n\nLyles, the Tokyo 2020 bronze medallist, has been dominant in his preferred 200m, winning the past three world titles.\n\nHe is the third-fastest half-lap runner in history, with his mark of 19.31sec set at the world championships in Oregon in 2022 ranking behind only Jamaica's Yohan Blake and Bolt's world record of 19.19sec.\n\nRetired Jamaican sprint superstar Bolt did the 100m-200m sprint double at three consecutive Games -- Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016, adding the 4x100m gold in London and Rio.\n\nThe first round of the sprint relay is on Thursday morning {"uri": "8265954170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:09:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:09:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:09:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://fortune.com/well/article/noah-lyles-covid-paris-olympics/", "title": "Should Noah Lyles and other Olympic athletes compete with COVID?", "body": "In grim news, we are facing yet another summer COVID surge. Rates of infection are rising across 84 countries, according to the World Health Organization. And amid an invigorating Olympics games, even the most elite of us all are not immune.\n\nAfter scoring bronze in the 200-meter finals Thursday, American sprinter Noah Lyles confirmed he tested positive for COVID two days prior. He's among dozens of other athletes who have tested positive during the Game. He had not disclosed his diagnosis to his teammates, he told the Olympics broadcaster NBC after the race.\n\n\"We were trying to keep this as close to the chest as possible,\" Lyles, wearing a mask, tells journalists following the race, according to NBC. \"You never want to tell your competitors you're sick. Why would you give them an edge over you?\"\n\nAccording to NBC's live update reporting, Lyles confided in his coach, medical staff, and family, and made the decision to stay in the race because it was his \"one shot.\" Unlike the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, officials were not strict on COVID protocol this time around and left competing with the respiratory virus up to the athletes and their staff.\n\n\"I knew if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I had from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy, so that was kind of the strategy for today,\" he tells reporters at the games. \"This is by far the best day I felt out of the last three days. I still wouldn't say I'm 100% but I would definitely say I'm closer to like, 90 to 95%.\"\n\nStill, it feels like quite the head-turner after years of intense COVID protocols. Many have taken their opinions online, critiquing the sprinter for competing with the heavily contagious illness. One simply asks what everyone's thinking: \"You are allowed to compete if you have covid?\" An epidemiologist commented on the news headline on Instagram, saying, \"This is not something to celebrate. Putting other athletes' (+ coaches, staff, fans, etc) health at risk is not OK.\" No matter people's illness severity, COVID is still highly contagious, experts have previously told Fortune.\n\nOlympians with underlying conditions, including Lyles, who has asthma, may be at an increased risk for complications from COVID. And people with mild cases may still also have reduced performance. The few who develop long COVID can also experience reduced exercise capacity. After Lyles completed his race, he fell to the ground and received assistance into a wheelchair to be led off the track.\n\nLater, Lyles reported having minor symptoms of COVID, saying he felt \"quite lightheaded after that race, and shortness of breath and chest pain was definitely active ... But after a while, I was able to catch my breath and get my wits about me. So I'm feeling a lot better now.\"\n\nThe USA Track & Field organization issued a statement in response, confirming Lyles diagnosis from earlier this week. \"In response, the USOPC [U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee] and USATF swiftly enacted all necessary protocols to prioritize his health, the wellbeing of our team, and the safety of fellow competitors.\"\n\nIt continues: \"Our primary commitment is to ensure the safety of Team USA athletes while upholding their right to compete ... After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight. We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely.\"\n\nIt's yet to be determined if Lyles will compete in the 4x100m relay this weekend, which would be his last event of the games. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) now recommends that people isolate themselves for at least 24 hours after they begin to feel better and are having no signs of fever without fever-reducing medication.\n\nAn official statement regarding public health protocol from the 2024 Summer Olympic and Paralympic Games, the World Health Organization, the French Ministry of Health and Prevention, the Sant\u00e9 publique France and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control acknowledges that attending mass sporting events \"increases your chances of being exposed to respiratory diseases, including whooping cough and COVID-19.\"\n\nThe guidance recommends staying up-to-date on vaccinations and staying home, or wearing a mask if you feel any symptoms of respiratory {"uri": "8260655508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "19:44:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T19:44:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T19:40:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13711567/Olympics-Athletics-Lyles-eases-200m-heat-bid-sprint-double.html", "title": "Olympics-Athletics-Lyles eases through 200m heat in bid for sprint...", "body": "By Mitch Phillips\n\nPARIS, Aug 5 (Reuters) - Less than 24 hours after winning 100 metres gold, Noah Lyles began his quest for the prestigious Olympic sprint double by cruising through his 200m heat on Monday in 20.19 seconds.\n\nThe American has always been stronger over the longer distance, where he is unbeaten in 25 races dating back to the Tokyo Olympics in 2021 when he came third, and he has won the last three world titles.\n\nLyles is targeting a possible four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay and, possibly, the 4x400m relay. That would emulate illustrious compatriots Jesse Owens and Carl Lewis, who achieved the feat at a single Games but with long jump instead of the longer relay.\n\n\"It feels good to be out here,\" Lyles told reporters. \"It was in my head win the 120, win the 150, check around, win the heat.\"\n\nAsked what life had been like since his photo-finish victory, he said: \"I've been trying to get some sleep with my phone going off constantly. Right now I've got to rush over and get my medal.\"\n\nFollowing him home in 20.30 was defending champion Andre de Grasse of Canada, the last man to beat him.\n\nAmerican Kenny Bednarek, silver medallist ahead of Lyles in Tokyo and runner-up to him at the 2022 worlds, shut down early but still clocked the fastest time with 19.96.\n\nHe too went well in Sunday\u00b4s 100m final, though his 9.88 was good enough only for seventh.\n\n\"I\u00b4m on a mission for this 200,\" he said. \"What happened yesterday happened. I\u00b4m taking it day by day.\"\n\nErriyon Knighton, world championship silver and bronze medallist as a teenager, made sure there would be three Americans in the semi-finals by winning his heat in 19.99, the only other sub-20 time on a warm Paris evening.\n\nNow 20, Knighton will seek to deliver on the biggest stage after seemingly being the next big thing for years but never quite reaching the top step.\n\nBotswana's Letsile Tebogo, sixth in Sunday\u00b4s 100m final in a national record 9.86 and a bronze medallist over 200m in last year\u00b4s world championships, cruised his heat in 20.10.\n\nWayde van Niekerk, the 400m world record holder and former world championship silver medallist over 200m, made it as the third automatic qualifier from the first heat in 20.42 having opted the skip the one-lap event in Paris.\n\n\"The decision (to run only the 200) was purely based on getting back to a space of enjoying the sport,\" said the South African. \"Finding peace in a sport that has helped me so much.\n\n\"If I look at my performance so far, I'm obviously well off the top tier guys. I\u00b4m going to have to pull a rabbit out of the hat to get among the top three.\" (Reporting by Mitch Phillips, editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. I woke up in the middle of the night feeling real chills, aching, sore throat, and those were a lot of the symptoms I've had right before getting Covid,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"We tested it, came back positive and we quickly quarantined in a hotel nearby the [Olympic] Village. Tried to get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure my body could keep the momentum going. I still wanted to run, it was still possible, we just stayed away from everybody. I knew that if I wanted to come out here and win, I had to give everything I have from the get-go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\"\n\nSpeaking about how he felt, he said: \"I've had better days, but I'm walking around again. I was quite light-headed after that race. Shortness of breath, chest pain, but after a while I could catch my breath and get my wits about me. I'm a lot better now.\"\n\n\"[Covid-19] definitely affected my performance. I've had to take a lot of breaks ... I was coughing through the night. I'm more proud of myself than anything, coming out here to get a bronze with Covid.\n\n\"We were trying to keep this close to the chest. The people who knew were the medical staff, coach, my mum. We didn't want everybody going into a panic, we wanted them to be able to compete. We wanted to make this as free as possible. I'm competitive.
