{"uri": "8264100528", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "19:27:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T19:27:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T19:25:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/lyles-cruises-into-200m-final-in-pursuit-of-olympic-treble/article_6b182ba1-e117-50e2-a074-8485be13f1f4.html", "title": "Lyles cruises into 200m final in pursuit of Olympic treble", "body": "Noah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nAmerica's Kenny Bednaraek, the second-fastest in the world this year over the distance, clocked 20.00sec to edge out Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic in the first semi-final.\n\nErriyon Knighton of the US, a silver and bronze medallist over 200m at the past two world championships, qualified first from the third semi-final, clocking 20.09, ahead of Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Makanakaishe Charamba and compatriot Tapiwanashe Makarawu, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and his compatriot Makanakaishe Charamba, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify after a season in which the Canadian has struggled for form.\n\nTreble-chasing Lyles has the chance to be the standout star of the athletics programme in Paris.\n\nMore from this section Feel Judged by Your Doctor? You Might Not Be Imagining It X's AI chatbot spread election misinformation, US officials say Kenya's Treetops hotel reopens after Covid shutdown\n\nJamaican sprint star Shericka Jackson withdrew from the women's 100m and then pulled out of her 200m heat.\n\nSt Lucia's Julien Alfred, pursuing the women's sprint double, came second behind Gabby Thomas in the 200m after winning the shorter sprint.\n\nLyles, the Tokyo 2020 bronze medallist, has been dominant in his preferred 200m, winning the past three world titles.\n\nHe is the third-fastest half-lap runner in history, with his mark of 19.31sec set at the world championships in Oregon in 2022 ranking behind only Jamaica's Yohan Blake and Bolt's world record of 19.19sec.\n\nRetired Jamaican sprint superstar Bolt did the 100m-200m sprint double at three consecutive Games -- Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016, adding the 4x100m gold in London and Rio.\n\nThe first round of the sprint relay is on Thursday morning but Lyles is {"uri": "8265858740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:43:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:43:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:38:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4431372582912445, "url": "https://www.si.com/olympics/paris-olympics-covid-protocols", "title": "What Are COVID-19 Protocols at the Olympics in Paris?", "body": "Noah Lyles after running the 200-meter at the Paris Games. He won bronze / Erick W. Rasco/Sports Illustrated\n\nAfter Noah Lyles secured the bronze medal in the 200-meter race on Thursday for the U.S., news came out that he tested positive for COVID two days ago, meaning he had run in a semifinal on Wednesday and the final on Thursday since the positive test. It was first reported by Lewis Johnson of NBC.\n\nLyles was seen wearing a mask before participating in the final. After the final when he secured bronze, he received medical attention and left the track in a wheelchair. Lyles has been outspoken about his asthma previously.\n\nShort answer: There are no formal or event-level requirements. How to handle the threat of the disease is decided by teams and individuals.\n\nUnlike the two other games (Toyko 2020, Beijing 2022) that had extensive athlete testing and protocols for positive tests, the regulations and requirements around testing are much more relaxed.\n\nAthletes do not have to be subjected to mandatory regular testing and reporting. Furthermore, positive tests do not stipulate sitting out from events. Participation for positive athletes is at the discretion of the athlete, teams, and medical staff.\n\nHere is some insight from Scientific American:\n\n\"The Paris Games also drop all previous COVID protocols, instead approaching the disease like other respiratory illnesses such as the common cold or the flu: officials now allow athletes and teams to determine for themselves how to prevent or respond to infection.\"\n\nAccording to SciAm, at least a handful of swimmers have already competed in events while having tested positive for COVID.", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", The mildest form of COVID I'm familiar with that isn't symptom-free is congestion that causes a loss of taste. Trying to sprint as fast as you possibly can with any form of that \"milder\" COVID and asthma? Fuhgeddaboudit.\n\nFor a little added context, Lyles publicly posted about his asthma and other adversity earlier on in the Summer Olympics.\n\nMany were giving Lyles grief for his assertion that NBA players aren't technically \"world champions\" when the win the title. Those critiques quieted down when he won 100m gold. Now people are calling him selfish for running despite the potential he had to spread COVID. "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/lyles-cruises-into-200m-final-in-pursuit-of-olympic-treble/article_114fac5f-e7f6-50d7-a952-44205e44ffb8.html", "title": "Lyles cruises into 200m final in pursuit of Olympic treble", "body": "Noah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nAmerica's Kenny Bednaraek, the second-fastest in the world this year over the distance, clocked 20.00sec to edge out Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic in the first semi-final.\n\nErriyon Knighton of the US, a silver and bronze medallist over 200m at the past two world championships, qualified first from the third semi-final, clocking 20.09, ahead of Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Makanakaishe Charamba and compatriot Tapiwanashe Makarawu, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify.\n\nThe two next-fastest qualifiers were Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and his compatriot Makanakaishe Charamba, meaning defending Olympic champion Andre De Grasse does not qualify after a season in which the Canadian has struggled for form.\n\nTreble-chasing Lyles has the chance to be the standout star of the athletics programme in Paris.\n\nJamaican sprint star Shericka Jackson withdrew from the women's 100m and then pulled out of her 200m heat.\n\nSt Lucia's Julien Alfred, pursuing the women's sprint double, came second behind Gabby Thomas in the 200m after winning the shorter sprint.\n\nLyles, the Tokyo 2020 bronze medallist, has been dominant in his preferred 200m, winning the past three world titles.\n\nHe is the third-fastest half-lap runner in history, with his mark of 19.31sec set at the world championships in Oregon in 2022 ranking behind only Jamaica's Yohan Blake and Bolt's world record of 19.19sec.\n\nRetired Jamaican sprint superstar Bolt did the 100m-200m sprint double at three consecutive Games -- Beijing 2008, London 2012 and Rio 2016, adding the 4x100m gold in London and Rio.\n\nThe first round of the sprint relay is on Thursday morning but Lyles is likely to be rested following his 200m semi-final.\n\nThe 200m final takes place at 1830 GMT on Thursday.\n\njw/gj\n\nMore from this section\n\nReformed Gangster Disciples Boss, Harold 'Noonie G' Ward Hosts Citywide treble gold bid", "body": "Noah Lyles, fresh from winning Olympic 100m gold, cruised his 200m heat at the Stade de France on Monday to keep his bid for a sprint treble alive.\n\nLyles, who won the 100m in a photo-finish from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79 seconds, topped his 200m heat in 20.19sec.\n\nThe triple world 200m champion had a slow start but as soon as he hit the bend he looked in total control.\n\nThe semi-finals are scheduled for 1802 GMT on Wednesday, with the final slated for 1830 on Thursday.\n\nAlso going through were fellow 100m finalists Letsile Tebogo of Botswana (20.10sec) and American Kenny Bednarek (19.96) as heat winners.\n\nA third American, Erriyon Knighton, a silver and bronze medallist at the past two world championships, topped another heat in 19.99sec.\n\nAnd Canada's Andre de Grasse, defending champion and silver medallist at the Rio Games, also qualified, clocking 20.20sec behind Lyles.\n\nSouth Africa's 400m world record holder and gold "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/olympics/noah-lyles-karsten-warholm-paris-snoop-dogg-great-britain-b2592850.html", "title": "Noah Lyles keeps sprint double bid on course by booking 200 metres final spot", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nNoah Lyles took one step closer to his dream of achieving an individual Olympic sprint double in Paris after securing his spot in the 200 metres final at the Stade de France.\n\nThe American claimed 100 metres gold by five one thousandths of a second on Sunday night, and needed to finish in the top two from semi-final heat two to automatically book his place in Thursday night's showdown.\n\nLyles crossed his fingers with a tongue-out grin as the camera cut toward him on the big screen.\n\nLike that 100m final, Lyles got out to the slowest start of the eight-man field, but made up for it when he crossed the line in 20.08 seconds for second spot behind Botswanan Letsile Tebogo in 19.96.\n\nLyles' time was still good enough for third-fastest of the semi-finalists behind Tebogo, the only man to clock a sub-20 time in the semis.\n\nSecond quickest was Lyles' American team-mate Kenny Bednarek, the 2022 world and Tokyo 2020 silver medallist, who made easy work of the first semi-final in exactly 20 seconds.\n\nDominican Alexander Ogando and a third American, Erriyon Knighton, rounded out the top five while Liberia's Joseph Fahnbulleh and Zimbabwe duo Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba also qualified.\n\nAmber Anning booked her place in Friday's women's 400 metres finals after posting a personal best 49.47 seconds in the last of three semi-finals.\n\nThe 23-year-old, who had already anchored Great Britain to a mixed 4\u00d7400 metres relay bronze, battled Natalia Kaczmarek all the way to the finish and crossed two hundredths of a second behind her Polish challenger.\n\nThere was also good news for Ireland's Rhasidat Adeleke, who made it through from the first semi in second.\n\nGreat Britain's Victoria Ohuruogu had fought her way back from the repechage round but was unable to progress.\n\nIt also was not meant to be for Laviai Nielsen, who was shown a yellow card but allowed to race, finishing 12 overall from the semi-finalists.\n\nEarlier, Guernsey hurdler Alastair Chalmers' evening came to an unfortunate end when he fell at the final bend of his 400 metres hurdles semi-final.\n\nHe said: \"Honestly I'm actually quite fine, I'm happy to make the semi-final and had a good heat the other day.\n\n\"To be in front of this crowd and racing these kinds of athletes is a dream. I just lost a bit of concentration between six and seven. It's a bit frustrating I guess, but I'm happy with how I set the race up, I attacked it and I'm honestly not that upset or disappointed.\n\nNorway's defending Olympic champion Karsten Warholm, who set a world and Olympic record 45.94 seconds at Tokyo 2020, was the fastest of the semi-finalists in 47.67.\n\nGreat Britain's Tade Ojora lined up in heat two of the men's 110 metres semi-finals but did not advance after finishing seventh.\n\nHe said: \"It was a great experience. Obviously I hoped to do better and expected to do better, I wish I'd done better, I let myself down but that's the emotions. I'm sure in a couple of days, maybe a couple of hours I'll be able to look back on that Olympic experience. {"uri": "2024-08-448619307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "22:29:29", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T22:29:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T22:02:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1147616/five-things-paris-olympics-day-thirteen", "title": "Paris 2024: Five takeaways from Day Thirteen", "body": "As the final weekend of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games draws closer, August 8 witnessed a jam-packed day of events across all sports. Numerous athletes fought to write their names, nations, and in some cases continents, into the history books as elsewhere controversies continued to gather steam.\n\nHere are five takeaways from Day Thirteen at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nFollowing American Cole Hocker taking a surprise gold in the men's 1500 metre on Tuesday, Day 13 saw another shock win as Botswana's Letsile Tebogo became the new 200m champion beating pre-race favourite Noah Lyles.\n\nMuch of the focus had been on 27-year-old Noah Lyles, who on Sunday became the first American to win an Olympic 100m title since Justin Gatlin in 2004 when he beat Jamaica's Kishane Thompson to gold by five-thousandths of a second.\n\nLyles was bidding to become the first man since Usain Bolt to complete the Olympic 100m and 200m sprint double but lost out to Botswana's 21-year-old Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo stopped Lyles' attempt to make history, instead writing his own name in the history books by winning in 19.46 seconds to become the first African to win the Olympic 200m. He dedicated the win to his mother who died earlier this year.\n\nCovid-19 lingers in the periphery\n\nThe Paris 2024 Olympic Games has been dogged by health concerns both before and during its run. Firstly poor air quality in Paris was highlighted when experts publicly scrutinised pollution levels and then once it had all kicked off, there were numerous cancellations and setbacks due to the poor water quality in the River Seine, where some events were scheduled to take place.\n\nMore recently Covid-19 has reminded us that it is still very much around affecting even the best athletes in the world. On Tuesday, the World Health Organisation (WHO) released a statement emphasising a new global rise in cases expressing that over 40 athletes competing at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games had tested positive for Covid-19.\n\nToday Covid-19's rise was accentuated further as Noah Lyles said he'd tested positive before his 200m race and was seen being spoken to by medical staff before being taken off the track in a wheelchair.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance,\" said Lyles. \"I still wanted to run. They said it was possible.\"\n\nThe water quality in the River Seine has posed a persistent problem for Paris 2024 organisers with numerous training sessions and events delayed or cancelled since the summer games began. Today, however, the women's 10km marathon swim was cleared and took place this morning.\n\nAfter two hours of rigorous swimming Sharon van Rouwendaal of the Netherlands took gold winning her second Olympic title after winning at Rio 2016.\n\nVan Rouwendaal had her own dedication to make after the race, only this time it was to her pet dog Rio, who died in May.\n\n\"My world stopped and I didn't care about swimming for like three weeks,\" said the 30-year-old. \"He was my little baby. I swam for him with my whole heart. I won it for him.\"\n\nA controversy involving two boxers who previously failed gender tests has dogged the summer games but it reached a boiling point in the last week with various parties trading blows.\n\nBoxers Imane Khelif of Algeria and Lin Yu Ting of Taiwan were disqualified from the Women's World Championships last year for failing gender eligibility tests but have both made it to the final in their respective categories at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee (IOC), who released a statement last week warning against the amassing outcry turning into a \"witch-hunt\", have come under fire from the International Boxing Association (IBA) which carried out the eligibility tests last year.\n\nOutcry gathered steam when the two boxers began competing, especially when Imane Khelif forced a 46-second withdrawal from Italy's Angela Carini who claimed she had never been hit so hard in her life.\n\nNow there is another chapter in the gender controversy which has become synonymous with the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nAfter Bulgaria's Svetlana Staneva was eliminated by Lin Yu-Ting in the women's -57kg category she held up crossed fingers in the form of an X to allude to the single X chromosome that men have. When Esra Yildiz of Turkey lost to Imane Khelif in the 66kg semi-final she did the same thing.\n\nNow with the IBA threatening to release information about the confidential eligibility tests that it carried out the Olympic Committees of Algeria and Chinese Taipei have threatened legal action against the IBA.\n\nThe controversy will no doubt continue indefinitely with both boxers set to play in their respective finals on Saturday.\n\nAs Day Thirteen at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games draws to a close the United States of America has consolidated its position at the top of the table staying ahead of the People's Republic of China by one gold medal.\n\nTeam USA also has the highest number of medals overall with 103, 30 of them gold, while the People's Republic of China has 29 golds and 73 medals overall.\n\nAustralia make up the top three with 18 golds considerably less than the top two while France follows Australia with 14 golds.\n\nGreat Britain, the Republic of Korea, and Japan sit in fifth, sixth, and seventh respectively having all won 13 golds though Great Britain's total medal count of 51 some way more than the other two.", "source": {"uri": "insidethegames.biz", "dataType": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 90}], "image": "https://cdn.dmcl.biz/media/image/301855/c/GettyImages-2165913489.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9792855", "eventUri": "eng-9792855", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-08", "textStart": 67, "textEnd": 75}], "sentiment": 0.02745098039215677, "wgt": 108, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8265221355", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:58:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:58:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:58:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/08/08/sports/olympics-2024-what-we-will-remember-most-about-paris-games/", "title": "What we will remember most about the 2024 Olympics", "body": "We're closer to the end of the Olympics than the beginning.\n\nThe so-called glamour events -- gymnastics, swimming, track and field -- are mostly over. We've already seen most of the athletes who are identifiable by one name: Biles, Ledecky, Lyles, Marchand. There's still some suspense over basketball and soccer and the remaining track finals, including Thursday's men's 200 meters, but this is a good time to zoom out and take stock.\n\nSo that's just what we're going to do.\n\nHere are the biggest winners of the Olympics so far:\n\nNoah Lyles\n\nHere's a smattering of things Lyles said publicly in the past year:\n\n\"I watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on their head. World champion of what? The United States? ... We [track and field] are the world. ... There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\n\"I'm a true believer that the moment isn't bigger than me. The moment was made for me.\"\n\n\"Everybody has their own vibe. I'm a showman.\"\n\nAnd, after failing to win his 100-meter heat in Paris, Lyles told NBC: \"I think I'm more excited now that I didn't win that heat. I'm pretty scared for everybody else right now.\"\n\nAll this to say, the difference between Lyles becoming an American Olympic legend and one of its all-time laughingstocks came down to five-thousandths of a second.\n\nThat's the margin by which Lyles ultimately won the 100-meter final in what was irrefutably the best moment of the Olympic Games -- a photo finish in its biggest single event. Lyles still has to run the 200-meter final on Thursday, but that's the event in which he's a massive favorite and it's slightly lower-profile than the 100.\n\nIt's been a long time since the U.S. had a 100-meter winner -- 20 years on the men's side, and that was Justin Gatlin, whose later PED suspension made his win in Athens hard to celebrate. If Lyles wins the 200, as he's expected to do, he'll be the first American man to complete the double since Carl Lewis in 1984.\n\nLyles not only could put himself in that company, but he's established himself as a brand name who can back up everything that comes out of his mouth.\n\nL\u00e9on Marchand\n\nIt's rare that a non-American athlete becomes must-watch television at the Olympics. The list, over the past 20 or so years, pretty much started and ended with Usain Bolt, at least until Marchand entered the scene.\n\nThe native of Toulouse, who swam at Arizona State in college, won gold in all four of his individual events in front of a delirious home crowd. Even on TV, the scene was astonishing -- the crowd timing its chants to Marchand's head bobbing out of the water on the breaststroke was something that will stay with people from these Games.\n\nMarchand going for two golds in a day in the 200-meter butterfly and 200-meter breaststroke -- chasing down Hungary's Krist\u00f3f Mil\u00e1k in the final 50 meters to seal the butterfly -- produced some of the best drama and best TV of the Games as Michael Phelps cheered him on.\n\n(On a related note, U.S. men's swimming was one of the major losers of the Games, with Phelps saying he was \"pretty disappointed\" at the results, which included just one individual gold.)\n\nEven as the United States produced some moments on the women's side and in the swim relays, finishing with the most gold medals at the meet after trailing for nearly the entire duration, it was Marchand who provided the best entertainment.\n\nSimone Biles\n\nSpeaking of Phelps, the greatest swimmer of all time feels like an apt comparison for Biles, the greatest gymnast of all time.\n\nBiles has carried the baton for the American Olympic team since 2016 in the same way Phelps did in Beijing and London. Even in her third Olympic Games, even after Tokyo went off the rails for her three years ago, every event in which Biles competed felt must-watch. And the redemptive arc that could have been pre-written by ChatGPT came true with Biles taking three golds and a silver medal.\n\nBiles even turned the silver -- which was a disappointment in the floor event, where she was supposed to win a fourth gold -- into a triumph as she and Jordan Chiles bowed down to Brazil's Rebecca Andrade in the sort of display of sportsmanship that fulfills every Olympic clich\u00e9.\n\nThe IOC has made a habit out of holding the Olympics in far-off countries, a couple of which have authoritarian governments, for the past decade.\n\nSince London 2012, the Games have gone to Sochi, Rio de Janeiro, Pyeongchang, Tokyo and Beijing. If you want to know why the Olympics haven't drawn quite as much of an American audience, start there. (Quick -- what's a tourist attraction in Pyeongchang? Do you know anyone who's visited? Now answer the same questions about Paris.)\n\nIt's difficult to follow the Olympics in a time zone that's 10-12 hours different from the East Coast. It doesn't feel good to read story after story about the Zika virus or athletes being stuck in China if they test positive for COVID. The pandemic -- and subsequent lack of crowds -- didn't help either.\n\nParis' time zone works perfectly for a U.S. audience, letting people wake up and watch the Olympics all day. In an era where streaming and social media make tape delay a hard proposition, a European time zone makes it so NBC can cover the Olympics both as a live event and in prime time with tape delay, giving it the best of both.\n\nHaving recognizable landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower be a part of the Games makes it feel bigger and a little more relatable. So does having American celebrities such as Snoop Dogg and Flavor Flav be characters around the Games, which, let's face it, is directly correlated to the Olympics being in Paris as opposed to a less appealing destination.\n\nParis hasn't been perfect -- using the Seine for the triathlon, for example, looks like a failed gamble, and residents of the city have rightful complaints about the security level that came with integrating so many temporary venues with tourist attractions. But compared to the hosts we've gotten for the last decade, it's lapping the field.\n\nNBC\n\nEverything in the above blurb, of course, serves to help NBC, which has seen its best Olympics ratings in a pretty long time, in part as a result of the Games being in Paris.\n\nBut NBC has also done the right thing with these Olympics, and deserves credit there.\n\nMike Tirico has come into his own as a studio host, and the addition of Phelps to the coverage was just as much of a home run as it looked on paper.\n\nGold Zone has been fantastic day-in and day-out -- and gave people who weren't diehard fans of the Premier League or \"The Office\" a reason to subscribe to Peacock.\n\nBeing less committed to tape delay, while keeping the prime time show that gives casual fans a way into the Olympics, was unequivocally the right call.\n\nIf we have one nitpick, it's that it should be easier to go online and see what each day's schedule is, what's live at a given moment and what the scores are at every live event. That's always been a problem with the Olympics because there's so much going on that it's hard to lay it all out in one place. But as the rights holder, it's something NBC take the lead on tackling for 2026.\n\nKristen Faulkner\n\nInevitably, there are 50 different stories from the Olympics that deserve more coverage than they get. Faulkner's, though, might lead the field.\n\nA 31-year-old who grew up in Homer, Alaska, Faulkner picked up cycling as a hobby after moving to New York in 2017. She eventually quit her job as a venture capitalist, turned pro and -- after getting hit by a car and breaking her shin bone last year -- made the Olympics.\n\nAlready having qualified for the cycling team pursuit, she got a spot in the women's road race after Taylor Knibb resigned to focus on the time trial and triathlon.\n\nThen Faulkner went and won gold in the road race by nearly a full minute, becoming the first American woman to do so since 1984.\n\nOn Wednesday, she helped the U.S. to gold in the team pursuit, joining a very short list of athletes ever to win gold in what's technically two different sports (\"road cycling\" and \"track cycling\") at one Olympics.\n\nIt's the sort of story that should be turned into a movie, the kind that would be laughed out of a room as unbelievable and clich\u00e9 if you pitched it. There might not be a better one that's played out in Paris.\n\nDoes a fiery pair of joint practices translate to actual juice for the preseason opener between the Giants and Lions on Thursday (7 p.m. ET, Fox)?\n\nErrr, probably not.\n\nHistory tells us \"juice\" and \"preseason\" are two words that almost never should be used in a sentence together. It's also worth noting that the practice fights generally involved players whose spots on their respective depth charts are sealed -- in other words, not the guys who will be on the field in, say, the third quarter of a preseason game.\n\nThe preseason opener is a good milestone to reach. It means real football is close.\n\nBut the general rule is the same as training camp: It's exciting until the moment it actually starts. Then you start getting antsy for the regular season.\n\nThe news from Port St. Lucie appeared to be all positive for Starling Marte on Wednesday. He didn't play the field, but hit three times as a DH, going 1-for-3 and adding a stolen base.\n\nThe Mets lately appear to have found some equilibrium between their awful start to the season and their Grimace-fueled resurgence, but they'll need to trend more toward the latter to make the playoffs, let alone to do something once there.\n\nParticularly in the midst of a long road trip that has produced an underwhelming 3-3 record after Wednesday's nail-biting 5-3 win over the Rockies, the possibility of getting Marte back soon should be enticing for this lineup.\n\nThough Marte struggled in 2023, he was in the midst of a bounce-back campaign with a 113 OPS+ before getting hurt.\n\nAfter a trade deadline when Jesse Winker was the only lineup addition, Marte would fulfill the prototypical saying that the best deadline acquisition is the player returning from injury.\n\nZach Messinger continued to roll on the mound. The Yankees right-hander tossed seven scoreless frames on Wednesday, striking out four for Double-A Somerset.\n\nMessinger, who also threw seven innings in his last start, has not gone fewer than five frames since June 21. His ERA now sits at 3.40, the lowest it's been since his first start of the year.\n\n-- Andrew Battifarano\n\n\u26be \"The Yankees look like the Yankees again,\" declares The Post's Mike Vaccaro, after a soggy doubleheader split in The Bronx that left them atop the American League standings. Two things to watch: The Yankees pushed back Marcus Stroman \"to work through some things,\" and what about a Juan Soto-Aaron Judge lineup flip?\n\n\ud83c\udfc8 Xavier Gipson isn't a Jets roster long shot anymore. In Year 2, he's trying to establish himself as a starting-caliber slot receiver.\n\n\ud83c\udfc0 Kevin Durant, whom Jim Boeheim calls the best international player ever, and Team USA face Nikola Jokic's Serbia in Thursday's Olympics semifinals (3 p.m. ET, USA Network).\n\n\ud83c\udfc0 The Las Vegas Aces, um, Team USA women reached the semis, too.\n\n\u26be Little League drama! Staten Island walked it off to set up a rematch with Morristown, N.J., with a World Series spot on the line.", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": {"uri": "8265914031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:36:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:36:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T20:30:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.si.com/olympics/noah-lyles-explains-why-he-raced-with-covid", "title": "Noah Lyles Explains Why He Raced Despite Positive COVID Test", "body": "Noah Lyles runs in the 200-meter final at the Paris Games / Erick W. Rasco/Sports Illustrated\n\nNoah Lyles, a favorite to win gold at the 200-meter final at the Paris Games, came in third, securing bronze. His place on the podium was a shock, until shortly after the race he was seen being tended to by medical staff and taken off in a wheelchair. The first thought was that he may have run through an injury, but the reality was he ran while ill from COVID.\n\nLyles tested positive a few days ago and described attempting to quarantine to the best of his ability leading up to the 200-meter. He did not break any Olympic protocols by participating in the event. Teams and individuals are able to participate at their discretion even if COVID positive in 2024 after restrictions for the past two Games.\n\nThe main reason Lyles opted to race, despite the illness, was resilience. He spoke after the race about how he was proud of being able to come out to participate despite the circumstances.\n\n\"My first thought [after testing positive] was not to panic, thinking I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122ve been in worse situations, I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122ve run with worse conditions, and we just took it day by day, trying to hydrate, quarantined off. It\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s taken its toll for sure, but I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122ve never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and get a bronze medal.\u00e2\u20ac\n\nHis medal, the same one he achieved last Olympics, feels much different this time around:\n\n\"It's taken its toll for sure, but I've never been more proud of myself for being able to come out here and getting a bronze medal where last Olympic I was very disappointed, and this time I couldn't be more proud.\"\n\nAsked if he ever considered not running, he said: \"No. No, I didn't. He received medical treatment after crossing the line and after the race, U.S. officials said he had COVID, putting his participation in Friday's sprint relay final in serious doubt.\n\nAdding to the chaos, a yellow card appeared against his name in the official results to mark a misconduct violation for damaging his lane box.\n\nLyles might still hog the limelight, but it was Tebogo and Africa's night. It is common to see a clutch of Africans in major middle and long-distance races, but this was the first time in Olympic history that four appeared in a sprint final.\n\nAlthough three filled the last three places in the final, Tebogo's place on top of the podium was a huge leap forward.\n\n\"I'm the Olympic champion, it's something I have never seen in my life or dreamt of - it is an amazing I tested positive around 5am on Tuesday morning. Woke up in the middle of the night feeling chills, aching, sore throat and those were a lot of the symptoms I've always had right before getting covid.\n\n\"We tested it and it came back positive so we quickly quarantined in a hotel near the village and get me on as much medication as we legally could to make sure that my body was able to keep the momentum going.\n\n\"I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible, so we just stayed away from everybody and tried to take it round by round. I knew if I wanted to come out here and win I would have to give everything I've had from the get go. I didn't have any time to save energy. That was the strategy.\n\n\"It definitely affected my performance. I am more proud of myself than anything. Coming out and getting the bronze medal with covid.\n\n\"We tried to keep it close to our chest. The medical staff, my coach and my mum knew.\n\nI do have covid. I still wanted to run, we decided it was still possible\n\n\"We didn't want everybody to go into a panic. We wanted to be able to compete. We wanted to be able to make it discreet as possible and you don't want to tell your competitors you are sick.\n\n\"Why would you give them an edge?\"\n\nThe American world champion at the distance was hoping to become the first man since Usain Bolt at the Rio 2016 Games to secure both the 100 metres and 200 metres titles.\n\nHe had managed to bounce back to win 100 metres gold in Paris, but this time could not compensate for what was again the slowest reaction time of the pack.\n\nTebogo crossed in 19.46 for his first Olympic title and the United States' Kenny Bednarek snapped up silver.\n\nLyles was slowest off the blocks in 0.173 seconds but had clawed his way up to third by the 20- metre mark and remained in bronze medal position for the rest of the race, finishing in 19.70.\n\nTebogo and Bednarek battled for their positions, the American holding the lead just after the halfway point, but it was the Botswanan's race to lose from the 120 metres mark and he never looked close to letting go.\n\nTebogo, 21, became the first man from his country to win an Olympic 200 metres final and dedicated the medal to his mother, Elizabeth Seratiwa, who passed away last He came out two hours later and electrified the crowd by winning the most competitive men's 100m in Olympic history.\n\nLyles is looking to become the first American in four decades to win the Olympic sprint double. He is aiming for potentially four golds in Paris, in the 100m, 200m, 4x100m relay, and -- if he is selected in the squad -- the 4x400m relay.\n\nCanada's defending champion Andre de Grasse, the last {"uri": "8265154437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "11:15:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T11:15:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T11:15:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/08/08/sports/2024-paris-olympics-us-sprinter-kenny-bednarek-accuses-olympics-of-favoritism-for-mens-200m-final/", "title": "US sprinter Kenny Bednarek accuses Olympics officials of 'favoritism'...", "body": "American sprinter Kenny Bednarek is accusing race officials of \"favoritism\" over the lane assignments of the Men's 200m final at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nBednarek, the world-ranked number 2 behind compatriot Noah Lyles, was unhappy with the lane assignment for Thursday's race as he was placed away from the \"preferred positions.\"\n\nBednarek won his semi-final race with a time of 20.00, the second fastest of the final qualifiers,\n\n\"Kung Fu Kenny\" was originally set to start in lane 4 while Lyles was set to race in lane 5. American Erriyon Knighton and Botswanan runner Letsile Tebogo were placed in lanes 6 and 7, respectively.\n\nThe middle lanes 5-8 are considered the preferred positions for the 200m, as the inside and outside lanes have issues with visibility around the bend.\n\nBednarek, the defending Olympic silver medalist, called out race organizers for the \"favoritism\" before the medal race.\n\n\"Never seen favoritism like this on a global scale,\" he said in a post to X.\n\nBednarek launched a protest about the lane assignments, which forced organizers to reassign the lanes.\n\nHe was moved to lane 8 following the protest.\n\nLyles, Bednarek, Knighton and Tebogo are the top-ranked runners in the event with the latter three all winning their semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nTebogo was the fastest out of all three semi-finals, finishing in 19.96, followed by Bednarek (20.00) and Lyles (20.08) while Knighton and Dominican Republic runner Alexander Ogando both ran at 20.09.\n\nOgando is now running in lane 4 after the officials switched him and Bednarek.\n\nWorld Athletics officials complete three separate draws to determine the lane assignments in for the 200m finals.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-448217172", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "14:20:47", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T14:20:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T14:20:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "url": "https://www.wlky.com/article/noah-lyles-nba-beef-explained/61826236", "title": "The Noah Lyles-NBA players beef explained", "body": "Noah Lyles is a charismatic, boisterous athlete who is not afraid to say what's on his mind in his effort to push track and field's profile higher in the sporting world. Last year, however, that put him at odds with some of the most high-profile basketball players in the NBA.At last year's world championships, Lyles won the 100-meter and 200-meter races - a double he's trying to repeat in the Olympics on Thursday night after winning the 100m on Sunday - and wasn't shy about comparing his accomplishments to those of his professional basketball counterparts back in the U.S.When speaking to reporters at the World Championships in Budapest, Lyles was asked about what he wanted to do for track and field and what he'd like to see to improve the sport's profile.Lyles said the medals he wins are the first step to raising track's awareness in the public's eye and that he wants more former world champions to be present at high-profile meets. And then he took a turn into taking a shot at the NBA.\"You know the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on they head. World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong, I love the U.S. - at times - but that ain't the world,\" Lyles said.\"We are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving, putting on their flag to show they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"Video below: Noah Lyles' mom shares her Olympic journey as her son makes historyLyles' comment hit on something that sports fans in the rest of the world often mock about U.S. sports culture. In almost every major American sport, the champion of the league is referred to as the world champion, even though those teams only play against other franchises that are based in either the U.S. or Canada.But the U.S.' distinct sporting culture means that the four major American sports - football, basketball, baseball and hockey - are head and shoulders above those sports' domestic leagues in other nations. Most of the best players from around the world in those sports end up playing for American teams, hence the claim to the title of world champion: case and point, the last six NBA MVP awards went to players who were born abroad.Lyles' comment was not welcomed by the American NBA players who he had called out.Two-time NBA champion and 2014 MVP Kevin Durant, who has also been named Finals MVP twice in his illustrious career, led the charge.\"Somebody help this brother,\" he wrote on Instagram, responding to an ESPN post.Four-time NBA champion Draymond Green also got involved, writing on Instagram, \"When being smart goes wrong\" with the face-palm emoji. Devin Booker, who plays on Team USA in these Olympics and the Phoenix Suns, just simply posted a facepalm emoji.So if Lyles ends up winning the 100m-200m double, don't expect very many American NBA players to be celebrating publicly.\n\nNoah Lyles is a charismatic, boisterous athlete who is not afraid to say what's on his mind in his effort to push track and field's profile higher in the sporting world. Last year, however, that put him at odds with some of the most high-profile basketball players in the NBA.\n\nAt last year's world championships, Lyles won the 100-meter and 200-meter races - a double he's trying to repeat in the Olympics on Thursday night after winning the 100m on Sunday - and wasn't shy about comparing his accomplishments to those of his professional basketball counterparts back in the U.S.\n\nWhen speaking to reporters at the World Championships in Budapest, Lyles was asked about what he wanted to do for track and field and what he'd like to see to improve the sport's profile.\n\nLyles said the medals he wins are the first step to raising track's awareness in the public's eye and that he wants more former world champions to be present at high-profile meets. And then he took a turn into taking a shot at the NBA.\n\n\"You know the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on they head. World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong, I love the U.S. - at times - but that ain't the world,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"We are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving, putting on their flag to show they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\nVideo below: Noah Lyles' mom shares her Olympic journey as her son makes history\n\nLyles' comment hit on something that sports fans in the rest of the world often mock about U.S. sports culture. In almost every major American sport, the champion of the league is referred to as the world champion, even though those teams only play against other franchises that are based in either the U.S. or Canada.\n\nBut the U.S.' distinct sporting culture means that the four major American sports - football, basketball, baseball and hockey - are head and shoulders above those sports' domestic leagues in other nations. Most of the best players from around the world in those sports end up playing for American teams, hence the claim to the title of world champion: case and point, the last six NBA MVP awards went to players who were born abroad.\n\nLyles' comment was not welcomed by the American NBA players who he had called out.\n\nTwo-time NBA champion and 2014 MVP Kevin Durant, who has also been named Finals MVP twice in his illustrious career, led the charge.\n\n\"Somebody help this brother,\" he wrote on Instagram, responding to an ESPN post.\n\nFour-time NBA champion Draymond Green also got involved, writing on Instagram, \"When being smart goes wrong\" with the face-palm emoji. Devin Booker, who plays on Team USA in these Olympics and the Phoenix Suns, just simply posted a facepalm emoji.\n\nSo if Lyles ends up winning the 100m-200m double, don't expect very many American NBA players to be celebrating publicly.", "source": {"uri": "wlky.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WLKY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Lyles", "type": The 27-year-old Lyles had to work hard to finish second in 20.08.\n\nAmericans Kenny Bednarek and Erriyon Knighton each won their semi-finals, Bednarek clocking 20.00 and the 20-year-old Knighton crossing in 20.09.\n\nRounding out the field for Thursday's final are Alexander Ogando of the Dominican Republic, Joseph Fahnbulleh of Liberia, and Zimbabwe's Tapiwanashe Makarawu and Makanakaishe Charamba. {"uri": "2024-08-447941333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "10:21:25", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T10:21:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T09:59:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4039215743541718, "url": "https://kion546.com/sports/cnn-sports/2024/08/08/the-noah-lyles-nba-players-beef-explained/", "title": "The Noah Lyles-NBA players beef explained - KION546", "body": "Paris (CNN) -- Noah Lyles is a charismatic, boisterous athlete who is not afraid to say what's on his mind in his effort to push track and field's profile higher in the sporting world. Last year, however, that put him at odds with some of the most high-profile basketball players in the NBA.\n\nAt last year's world championships, Lyles won the 100-meter and 200-meter races - a double he's trying to repeat in the Olympics on Thursday night after winning the 100m on Sunday - and wasn't shy about comparing his accomplishments to those of his professional basketball counterparts back in the US.\n\nWhen speaking to reporters at the World Championships in Budapest, Lyles was asked about what he wanted to do for track and field and what he'd like to see to improve the sport's profile.\n\nLyles said the medals he wins are the first step to raising track's awareness in the public's eye and that he wants more former world champions to be present at high-profile meets. And then he took a turn into taking a shot at the NBA.\n\n\"You know the thing that hurts me the most is that I have to watch the NBA Finals and they have 'world champion' on they head. World champion of what? The United States? Don't get me wrong, I love the US - at times - but that ain't the world,\" Lyles said.\n\n\"We are the world. We have almost every country out here fighting, thriving, putting on their flag to show they are represented. There ain't no flags in the NBA.\"\n\nLyles' comment hit on something that sports fans in the rest of the world often mock about US sports culture. In almost every major American sport, the champion of the league is referred to as the world champion, even though those teams only play against other franchises that are based in either the US or Canada.\n\nBut the US' distinct sporting culture means that the four major American sports - football, basketball, baseball and hockey - are head and shoulders above those sports' domestic leagues in other nations. Most of the best players from around the world in those sports end up playing for American teams, hence the claim to the title of world champion: case and point, the last six NBA MVP awards went to players who were born abroad.\n\nLyles' comment was not welcomed by the American NBA players who he had called out.\n\nTwo-time NBA champion and 2014 MVP Kevin Durant, who has also been named Finals MVP twice in his illustrious career, led the charge.\n\n\"Somebody help this brother,\" he wrote on Instagram, responding to an ESPN post.\n\nFour-time NBA champion Draymond Green also got involved, writing on Instagram, \"When being smart goes wrong\" with the face-palm emoji. Devin Booker, who plays on Team USA in these Olympics and the Phoenix Suns, just simply posted a facepalm emoji.\n\nSo if Lyles ends up winning the 100m-200m double, don't expect very many American NBA players to be celebrating publicly.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. But he's not the only one.\n\nLyles' diagnosis two days ago was first reported by NBC on Thursday and confirmed by the athlete after he failed to complete a sought-after sprint double in the 200-meter final, where he finished third.\n\nThe 27-year-old won the 100-meter race on Sunday, but was never appeared to be a serious contender for victory in Thursday's race, eventually surging to earn a bronze medal before struggling to leave the track and ultimately leaving the stadium floor in a wheelchair.\n\n\"After a thorough medical evaluation, Noah chose to compete tonight,\" according a statement from USA Track & Field. \"We respect his decision and will continue to monitor his condition closely. As an organization, we are rigorously adhering to CDC, USOPC, and IOC guidelines for respiratory illnesses to prevent the spread of illness among team members, safeguarding their health and performance.\"\n\nIn contrast to the Tokyo Games that were delayed to summer of 2021 by the global pandemic and the 2022 Winter Games in Beijing whose footprint included frequent testing, widespread mask wearing and social distancing, the Paris Games have stadiums full of fans and zero lingering protocols. Athletes and teams, rather than medical personnel, are given the responsibility to gauge their health and respond to issues.\n\nLyles said he boosted hydration to treat himself and voluntarily quarantined \"to not pass it off\" to teammates. Games-wide, athletes who are not feeling well are not required to wear masks or wash hands but are encouraged to avoid close contact and utilize single rooms in the Olympic Village and separate transportation to and from events.\n\nHe is an asthma sufferer and was seen wearing a mask for two days since his Tuesday diagnosis but said after the race that he'd \"never considered\" not running the 200. He is, however, leaning toward not running his leg in the 4x100-meter relay final on Friday.\n\nScientific American reported Wednesday that \"at least 19\" athletes in Paris had tested positive for COVID, many of them competing in aquatic sports -- including Australian swimmers Lani Pallister and Zac Stubblety-Cook and Great Britain's Adam Peaty.\n\nSome athletes have dropped out of events but Manuel Ertel, a German decathlete, is the only one who's left the Games. A 2024 study of German athletes indicated elite athletes typically had milder infections than non-elite counterparts, but still had symptoms that lingered for several weeks.\n\nA World Health Organization representative said Tuesday that COVID rates have increased worldwide in the last few weeks and that more than 20 percent of COVID tests in recent weeks have been positive.\n\nLyles said {"uri": "2024-08-447385538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "21:24:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T21:24:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T20:54:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3607843220233917, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/olympic-games/20240807-el-bakkali-gets-olympic-double-hall-stretches-to-400m-gold", "title": "El Bakkali gets Olympic double, Hall stretches to 400m gold", "body": "Paris (AFP) - Morocco's steeplechase king Soufiane El Bakkali on Wednesday became just the third Arab to win double Olympic gold while Jamaica's Roje Stona upset the favourites to claim a memorable men's discus title.\n\nIn a thrilling 400m final, American Quincy Hall overtook Britain's Matthew Hudson-Smith in the final metre to win the 400m and become the fourth-fastest one-lap performer in history.\n\nA capacity 69,000 crowd at the Stade de France also saw Nina Kennedy bag a first-ever women's pole vault gold for Australia.\n\nThree-time world champion El Bakkali timed 8min 06.05sec for victory in the 3000m steeplechase ahead of American Kenneth Rooks and Kenya's Abraham Kibiwot.\n\nHis second Olympic gold, having first win in the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games, leaves him in a small group of Arab athletes to have doubled up at the Summer Games.\n\nOnly his Moroccan compatriot Hicham El Guerrouj, who won 1500m and 5,000m gold in Athens 2004, and Tunisian swimmer Oussama Mellouli (1500m freestyle in Beijing 2008 and 10km marathon in London 2012) have achieved the feat.\n\nThe discus produced a feast of high-level throwing, Stona coming out on top to upset world record holder Mykolas Alekna.\n\nLithuanian Alekna had broken the Olympic record with his best mark of 69.97m on his second effort.\n\nBut plans to emulate his father Virgilijus, who won two Olympic titles in 2000 and 2004, were scotched by the Jamaican.\n\nStona, coached by American Ryan Crouser who won an unprecedented third consecutive shot put gold on Saturday, stole the show when he threw out to an Olympic record of 70.00m on his fourth attempt.\n\nOn the track, Hall produced a perfectly-timed finish and savage dip for victory in the 400m in 43.40sec.\n\nThe 26-year-old pipped a desperately disappointed Hudson-Smith, who improved his own European record to 43.44sec. Zambia's Muzala Samukonga took bronze in 43.74sec.\n\nIt was the first time ever five athletes had gone below 44 seconds in the same race.\n\nHall became the first American man to win the one-lap event at the Olympics since LaShawn Merritt in Beijing in 2008.\n\n\"It means a lot,\" said Hall, who was only a bronze medallist at last year's world championships. \"I've been putting a lot of work in. This is my second year running the 400.\n\n\"Last year I told you guys I was going to get a better medal this year. Guess what? I got one gold.\"\n\nThe fourth gold of the night went to Australia as Kennedy cleared a best of 4.90m.\n\nAmerican Katie Moon, the defending champion with whom Kennedy had shared world gold in Budapest last year, claimed silver on countback from Canada's Alysha Newman after they both managed 4.85m.\n\nLyles on track\n\nA trio of track stars safely negotiated their way into their respective event finals.\n\nNoah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79sec, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nDefending champion Karsten Warholm wrapped up his semi-final to progress to Saturday's final of the 400m hurdles.\n\nWarholm, who set a sensational world record in winning gold at the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games three years ago, will be joined by arch-rivals Rai Benjamin and Alison Dos Santos, although the latter had to qualify as a fastest loser.\n\nAnd finally three-time world champion Grant Holloway's quest for an elusive Olympic 110m hurdles gold remained on track.\n\nThe 26-year-old American streaked home in an impressive 12.98sec, finishing far ahead of the rest of the field after a dynamite start.", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", (AFP)\n\nMorocco's steeplechase king Soufiane El Bakkali on Wednesday became just the third Arab to win double Olympic gold while Jamaica's Roje Stona upset the favourites to claim a memorable men's discus title.\n\nIn a thrilling 400m final, American Quincy Hall overtook Britain's Matthew Hudson-Smith in the final metre to win the 400m and become the fourth-fastest one-lap performer in history.\n\nA capacity 69,000 crowd at the Stade de France also saw Nina Kennedy bag a first-ever women's pole vault gold for Australia.\n\nThree-time world champion El Bakkali timed 8min 06.05sec for victory in the 3000m steeplechase ahead of American Kenneth Rooks and Kenya's Abraham Kibiwot.\n\nHis second Olympic gold, having first win in the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games, leaves him in a small group of Arab athletes to have doubled up at the Summer Games.\n\nOnly his Moroccan compatriot Hicham El Guerrouj, who won 1500m and 5,000m gold in Athens 2004, and Tunisian swimmer Oussama Mellouli (1500m freestyle in Beijing 2008 and 10km marathon in London 2012) have achieved the feat.\n\nThe discus produced a feast of high-level throwing, Stona coming out on top to upset world record holder Mykolas Alekna.\n\nLithuanian Alekna had broken the Olympic record with his best mark of 69.97m on his second effort.\n\nBut plans to emulate his father Virgilijus, who won two Olympic titles in 2000 and 2004, were scotched by the Jamaican.\n\nStona, coached by American Ryan Crouser who won an unprecedented third consecutive shot put gold on Saturday, stole the show when he threw out to an Olympic record of 70.00m on his fourth attempt.\n\nOn the track, Hall produced a perfectly-timed finish and savage dip for victory in the 400m in 43.40sec. The 26-year-old pipped a desperately disappointed Hudson-Smith, who improved his own European record to 43.44sec.\n\nZambia's Muzala Samukonga took bronze in 43.74sec.\n\nIt was the first time ever five athletes had gone below 44 seconds in the same race. Hall became the first American man to win the one-lap event at the Olympics since LaShawn Merritt in Beijing in 2008.\n\n\"It means a lot,\" said Hall, who was only a bronze medallist at last year's world championships.\n\n\"I've been putting a lot of work in. This is my second year running the 400. \"Last year I told you guys I was going to get a better medal this year. Guess what? I got one gold.\"\n\nThe fourth gold of the night went to Australia as Kennedy cleared a best of 4.90m.\n\nAmerican Katie Moon, the defending champion with whom Kennedy had shared world gold in Budapest last year, claimed silver on countback from Canada's Alysha Newman after they both managed 4.85m.\n\nLyles on track A trio of track stars safely negotiated their way into their respective event finals. Noah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79sec, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nAnd finally three-time world champion Grant Holloway's quest for an elusive Olympic 110m hurdles gold remained on track.\n\nThe 26-year-old American streaked home in an impressive 12.98sec, finishing far ahead of the rest of the field after a dynamite start.", "source": His gold medal comes with a $50,000 prize, and he had reportedly signed the richest endorsement deal for any runner since Usain Bolt.\n\nThis win, however, should also catapult him into one of sports' most marketable athletes, and lead to even bigger paydays. {"uri": "2024-08-448517371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "19:55:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T19:55:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:49:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3568627536296844, "url": "https://www.sunherald.com/sports/article290888814.html", "title": "What Are COVID Protocols at the Olympics in Paris?", "body": "After Noah Lyles secured the bronze medal in the 200-meter race on Thursday for the U.S., news came out that he tested positive for COVID two days ago, meaning he had run in a semifinal on Wednesday and the final on Thursday since the positive test. It was first reported by Lewis Johnson of NBC.\n\nLyles was seen wearing a mask before participating in the final. After the final when he secured bronze, he received medical attention and left the track in a wheelchair. Lyles has been outspoken about his asthma previously.\n\nWhat are the COVID Protocols at Paris Games?\n\nShort answer: There are no formal or event-level requirements. How to handle the threat of the disease is decided by teams and individuals.\n\nUnlike the two other games (Toyko 2020, Beijing 2022) that had extensive athlete testing and protocols for positive tests, the regulations and requirements around testing are much more relaxed.\n\nAthletes do not have to be subjected to mandatory regular testing and reporting. Furthermore, positive tests do not stipulate sitting out from events. Participation for positive athletes is at the discretion of the athlete, teams, and medical staff.\n\nHere is some insight from Scientific American:\n\n\"The Paris Games also drop all previous COVID protocols, instead approaching the disease like other respiratory illnesses such as the common cold or the flu: officials now allow athletes and teams to determine for themselves how to prevent or respond to infection.\"\n\nAccording to SciAm, at least a handful of swimmers have already competed in events while having tested positive for COVID.\n\nThis article was originally published on "news", "sim": 0.3450980484485626, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/sport/20240808-paris-olympics-el-bakkali-clinches-olympic-double-hall-swipes-400m-gold", "title": "Paris Olympics: El Bakkali clinches Olympic double, Hall swipes 400m gold", "body": "Wednesday's Olympics athletics events saw Morocco's Soufiane El Bakkali reach rarefied air with his second 3000m steeplechase gold, while American Quincy Hall's last gasp 400m win and Jamaican Roje Stona's record-breaking discus performance dazzled a capacity crowd at the Stade de France.\n\nMorocco's steeplechase king Soufiane El Bakkali on Wednesday became just the third Arab to win double Olympic gold while Jamaica's Roje Stona upset the favourites to claim a memorable men's discus title.\n\nIn a thrilling 400m final, American Quincy Hall overtook Britain's Matthew Hudson-Smith in the final metre to win the 400m and become the fourth-fastest one-lap performer in history.\n\nA capacity 69,000 crowd at the Stade de France also saw Nina Kennedy bag a first-ever women's pole vault gold for Australia.\n\nThree-time world champion El Bakkali timed 8min 06.05sec for victory in the 3000m steeplechase ahead of American Kenneth Rooks and Kenya's Abraham Kibiwot.\n\nHis second Olympic gold, having first win in the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games, leaves him in a small group of Arab athletes to have doubled up at the Summer Games.\n\nOnly his Moroccan compatriot Hicham El Guerrouj, who won 1500m and 5,000m gold in Athens 2004, and Tunisian swimmer Oussama Mellouli (1500m freestyle in Beijing 2008 and 10km marathon in London 2012) have achieved the feat.\n\nThe discus produced a feast of high-level throwing, Stona coming out on top to upset world record holder Mykolas Alekna.\n\nLithuanian Alekna had broken the Olympic record with his best mark of 69.97m on his second effort.\n\nBut plans to emulate his father Virgilijus, who won two Olympic titles in 2000 and 2004, were scotched by the Jamaican.\n\nStona, coached by American Ryan Crouser who won an unprecedented third consecutive shot put gold on Saturday, stole the show when he threw out to an Olympic record of 70.00m on his fourth attempt.\n\nOn the track, Hall produced a perfectly-timed finish and savage dip for victory in the 400m in 43.40sec.\n\nThe 26-year-old pipped a desperately disappointed Hudson-Smith, who improved his own European record to 43.44sec. Zambia's Muzala Samukonga took bronze in 43.74sec.\n\nIt was the first time ever five athletes had gone below 44 seconds in the same race.\n\nHall became the first American man to win the one-lap event at the Olympics since LaShawn Merritt in Beijing in 2008.\n\n\"It means a lot,\" said Hall, who was only a bronze medallist at last year's world championships. \"I've been putting a lot of work in. This is my second year running the 400.\n\n\"Last year I told you guys I was going to get a better medal this year. Guess what? I got one gold.\"\n\nThe fourth gold of the night went to Australia as Kennedy cleared a best of 4.90m.\n\nAmerican Katie Moon, the defending champion with whom Kennedy had shared world gold in Budapest last year, claimed silver on countback from Canada's Alysha Newman after they both managed 4.85m.\n\nLyles on track\n\nA trio of track stars safely negotiated their way into their respective event finals.\n\nNoah Lyles qualified for the 200m final on Wednesday to stay on track for the first Olympic men's sprint treble since Usain Bolt achieved the feat at the 2016 Rio Games.\n\nThe American three-time world champion, who won the 100m by five thousandths of a second from Jamaican Kishane Thompson in 9.79sec, finished second in his semi-final behind Botswana's Letsile Tebogo.\n\nTebogo, also a finalist in the 100m, struck a psychological blow to Lyles, crossing the line in 19.96sec, while Lyles timed 20.08sec.\n\nDefending champion Karsten Warholm wrapped up his semi-final to progress to Saturday's final of the 400m hurdles.\n\nWarholm, who set a sensational world record in winning gold at the Covid-delayed Tokyo Games three years ago, will be joined by arch-rivals Rai Benjamin and Alison Dos Santos, although the latter had to qualify as a fastest loser.\n\nAnd finally three-time world champion Grant Holloway's quest for an elusive Olympic 110m hurdles gold remained on track.\n\nThe 26-year-old American streaked home in an impressive 12.98sec, finishing far ahead of the rest of the field after a dynamite start.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8265966275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "21:22:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T21:22:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T21:21:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3372549116611481, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/olympic-games/track-and-field/2024/08/08/66b526c2e2704e95708b458d.html", "title": "Noah Lyles slammed for running 200m final with COVID: What are the Olympics' health and safety protocols?", "body": "Lyles, who won the 100m sprint in a photo finish, has quickly seen his hero status wiped away amid frustration from fans that he opted to race on Thursday despite testing positive for COVID -- and entering isolation -- two days prior. The controversy has led many to question what the health and safety protocols are at the Olympics amid a summer surge in COVID cases.\n\nAccording to NBC News, at least 40 athletes -- now including Lyles -- have tested positive for COVID during the Summer Olympic Games. COVID spikes during the summer months have been common since the pandemic began in 2020, and strict restrictions were in place for the 2020 Summer Games in Tokyo (held in 2021) and the 2022 Winter Olympic Games in Beijing.\n\nNot anymore. The 2024 Summer Games has had no mandatory, preventive measures in place to slow infection rates. Masking and testing have not been required, but an International Olympics Committee spokesperson told NBC that the organization is \"following good practices in managing infectious diseases\" at Paris 2024.\n\nThe United States Olympic & Paralympic Committee implemented its own preventive program under the slogan \"don't let a cold keep you from the gold.\" It encouraged athletes like Lyles -- who was visibly exhausted and laid down to the track following the 200m sprint -- to wash their hands frequently and to wear masks during long travel periods.\n\nEven though officials were confident that the 2024 Summer Olympics would not be a \"superspreader event,\" dozens have cases have now been confirmed and an athlete was permitted to race in spite of a positive COVID test. Only time will tell as to whether the IOC reconsiders its stance or finds a way to minimize the present damage.", "source": {"uri": "marca.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MARCA"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-08-448530105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-08", "time": "20:13:16", "dateTime": "2024-08-08T20:13:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-08T19:38:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.321568638086319, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/olympic-games/20240808-tebogo-delivers-olympic-glory-for-africa-and-late-mother", "title": "Tebogo delivers Olympic glory for Africa and late mother", "body": "Paris (AFP) - Letsile Tebogo has always said an Olympic medal would not just be for Botswana but the continent of Africa and he duly delivered on Thursday by becoming the first African to be crowned 200m Olympic champion.\n\nThe 21-year-old produced a stunning run in Paris to leave pre-race favourite Noah Lyles trailing in third.\n\nIn fact, Tebogo is only the second athlete from Africa to even win a medal in the 200m.\n\nNamibian Frankie Fredericks had blazed the way for Tebogo by winning the second of his two silvers in Atlanta in 1996.\n\nTebogo set an African record of 19.46sec in the Stade de France to put the cherry on the cake.\n\n\"Africans were known for the long distance, marathon, and quarter mile,\" Tebogo told NBC earlier this year.\n\n\"I just wanted to change that role and make sure that (people know) Africans can be sprinters too.\"\n\nTebogo is proud of his background and listens to traditional Botswanan songs prior to races.\n\nHe also operates on a set of strong principles.\n\n\"Respect and dedication to what you do,\" he said. \"(It's important) to show people how the culture is.\n\n\"Don't throw away the culture, and then adopt the city life. Keep on pushing the culture so that people can (see) what you're really made of.\"\n\nDevastating loss\n\nTebogo's Olympic achievement is even more impressive having been very hard hit by the death of his greatest fan, beloved mother Seratiwa, in May.\n\nHis mother had faithfully followed her son around, slipping into Budapest without Tebogo knowing to watch him become the first male Botswanan athlete to win world championship medals last year.\n\n\"There are many moments that stand out!\" she told TheVoiceBW in May this year, just days before her sudden death.\n\n\"For him to be the first Motswana to raise the blue, black and white flag in short sprints in Kenya 2021 takes centre stage, as does being the first Botswana man to medal at the World Championships last year, and breaking the 200m African record, which stood for over 27 years.\"\n\nIt wasn't always easy for the single mum to handle Tebogo, as well as a daughter who is nine years younger.\n\n\"Letsile has always been a hyperactive child,\" she said.\n\n\"I'd be chopping veggies and he'd be hiding under the table picking them then eating them raw.\"\n\nTebogo gave up his first sporting love, football, as he did not take well to being substituted.\n\n'Boy next door'\n\nHowever, Tebogo also realised if he became an athlete there was a better chance of him being \"able to put food on the family's table\" and repay his mother for all her sacrifices.\n\nNevertheless as he grew up with his extended family he still had to train for athletics and play football without shoes -- he told NBC \"everything had to be equal.\"\n\nHe called his mother his \"rock\" -- and she did everything for her son.\n\n\"Putting my interests on hold and emptying my savings just to be with him,\" she recalled.\n\n\"Note that our relationship is more than that of mother and son, we are more brother and sister now -- more so that, for the longest time, it was just me and him.\"\n\nShe provided stability off the track while his coach Kebonyemodisa 'Dose' Mosimanyane provided it in his athletics career.\n\nHowever, it was mum who ruled the roost in almost every respect.\n\n\"He is the boy next door,\" she said.\n\n\"You should see him at the cattlepost doing everything any Motswana child does.\"\n\nNevertheless she had bought a new car this year for his birthday -- giving it to him early as he was to leave for a meet.\n\nHer death left him bereft.\n\n\"It doesn't even feel like my birthday anymore. I don't think I will enjoy it anymore,\" Tebogo posted on social media.\n\nMost of all, she was not there to see her boy crowned Olympic champion.", "source": {"uri": "rfi.fr", "dataType": "news",
